HEADLINE: Despite Taliban Vow, Afghan Opium Production Is Up, U.N. Says

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
The Muslim fundamentalist Taliban movement has pledged to crack down on opium poppy cultivation in Afghanistan, but opium production there has jumped by 25 percent over the last year, with almost all of the increase occurring in Taliban-controlled areas, United Nations International Drug Control Program officials said Wednesday.
The United Nations agency's 1997 survey, scheduled for release Thursday, estimates that Afghan opium production rose to about 2,800 metric tons this year from 2,300 metric tons in 1996. United Nations officials report that Afghanistan now produces the raw ingredient for nearly half of the world's heroin. 
 Last year, Afghanistan ranked second to Myanmar, which produced 2,500 metric tons of opium, according to a State Department estimate.
Pino Arlacchi, executive director of the United Nations International Drug Control Program, said the increase could mean more heroin flowing into Europe at cheaper prices. European heroin users consume about 80 percent of the heroin refined from opium grown in Afghanistan. Part of the remainder reaches the American market, which is dominated by heroin from Colombia and Southeast Asia.
Mr. Arlacchi said he would raise his concern about the output of Afghan opium at meetings with other United Nations officials in New York today and on Friday.
"I want to inform them because we are very worried about the increase," Mr. Arlacchi said in a telephone interview from Vienna.
A United States counterdrug official in Washington expressed no surprise at the United Nations estimate of Afghanistan's opium crop. "Production has skyrocketed, we know that, and production is sanctioned by the Taliban," the official said.
Officials say the Taliban, which has seized power in 22 of Afghanistan's 32 provinces, now controls 96 percent of its poppy-growing areas.
The increase resulted from higher poppy yields, which were attributed to favorable weather, improved cultivation techniques and the shifting of some farmland to poppy cultivation. The total number of acres under poppy cultivation increased by only 2.8 percent, the survey estimated. United Nations survey teams based their estimate on visits to 18 provinces.
The report offered fresh evidence that the Taliban has not fulfilled its promises to crack down on opium production. Taliban officials say they cannot stop peasants from growing opium poppies without other crops to substitute, and contend that persuading them to switch depends on economic assistance from the international community.
The United States and many other countries have kept the Taliban at arm's length because of its violent rise to power and repressive policies like the relegation of women to inferior status. But international officials and journalists traveling in Afghanistan reported that the Taliban is not just tolerating opium production but also taxing it for desperately needed revenue and that Taliban militiamen have been seen guarding opium warehouses and helping transport the crop.
Taliban officials, while denying any involvement in the opium trade, concede that it is flourishing.
Afghanistan is one of six countries identified by the State Department as not cooperating sufficiently in the international fight against illegal drugs. The other countries are Colombia, Iran, Myanmar, Nigeria and Syria. The State Department report said, "While the Taliban banned opium production in late 1996, it made no effort to enforce this ban."

HEADLINE: Exxon Valdez Money to Aid City Wetlands

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
In March of 1989, the Exxon Valdez spilled 11 million gallons of oil into the pristine waters of Alaska's Prince William Sound, causing one of the worst environmental disasters in history.
Yesterday in Central Park, New York City received some of the money that the Exxon Corporation paid to settle a lawsuit stemming from the spill. The money is to be used to help clean marshes and wetlands in the city. 
 To settle the suit, filed by Alaska and the Federal Government -- in addition to the $2 billion the company paid for direct cleanup costs -- Exxon agreed to pay $900 million to be used for environmental good works around the nation.
Most of the money went to environmental projects in Alaska and the Florida Everglades, but $4.5 million was earmarked for smaller state and city projects that were chosen after a competition run by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
New York City was awarded $150,000, which the E.P.A. said was the largest award given so far as a result of the competition.
The Parks Department will use the money to plant trees, shrubs and herbs along hillsides lining streams and marshes in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens in a campaign to reduce harmful runoffs into the waterways.
The plants, including blueberry, azalea and bayberry root, will stabilize the soil, making it more difficult for harmful pollutants to filter through. The process is intended both to clean up existing pollution and prevent more.
"The Exxon Valdez disaster, with its images of oiled birds and devastated landscapes, drove home in mind-boggling magnitude the importance of preventing pollution before it occurs," said Jeanne M. Fox, a regional administrator for E.P.A., as she presented a giant facsimile of the check.
The local work will be done by the Parks Department's Natural Resources Group, which was founded in 1984 and has won numerous awards for restoring damaged environments. One of the group's continuing projects involves restoring more than a mile of shoreline damaged by oil spills in the Arthur Kill. This is also being financed by Exxon as a result of a 1990 spill in the Arthur Kill, between Staten Island and New Jersey.
The resources group has added 1,000 acres of natural lands to the city park system in the last four years and has established breeding sites for peregrine falcons. New York City is believed to be the nation's largest urban breeding place for the birds.
The latest project will use the settlement money to work on the edges of marshes in the Riverdale and Bronx Parks in the Bronx, Marine Park and Four Sparrow Marshes in Brooklyn and the Alley Pond Park watershed in Queens. Two full-time workers will be hired, and they will be assisted by volunteers.
"Soil stabilization is the key to protecting both the city's terrestrial and aquatic resources, thereby promoting a productive economy," said Marc A. Matsil, chief of the resources group. "The re-established native communities are capable of self-repair."
Yesterday's ceremony during which the city received the money was held at the Harlem Meer in Central Park, a bucolic lake created from a stagnant pond in a major restoration project several years ago. Dignitaries planted a great bulrush plant with a gold shovel along the shore.
The Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, said he only reluctantly agreed not to plant a hazelwood tree, a wry reminder of Joseph Hazelwood, the captain of the ill-fated Exxon Valdez. Instead, hazelnut-flavored coffee was served along with goldfish crackers. "The crackers are in memory of the victims," Mr. Stern said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At yesterday's award ceremony, a great bulrush was planted at the Harlem Meer, a lake created from a stagnant pond in Central Park. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks to Make Trade Deals Congress Can't Amend

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton began a tough struggle today with the nation's labor unions and much of his own party in Congress over his authority to negotiate new trade deals that he declared are "absolutely critical for our world leadership."
Arguing for authority to make trade deals that Congress can accept or reject but not amend, Mr. Clinton portrayed the stakes as far more than a dispute about job losses or the effect of trade on the environment. He said that without the ability to negotiate such accords, he would be crippled in conducting foreign policy. 
 "This is about more than economics," Mr. Clinton told a gathering of 100 executives of small and large businesses who are heavily dependent on export markets, and were invited to the East Room today to cheer on the President's efforts. "It's about whether other countries will continue to look to the United States to lead to a future of peace and freedom and prosperity."
Asserting economic links now form the core of relations with most nations, he argued that renewal of his negotiating authority was "about whether our economic ties will lead to cultural ties and ties of partnership, or whether we will be viewed as somehow withdrawn from the world, not interested in leading it, and therefore not nearly as influential as we might otherwise be for the causes in which we so deeply believe."
But even as he argued that far more than economic pragmatism is at stake, Mr. Clinton's advisers struggled over how to word trade legislation to assure majority votes in both Houses.
The drafting process is bogged down because it must navigate the huge divisions among unions and environmentalists, Democrats suspicious that free-trade accords cost jobs at home, and Republicans whose votes Mr. Clinton desperately needs. So the President found himself today in the embarrassing position of advocating passage of a bill that does not yet exist, and whose main provisions are still cloaked in secrecy.
"We wait for language," Representative Philip Crane, chairman of the trade subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. "We've been waiting two years for language," he said, a reference to the Administration's decision to drop the effort to get new trade authority during last year's Presidential election.
The debate over granting Mr. Clinton what is called fast-track authority -- the authority to negotiate trade deals that Congress must approve or reject as is -- mirrors the arguments four years ago over the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Labor unions, which staged protests in front of the White House today, are insisting that accords include provisions that would for example set minimum wages in foreign countries or force those nations to cut industrial emissions. Such restrictions, they argue, are the only way to assure that American jobs are not threatened by countries that pay their workers less or attract American investment because they have looser environmental rules.
Mr. Clinton knows what he wants: A "fast track" bill that appears to recognize environmental and labor goals but does not require their inclusion in specific accords.
But Republicans have already said they will not go along with any wording that sets labor and environment restrictions that are not directly "trade related," a phrase the Administration adopted several years ago but declines to define. The Republicans fear that once negotiations start down that road, trade agreements will necessarily include changes in American labor and environmental regulations, as well.
One of the oddities of the debate is that it comes at a time of extraordinary prosperity, much of it based on growing American exports. That means the United States is in an unusually advantageous position to negotiate new accords.
And today Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, listed the global talks that will begin soon under the auspices of the World Trade Organization. They range from the rules that govern procurements by governments, a $1 trillion market over the next decade in Asia alone, to the regulations surrounding financial services and telecommunications.
But the accord that has attracted the most concern in Congress is the extension of Nafta to include Chile, probably the most advanced economy in Latin America. While Chile's inclusion is not itself controversial, it sets a precedent for allowing other nations into the accord. The Administration, however, is insisting that the new talks have little in common with the free-trade agreement -- an accord tinged with drug and immigration problems with Mexico -- and today Mr. Clinton very deliberately never even mentioned it.
But in Congress, the agreement is being argued about constantly, and the "fast track" debate has become something of a review of the free-trade pact's successes and failures. Mr. Clinton's political problem is that it is far easier to identify jobs lost because of changes in the global economy -- a textile factory that closes in South Carolina, for example, and moves to Mexico -- than it is to identify jobs created by the growth in exports.
Politically, though, the fast-track legislation is a bigger problem for Vice President Al Gore, who also spoke quite forcefully today in favor of granting Mr. Clinton the authority he seeks. One reason the White House has failed to release a draft of the legislation is that Mr. Gore's aides are arguing for language that would address many of the concerns of the unions, whose support Mr. Gore needs for his run for President in 2000. One of his likely opponents for the Democratic nomination, Representative Richard Gephardt, the House minority leader, has joined with the unions in opposing the fast-track concept, and will spend the week campaigning against the measure even though, like others, he does not know exactly what it says.
Mr. Clinton's aides, in contrast, would rather adopt something closer to the Republican language and offer labor vague promises, including pressing for better labor conditions through international organizations like the International Monetary Fund or the International Labor Organization.
"The problem with this is that we guarantee nothing other than to talk about these issues," an Administration official said recently.
Some union leaders made clear that they hope to replay the free-trade-pact debate of four years ago. Stephen P. Yokich, president of the 800,000 United Automobile Workers, strongly criticized President Clinton today for even suggesting that the free-trade pact might be expanded.
"We don't want Nafta," he said. "It has been a failure."
He said his union would not even endorse trade accords that included stringent protections for workers' rights and the environment. "I even oppose that because we can't even enforce labor rights here in this country," he said.
As a matter of international diplomacy, it is extraordinarily difficult to mandate how other nations treat their workers or regulate industry. Latin American and Asian nations say it is the height of arrogance for Washington to dictate their economic and social policies, noting that the United States would not allow a similar infringement of its policies.
"It's amazing what your Congress debates," an ambassador from Southeast Asia said today. "Supposing Thailand wanted to mandate the minimum wage in the United States. What do you think Americans would say?"

HEADLINE: As Rules on Welfare Tighten, Its Recipients Gain in Stature

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Welfare recipients, last year's political pariahs, are shedding their outcast status.
Not long ago, a woman on public aid could have turned to C-Span and heard a Congressman likening her to alligators or wolves, or the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, warning that she posed a threat to American civilization. 
 Now on WSFA, the NBC affiliate in Montgomery, Ala., she can find a weekly feature portraying a welfare family in favorable terms. "Dump the stereotypes," the correspondent says. On St. Louis radio, she can find an advertising campaign lauding those with the "guts to get off welfare." In Charlotte, N.C., she can see billboards -- paid for by the county and posted by the Chamber of Commerce -- exhorting employers to give recipients a chance.
The mood change goes more than billboard deep. State legislatures, including several in the Deep South, have rejected many of the harshest proposals to emerge under the new state-run systems. Likewise, after cutting immigrant benefits by more than $22 billion last year, Congress hurried back this summer and restored nearly $12 billion.
To be sure, the sweeping Federal legislation passed last year has put more restrictions than ever on welfare benefits, and the aura of good will could quickly fade. It is too soon to tell how many families will prosper in the new era of time limits and work requirements, and how many will sink deeper into poverty. But for the moment at least, the tougher rules coincide with new civic, business and political efforts to recast recipients in a positive light.
"The whole climate in talking about welfare recipients has changed, from negative to positive," said Ron Kaufman, a Republican political strategist who is advising the Welfare to Work Partnership, a nonprofit group that encourages businesses to hire people on public assistance. "Everyone's on their best behavior politically, if you will."
The reappraisal has multiple roots. With caseloads crashing, much of the news coverage has suddenly turned to welfare successes. With labor markets tight, businesses are being forced to give recipients a second look. With tax revenues up, legislatures can afford more generosity. And with the most divisive questions settled by last year's law, many legislators have found themselves guided less by ideology than by a new, nuts-and-bolts practicality.
Consider the journey of Mike Coffman, a Republican State Senator in Colorado and an author of that state's welfare law. When he started working on welfare issues three years ago, Mr. Coffman said, he began with "a primitive approach" that focused on cutting spending and punishing bad behavior.
But this year, as the state began imposing a five-year time limit on cash benefits, Mr. Coffman joined the push for support services, including child care, health care and cash supplements for those seeking training or education.
"When I was outside the system, it was very easy to be ideological and have simplistic solutions," he said. "As I began to learn more, I began to see welfare recipients as victims of bad government policy. I developed a degree of sympathy for them."
Not everyone is impressed.
Peter Edelman, a former welfare official who resigned from the Clinton Administration last year to protest the new law, warned that the mood could quickly sour should the economy do so.
"It would be embarrassing to legislators to be mean and nasty and cut the money when we're rolling in dough," Mr. Edelman said. "If the unemployment rate in Charlotte was 8.2 percent instead of 3.2 percent, you wouldn't have the Chamber of Commerce running around telling businesses to hire people on welfare."
"I really dislike the hype that says everything is wonderful," he added. "The heavy lifting hasn't started."
In signing the welfare law last summer, President Clinton expressed a hope for civic efforts like those now taking place.
"Welfare's no longer a political football to be kicked around," Mr. Clinton said. "It's a personal responsibility of every American who ever criticized the welfare system to help the poor."
But even he might have had a hard time predicting that President George Bush's political director (Mr. Kaufman), President Ronald Reagan's pollster (Richard Wirthlin), and a host of corporate executives would come together in an effort to erase the stigma of being on welfare.
The effort is being coordinated by the Welfare to Work Partnership, which was established this spring with Mr. Clinton's encouragement. Among its tools is an advertising campaign, scheduled this fall for radio, television, and print.
"Welfare mothers are irresponsible," states the underlying text of one of the print advertisements. But the line has been rewritten to read: "Welfare mothers make responsible employees." The same goes for "welfare is a program that creates dependence." It becomes, "welfare to work is a program that creates independence."
The advertisements were designed without charge by Ammirati Puris Lintas, a blue-chip firm more accustomed to selling BMW's than the talents of the poor.
"We're trying to present the stereotype and smash it at the same time," said Duncan Pollock, the chairman of the firm's office in New York. "If there are latent feelings, we felt that to be effective we had to bring them to the surface -- get them on the table and deal with them."
The campaign was tested in St. Louis in August, in coordination with a visit by President Clinton to promote the hiring of people on welfare. Before the campaign, 43 percent of those business leaders who expressed an interest in hiring recipients said they considered them "a good source of employees."
After the campaign, which consisted of a modest number of print and radio advertisements, that figure rose to 52 percent.
"A focused effort can change the underlying perceptions," said Maury Giles, a researcher at Wirthlin Worldwide, which collected the data.
But the numbers also underscore the challenge that remains. Another way of reading the data is that even among employers who expressed an interest in hiring recipients, about half doubted their abilities.
In Charlotte, the Chamber of Commerce began an advertising campaign last year with an $84,000 contract from the county department of social services. The president of the agency that designed it, Pam Boileau, was once on welfare herself.
"There's such a stigma around welfare recipients," Ms. Boileau said. "Each one of us has to accept the responsibility of helping recipients get off the rolls."
 In Montgomery, it is not an advertising agency but a television correspondent, Jennifer Schram, pushing a new look at recipients. Her weekly profile of a welfare family is designed, in part, to help the state recruit mentors to work with those leaving the rolls.
"I show that it could be any of us," Ms. Schram said. "Some unforeseen accident could happen. Where would we turn?"
The flood of optimistic accounts could raise unrealistic expectations. Not all the "myths" about welfare recipients' problems are wrong.
Should progress stall as the nation confronts the tougher cases that remain on the rolls -- people with little education, little work experience or problems with alcohol and drugs -- the conversation could return to the tone set by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. Mr. Gramm ran for President last year in part by demanding that people on welfare "get out of the wagon and help the rest of us pull."
For now, the mood swing has brought results. Perhaps none has been as dramatic as the decision by Congress to reinstate $11.7 billion of welfare benefits for immigrants, just months after contending that the program, Supplemental Security Income, was rife with fraud and abuse.
The move partly reflects an ebbing of budgetary pressure. It also derives from a growing fear of the Hispanic vote. And the concern over last year's cuts may have been stoked by press accounts of several immigrants thought to have committed suicide partly in despair over losing their benefits.
While partially restoring the immigrant cuts, Congress also allotted an additional $3.4 billion for programs to help recipients find work.
"Things have changed substantially since last year," said Ellen Nissenbaum, who follows anti-poverty legislation for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington advocacy group.
State legislatures have also shown more concern about the needy than opponents of the new law predicted.
"What I saw wasn't just sympathy but support -- support in a tangible way," said Jack Tweedie, who tracks welfare programs for the National Conference of State Legislatures.
 In New York, for instance, the Legislature rejected Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut benefits by 45 percent over four years. In California, the Legislature blocked a proposal by Gov. Pete Wilson to enforce time limits as short as one year. Both legislatures also rejected the Governors' proposal to abolish general assistance programs, which provide cash payments to single adults.
To some extent, the fights merely reflect party divisions. Both Governors are Republicans, and three of the four legislative bodies in those states are controlled by Democrats. But there were other forces at play, including a fear of county officials from both parties that a withdrawal of state aid would leave them awash in needy people.
"Our views on these matters are not philosophical or political," wrote a group of Republican county officials in New York, in an April letter opposing various aspects of Mr. Pataki's plan. "Rather they concern the fiscal and practical impact that the choices made in Albany will have on local governments."
In Arkansas, Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, proposed a two-year limit with few services or exemptions. But the Democratic-controlled Legislature created exemptions for recipients with "extraordinary barriers." And it postponed the start of time limits until next summer, to give the state time to put other support services in place.
Similarly, the Alabama Legislature moved to soften a proposal by Gov. Fob James Jr., a Republican. Though both Houses are controlled by Democrats, some of the work was led by a Republican, Representative Jim Carns. He pushed for earnings supplements for recipients who find jobs and child care for teen-aged mothers.
"I had the typical knee-jerk reaction before I got into this," Mr. Carns said. "I thought it'd be easier to save money."
His work drew praise from State Senator Rodger Mell Smitherman, a Democrat who serves as chairman of the Senate Black Caucus.
"There's a realization that it's one thing to say you want people to work, but it's another to create the environment for them to do that," Mr. Smitherman said. "I was pleased to see that it wasn't all harsh."
The compromise fashioned by Mr. Smitherman and Mr. Carns even contained an increase in benefit levels, the only one in the country. But the two were shocked when the bill was defeated by a last-minute filibuster: with Alabama ranked almost last in benefits, a few legislators decided that the grant increase, from $164 a month to $185, was not enough.

HEADLINE: Arafat Must Take Greater Steps To Halt Terrorism, Albright Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright made a public show of support today for Israel and for Israeli victims of Palestinian terrorism and accused the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, of not doing nearly enough to crack down on the support network for the terrorists.
In a hospital visit to speak to Israelis wounded in the last two suicide bombings, in a tour of the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial and in her public statements, Ms. Albright used the first day of her first official trip to the Middle East to underline America's close relationship with Israel, its security and its people. 
 "I will be seeing Chairman Arafat tomorrow, and my message will be clear," Ms. Albright said at a news conference alongside the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. "It is essential that Israeli-Palestinian security cooperation be serious, sustained and effective.
"At the same time, the Palestinian Authority must take unilateral steps and actions to root out the terrorist infrastructure. If we are to create and sustain an invigorated and accelerated negotiating process, there is simply no other way."
Senior American officials said they agreed with Mr. Netanyahu that Mr. Arafat "is not doing nearly enough" to crack down on radical Palestinian groups like Hamas and Islamic Holy War despite a series of arrests in the last few days.
They said they based that judgment on the evidence provided by an American intelligence officer who sits with the Israeli and Palestinian security chiefs when they meet.
But in private talks with Mr. Netanyahu, Ms. Albright warned him that putting too much pressure on Mr. Arafat would deprive the Palestinian of any political leeway and could force him to defy the Israelis.
In another private discussion, the Israeli President, Ezer Weizman, urged her to be firm with Mr. Netanyahu, a move that drew criticism from Israelis when the conversation was disclosed.
But Ms. Albright is a firm believer in public diplomacy, and it was her public stand that drew immediate cries of bias from Palestinians.
A senior Palestinian official, Hanan Ashrawi, was sharply critical of the way Ms. Albright had begun her one-week visit to the region, saying she had displayed "a wholeheartedly one-sided approach."
Speaking in the West Bank city of Ramallah, Ms. Ashrawi said, "At some point the United States has to decide whether it wants to serve only Israeli interests or whether it wants to serve the interests of peace in the region."
On the other hand, Mr. Arafat had been eager for Ms. Albright to visit the region, as he can use her diplomacy to his advantage. If he decides, for example, that he must respond to pressure for a firmer crackdown, he could present it as a response to the Americans.
Senior American officials rejected Ms. Ashrawi's complaint. They repeated Ms. Albright's assertion that "security is the sine qua non" for progress in restoring genuine mutual confidence and real peace talks, and they said the American strategy had been drawn up with the interests of all parties in mind.
In her public comments, they noted, Ms. Albright insisted on the preservation of the Oslo accords and the need for both sides to keep commitments, including two further Israeli troop withdrawals from the West Bank, which aides to Mr. Netanyahu say Israel would prefer to skip.
She told the Prime Minister to refrain from "unilateral actions" that would pre-empt peace talks.
"Clearly Israel also has a responsibility to shape an environment which will give that process a chance to succeed," Ms. Albright said at the news conference with Mr. Netanyahu. "This means that Israel should be taking steps that build confidence and refrain from actions that undermine confidence and trust."
But she was much harsher and more specific in her comments about Mr. Arafat's need to be convincing on his promises of security cooperation, and American officials said the tack was deliberate.
The officials acknowledged that establishing Israeli confidence about Palestinian security commitments would take some time, and that any serious discussion of political issues -- like peace talks on a final settlement between the two sides -- was many weeks away.
Mr. Arafat, they said, will have to choose between preserving Palestinian unity and making progress in peace negotiations, they said.
"Unless he moves hard against the enemies of peace, who are also his own enemies, there can be no peace process," an American official said.
But in their closed session, American officials said, Ms. Albright also told Mr. Netanyahu that Mr. Arafat needed "more political space" in which to carry out a sustained crackdown on terrorism.
She said Mr. Netanyahu should move quickly to respond to early steps by Mr. Arafat with an easing of the economic pressure that Israel has put on the Palestinian Authority.
The United States has criticized Mr. Netanyahu for holding back tax revenue that Israel owes the Authority, and Ms. Albright asked him to consider "how the long-term fight against terrorism could occur in an environment where Arafat's political space and funds are tightened."
A senior Israeli official said Mr. Netanyahu and Ms. Albright had discussed a list of Israeli actions, which the official did not describe, that could reciprocate Palestinian steps on terrorism. But he emphasized that Mr. Arafat would have to move first, and convincingly.
Having conducted a series of arrests in Gaza this week, the Palestinian Authority moved today to shut down the Islamic Bloc Youth Union there. The organization represents thousands of students and is identified with Hamas.
But Mr. Netanyahu dismissed such moves as the arrests of "sardines, not sharks."
For her part, "Albright thinks a lot more needs to be done by Arafat," an American official said. "She will say to him, 'What more do you need to know that these people are destroying your chance of making peace?' "
At breakfast with President Weizman, Ms. Albright was urged to "be ready to put pressure on Netanyahu" and "bang some heads together, not now necessarily, but later," an American official said. Mr. Weizman, a former Defense Minister, also criticized Mr. Netanyahu's humiliating treatment of Mr. Arafat and said that it was "dangerous to have hungry neighbors," the official said.
Disclosure of that conversation set off a furor among Israeli politicians, some of whom accused Mr. Weizman of privately departing from the political neutrality he is supposed to keep as President. Ms. Albright was visibly moved by her conversations with victims of the suicide bombings at Hadassah University Hospital-Mt. Scopus.
She thanked the 11 patients, most of whom suffered burns and shrapnel wounds, for letting her have what she called "a chance to see real people with tremendous injuries" and added, "I will carry this in my heart."
Daniel Williams, 19, a young seminary student from Miami, was in Israel for only 23 hours before the Sept. 4 bombing but intends to stay. He gave Ms. Albright a letter urging her to be tough on Mr. Arafat and urged her to remember the victims "when you go to embrace Arafat."
Appearing a little annoyed, the Secretary said, "I don't intend to embrace Arafat."
Ruth Sultan, 20, suffers from severe burns and thanked Ms. Albright for coming to meet her and her mother. "I hope her visit will help," Ms. Sultan said, "but I know and feel that those things will happen again and again. I will go on. We don't have a choice; this is our country."

HEADLINE: Accord Ends Con Edison's Monopoly and Cuts Rates by 10%

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Facing criticism that an early version of a proposed rate reduction favored large businesses, Consolidated Edison and state regulators agreed yesterday to an across-the-board 10 percent cut in electric rates, the largest rollback in half a century.
The agreement, approved yesterday by the state Public Service Commission, is part of a deal that will drastically reshape the power industry in New York. Besides cutting rates, it will break up Con Edison into several pieces and open the door to competition among power companies in a market that Con Edison has held for decades as a monopoly. The commission intends to do the same with each of the state's seven regional electric monopolies, hoping that competition will lower New York's electric rates, which are among the highest in the nation. 
 The first version of the state agreement with Con Edison, released in March, would have cut residential and small business rates by 3.3 percent over five years, and large business rates by 10 percent over five years, while giving an immediate 25 percent cut to a handful of large industrial customers. After consumer groups and elected officials, including state Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, protested loudly that the plan did not do enough for ordinary customers, the commission began renegotiating the deal.
With some behind-the-scenes prodding from Gov. George E. Pataki, who appointed them, the commissioners insisted that small users be guaranteed the same 10 percent reduction as large customers, and Con Edison agreed. For the average residential customer, the savings will be about $5 a month when the plan is fully in effect, five years from now.
"The agreement will save New York City and Westchester County consumers over a billion and a half dollars over the next five years," said John F. O'Mara, the commission chairman.
In sheer dollars, it is by far the largest rate reduction ever by a New York utility, commission officials said. It is the first reduction for Con Edison customers since a 3 percent cut in 1987, and based on percentage, it is the largest decline in the utility's rates since 1948.
But consumer advocates remained largely dissatisfied, arguing that the utility's stockholders should have been forced to absorb a large chunk of the company's outstanding obligations on capital investments and high-priced power purchase contracts, which Con Edison estimates at up to $6.2 billion. The agreement allows the company to recover 90 percent to 100 percent of those costs from its customers.
"By making shareholders share the burden, we could double the rate savings," said Travis Plunkett, state legislative representative for the American Association of Retired Persons.
Mr. Pataki also intervened with the commission this week to help salvage a program that requires Con Edison to help its customers reduce their demand for electricity through measures like subsidizing replacement of inefficient appliances and advising businesses on how to cut their consumption. The program's budget has already dropped from $125 million in 1993 to $48 million this year, and the commission had planned to cut it to just $6 million a year. Instead, the program will get $30 million.
Most environmental groups protested that the number was still too low and refused to support the agreement. But Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, which helped negotiate the final figure, called it "a floor we can build on."
The New York Public Interest Research Group said that, despite the changes, it opposed the agreement on both consumer and environmental grounds. "The whole thing was stage managed so that the Governor could look like the hero by improving somewhat on a truly terrible deal," said Larry Shapiro, a lawyer at the group.
But the Giuliani administration hailed the result as a victory. "It will provide real relief to residents and small businesses," said Deputy Mayor Randy M. Mastro.
The immediate 25 percent cut for a few large industrial customers also remains in the agreement.
A last-minute change in the deal will save the city, the Transit Authority and other public agencies a total of $40 million a year by averting an increase in Con Edison's charges for delivering low-cost power from the New York Power Authority.
Joan S. Freilich, senior vice president of Con Edison, said the rate reductions "are going to be a stretch" for the company.
But industry analysts say that the cost of producing power has generally declined in recent years, and that Con Edison will probably be able to sell its power plants for much more than experts anticipated even a year ago. The agreement will require Con Edison to sell at least half of its generating capacity in New York City. The company owns 13 power plants, 9 of them in the city.
Under the plan, Con Edison will split into three separate companies under a single holding company. One will own power plants and compete on the wholesale level with other generators. A second will be a power retailer, buying power from wholesalers and competing with other retailers for customers' business, much like the long-distance telephone companies.
The third company will maintain monopoly ownership of the wires that link customers to the state's power grid, and will charge competing retailers for the use of the network.
Critics of the plan, including out-of-state power companies that want to break into the New York market and many business groups whose members hope to benefit from the lower rates competition promises, say that it shields Con Edison from most real competition by allowing the utility to charge high rates for delivering a competitor's power.
As states around the country move toward dismantling electric monopolies and introducing competition, few have as much incentive as New York, where high rates are often said to drive away businesses.
Con Edison's rates are about double the national average, and are the second-highest in the continental United States, after the Long Island Lighting Company's.

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE VOTERS -- On Their Home Turf, a Wide Gulf in Enthusiasm for Two Candidates;
In Messinger Land, Talk of Apathy And Its Aftermath

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
Imagine a diehard Ruth W. Messinger voter, and Fred Kramer may come to mind. A novelist and a longtime resident of the Upper West Side, Ms. Messinger's home turf, he carries books in the pocket of a rumpled blue suit stained with red sauce.
"I like her politics," Mr. Kramer said matter-of-factly while walking up Broadway, the city's central avenue for traditional American liberalism. But like so many in his party, Mr. Kramer broke with expected political behavior this week. He voted for Sal F. Albanese, the Brooklyn Councilman, because he supports the death penalty. 
 Mr. Kramer says he has not decided how he will vote in the runoff between Ms. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton, and he said, "I have not closed the door on Giuliani, because I like what he's done on crime."
The day after Ms. Messinger failed to win 40 percent of the Democratic primary vote, few Democrats interviewed in an area that is her traditional base expressed much passion or commitment for her. The people who seemed to express the most enthusiasm for her are New Yorkers in low-income areas, including some who voted for Mr. Sharpton.
Many middle-class Democratic voters said they were reasonably happy with the way the city is being governed, which could go a long way toward explaining why only 18 percent of the registered Democrats voted in the primary. A large number of people expressed apathy about the primary, saying the outcome in November was already assured.
"I did not vote and I am ashamed," said Gladys Foxe, a 56-year-old psychotherapist who lives on West 74th Street. "I had that thought in the back of my mind that Giuliani will win a second term."
She added that she planned to vote in the runoff on Sept. 23, but that she had not yet made up her mind.
"Al Sharpton represents voices who are too rarely heard, but there are aspects of his politics I don't agree with," Ms. Foxe said. "Ruth Messinger is a kind of Democrat and a woman whom I would feel more familiar with, but I don't like to automatically vote for just what is familiar."
Some Democrats said that Ms. Messinger's disputed commercial about school crowding had backfired. School officials condemned the advertisement -- a staged scene that showed a class crammed into a bathroom -- as misleading and unfair. Others said Ms. Messinger had failed to express clear views on the issues they thought were Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's weak points, namely jobs and police brutality.
"Things are good in New York, and it is hard to run against that," said Susan Gutterman, a 60-year-old homemaker on West 95th Street who said she nevertheless had planned to vote for Ms. Messinger until she saw the bathroom ad.
Claudia Fernandez, 21, a Barnard College administrative assistant who voted for Ms. Messinger on Tuesday, said, "Ruth is a worthy challenger, and I really want her opinions heard, especially on education." But she added, "I'll probably vote for Giuliani in the general election."
While responses to Ms. Messinger were largely tepid on the Upper West Side, interviews showed that she was more popular with factory workers in the East Williamsburg Industrial Park in Brooklyn, who expressed much concern about the city economy and job security.
"I like Ruth," said Frank Jenkins, a 39-year-old plumbing company handyman and resident of Bedford-Stuyvesant. Mr. Jenkins said that he hat not voted on Tuesday because he thought Ms. Messinger was a sure winner, but that he definitely would vote for her in November. "She can't do worse than Giuliani, laying off people with budget cuts," Mr. Jenkins said.
"I think she has a chance," said Peter Perez, a 23-year-old forklift operator who lives on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. "I don't think Giuliani is very popular."
Interviews in middle-class neighborhoods in Queens and Brooklyn suggested that if Ms. Messinger survives the runoff, she has her work cut out in trying to retrieve an important bloc of voters from Mr. Giuliani's camp.
"Outer-borough voters see Ruth Messinger as the Manhattan Borough President who will think of Manhattan first," said Chris Ahl, 46, a Staten Island telephone repairman sitting in his truck on Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst.
During a political discussion in the Amaf Supply appliance store in Flushing, a number of customers and employees expressed the feeling that they did not really know what Ms. Messinger stands for. Joseph Tarantini, 30, a firefighter, said he would have voted for Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi had he run for mayor, but he did not think Ms. Messinger was strong enough to do the job. "As a city resident, I can't argue with what Giuliani has done," he added.
Alfonso Velasquez, 43, a salesman, said: "I'm a registered Democrat, but I don't think she can beat Giuliani. I won't vote for him, though."
A second salesman interrupted him. "Why not?" he said. "Crime is way down."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 12, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about reaction to the mayoral campaign of Ruth W. Messinger misstated the view of one Upper West Side voter, Fred Kramer, on the death penalty. Mr. Kramer says that while he voted for Councilman Sal F. Albanese, who supports the death penalty, Mr. Kramer himself opposes capital punishment.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Leaders Back Bill on Religious Persecution

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
A coalition of religious groups led by evangelical Christians today won critical support from the Republican leadership in its effort to mandate economic sanctions against any country engaged in religious persecution.
The endorsement of the Freedom From Religious Persecution Act by the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and Speaker Newt Gingrich gives the bill enough momentum to create a quandary for the White House and its business allies who already complain that American trade is too encumbered. 
 Beyond the foreign policy implications, support for the measure provides further evidence of the emerging political clout of conservative Christian groups in an area of foreign policy that has been the exclusive preserve of human rights groups like Amnesty International.
The bill backed by the coalition would create a new office within the White House to monitor the treatment of religious minorities around the world. It would also require economic sanctions against nations that abuse their citizens on the basis of religion. And it would give those fleeing religious persecution priority over other refugees in gaining entry into the United States.
Even though the Clinton Administration opposes the bill in its current form, it is likely to pass, although with some amendments.
"This is one of the top priorities of this Republican Congress," Mr. Gingrich said today as he met with more than 30 leaders of religious organizations, which, with a few exceptions, represented Christianity's fundamentalist and evangelical denominations. Among the leaders was Cheryl Halpern, national chairwoman of the National Jewish Coalition.
State Department officials have objected that the bill is a blunderbuss approach that removes their flexibility in combating religious persecution around the world. They also complain that while the sanctions in the bill are relatively modest, their imposition could harm American relations with key allies like Saudi Arabia and Egypt.
"The Administration strongly supports the objectives of eliminating religious persecution," John Shattuck, Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, said Tuesday in testimony before the House International Relations Committee. "But we believe the current draft in the legislation would frustrate that goal."
Administration officials say privately, however, they would be willing to discuss possible alternatives, including more monitoring of religious harassment, increased reports to publicize the practice in countries like the Sudan, Iran, China, Egypt and Indonesia, and insuring that current human right laws explicitly cover repression of religious minorities.
In the past year, using denominational newsletters and broadcasts on Christian radio and television stations, groups like the National Association of Evangelicals, the Southern Baptist Convention and the Family Research Council have quietly built up a powerful grass-roots constituency that has pressured the Clinton Administration and Congress into taking a number of steps.
Last year, the groups pressured the White House to agree to set up a committee to recommend ways to fight religious persecution around the world. This summer, the State Department issued a report on the harassment of religious minorities, with an emphasis on persecution of Christians. The groups also steered the debate over the trading status of China to include that country's persecution of Christians. And now the religious persecution bill has picked up the endorsement of the leaders of both Houses of Congress.
Leaders of the movement say their efforts are revitalizing what had become a moribund rights movement.
"With the dismantling of the Soviet Union, the end of apartheid in South Africa and the democratization of South America, the human rights movement here fell apart at the grass-roots level," said Nina Shea, director of the Center for Religious Freedom of Freedom House, which has been working with evangelical Christians. "This is a new lobby that is emerging."
Last month, these evangelical groups were joined by the Chrisitan Coalition, which declared that ending religious persecution around the world was their "top legislative priority."
The new human rights group is being greeted with both enthusiasm and wariness by traditional liberal human rights groups and mainstream religious organizatons that have normally have been involved in foreign policy matters.
On one hand, the Christian right's political power is welcomed by human rights groups, which are routinely out-muscled by business interests in the debate over using trade sanctions to foster human rights. But some human rights advocates question whether the fundamentalist Christians will argue for people other than persecuted Christians.
Indeed, some leaders of mainstream churches note that the bill backed by the coalition, which is still in draft form, makes no reference to persecution of Jews, and speaks only of harassment of "moderate Muslims" in the Sudan. The plight of Jews in Syria or Muslims in Bosnia is not mentioned.
William Schulz, executive director of Amnesty International, U.S.A., the country's largest grass-roots rights group, with 300,000 members -- far below the 15.6 million-strong Southern Baptist Convention -- expressed the ambivalence some human rights advocates are feeling in a column in his organization's newsletter.
Describing his ideology as "left-wingey," Mr. Schulz said he welcomed the involvement of "those who genuinely care about human suffering, no matter what their views of God or the state." But he also pointedly asked: "Is it right for Christians to limit their outrage to violations against Christians? What about Muslims in China's Xinjing Province or Buddhists in Tibet? What exactly is the motive of political and religious conservatives, and is it pure?"

CORRECTION-DATE: September 13, 1997, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about the growing involvement of evangelical Christians in the human rights movement misstated the opinion of William Schulz, executive director of Amnesty International U.S.A. While Mr. Schulz has written that some human rights advocates are wary about the emergence of evangelical Christians in their movement, he has made it clear that he does not share these doubts and welcomes "all political and religious stripes."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Adventure and Loneliness Riding Freights in the 30's

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
The romantic spirit and visual prettiness of "Riding the Rails" are unexpected, since this documentary deals with hard times. But during the Great Depression, as this film by Michael Uys and Lexy Lovell attests, a world of adventure briefly revealed itself to certain daring American teen-agers.
As families struggled for economic survival, the solution to domestic quarrels or restless yearnings might simply be running away on the railroad. 
 According to Thomas Minehan's 1934 book, "Boy and Girl Tramps of America," on which the film is partly based, as many as 250,000 young Americans may have taken this drastic escape route. "I'll write," one of the film's interviewees recalls having said, in a note placed on a pillow before leaving home.
This warmly nostalgic film, which opens today at Cinema Village, is largely based on the reminiscences of those who shared the itinerant experience. (Mr. Uys solicited stories from, among others, the readers of Modern Maturity magazine, and he heard from 3,000 people.) It mixes newsreels, photographs and letters capturing the young travelers with present-day scenes of the elderly telling their tales. In this it recalls "Fire on the Mountain," another documentary (about brave skiers recruited for World War II military service) about the profound effects of youthful adventure. All the men heard here, and one remarkably gutsy woman named Peggy De Hart, sound deeply touched by what they learned and saw.
"Riding the Rails," which will be shown on a bill with William Wellman's 1933 drama "Wild Boys of the Road," a fictional tour of the same terrain, begins with the travelers' optimism.
The lean, fresh faces seen in old group photographs are often so handsome that they resemble current fashion advertisements. "I think it's the last free red-blooded adventure available to today's Americans," says a man known as Guitar Whitey, who still rides freight trains whenever he can.
But the film also describes how some of these young itinerants evolved into hobos, shunned and ostracized in the towns where they would stop. Clarence Lee, a black man who is moved to tears by some of his memories, describes the racial prejudice he also encountered. And the speakers tell of terrible loneliness. There is the image of a young man weeping over the birthday cake his mother sent him from a faraway home.
"For many, it was a brutal education," the film explains, while telling how a young man could load coal for an entire day and find himself paid with two tomatoes. In a documentary that is of course accompanied by the music of Woody Guthrie and other folk greats, there is the growing awareness of wild adolescent freedom coming to an end. "I was young and I felt nothing could defeat me," one man says with simple eloquence. "But some of these men, they were older and you could see that they had become defeated."
"Riding the Rails" conveys the full weight of this knowledge, even as it follows its interviewees to the end of their youthful travels, right up to the bittersweet experience of returning home.

RIDING THE RAILS

HEADLINE: No Chinese Connection?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 7 news article on the end of phase one of Senate hearings on campaign finance practices lists Yah Lin Trie, a friend of President Clinton, and members of the Riady family, longtime financial backers of the President, as potential witnesses who are outside the reach of subpoenas. The article states "but these people either have no relationship with the Chinese Government or their connection is so slight that there is little reason to believe that the donations they were involved with came from Beijing."
The hearings, however, established a link between the finances raised by Mr. Trie for the Democratic National Committee and Ng Lap Seng, a Chinese developer, who wired $200,000 from a Bank of China account to an account he shared with Mr. Trie, a business partner. Mr. Ng happens to serve on the "People's Consultative Congress," an organization that provides economic advice to the Beijing Government. Mr. Trie was also responsible for arranging for Wang Jun, China's most important arms dealer, to attend a White House coffee with the President. 
 Members of the Riady family are owners of the Lippo Group, the Indonesian conglomerate that has developed close ties to commerce officials of the Chinese Government, whose investment in Lippo's Hong Kong bank was made shortly after the President's election.
Are these these connections really "so slight that there is little reason to believe" the contributions came from Beijing?
 
WILLIAM NICOSON
Washington, Sept. 7, 1997

HEADLINE: Sitting in the 70's;
With Outdated Styles, Furniture Sellers Are Struggling

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
By every visible measure, there is no excuse for not making money in the furniture business these days.
New homes have been selling briskly, the number of decorating magazines has risen sharply in recent years and Martha Stewart long ago legitimized obsessive homemaking. 
 But when the Levitz Furniture Corporation, one of the country's largest furniture chains, sought bankruptcy protection last week, it underscored a painful truth: Consumers may be willing to spend money on furniture for their homes, but a lot of retailers are simply not giving them the products they want.
Indeed, furniture sellers and experts agree that while other retailers have scrambled over the last several years to keep up with changing consumer demands, much of the furniture business has lagged hopelessly behind.
As clothing has become more casual and cars more sporty, furniture has remained firmly entrenched in the 1970's, when many suburban middle-class homes had the same basic easy chairs and dinette sets. Moreover, many mainstream retailers have been far more focused on pushing easy credit terms rather than updating the style of their living room and bedroom offerings.
"The furniture business has been changing," said Gerald Birnbach, chief executive of Rowe Furniture, a Levitz supplier now owed $4 million by the retailer. "The large players don't seem to realize it because they are mired in tradition. What stimulates most Americans is their aspirations. They want nice things, and our industry is not exposing them to them."
Taking advantage of the weaknesses among the traditional stores are specialty chains like Crate and Barrel, a unit of Euromarket Designs, and Pier 1 Imports, whose furniture selection, while limited, is trendy and eye-catching.
Levitz, after being stuck in a rut for a decade, was struggling to breathe new life into its business. But it was hobbled by heavy debt, making it that much more difficult to let shoppers know that the company was changing its ways, said Michael Bozic, who became chief executive in late 1995.
Mr. Bozic, a former chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Company and widely respected in the retail industry, said in an interview this week that he had made up-to-date offerings and a pleasant shopping experience his main goals when he took over. Sales did improve: This spring, for the first time in two years, the company posted back-to-back sales gains at its stores open at least a year, the industry's traditional benchmark. Month to month, though, sales have been wildly inconsistent this year.
And Levitz, based in Boca Raton, Fla., was facing $1 million in weekly interest payments, remnants of a 1985 leveraged buyout that saddled the company with debt and left it with a thin financial cushion that unnerved suppliers.
The final blow, Mr. Bozic said, came when Montgomery Ward filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July, causing suppliers to worry about other weak retailers and cut off shipments. "Suppliers had heightened concerns," he said, "so what they did was very understandable, which was put us under credit restrictions.
"Ironically, we had the biggest three days of business over Labor Day weekend, but we could only deliver half of that."
And Levitz is far from alone, with national chains like Jennifer Convertibles, the Bombay Company and Krause's Furniture suffering declining sales in recent years. Department stores have pulled back sharply from selling furniture. Even Heilig-Meyers, the furniture giant in Richmond with $1.5 billion in annual revenue, said last month that its second-quarter earnings would be lower than expected.
So what plunged the $50 billion furniture industry into such a mess? For one thing, while other retailers consolidated over the last decade, the furniture business remains highly fragmented, with hundreds of local family businesses and only a few true national players.
Experts on the business also say that furniture sellers and manufacturers have not formed the relationships needed to come up with creative products or create strong marketing and public relations campaigns. The marketing is especially key because while shoppers may go to Macy's to buy Tommy Hilfiger shirts, they are hard pressed to identify a brand-name furniture company.
"We haven't done a great job of attracting the consumer," said Kimberley Wray, editorial director of High Points, a trade publication in High Point, N.C. "There is no 'incredible edible egg' campaign for furniture."
Logistical problems also abound. Because furniture is so big, managing inventory is difficult, often forcing shoppers to wait five weeks or more for a couch or a chair. The delivery process poses problems, too. It is hard to maintain a team of people who both know how to assemble furniture and are willing to climb four flights of stairs to do it. And with more two-career couples, there is often no one at home to receive the delivery.
Most important, furniture fashion has struggled to keep up with increasingly sophisticated consumer tastes. Shoppers who have seen the bright colors and casual styles in House & Garden or Martha Stewart Living magazines are hard pressed to find such items at traditional retailers, particularly at a reasonable price.
While the national chains have struggled, retailers like Pottery Barn, a unit of Williams-Sonoma Inc., Crate and Barrel and Pier 1 have rushed to fill the vacuum. They have a simple trick: lure shoppers who have come in for a candle or a set of wine goblets into checking out pillows, couches and beds while in the store. And tables are handsomely laid out with, what else, that store's dishes and flatware.
The furniture offerings at these specialty stores are by no means as deep as the selections at the vast Levitz warehouses. But what the stores do offer is casual, slightly hip styles that are a far cry from leather easy chairs and glass coffee tables.
"Levitz was known for the great big velvet thing that guys love in the den," said Ms. Wray, the High Points editor. "But the consumer wants fashion. She wants to see what she sees on 'Friends.' That is why these life-style retailers like Pottery Barn have done well."
Tanisha Peten, who spent her lunch hour at Crate and Barrel in Manhattan yesterday, said she had turned to that store to furnish her Brooklyn apartment. "Those places like Levitz are too stuffy," she said. "This is more contemporary. It isn't like a place my parents would shop."
Pier 1 has made its name in fairly inexpensive wicker. Crate and Barrel has dining tables that look like antiques. Pottery Barn made a huge splash with inexpensive lamp shades fashioned from beads or in unusual colors like lavender and mint.
"Three years ago, people were more concerned with what color the fabric was," said Mr. Birnbach of Rowe Furniture. "Today, it is, 'Does it feel nice?' Chenilles and those kind of fabrics and bright colors are popular. Things are soft and casual, like the way we are living."
Ethan Allen Interiors is one of the few large furniture retailers that seems to have adjusted to changing tastes. The company, which makes its own furniture, was known since 1932 for its purely American colonial offerings. But over the last six years, Ethan Allen replaced nearly 90 percent of its merchandise, and half of it is now casual.
The company also trained its sales staff and hired interior decorators to help shoppers with decorating ideas. And uniquely, Ethan Allen's management is now 90 percent women, up from almost zero 10 years ago, said Farooq Kathwari, the company's chief executive. "That change was one of the most important we made," he added.
"The sensitivity toward advertising and color was missing," Mr. Kathwari said. A proposed new line of bedroom furniture was rejected recently, he said, because the female managers deemed the pieces too dark and not romantic enough.
The strategy has paid off. For the quarter ended June 30, Ethan Allen reported net income of $14.9 million, or $1.02 a share, up from $7.5 million, or 51 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Shares in the company have risen from about $20 in April to more than $30, adjusted for a split. It closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $33.375, up $1.25.
Ethan Allen aside, furniture may be one of the few areas in retailing where smaller can be better, analysts say, because economies of scale are hard to achieve, and managing a business where the product is cumbersome can be easier on an individual store level.
"Size can be a handicap," said David C. Childe, a retail analyst with Salomon Brothers. "The price differential between buying a couple of sofas and 100,000 sofas is not that great. Also, delivery schedules are hard to manage on a national level."
One relatively new entrant to the market is Rooms to Go, based in Seffner, Fla., and run by the Seaman family, which once owned the chain known best for its perpetual "one-time" sales. Seaman's was recently sold to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm.
Rooms to Go has 52 stores in 5 Southern states, serving up what are essentially Crate and Barrel knockoffs at a lower price. Customers see complete rooms decorated with contemporary furniture, a far cry from the screaming Seaman's ads that encouraged shoppers to come in and save money on dowdy living room sets jammed into a large showroom.
"Seaman's was a 1980's concept," said Jeffrey Seaman, president of Rooms to Go, which he started with his father in 1991. "Now, customers want simplicity. They want a clean presentation with a lot of clarity."
Can Levitz take a big national company with giant stores and make them work as well? The company has been dogged by cash problems for years. After going public in 1968, it was acquired in a leveraged buyout in 1985, only to go public again in 1993. But rather than pay down debt, it bought a small retailer in the Chicago area for cash and failed to invest in turning the company around. "We didn't make the changes we could have and should have with cost structure and merchandise," Mr. Bozic said.
With protection from creditors and a new mix of merchandise, Levitz may indeed have a new lease on life. But Wall Street will have to be patient, analysts say. "Turning around a furniture retailer is akin to turning around a battleship," Mr. Childe, the analyst, said. "It sometimes takes two years or so to get new customers."
But Ms. Wray and others say they have confidence in Mr. Bozic. "He has done an incredible job with what most people consider an unmanageable situation," she said. "They have been hamstrung by debt and an excess of real estate that didn't make sense, and previous management ran it into the ground. They just need more time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With large stores like this one in Queens, Levitz is one of several furniture chains that have struggled to keep up with changing consumer tastes. New entrants like Rooms to Go, below right, have become increasingly popular. (Photographs by Susan Farley (above) and Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Wrong Signal

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
If there is one person in the world who best symbolizes human resistance to tyranny, it is the Chinese prisoner Wei Jingsheng. Alone, he has challenged the most powerful tyranny on earth -- and been willing to pay the fearful price it exacted. For advocating democracy in China, he was imprisoned for 14 years and is now serving another 14-year sentence under brutal conditions.
In his courage, Wei Jingsheng speaks for the values of freedom that we Americans assert in the world and aim to protect. But if influential forces in Congress have their way, this country will soon tell the world that he and his cause matter less to us than another concern: religious persecution. 
 That would be the effect of legislation called the Freedom From Religious Persecution Act. Supported by fundamentalist and evangelical Christian denominations, it was endorsed this week by the Republican leaders of the House and Senate and seems headed for passage.
The bill would set up an Office of Religious Persecution Monitoring in the White House, independent of the State Department. Whenever the office's director found religious persecution in a country, regardless of other foreign-policy concerns, economic and other sanctions would automatically come into force against that country.
Anyone claiming to be a victim of religious persecution and seeking asylum in the United States would be given priority in consideration by our immigration authorities. The victims of torture, threatened assassination, female genital mutilation and other horrors would get shorter shrift.
Making religious persecution the paramount concern in our law of human rights would send a signal to other governments that we care less about such things as genocide, political repression and racial persecution. It would also tell the world that we now favor what we in this country have always opposed: the idea of a hierarchy of fundamental rights.
Asian autocrats such as Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore, seeking to justify their repression, have advanced the notion of "Asian values." To Asians, they said, a full stomach and an orderly society are more important than freedom of speech and other human rights. The U.S. stand against that destructive proposition would be undercut by a law indicating that some rights are more important to us than others.
The legislation reflects genuine and growing American concern about religious persecution in the world. The Chinese Government's restriction on Christian worship except in approved churches has drawn particular attention.
But as drafted, the bill would most likely make the U.S. Government less effective in combating religious persecution and in pressing more broadly for human rights. And it would complicate our foreign policy.
Consider Saudi Arabia, for example. A recent State Department report on religious discrimination in the world included a blistering section on Saudi Arabia. The director of the proposed new office in the White House could hardly fail to find that the Saudi Government engages in religious persecution.
The result would be to impose economic sanctions on Saudi Arabia and, among other things, subject its diplomats to intensified visa checks. Would that advance the cause of religious tolerance in Saudi Arabia?
China already presents daunting problems for Americans who want to advance human rights. Would there be a better chance of Wei Jingsheng's release from prison -- and of a general easing of repression -- if the United States denied most-favored-nation trading status to China? Or make political freedom follow increasing economic freedom? The questions are hard, and they would be made harder by a one-dimensional focus on religion.
The doubts about this legislation are increased by the fact that conservative Christian groups, including the Christian Coalition, are its strongest though not only backers. Of course their concern for persecuted Christians in the world is sincere. But they undoubtedly have another object, too: to advance their cause of giving religion a prime role in the American political structure.
Considering only the declared object of the bill -- the desirable end of fighting religious persecution in the world -- the means are mistaken. It is an attempt to impose a simple, mechanical solution on a complicated problem: a recipe for unintended consequences.

HEADLINE: Pillowtex to Acquire Fieldcrest for $400 Million

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The Pillowtex Corporation, a maker of textiles for the bedroom, said yesterday that it would acquire Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., another maker of household linens, for about $400 million in cash and stock. Including debt assumption, the value of the transaction is more than $700 million.
The merged company will be the third-largest player in the $3.6 billion home textile business, which includes towels, bed pillows, blankets and similar items, with about $1.5 billion in sales. 
 Although Pillowtex, which is based in Dallas, has far smaller sales than Fieldcrest -- about $500 million and $1 billion, respectively -- as well as a smaller market capitalization, Pillowtex has performed better than Fieldcrest, and is viewed as a stronger operator.
"It is kind of like David buying Goliath," said Josephine R. Esquivel, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter. "But because there is such little overlap in products, and because Fieldcrest has been such a weak player, I think it could be a very good move."
Outside of economies of scale in purchasing and merged back-room operations, Pillowtex reaps Fieldcrest's well-known brands in sheets, comforters, towels -- some of these areas that Pillowtex had no representation in.
"We feel that through this merger," said Charles M. Hansen, chief executive of Pillowtex in a telephone interview, "we can enhance brands by increase the depth of products and offering complete sets along product lines." For example, Mr. Hansen said, Fieldcrest's well-known Royal Velvet towel, the best- selling brand in the United States, or its Cannon lines could be extended to mattress pads, comforters and other bed products through the merged business. Pillowtex also sells the Ralph Lauren, Disney and Martha Stewart lines of towels and sheets.
Fieldcrest has had trouble getting its brand names to work as hard as they could for them, analysts said, and may have weakened their position by trying too hard to get into too many types of stores.
"Some of the brand positioning was not as well thought out as it should have been," Ms. Esquivel said. "And yet they have never been able to maximize those names. The other issue is that these mills in the United State have so aggressively targeted the Wal-Marts and Kmarts. A lot of people think that is smart, but once you start to fight for a penny business, you're looking at tight margins."
Mr. Hansen said that the merged company would spend money trying to enhance the combined brand names. "They spent $45 million on capital expenditures last year," he said. "And we will take it to $60 million this year."
Bear, Stearns & Company advised Pillowtex in the deal, and Fieldcrest Cannon was represented by Credit Suisse First Boston.
In the transaction, each Fieldcrest Cannon common share will be exchanged for $27 a share in cash and $7 of Pillowtex stock, while each Fieldcrest Cannon preferred share will be exchanged for $46.15 in cash and $11.97 in Pillowtex stock.
Pillowtex said it would finance the purchase with bank loans, new debt securities and a $65 million convertible preferred stock issue to Apollo Management L.P., an investment group led by the financier Leon Black. Mr. Hansen said that he expected the merger to result in $30 million in cost savings.
There has been speculation about such a merger, still subject to shareholder and regulatory agency approval, in the marketplace for more than a year. In July, when talk of the deal heated up, shares in both companies began long rides up. In April, Fieldcrest's shares traded around $15. They closed yesterday at $34.125, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Pillowtex traded around $16 in April, and closed yesterday at $28.25, up $4.4375.
Pillowtex had acquired a Fieldcrest Cannon blanket-making plant and assets for $30 million in November.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Off Sharply

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The number of unemployed workers filing initial claims for jobless benefits fell by 14,000 in the latest week, the Government said today, in part because of the shortened Labor Day holiday week. The Labor Department said 310,000 people filed first-time claims for state compensation in the week that ended last Saturday, down from 324,000 claims in the previous week. The figure was lower than expected by Wall Street economists, who had forecast 325,000 claims. The four-week moving average showed 324,000 new claims, down 1,750 from the prior week.
