HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Shrinks by 11.2% Annual Rate

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Japan's economy saw its sharpest contraction since the oil shock 23 years ago, with economic output in the second quarter falling at a startling annual rate of 11.2 percent, the Government said today.
While economists had expected a contraction because of the effects of a sharp increase in the national sales tax during the quarter, the size of the drop in output was surprising and dashed hopes that an early recovery from the nation's long economic slump was in the works. Japan had strong growth in the first quarter, and so officials had suggested that a turnaround was in the works. 
 The decline in output -- and particularly the fact that it was exacerbated by weak consumer demand -- is sure to fuel friction between Japanese and American officials, who have been urging Japan to pay closer attention to its domestic economy and not to try to export its way out of its slump. Strong Japanese exports and stagnant imports have contributed to a persistent climb in Japan's trade surplus, which rose again in July, the Government said today.
So, as the economy of the United States gallops along, with Europe cantering behind, the drop in Japan stands out as a major policy failure and underscores the enormous challenges that Japan still faces in trying to recover from its economic mess.
"It is a terribly shocking figure," said Masaru Takagi, chief economist at Fuji Research Institute. "I had a very negative outlook to begin with, but what happened was even worse."
The economy has dramatically seesawed this year primarily because of the increase in April, to 5 percent from 3 percent, in the sales tax on virtually all goods sold in Japan. Frantic buying ahead of the tax increase had helped Japan's economy -- its real gross domestic product -- leap ahead at an annual rate of 5.7 percent in the first quarter, compared with a year earlier, according to revised figures released today by the Government's Economic Planning Agency. In last year's second quarter, output shrank at an annual rate of 1.1 percent, though in the fourth quarter of 1996, it grew at a rate of 3.8 percent.
"Complete uncertainty prevails," said Jesper Koll, an economist at J. P. Morgan Securities Asia Ltd. in Tokyo. "It's such a Yo-Yo pattern, such a stop-and-go. And that's the problem for the recovery and for anyone dealing with Japan. Every other quarter the bulls are right. And every other quarter the bears are right."
Today's figures are embarrassing for policy makers particularly because the Government had repeatedly insisted that the economy was strong enough to bear the sales tax increase. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and the Finance Ministry have argued that only by raising taxes can they put the Government on a sounder financial footing.
But economists here said that policy makers clearly misjudged the impact of the tax increase, and the Economic Planning Agency's deputy minister, Shimpei Nukaya, acknowledged today that the contraction was larger than initially anticipated.
As recently as Wednesday, Finance Ministry officials were declaring that Japan's economy continued to be on a mild recovery trend. And after the figures were announced today, Deputy Finance Minister Takeshi Komura gave an optimistic view of the economy.
"The tempo of economic recovery has slowed down temporarily in reaction to a buying rush ahead of the April 1 consumption tax hike," Mr. Komura said at a news conference today. "But the Government has not changed its view that the economy is slowly continuing to recover."
Mr. Takagi at the Fuji Research Institute, however, warned that Japan's economy stood on a fragile base and might be entering a recession, and several economists said the economy was unlikely to match the Government's growth target of 1.9 percent for the fiscal year ending next March 31.
Still, other economists said that the second quarter probably represented the bottom of the cycle.
"Delayed is the right word, not derailed," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers Inc. in Tokyo. "But the Japanese Government has a lot of work to do, and the Japanese Prime Minister would be the first to admit that."
Japan is likely to be severely criticized at the coming meeting in Hong Kong of the Group of Seven industrial countries. Prime Minister Hashimoto and other Japanese officials have personally told American officials, like Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, that Japan will not export its way out of its economic woes but instead will rely on growth from the domestic economy.
In fact, figures released today showed that the only bright spot in the economy was exports, which lessened the economic contraction by one percentage point for the quarter, while all other areas of potential growth -- from consumer buying power to corporate and housing investment -- were in retreat. Indeed, trade figures also released today showed that Japan's July current account surplus, measuring the flow of goods, services, investment income and other transfers, surged by 63 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier.
This was the fourth straight monthly increase in the current account surplus and raised new concern about Japan's trade relationship with America. A key benchmark -- the ratio of the surplus to gross domestic product -- rose to 2.6 percent, above the target that American officials have said they feel comfortable with, and this development is likely to raise trade frictions between America and Japan.
Perhaps in anticipation of the American response, Deputy Finance Minister Komura added today, "We are ready to promote domestic demand-led economic growth through further deregulation and fiscal structural reform."
Indeed, some economists said that today's figures could prompt the Government to abandon its fiscal austerity program and perhaps even cut corporate taxes, a move that has been encouraged by a number of Government ministries.
"For Japan to be a good global citizen," Mr. Koll at J. P. Morgan said. "It needs additional policy stimulus."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Extend Losses A Third Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities lost ground for the third consecutive day yesterday, with traders and investors concerned that today's reports on producer prices and retail sales would show rapid growth and inflation pressures.
The 30-year bond fell 1 3/32, to a price of 96. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.69 percent, from 6.65 percent on Wednesday. 
 The average rate at the Treasury's one-year bill auction yesterday was 5.30 percent, up two-hundredths of a percentage point from last month's auction. Market analysts said selling in futures trading contributed to the negative sentiment in the cash market as well.
The supply of corporate and global debt also remained a concern of market participants, but was not seen as a major problem. The Nationsbank Corporation sold $4 billion in asset-backed debt, while Venezuela issued the same amount of 30-year bonds. The Treasury added to that with the sale of $12.5 billion of a new 52-week bill that was well bid and helped by the flight out of a slumping stock market, as the Dow dropped below 7,600 for the first time since June 26.
A morning report on weekly jobless claims raised eyebrows with a larger-than-expected drop. The weekly jobless claims for the period ended Saturday, fell 14,000, to 310,000, from the previous week, helping to further unnerve a bond market already on edge in anticipation of today's economic data for August. These indicators, along with next Tuesday's Consumer Price Index, industrial production and capacity utilization data, are likely to determine the bond market's direction and tone over the next couple of weeks.
"The Federal Open Market Committee, and particularly Fed chairman Greenspan, is known to be looking at consumer spending as the key to the economic outlook," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "and if August retail sales rise by six-tenths of a percent or higher, as many market observers expect, it will certainly lend credence to the view that consumption during the third quarter is rebounding at roughly a 4 percent pace."
Mr. Fine added: "This would most assuredly raise a yellow caution flag at the Fed, and while it may not be enough at this point to turn the tide toward tightening at the Sept. 30 F.O.M.C. powwow, any continuation of this robust consumer spending over the next two months would clearly raise the probability of a move to a less accommodative posture at the November meeting."
Inflation as measured by the core rates, excluding food and energy, for both the Producer Price Index today and Consumer Price Index on Tuesday is expected to remain subdued. But a less favorable picture is likely to emerge for the overall indexes, Mr. Fine said. In both cases the disturbing element is expected to be gasoline prices, and as a result the Producer Price Index is expected by many analysts to rise three-tenths or four-tenths of a percent.
On the heels of seven consecutive monthly declines, a jump this large will certainly be noticed. "Indeed," Mr. Fine said, "even if both retail sales and the P.P.I. hit the tapes as expected, bond market yields could still move to higher ground over time, and while an unchanged Fed policy over the near term seems to be the most likely prognosis at the moment, it is by no means carved in stone."
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of a new 52-week bill:

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall for 2d Day on Profit Forecasts

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Most major stock market indexes fell for a second day yesterday as investors reacted to another round of company announcements of expected earnings shortfalls in the third quarter.
In particular, Ascend Communications and Corning suffered heavy declines after both companies announced that third-quarter earnings would probably fall below forecasts. 
 In response to such news, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 58.30 points, to 7,660.98. The Dow is now only 38.56 points above the low of 7,622.42 it touched after reaching its record high of 8,259.31 on Aug. 6.
The Standard and Poor's index of 500 companies slipped 6.44, to 912.59.
But the Nasdaq composite index, which contains a concentration of small companies and technology stocks, managed to eke out a gain of 0.61 point, to 1,639.86.
The previous day's drop -- the Dow fell more than 130 points on Wednesday -- was caused in part by the recent strength of the dollar. Investors fear that a stronger dollar could reduce the earnings of large, multinational companies, which gain a portion of their revenues from business activities abroad.
But the dollar was mixed yesterday. It declined against the German mark for the second consecutive session but continued its strong performance against the Japanese yen and most Southeast Asian currencies. Prices of Treasury securities fell for a third day, and the yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.69 percent.
Still, investors remained skittish amid the latest earnings disappointments and as they awaited the release of some of the first August inflation indicators, today's Producer Price Index and retail sales reports.
"There is a real worry in the stock and bond markets that things may have accelerated on the economic side in August," said Hugh Johnson chief investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation.
After the close of trading yesterday, there was another jolt: Motorola announced that its third-quarter earnings would be hurt by weakening demand for pagers in the United States and China and because of a one-time $95 million charge for leaving the market for Apple Macintosh computer clones.
As trading opened, stocks immediately moved lower, with the Dow off as much as 138.43 points at one point. But equity prices moved away from the lows in the afternoon, analysts said, because investors were encouraged by comments from two market watchers.
In a speech in Denver to some regional board members of the Federal Reserve, Alice Rivlin, the Fed vice chairwoman, reiterated a stance taken last week by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, saying that the economy has been growing strongly and experiencing low unemployment without a significant pickup in inflation.
Some investors took that to mean that the Fed might be reluctant to raise interest rates.
In addition, Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of Goldman, Sachs & Company's investment policy committee, said in an interview in a French magazine that she thought that stocks would recover from their recent lows and set new records.
Ascend Communications, a computer networking company, was the most actively traded issue, with 27.7 million shares trading. Shares of the company fell more than 5 percent amid concerns that slowing sales and growing competition would hurt third-quarter earnings. Ascend fell 2 3/16, to 37 13/16, a 52-week low.
In addition, Corning shares fell 11.5 percent, or 5 7/16, to 41 15/16. The glass materials and component manufacturer cited decreased demand from telecommunications equipment manufacturers for its fiber optic equipment.
Motorola moved little during the day but plunged in after-hours trading, when it fell 8 3/8, to 66.
But not all of the earnings news was negative.
Adobe Systems rose 3 9/16, to 44 9/16, after the company said it expected to exceed analysts' forecasts because of strong orders for its desktop publishing and graphics software products.
AT&T shares gained 1 1/16, to 43, because of investor optimism that the company would meet earnings forecasts, analysts said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Profit Warnings Push Most Market Indexes Down
Warnings from Ascend Communications, Corning and other companies about earnings coming in lower than expected sent most major stock market indexes falling again. 
 The Dow industrials were down 58.30 points, to 7,660.98. But the Nasdaq managed a tiny gain. [Page D6.]

Shares of two biotechnology companies rose on positive clinical trial data. The concerns are Immunex, which has a new drug for rheumatoid arthritis, and Scios, which has a drug for congestive heart failure. [D13.]
 
A Merger in Household Linens
Pillowtex is buying Fieldcrest Cannon for about $400 million in cash and stock, creating the third-largest home textiles business. [D6.]
 
Aerospace Industry Merger Talks
Rohr, which makes housing compartments for airliner engines, said it might be acquired for stock valued at $847 million, but would not identify the company with which it is in talks until negotiations are completed. One analyst said the most likely buyers were Lockheed Martin or Northrop Grumman. [D2.]
 
Overseer Ponders Carey's Fate
The Federal official overseeing the International Brotherhood of Teamsters election said new evidence and new witnesses were causing her to reconsider her decision not to disqualify the union's president, Ron Carey, from running for re-election. [A14.]
 
Marvel Lacks a Deal With Creditors
Spider-Man can do it all on the comic pages, so perhaps he should be called into action to produce a miracle for his parent company, Marvel Entertainment. Right now Marvel's efforts to emerge from bankruptcy have been unsuccessful, in large part because the players are unable to fashion a deal that everyone can accept. Marvel's latest financing package is set to expire next week, but it plans to offer a new deal. [D2.]
 
Mexico Debates Its Financial State
President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico and his economic team are defending the fiscal discipline they have championed, but critics say that their policies have not benefited working people. [D4.]
 
Current-Account Gap Narrows
The United States' deficit on the current account, which measures trade in goods, services and investments, narrowed to $39.03 billion in the second quarter from a revised $39.97 billion in the first quarter. [D2.]
 
La Jolla Capital Penalized
Regulators ordered La Jolla Capital and five of its current and former executives to pay $912,385 in penalties for inducing customers to sign misleading letters in a scheme to evade penny-stock rules. [D13.]
 
Treasury Securities Decline
Treasury securities lost ground for the third consecutive day, with traders and investors concerned that today's reports on producer prices and retail sales would show rapid growth and inflation pressures. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.69 percent from 6.65 percent. [D13.]
 
Dollar Falls Against Mark
The dollar hit a two-month low against the mark. It rose against the yen after the Japanese Government reported that its economy contracted at an annual rate of 11.2 percent in the second quarter. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Salmon War in Northwest Spurs Wish for Good Fences

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 11

 BODY:
It started with a maritime blockade angry Canadian fishermen holding an Alaska ferry at bay for three days. Then came an abrupt move to shut down an American torpedo-testing range in British Columbia, followed by three international lawsuits and a barrage of insults between politicians who usually excel at cross-border backslapping.
Talk radio in Vancouver has been hot with anti-American sentiment, while south of the 49th parallel, a Seattle newspaper ran a suggestive headline: "Let's Take Canada, Eh?" 
 This is war, both sides insist, though it is only the kind of war that a region once called Ecotopia could produce -- the "salmon war," a fight over who gets to keep fish that are ignorant of an invisible line of sovereignty in 52-degree water.
It is somewhat surprising that people are at each other's throats over the most sacred of regional icons: "salmon, our statue of liberty," in the words of Ethan Seltzer, a professor of urban studies at Portland State University.
But what has perplexed many in the Pacific Northwest and British Columbia is that an area that has held itself up as a 21st-century model -- a bio-region without borders -- has fallen into old-fashioned nationalism: flag-burnings, insults based on national stereotypes, and even a mild version of gunboat diplomacy.
All of this was not supposed to happen in the self-named region of Cascadia, a region that shares a rainy climate, a culture tilting toward Asia and a sense that it is the envy of the world.
"You don't go around saying some of the things that have been said in recent days without causing some serious, long-term damage," said Alan Artibise, president of the Cascadia Institute, a nonprofit research group in Vancouver. "If we can't cooperate over the very thing that we brag about so much, which we all love, what does that say about us?"
Raising the stakes in the conflict, Premier Glen Clark of British Columbia filed a lawsuit in Seattle this week, contending that American fishermen had broken an international treaty, and seeking damages from the United States in excess of $300 million. The suit has infuriated Washington's normally low-key Governor, Gary Locke, a Democrat.
Premier Clark had already taken aim at Governor Locke and others in an extraordinary advertising campaign this summer, in which he accused Americans of trying to kill the great salmon bounty.
"I had a private talk with Premier Clark, and he made it very clear to me he's willing to grandstand this issue, and fish the salmon to extinction if that's what it takes," Mr. Locke said in an interview. "He's very good at trying to stir up feelings of resentment against us. That won't save a single fish."
The Canadians say Americans are taking more than 500,000 sockeye salmon as they swim through Alaskan waters on their way south to Canada to spawn. The Americans say the Canadians have excessively fished the prized coho and chinook salmon off British Columbia as they make their way to American spawning waters.
The British Columbians, who have long regarded their distant capital in Ottawa the way many Pacific Northwesterners regard their distant capital in Washington, D.C., filed the lawsuit against the wishes of their own national government, which is the only body than can negotiate international salmon treaties. But even though the fight involves perhaps no more than 300 fishing jobs, it has symbolic resonance that goes well beyond its economic numbers.
"The people of British Columbia are with me," Mr. Clark said. "That's all I care about. This fight goes to the very soul of British Columbia."
In fact, it goes to the soul of the entire region, an area promoted abroad as a "two-nation vacation," and held up by President Clinton as a model of Pacific Age cooperation. In art, literature, trade, transportation, food trends and geographic self-identity, the Cascadia region of Oregon, Washington, British Columbia and southeastern Alaska has seemed to grow closer every year.
But all of that changed in July, when nearly a hundred Canadian fishing boats prevented the Alaska ferry Malaspina from leaving the British Columbia port of Prince Rupert. It was a protest, they said, against American fishing of salmon bound for Canadian spawning streams.
A month before the blockade, four American fishing ships were detained in a British Columbia port, prompting Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, to suggest a Coast Guard or Navy escort for other fishing vessels.
What started as a fishing dispute spread. After the the three-day blockade, Alaska canceled ferry service to Prince Rupert, cutting off a main two-way tourist link. Merchants in the town say they have lost nearly half their summer business, and have been flooded with phone calls by people wondering if it is safe to travel the normally placid byways of British Columbia.
"We've been getting all kinds of messages from people concerned about their safety, people wondering if they should change their American license plates to avoid trouble once they get here," said Bill Smith, the city manager of Prince Rupert. "We have so much in common, it just doesn't make any sense to be hammering at each other like this."
This week Alaskan officials announced the cancellation of ferry service to Prince Rupert through the summer of next year, as well. The cancellation came after Premier Clark tried to evict the United States Navy from a torpedo testing range at Nanoose Bay, British Columbia. The effort has been halted, temporarily, by the Canadian Government, which asserts that the province does not have jurisdiction over the Navy's lease.
As much as the ferry blockade incensed people, the burning of an American flag at the height of the Prince Rupert protest is frequently evoked in talk radio and newspaper letters as a flare-up point for long-dormant nationalism.
But Mr. Smith noted that the flag-burner was a fisherman with both Canadian and United States citizenship, making the point that perhaps Cascadia lives even in a salmon war.
The last time the word "war" was widely used to describe a conflict between two countries was in 1859, and a pig was at the root of the dispute. A pig owned by a British settler on San Juan Island in Juan de Fuca Strait, north of Puget Sound, wandered into the potato patch of an American farmer, who shot it. The British said the farmer had no right to shoot a pig on British soil, though the Americans also claimed the island.
The United States deployed troops to San Juan and British warships promptly appeared, but the "pig war" ended without a shot being fired. The boundary dispute was finally resolved in 1872, when the San Juan archipelago was given to the United States.
Much of the current conflict has been characterized as a comic descendant of the pig war.
"It reminds me of that Monty Python movie with a siege at a medieval castle," said Mr. Seltzer, the Portland State professor. "One side throws insults down the wall and the other threatens to hurl cows back."
Recent polls show that the heated talk has helped Mr. Clark, who is in his second year as Premier of the most prosperous province in Canada. But the Canadian Government has been urging him to back down and let American and Canadian diplomats work toward a renewed salmon treaty. Provisions that govern the number of fish that can be taken by each side expired in 1994.
Mr. Clark said he expects the current diplomatic efforts to go nowhere. "They are just talking about talk," he said. So he is using lawsuits, the threat to the torpedo range and media pressure to force the issue.
The Premier expressed sympathy with the ferry blockade, calling the action of the fishermen "courageous." They have been sued by the State of Alaska for causing a loss of millions of dollars in revenue.
Governor Locke expressed hope that the salmon war was only between politicians. "Mr. Clark has made this very personal, by attacking the leaders in the United States," he said. "The bond between our people remains strong."
The view in another reach of Cascadia is somewhat different. "We have a saying here in Canada," said Mr. Artibise in Vancouver. "The Americans are our best friends, whether we like them or not."

Map of Canada and Washington showing locations of Vancouver and Seattle: A region called Cascadia shares a climate, culture and icon: salmon. (pg. A26)

HEADLINE: Major Shift for Communist China: Big State Industries Will Be Sold

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Friday, Sept. 12

 BODY:
China's leaders have agreed to sell off most of the nation's big state-owned industries, and outlined plans today at the opening of a Communist Party congress that is setting the nation's political and economic agenda for the post-Deng era.
A central theme of the congress, the party's 15th, will be endorsing a ground-breaking shift from socialist-style state ownership to a system of share-holding. More than 10,000 of China's 13,000 large and medium-sized state enterprises are likely to be sold, though many issues -- like who the buyers will be -- remain unclear. 
 Elder party members have objected that China may be dissolving the last solid pillar of its socialist system, but President Jiang Zemin has apparently persuaded decision-makers that they can no longer afford the burden of inefficient and money-losing industries, no matter the risks.
Still ruled by a party that calls itself Communist, however, Mr. Jiang and his allies are relying on semantical gymnastics to justify the move. Avoiding the word "privatization," they instead insists that when ordinary people buy shares of stock it is a form of "public ownership."
"Even if the state-owned sector accounts for a smaller proportion of the economy, this will not affect the socialist nature of our country," Mr. Jiang said today in a speech at the opening of the congress.
By whatever name, Chinese leaders are essentially abandoning what has been a central principle of Communist rule since the revolution here nearly 50 years ago: that the state would retain its position as the dominant owner of industry.
"What is socialism?" said Dong Fureng, a senior economist advising government leaders on how to make the shift to share-holding. "It means seeking social equality, not that the state has to keep a majority stake in every industry."
The long-term effect of changing such a critical system of ownership, perhaps lying beyond the political calculus of leaders now consumed by short-term crises, seems destined to move China's economy toward an even more capitalist and free market system, one where the Communist Party may have difficulty preserving the role it has today.
For now, however, the party dominates politics in this country, and the congress, with more than 2,000 delegates, is the most important political gathering here since the last party congress five years ago. With the main policy issue already decided, the principal drama at the weeklong congress is expected to lie in changes in the top leadership.
Since China's leaders still select themselves and make important decisions in secret, with little accountability to public opinion, high-level politics resemble a continuous campaign of infighting and ever-shifting alliances among the 19 members of the Politburo, particularly among the top three: President Jiang, Prime Minister Li Peng and the legislative chief, Qiao Shi.
A party congress is generally stage-managed to display an aura of unity to the public, while the senior leaders are actually involved in intense power struggles backstage, sometimes yielding important decisions only at the last minute.
One of the most-watched issues at this year's congress is what jobs await Mr. Jiang's top colleagues and rivals, Mr. Li and Mr. Qiao, both of whom are expected to relinquish their current positions. Though the congress has begun, the answers remain uncertain.
Like all capital cities, Beijing thrives on rumors and intrigue. But the center of power here is so well concealed by secretive tradition, and insulated by loyal aides, that outsiders rarely learn much about inside politics until well after the fact, if then.
It is clear, however, that the 15th party congress -- coming six months after the death of Deng Xiaoping -- is well timed to showcase Mr. Jiang as the leader likely to dominate the near future. A move to enshrine "Deng Xiaoping theory" in China's Constitution alongside "Mao Zedong Thought" appears to be an effort to line Mr. Jiang up as a leader on a par with Mao and Deng.
Although economic reality is helping force Mr. Jiang's hand on state enterprises, the political timetable of the party congress may have spurred him to act sooner than he would otherwise. Mr. Jiang needs to show he can be bold and is not just a follower of Deng, and reforming state ownership is the issue he has grasped.
Shifting ownership is a tremendously complex legal and organizational challenge, several economists said, with a serious danger that state assets will disappear into the pockets of factory managers during the transition. Industrial managers, traditionally an important constituency in China, are likely either to become corporate executives, or to get left out of the new system altogether if they cannot adjust.
Many officials argue that despite the planned changes, the state may remain the main owner in China for some time, since in many cases the shift to a share-holding system will transfer ownership to shares controlled by a specific government-run organization or company.
Since the plans have not yet been announced in detail, it is unclear exactly what role the state will play. Yet a vast sale of state assets will sharply reduce central control over large enterprises.
At greatest risk may be tens of millions of urban workers whose jobs are at stake. Yet leaders seem to think their best hope is to brave layoffs, which are inevitable, at a time when the overall economy is growing fast and some labor can be absorbed by non-state companies that are expanding.
After all, China's recent economic history has confounded most experts, domestic and foreign.
Not long ago, it was inconceivable that ordinary people in China would be able to buy and sell shares of stock freely, or have access to almost any consumer goods on the world market. Or that such choice would be accompanied by a significant loosening of government control over daily life, like choosing a job or where to live.
Perhaps the greatest paradox in China today is the way its enormous economic and social change over the last decade has seen virtually no corresponding alteration of the political structure, which is still dominated by Communist Party officials.
"There is no real point in talking about political reform at this point," said a Chinese political scientist in Beijing. "Leaders will not change the system themselves, they will only respond to demands from society. So ownership reform is very meaningful in that it gives ordinary people a voice."
In recent years, though the private sector of China's economy has grown fast while the state sector atrophied, leaders seemed stymied about what to do with state industries, which have always been described as the unshakable core of China's economic system. Before starting any bold initiatives, it seemed, leaders were waiting for Mr. Deng's death, which finally came this year on Feb. 19.
Mr. Jiang broached the topic of ownership reform in May in a speech at the Central Committee's Party School, winning consensus from other leaders over the summer.
On Sept. 2, the New China News Agency carried an authoritative report specifying that more than 10,000 of the nation's 13,000 large and medium-sized enterprises would be "encouraged to switch to various forms of public ownership."
"The financial dilemma of the state sector continues to be the outstanding problem of the Chinese economy," the agency said. "But hope returned when Chinese President Jiang Zemin called for a powerful change in economic reform."
The same dispatch was accompanied by a spirited rejection of any suggestion that Mr. Jiang might be endorsing privatization, which has always been a bad word in Communist China's political lexicon.
"The share-holding system has nothing to do with privatization," said Wang Jiaqiu, vice president of the Party School, the news agency reported. "The system only provides a method to achieve public ownership and will bring no change to the present economic structure where public ownership is in the leading position."
Stressing "public ownership," while selling state industry, recalls Chinese slogans like "a socialist market economy" or "socialism with Chinese characteristics," that justify a capitalist economic necessity by invoking socialist ideology.
A key role in Mr. Jiang's efforts to push through approval of a share-holding system will be played by the man most likely to carry it out: Deputy Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, who is widely expected to become Prime Minister next year. Sometimes called "China's Gorbachev" by Westerners who see him as a strict manager and visionary, Mr. Zhu is said to hate the name, worrying that it exposes him to accusations that his leadership might lead to the undermining of the party.
A former Mayor and party chief of Shanghai, where he battled an entrenched bureaucracy and began a stunning economic transformation, Mr. Zhu moved to Beijing in 1993 to take the seemingly impossible task of bringing order to China's economy. Inflation had surged to 24 percent and raised fears that it would provoke unrest among China's low-paid factory workers.
Mr. Zhu dismissed the head of China's central bank, assuming the job himself and instituting a strict credit policy that was deeply unpopular with factory heads, who were used to getting whatever subsidies and loans they needed. To virtually everyone's surprise, Mr. Zhu stuck to his position, and inflation fell to 2 percent in this year's second quarter, without hampering China's overall economic growth rate.
Now Mr. Zhu has pledged that he will attack state-owned enterprises with the same vigor to achieve their reform within three years.
"The key problem in China's industry is that ownership is unclear," said He Yang, a former official who now runs his own investment company. "People say 'the state,' but who is that? The central government? A certain ministry? A local government? Everyone wants to exert authority, and take profit, but no one wants to take responsibility when there are losses."
Mr. He cited a typical predicament for a large electronics company: the State Planning Commission supervises its investment plans, the Ministry of Electronics Industry appoints its leaders and the Ministry of Internal Trade looks after its sales.
"They all want power, none want responsibility," Mr. He said. "No one, and I mean no one, takes responsibility when a company fails. It's always someone else's fault."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 17, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the Communist Party congress in China misstated the date of the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in central Beijing. It was 1989, not 1988.

Chart: "KEEPING TRACK: Erosion of Maoism"
 
1977 - 11TH PARTY CONGRESS
A year after the Cultural Revolution ended, Mao's successor, Hua Guofeng, promises to uphold Maoist policy, speaks about inevitability of a world war and describes relations with the United States as "temporary, vacillating, unstable, unreliable and conditional."
 
1982 - 12TH PARTY CONGRESS
Deng Xiaoping, now the undisputed leader, presides over a gathering that repudiates everything endorsed at the previous congress. His hand-picked deputy, Hu Yaobang, calls Maoism "wrong in its theories, policies and slogans." Deng presses his campaign to build "socialism with Chinese characteristics," including disbanding communes and allowing farmers to sell grain on an open market.
 
1987 - 13TH PARTY CONGRESS
With Deng in the background and Hu sacked nine months earlier, Zhao Ziyang presides as the new party chief. He says China is in "the primary stage of socialism," meaning that since Communism will not be reached for another 100 years, it is O.K. to experiment with distinctly non-Communist measures, like profit incentives for factories and free enterprise on a small scale.
 
1992 - 14TH PARTY CONGRESS
With Zhao sacked after resisting the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1988, Jiang Zemin is the new Communist Party chief, but relies heavily on the authority of the frail Deng. Making a "socialist market economy" is the favored phrase, meaning any effort can be made to achieve an efficient market economy as long as everything is called socialist.
 
1997 - 15TH PARTY CONGRESS
With Deng dead and other rivals sidelined, Jiang asserts his authority as the new leader of China. A plan to sell most state-owned industries to a share- holding system is deemed appropriate by calling it "public ownership" instead of the "state ownership" that is mandated in the Constitution.

HEADLINE: Don't Fear Inflation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 6 Business Day article on the latest public statement by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, highlighted his recognition that recent robust economic growth, coupled with little price inflation, has not been in accord with historical experience. As a result, the Fed's analysts are handicapped for lack of accurate data to work on.
Fiscal policy is drastically tighter today than it was in the 1980's and early 90's. Thus, the Federal budget is no longer pouring huge amounts of excess liquidity into the economy, leaving the job of overall demand management to the Fed. On the contrary, fiscal policy is automatically draining away a large part of any excess liquidity through its shift toward budget surpluses. 
 In this environment, the Fed must be careful not to be an agent of instability. Premature tightening of monetary policy could result in a sharp slide back into budget deficit. Mr. Greenspan, knowing this, is unlikely to try to constrain growth without more evidence than we have that demand is outrunning productivity.
Alarmists who see inflation lurking behind every bush are failing to recognize a big change in the Federal budget's role as an automatic stabilizer.
 
LEON KOROBOW
Great Neck, N.Y., Sept. 7, 1997
 
The writer is a retired assistant vice president and economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Seeing Money as the Ruler, More Despotic Than Kind

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
The United States has a new social disease, or maybe it's just an old one with a new name. As introduced on Monday, "Affluenza" is "an unhappy condition of overload, debt, anxiety and waste resulting from the dogged pursuit of more." Among the symptoms collected by doctors, psychologists, environmentalists, poll experts, therapists and authors of books with titles like "Marketing Madness" and "Your Money or Your Life" are swollen expectations, shopping fever, chronic stress and fractured families.
Scott Simon of National Public Radio sets the program's tone, delivering the dire diagnosis with a smile, relieving his moralisms with mild jokes. His concerns are heavy, his touch is light. 
 From the ancient prophets to today's public scolds, the basic ailment -- money as the root of malaise -- has not gone unnoticed, but the desperate cases described here seem particularly susceptible to the merchandising mania of our time: young couples, inveigled into accepting credit cards and whipped into a frenzy of shopping by television commercials, spend their waking hours at malls, plunge into bankruptcy and wind up feeling that their lives are as empty as their bank accounts.
Monday night's anti-materialistic alliance finds conservative evangelical ministers joining liberal secularists in an anti-buying campaign. They are especially troubled by advertising's power over children, who learn the brand names before they learn to read, and quickly master the 11th Commandment -- Thou Must Have That -- before finding out about the others. (A Disney marketeer explains that his high-pressure tactics are "empowering" children.)
As long as "Affluenza" demonstrates how the buy-buy-buy engine runs the economy and directs mass desires, it is persuasive if not notably original. (Thorstein Veblen had something to say about such matters a century ago.) And the advice to the stressed-out to reflect on the meaning of things is surely wholesome.
This otherwise welcome and peppy program may leave the impression that if only the marketers and advertisers laid off, the rich would be less hoggish and the poor would be more content. When it turns to the gap between rich and poor in the United States and elsewhere, the program becomes a touch soft-minded as well as soft-hearted: two young women who have visited Mexico report that Mexicans are loving and giving despite being poor. And it is wishfully suggested that an anti-growth movement is asurge around the world.
Despite claims made in the program for the spread of thrift and the celebration of those who are snipping up their credit cards and going in for "voluntary simplicity," my money remains on the power of conspicuous consumption.
 
'Wallace Stegner'
'A Writer's Life'
PBS, tomorrow night at 7
 This affectionate portrait concentrates on Wallace Stegner's vision of America's West, which contradicted Hollywood's wide-open-spaces mythology. Best remembered for his early novel, "Big Rock Candy Mountain," and for "Angle of Repose," which brought him a Pulitzer Prize, Stegner saw the region's history as a series of raids by the powerful on the powerless for control of nature's riches. His heart was with the little losers and the big country.
The program makes striking use of pictures of the lands that inspired both Stegner's fiction and his articles in behalf of conservation. The narration, delivered by Robert Redford, avoids the shadows of literary criticism. Whatever the fate of his reputation as a writer, Stegner, who was extensively interviewed in the months before his death in 1993, makes a thoughtful, likable, unassuming commentator on his career.

HEADLINE: Life Insurer, In Comeback, Is Set for Sale

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Six years after the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company became the largest American insurance company ever to collapse, the company has been revived and is expected to announce on Monday that it is for sale.
No price has been established, but investment bankers estimate that the company could bring as much as $1.5 billion. 
 The book value, or net worth, of the company is about $500 million, and life insurers have sold recently for up to two and a half to three times book value.
For the 450,000 policyholders and pension plan members of Mutual Benefit, a sale should come as much-awaited good news. The uncertainty of the future of their investments will be gone, the interest rates on their investments will be restored to at least market rates and they will share in the proceeds of the sale.
Investment bankers and insurance analysts said they expected, as one banker put it, "significant interest in this situation."
"Everybody in the business is looking to achieve economies of scale," the banker said. "The size is right. It's large enough, but not so large as to knock out a lot of potential buyers."
Some analysts said they expected to see low bids because as a company in rehabilitation -- the insurance equivalent of bankruptcy -- Mutual Benefit has been on the sidelines of the industry, unable to generate new business and keep up with advances in technology and product design. Yet Ronald McIntosh, an insurance analyst at the Fox-Pitt Kelton brokerage firm, said, "These types of distressed and recovered properties have provided very handsome returns to people who have bought them in the past."
Alan J. Bowers, the chief executive, said the company, which now operates as the MBL Life Assurance Corporation, plans to formally announce its sale intentions on Monday. He has been briefing employees, creditors and policyholder representatives since the board voted unanimously on Tuesday in favor of selling.
A sale will be subject to the approval of the company's major creditors, the New Jersey Superior Court and Elizabeth E. Randall, the Commissioner of Banking and Insurance in New Jersey.
Ms. Randall, who, at the direction of the court has been presiding over the recovery as chairman of Mutual Benefit, said the company had fully recovered and was ready to resume normal operations, more than two years before the target date of Dec. 31, 1999.
"The company is in exceptionally good health," Ms. Randall said, "and is now being offered for sale."
Larry Mayewski, a senior insurance analyst at the A. M. Best Company, a rating agency, said that potential buyers might include some of the big mutual life insurance companies like Prudential Insurance, Metropolitan Life, New York Life and John Hancock. Other analysts said that American General and Conseco, which have been leading a consolidation trend, might also want to take a look.
The Newark-based Mutual Benefit was seized by New Jersey insurance regulators on July 16, 1991, as the gap between its assets and its liabilities grew to an estimated $1 billion. Since then, it has essentially been a company frozen in time.
Still, it does have several selling points, including 450,000 customers who hung on to their policies and pension plans rather than cash out at a steep discount. It also has assets of $14 billion, which produced revenues last year of $2.1 billion, and an investment portfolio that is heavy on corporate bonds and light on real estate, the reverse of the situation when the company was taken over by the regulators. Its net worth has risen to about $500 million from $57 million in 1994, with the increase attributed mainly to the sale of real estate.
Analysts said the company was coming on the market at a time when there are more buyers than sellers and prices are good. "It's entirely possible that one of the leading acquirers will look at this block of business and conclude that they can cut costs materially or improve the claims experience and make a bid," said Eric N. Berg, an insurance analyst at Oppenheimer & Company.
"There are two parts that people look at in valuing a life insurance company," Mr. Berg said. "The insurance already on the books and the value that flows from having agents that can produce new business. Today distribution -- the sales force -- is at a premium."
Although MBL Life has no full-time agents, the company has about 2,500 independent agents under limited contract, many of whom were part of a 1,400-member force that was disbanded after Mutual Benefit's collapse. They have been collecting commissions on policy renewals and responding to customer queries.
Those independent agents, Mr. Berg said, add something to the price of the company. "These are agents that are familiar with the company and willing to produce new sales for it," he said. "There's value there."
Mutual Benefit's troubles began in the 1980's when, trying to provide high interest rates that would keep its insurance policies and pension plans competitive, it invested heavily in real estate and leveraged buyouts. But real estate prices collapsed, and many of the buyout deals failed. The company's ratings then began to fall, and customers started cashing in their policies and pensions. The company, however, could not raise money from the depressed real estate and, with the company's deficit growing, the regulators stepped in.
Many insurance companies got into similar difficulties, and several failed. Mutual Benefit was the biggest, ranked 21st at that time in terms of assets, behind Allstate's life insurance operations, which had $14.8 billion in assets.
The recovery was begun by the Palmieri Company, a turnaround specialist firm led by Victor H. Palmieri. He had made a name for himself by nursing the Penn Central Transportation Company back to health in the early 1970's but he lost some of his luster when he was unable to resuscitate the Crazy Eddie electronics retailer in the late 1980's. The plan Mr. Palmieri developed for Mutual Benefit -- which was paid for by Mutual Benefit and involved no financial cost to New Jersey or industry-backed guarantee funds -- called for hiring an executive to complete the job. In mid-1995, Mr. Bowers, a managing partner in the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, was named chief executive.
Mr. Bowers accelerated the sale of real estate and the investment in bonds, and negotiated an end to a dispute between creditors and policyholders over the assets of the company. The 14 major creditors, including the Bank of America, Bankers Trust New York, Morgan Guaranty Trust and Citibank, along with hundreds of smaller creditors eventually agreed to accept 70 percent of the company, leaving 30 percent to the policyholders. When the company is sold, the proceeds will be shared in those proportions.
For the last several months, Mr. Bowers and his staff; the Monitor Company, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., founded by Michael Porter of the Harvard Business School, and investment bankers from Goldman, Sachs & Company have been studying whether the company should resume regular business on its own, enter a joint venture or be sold. In a two-day meeting on Monday and Tuesday, Mr. Bowers reviewed the options with the 10-member board of MBL Life and the board chose the option of selling. Goldman, Sachs is to handle the transaction, Mr. Bowers said.
In the end, Mr. Bowers said, the pivotal question became whether "to try to catch up with the marketplace by ourselves or to become part of another leading, well-rated, highly respected financial services organization."

HEADLINE: Black and Cuban-American: Bias in 2 Worlds

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 12

 BODY:
When black and Hispanic residents in this racially polarized city fought over a vacant City Commission seat, Henry Crespo stepped in and offered himself as the solution.
Being both black and Cuban, and a Spanish-speaker who lives in a black neighborhood, Mr. Crespo said he could bridge their worlds. But blacks said they would only accept a "black American" and Cubans regarded him as an oddity with questionable allure. 
 Mr. Crespo was not appointed to the commission; the seat went to an African-American woman.
"I'm as black as you can get but I'm Cuban," Mr. Crespo, 33, said recently, while on his job as housing director of the small city of Opa-Locka, near Miami, where he lives. "I have to be myself, understanding that I can't please everybody."
As black and Hispanic, Mr. Crespo is part of two worlds he says he relishes equally. But as African-Americans and Hispanic Americans wrestle for political influence here and the Hispanic majority increases, what Mr. Crespo sees as an advantage, indeed a rich example of multiculturalism, can also be a liability.
Black Cuban-Americans find themselves in a bind. As Cubans they belong to an immigrant group that has enjoyed tremendous economic and political success. But as blacks they have experienced the discrimination and hardships of African-Americans.
And they remain virtually invisible in the Miami power structure -- there are no black Cuban-American elected officials, no leaders of a major exile group and no major academic studies documenting their migration -- even though they are more representative of an island where half or more of the population is now estimated to be black and mulatto.
"People think I'm Dominican," said Alexis Barcelay, 25, a black boxer who left Cuba by going to the American naval base on Guantanamo Bay three years ago. "I have to tell them that there are blacks in Cuba, too."
Part of their invisibility is the result of their small numbers. The 1990 census found that fewer than 30,000 of nearly one million Hispanic residents in Dade County, or 3 percent, were black, most of them Cubans, with some Dominicans and Puerto Ricans. Nationwide, black Hispanic residents were also 3 percent of all Hispanic residents, the census showed.
Sociologists here say one reason that whites have overwhelmingly predominated in the exodus from revolutionary Cuba in the last 38 years is that the first waves of immigrants consisted mainly of the white elite who then sponsored relatives into the United States. And many blacks stayed behind longer because they had supported a revolution that provided social gains, opening educational and professional opportunities previously denied them, even if it had not extended equally to leadership positions in government.
But black Cubans say Cuba's Government has also hampered their migration through propaganda that paints the United States society as violently racist and by portraying those who want to leave as not only traitors but ingrates.
Cuba's dismal economic problems have compelled more blacks to leave in recent years, experts on Cuban affairs say, although information on the demographics of the most recent waves of immigrants is scarce. The Immigration and Naturalization Service, for instance, says it keeps no racial breakdown of the estimated 20,000 Cubans allowed to immigrate legally into this country each year.
But even more crucial than numbers in determining influence for black Cubans here has been their inability to fully integrate into either the black or Hispanic worlds, which requires them to overcome cultural and linguistic barriers among blacks and racism among white Hispanic residents.
Studies by a geography professor at the University of Miami, Thomas D. Boswell, show that the median income of black Hispanic residents of Dade County lagged behind that of white Hispanic residents -- $8,000 to $11,100 -- although the disparity was less than that between non-Hispanic whites and blacks. And his analysis of the 1990 census found the largest concentrations of black Hispanic Miamians in neighborhoods like Allapattah, sandwiched between Hispanic Little Havana and black Liberty City.
The predicament afflicts parents like Emmanuel and Luz Mery Angarica, a black Cuban and a white Colombian, who say they are rearing their 6-year-old son as "American," with no racial or ethnic labels, after two older sons suffered confusion and harassment from schoolmates over choosing an ethnic identity. "We never said anything but there was pressure from the other children to join their band," Mrs. Angarica, 47, said. "One of them came home from school and told me, 'Mommy, I am red.' Now we're going to be more careful."
The two older brothers chose black because African-Americans were in the majority at their school.
Black Cubans like Carlos Moore, 53, are not torn about their ethnic identity. In 1986, when Mr. Moore was a professor at Florida International University, he came under harsh attack on Spanish-language radio and received death threats for focusing on racial issues and portraying revered white Cuban patriots as racists in a course at the university. He said the harassment forced him to leave Miami in 1987.
Mr. Moore, now a professor of international relations at the University of the West Indies in Trinidad, said his experiences here convinced him that those like him should come out "against racism" and ally themselves with other blacks, both Hispanic and African-American.
The substantial number of blacks in Cuba are descendants of slaves brought to the island from Africa to work the sugar plantations, and blacks from other Caribbean islands who came after slavery to do the same work.
"I have everything in common with the American black," Mr. Moore said, "the history, slavery, being kicked by whites."
For Rosa Reed, 43, a manager for a pharmaceutical company who moved to the United States from Cuba when she was 5, a watershed moment came in 1990, when she said she was dismissed from a Cuban-American organization when she assumed the role of spokeswoman for one of its programs.
"I was told that when Americans saw a black person they saw crime and poverty and that for the benefit of the organization I couldn't be a spokesperson," Ms. Reed said. "It was so shocking."
Ms. Reed now writes a current affairs column for a black newspaper, The Miami Times, is engaged to an African-American and belongs to a group of black Cuban-Americans that is holding talks with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People intended to start a nationwide black Hispanic section. The group is rallying around domestic issues like sensitizing white Hispanic Americans to racial discrimination in employment and other forms of racism suffered by black Hispanic Americans.
But the group of black Cuban-Americans says it is also concerned about supporting blacks in Cuba, who they say suffer the island's economic hardships more acutely than whites because fewer can count on relatives here to send them money and basic necessities.
A poll of Cuban-Americans in Dade County this year by Florida International University and The Miami Herald indeed showed marked differences between black and white Cubans in attitudes toward Cuba, with more blacks favoring a dialogue with the Cuban Government to help bring about democracy and opposing continuing the American embargo of Cuba or military action to overthrow President Fidel Castro.
Because Hispanic populations are the product of different racial influences, for instance, racial self-definitions go beyond black and white. A Cuban regarded as black by American standards could be "moro," "indian" or "jabao" in Cuba, depending on skin color and hair texture, with the gradations making racial classifications more ambiguous.
Cubans like Manuel Elizondo, 38, a trainer on the Cuban Olympic boxing team who defected in 1994, said they find racism to be worse in this country.
"In Cuba, racism dictates who is a leader and who is not," Mr. Elizondo said. "Here, because private property is allowed, the racism is determined by money. There are more class differences."
But ethnicity has a stronger pull than race in his new country, which has forced two new identities on him: black (in Cuba he was considered mulatto or Indian) and Hispanic.
"I'm Cuban and I speak Spanish," Mr. Elizondo said. "I am who I am, and I live in my own world."
But those with political aspirations like Mr. Crespo, a Manhattan native, have no such luxury. The sharpest criticism against Mr. Crespo when he sought a City Commission seat vacated by a Hispanic lawyer facing criminal charges, who himself had replaced a black commissioner who is in prison on a bribery conviction, came from black civic and political leaders. The loss of the commission's only black left the panel with four Hispanic members and one white one.
"It worked against him by the fact that he tossed the word Cuban out there," said one of the critics, the Rev. Willie E. Sims Jr., assistant director of the Dade County office of black affairs. "When things get hot, people go back to those they're comfortable with."
Mr. Crespo, in a response in The Miami Times to his critics, insisted on claiming ownership of two cultures.
"What may I ask you authenticates one's blackness?," he wrote in a letter to the editor. "Is it that tired age-old debate of skin color? If so, I'm chocolate brown. Is it if one's ancestors were slaves? If so, my great-grandfather was born a slave. Is it if one's family knows the suffering and humiliation of segregation? If so, my mother was forced off the bus in 1959.
"But really, is not this whole discussion silly?"

"I have to tell them that there are blacks in Cuba, too," said Alexis Barcelay, 25, who began his journey to the United States in 1994. An effort by Henry Crespo, a black and a Cuban, to offer himself as an ideal Miami City Commissioner met rejection from blacks and Cubans. (Photographs by Cindy Karp for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: At I.M.F.'s Urging, Romania Shelves Copter Deal

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Several years ago, Romania began lining up a $1.4 billion deal intended to please Washington: the purchase of 96 Cobra attack helicopters under an arrangement that would also give the manufacturer, Bell Helicopter Textron, an assembly plant in Eastern Europe.
Bell and American military officials had told Romania the deal was sure to impress Washington with the seriousness of Romania's bid to join the West. And it seemed to be having an effect: President Clinton praised the deal during a visit in July. 
 But since the summer began, Romania has gotten two pieces of bad news. NATO, largely at the United States' initiative, formally decided that Romania was not ready to join the alliance. And the International Monetary Fund, looking over the country's shaky economy, decided that Romania simply could not afford the helicopter deal.
Now, at the I.M.F.'s insistence, Romania has put the deal on indefinite hold, Romanian and fund officials said. This opened the way for the board of the I.M.F. to approve release of the second stage of a $430 million loan for Romania. [The loan installment was approved at a meeting in Washington on Friday.]
The way the deal was sold, and how it fell apart, offers an unusually clear look at how the two threads of American policy toward the West's new Eastern Europe allies can contradict and undermine each other.
A senior Clinton Administration official said Washington urges these countries to be fiscally prudent and meet budget targets as they remake their command economies into market economies. At the same time, he said, as part of commercial and military diplomacy in the region, the Pentagon and the State and Commerce Departments encourage American arms suppliers as they try to sell expensive equipment.
The purchase of the helicopters was to have been the first sizable military procurement in the region since the fall of Communism.
The three Eastern European countries that were admitted to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in July -- the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland -- have all been pressed by American companies to make sizable purchases of fighter jets. But these nations have not started serious talks with the manufacturers and are first likely to lease such planes as a cost-saving measure.
Thus, the Romanians were the closest to actually buying American equipment, even though their economy is far weaker than those of the Czechs, Hungarians or Poles.
The deal was aggressively pushed by the United States Embassy working in tandem with Bell Helicopter Textron, a division of Textron Inc., even as Treasury officials expressed reservations about the expense for Romania. The American Ambassador until July, Alfred H. Moses, said in an interview this week he had urged the Romanians a number of times to buy the helicopters for economic as well as military reasons.
In an interview, Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea said he was "convinced that it is necessary to have the right equipment for the Romanian Army so that it is interoperable with NATO."
"That's why the contract was signed between the Ministry of Defense and Bell Helicopter. But the issue is the financing of the project. We are making special efforts to be within a budget deficit of 4.5 percent of G.D.P." Last year, the deficit was 13 percent of the gross domestic product, he said.
Officials of the I.M.F. who reviewed Romania's financial situation in July said they told the Romanians that they could not pay for the helicopters and keep their debt-limitation agreements with the fund.
Mr. Ciorbea's Government, which came to power last November after seven years of economic stagnation under the rule of ex-Communists, is eager to please the fund.
Faced with limited resources, Mr. Ciorbea said, priority had to go to the severely depleted health and education systems. So last month, he told Bell's chairman, Webb F. Joiner, that the sale was being delayed.
Part of the deal involved reviving an old helicopter plant at Brasov, north of here, where Bell had intended to manufacture much of each helicopter. The company had agreed to pay $50 million for a 70 percent share of the plant, where a French company has produced helicopters under license. By winning this helicopter license, Bell was effectively squeezing out the French, who had been lobbying just as hard to sell their own helicopters.
Lloyd Schoppa, a Bell vice president, told Gen. Constantin Degeratu, the Romanian Army chief of staff, the deal meant the "rebirth of the aviation industry in Romania." He said Bell was already committed to $250 million in exports from the plant. The shelving of the deal for now does not mean that talks with Bell have ended. Mr. Ciorbea said he was still seeking a solution with Bell that would get Romania equipment compatible with NATO while reviving the helicopter plant.
Bell's public affairs director, Carl Harris, said the company still believed that the American-produced helicopters would improve Romania's possibilities of joining NATO. "We've felt the Cobra buy was important because they'd become a security provider rather than a security user," Mr. Harris said of the Romanians.
And 10 days after Mr. Joiner was told that the sale could not go ahead because of the budget restrictions set by the I.M.F., he was still lobbying. He wrote a letter to Finance Minister Mircea Ciumara.
In the letter, obtained by The New York Times, Mr. Joiner said that it had been a pleasure to see Mr. Ciumara at a dinner in Bucharest given by the United States charge d'affaires, Michael Einik, and that he was sending information regarding the "benefits to Romania which will accrue from the program."
"It is my understanding that you will want to use this with the I.M.F.," Mr. Joiner wrote.
Bell estimated, Mr. Joiner said, that the $1.5 billion sale would "bring $2.7 billion in economic benefits to Romania" in the forms of direct investment, technology infusion and job creation.
Asked in the interview if he believed that $2.7 billion would accrue to Romania from the deal, Mr. Ciorbea raised his eyebrows and said diplomatically, "It's a lot of money."

HEADLINE: Who Should Define HDTV?

BYLINE: By Reed E. Hundt; Reed E. Hundt is the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Congress ordered the Federal Communications Commission to give broadcasters space on the nation's airwaves that is worth billions of dollars. This is the spectrum that could be used for digital television, a new medium for broadcasting video, data or even radio.
Some broadcasters wanted to use it primarily for a single channel of so-called high definition television, which would give viewers a crystal-clear picture that, for example, shows hockey or live crowd scenes in vivid relief. 
 But now others, principally ABC Television and the Sinclair Broadcast Group -- are saying that they would rather use the spectrum to broadcast five or 10 different programs simultaneously, each with clarity at least as good as today's television, than for a single high-definition channel.
Great. Let digital broadcasters experiment with the medium. Let the market dictate what uses they come up with. But Representative Billy Tauzin, a Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the House Telecommunications Subcommittee, has said that if broadcasters don't use the spectrum primarily or even exclusively for a single high-definition program, he might urge Congress to impose special fees on them.
Next week, the Senate Commerce Committee is scheduled to hold a hearing on the broadcasters' proposals to use the spectrum for purposes other than high-definition television, or HDTV. No new taxes is my answer -- not even on broadcasters who should have been required to bid for the licenses to use this spectrum instead of getting them free. The power to tax is the power to destroy, and the last thing we should do with this new technology is destroy experimentation.
In fact, the Telecommunications Act of 1996 does not require broadcasters to use the spectrum only for a single high-definition channel. That would have been not only bad economic policy, but also a constraint on speech for no reasonable purpose. Why should a broadcaster who wants to send out six new channels instead of one offering very vivid pictures be punished or limited by Government?
But the Telecommunications Act did require broadcasters to give something back for their free licenses. It wasn't sharp pictures -- the Federal Government shouldn't be in the business of making sure television pictures are as crisp as possible. Rather, it was a commitment to serve the public interest.
If Congress is really interested in browbeating broadcasters, it shouldn't be trying to get them to broadcast in high definition. Rather, Congress should require broadcasters to meet specific public interest obligations. For example, it could demand that broadcasters offer a quantifiable amount of educational television and about $400 million worth of free time for political debate so that real campaign finance reform would be possible.
Moreover, letting broadcasters send out more channels instead of just one high-definition picture is in keeping with the values of the First Amendment. More channels mean more speech, whether it is about sports, entertainment or politics.
To focus on how sharp a picture should be instead of allowing the market to work and to serve the public interest takes the debate about digital television in the wrong direction.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Retail Sales and Producer Prices Up, but Modestly

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Retail sales rose in August, and producer prices increased for the first time this year. But the reports were generally in line with expectations and did little to alter perceptions that the economy continued to advance with prices in check.
"It's a solid gain in sales," said Stuart G. Hoffman of the PNC Corporation in Pittsburgh, "once again accompanied by muted inflation pressures." 
 Consumers spent $213.7 billion at retail counters and in showrooms last month, four-tenths of 1 percent more than in July, the Commerce Department estimated today. While this was slightly less than expected, analysts said this was offset by a hefty upward revision in July sales.
The Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods, though posting its first increase of 1997, was driven mainly by a surge in energy prices that analysts dismissed as normal gyration. With energy and food disregarded, the index edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent, in line with the trend of core inflation over the last 12 months
Over all, the index rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the most since December's rise of five-tenths of 1 percent that was followed by an unprecedented seven consecutive declines.
The bond market rallied on today's set of figures, apparently reflecting relief that they produced no unpleasant inflationary surprises. Interest rates tumbled about one-tenth of a percentage point across a broad front as many economists and investors concluded that the already slim chance that the Federal Reserve would tighten monetary policy at its Sept. 30 policy meeting had receded further.
"These two numbers pretty well cinch the fact that the Fed isn't going to do anything," said Irwin L. Kellner, consultant to the Chase Manhattan Bank. "Growth is moderate and inflation nonexistent."
Few economists, however, rule out a possible Fed decision to strike an anti-inflation blow at its meetings in mid-November or mid-December.
The stock market first climbed today, then skidded well into negative territory before surging after lunch to finish with a gain of more than 80 points.
But while some saw signs in today's figures of a welcome slackening of the economy, others cautioned that growth could still be running at an unsustainably rapid pace.
"It looks like it's a softer trend, but it's not," said Michael H. Strauss, chief economist at Sanwa Securities in New York. After pointing to the revision that increased July's retail sales gain to nine-tenths of 1 percent from six-tenths of 1 percent, he predicted a similar result for August.
"It's not where the numbers start out, it's where they end up," Mr. Strauss said, contending that gasoline, food and apparel were probably all undercounted in today's estimate based on a small sample of the department's respondents.
Durable goods, those designed to last at least three years, posted a seven-tenths of 1 percent sales increase last month, with gains of about that much for automotive dealers, for merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes and for those selling furniture and other home equipment.
The larger nondurables category was less vigorous, with food stores reporting two-tenths of 1 percent less revenue and the drugstore and restaurant categories showing only slender increases. Clothing stores and those selling general merchandise gained six-tenths of 1 percent each while gasoline service stations posted a five-tenths of 1 percent rise, much of it reflecting higher prices.
Last month's total retail sales, which account for about one-third of economic activity, were 5.3 percent higher than in August 1996 with no allowance made for inflation.
Some analysts guessed that the 15-day United Parcel Service strike, which began on Aug. 4, trimmed sales for the month by perhaps one-tenth of a point because of an inability of some stores to restock depleted shelves or to ship merchandise. Mail-order results, for which reporting lags by a month, were not included.
The rise in the Producer Price Index was dominated by a 1.4 percent jump in the cost of energy but food prices also contributed by rising three-tenths of 1 percent.
Gasoline rose 5.9 percent, beef and veal 3.3 percent and fresh and dry vegetables 17.5 percent; by contrast, the price of eggs dropped 8.9 percent after soaring 21.7 percent in July.
Analysts found little to fret about in the prices of goods at the intermediate stage of production or in raw materials. Intermediate goods like paperboard edged up one-tenth of 1 percent. The price of crude goods rose seven-tenths of 1 percent after a small July decline, the most prominent change being an 18.5 percent surge for wastepaper.
