HEADLINE: Down but Not Out, Clearly Down Under;
Lean Times at an Australian Mainstay

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: PERTH, Australia, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Write-offs of more than $1 billion over the last two years. Sagging earnings and stockholder equity. Huge cost overruns at a much heralded iron ore processing plant here in mineral-rich Western Australia and a troubled copper investment in the United States. Three resignations of senior executives. And a chairman who acknowledges he is "ashamed" and "a bit flabbergasted" by it all.
For the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the sprawling mining empire known for much of its 112 years as the "Big Australian," it has been a time of big disappointment -- and of an equally broad reassessment. 
 As an icon of an Australian economy in transition, not to mention the country's biggest company, Broken Hill has come under intense fire from the financial press, analysts and academics.
"Companies of the size of B.H.P. should be able to avoid such large mistakes," said Andre Morkel, a professor of management at the University of Western Australia. "We in Australia have to learn to be more professional in our management, up our game."
All commodity producers have taken their lumps adjusting to a period of low inflation, plentiful supplies and lackluster demand. But B.H.P., based in Melbourne, has been battered more than most by its delayed reaction to the arrival of the global economy.
"Globalization has put pressure on everybody," said Neil Goodwill, an analyst at J. B. Were & Company, a Melbourne investment house. "At B.H.P., they realize they have to get leaner and meaner, but have been a little slower to act than most."
One reason may be that the company's icon status in Australia has made Broken Hill less ruthless than its competitors. Its labor contracts, for example, are generally seen as the most generous in the industry.
But a bigger reason is that B.H.P., long sheltered by the barrier reefs of high tariffs, used to have little to worry about. Because of its protected home market and strong asset base -- in addition to iron, it produces oil, coal, copper, manganese and other commodities -- B.H.P. had become complacent, in the view of some, particularly when compared with the aggressiveness of many other Australian companies, notably those in media, information technology and medical research.
Julian Stock, chairman of the Melbourne branch of the Australian Shareholders Association, faults a "highly centralized bureaucratic management, no flexibility and cradle-to-grave jobs."
Now, however, the Big Australian, which also makes steel and is moving into a variety of business services, is feeling the gales of competition like everyone else -- and is starting to take the harsh actions that have long gone against its grain.
Rising imports due to lower steel tariffs, for example, were a factor behind a B.H.P. decision last April to shut down primary steel production in the east coast town of Newcastle, provoking an outcry from labor and community leaders.
"It is no longer business as usual at B.H.P.," said John B. Prescott, the company's managing director and chief executive.
There is little choice, what with all the harsh new realities.
Indeed, given the new low inflation environment, "no longer is it possible to simply produce commodities and collect an inflation windfall," said Frank Harman, senior lecturer in economics at Perth's Murdoch University.
Then, too, there is increased competition from rival suppliers, such as Indonesia, which is emerging as a major coal exporter and is closer to Asian customers than Australia.
"Even though some markets, especially in Asia, have been expanding," Mr. Harman said, "you have to work harder to participate and maintain market share."
But B.H.P. has to work harder as well because of declining prices. Thanks to new supplies and weak demand, world prices of coal and iron ore are half the levels of the early 1980's.
Copper is more volatile. Since June, prices have fallen about 20 cents a pound. B.H.P. says every cent per pound affects its annual after-tax profit by $13 million. So if the 20-cent reduction remains for the full fiscal year, which ends next May 31, the company would give up $260 million in earnings, an amount that would represent 85 percent of last year's net profits of $313 million.
For all its difficulties, some observers think the company is learning from its mistakes and will rebound in the not-too-distant future.
"We believe management is very serious about changing its approach," said Elaine Prior, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in Sydney. "The path ahead may not be smooth. The new B.H.P. may be a less comfortable place to work than in the past. New skills will be required."
Indeed, she expects the share price to rise 20 percent over the next 12 months, and has just termed the stock a "long-term buy."
The Big Australian started as a miner of silver, lead and zinc at Broken Hill, New South Wales. Today, it is one of the globe's corporate behemoths, with 61,000 employees in 90-odd business units in 70 countries. With sales last year of $16 billion and total assets of $28 billion, it ranks as the world's second-biggest producer of iron ore (behind Brazil's recently privatized Companhia Vale do Rio Doce) and copper (behind Chile's state-owned Codelco). It is the 3d- biggest producer of manganese, 7th of coal, 14th of steel and 18th of oil and gas.
But to maintain that size, the company has had to look farther and farther afield. In January 1996, it bought Magma Copper of Tucson, Ariz. It already owned the big Escondida copper mine in northern Chile. It mines coal in New Mexico and Indonesia, pumps oil from the Gulf of Mexico, extracts titanium from Mozambique. Next year, it will begin production from Canada's first diamond mine, in the Northwest Territories near Yellowknife.
Forty percent of what B.H.P. sells is produced overseas and sold overseas, 30 percent produced in Australia and sold overseas and 30 percent produced and sold in Australia.
Despite all the growth overseas, return on equity has slipped to half the rate of the early 1990's. Profits and gross profit margins are at the lowest levels in a decade.
The huge write-downs of B.H.P.'s asset portfolio, including $420 million on the $2.4 billion purchase of Magma Copper, suggest that all those years as the great icon of Australian business may have led the company to drop its guard.
In the case of Magma, Australia's biggest international takeover, B.H.P. acknowledged with embarrassment the breakdown of the "due diligence" process under which proposed acquisitions are appraised within the company.
B.H.P. executives insist they have taken remedial action, including the hiring of a former Union Bank of Switzerland executive in New York, Anna Lou Fletcher, as manager of financial planning and analysis, to vet such decisions in the future.
The write-down followed what B.H.P.'s chairman, Jeremy K. Ellis, called a "misunderstanding of the resources at one of the mines," in Nevada.
"Magma was a public company and there is only so much due diligence you can do," he said, "and most of it is bookwork and paperwork behind closed doors." He defended the purchase for broadening the company's base in copper and giving it "the best smelter in the world."
Mr. Ellis, who was elevated to chairman earlier this year, had been chief executive of the B.H.P. minerals group and was chiefly responsible for the acquisition.
"Of course, it's not a great joy to see us having to do these write-offs," he recently told a group of shareholders. "I didn't choose an easy life obviously."
But even as the business community was evaluating the depressing effects of the Magma write-down and others on the fiscal year ended last May 31, B.H.P. faced new troubles: delays and large cost overruns at the iron ore processing plant under construction at Port Hedland, about 1,000 miles north of Perth.
That plant, in the heart of Western Australia's iron ore country, is to produce 2.5 million tons a year of hot briquetted iron for use by electric arc steel mills around the world. Initially it was to cost $1 billion. Now the company concedes the cost will be closer to $1.5 billion.
Analysts are critical of a breakdown in communications that apparently left headquarters in Melbourne unaware of the magnitude of the overrun until early last month. The new head of the minerals division, Richard J. Carter, and the head of the division's iron ore unit, Geoffrey L. W. Wedlock, were suddenly forced to resign. They have declined all comment.
"Why wasn't the information forthcoming to the managing director, to the internal auditors, to other parts of the management team who were obviously looking at this?" asked Ross Greenwood, editor of Business Review Weekly, the Australian equivalent of Business Week.
The managing director, Mr. Prescott, tried to explain: "We were given all sorts of assurances. There's not time in these sorts of affairs to go into all of that, but we had detailed arrangements. We put great focus on monitoring this particular project and what we've seen is a breakdown in those arrangements."
Engineering difficulties, problems with some of the components built overseas and high labor costs are among the factors blamed.
Adding to the sense of disarray was the resignation of a third senior executive, John J. O'Connor, executive general manager of the petroleum group.
He argued that stockholders would be better served if the much better performing petroleum assets were turned into a separate company, much as stockholder benefits have accrued in the United States from the splitting off of Lucent and NCR from AT&T.
The board thought otherwise. "It is quite clear to us that the company as a whole has more value than the sum of its parts," Mr. Prescott declared.
The asset write-downs, cost overruns and public disagreements in the executive suite suggest to many outsiders a management in chaos.
Stockholders are "bloody furious" over recent events, said Mr. Stock of the Australian Shareholders Association. The company's share price now fluctuates around a dollar above its low for the year and is at the same level as at the start of 1994.
Both Mr. Prescott and Mr. Ellis insist they have taken the steps for rehabilitation, including commitments for greater accountability and improved returns on capital.
The company's performance, for example, is to be measured against that of other companies in the same sector. And a greater share of compensation at the top is going to be tied to that performance.
"We have put more of our senior managers' salary at risk," Mr. Prescott said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Rebound Strongly On Economic Reports
The stock market regained some of the ground it lost in the previous two trading sessions, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 81.99 points, or 1.07 percent, to 7,742.97. After faltering a bit in the last few days, smaller stocks continued to climb. 
 One of the stocks that helped buoy the market was Motorola, which rebounded slightly after a big drop the day before, when the company issued a warning of lower-than-expected earnings. [Page 37.]
 
Bonds Up for First Time in 4 Days
Bond prices rallied strongly, the first gain in four days, after tame reports on producer prices and retail sales for August suggested that the Federal Reserve might not need to raise interest rates this month. The yield on the 30-year Treasury fell to 6.58 percent, from 6.69 percent. [36.]
 
Times Mirror Chief Adds a Title
Mark H. Willes, the chairman, president and chief executive of Times Mirror, became the publisher of the company's flagship newspaper, The Los Angeles Times. He replaces Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, who resigned. Mr. Schlosberg had wanted the chairmanship when Mr. Willes was hired for that post from General Mills two summers ago. [36.]
 
China Plans Economic Changes
President Jiang Zemin embraced a program of bold transformation for China's ailing state-owned industries as he opened the 15th Communist Party Congress. Among his proposals was the privatization of the majority of China's 13,000 large and medium-sized state-owned enterprises, as well as most of its 300,000 smaller companies. [7.]
 
Thermo King Sale Expected
An announcement about the sale of Westinghouse Electric's Thermo King unit, which makes refrigeration equipment, could be made as early as Monday. Several companies have been mentioned as possible buyers, including Emerson Electric. [44.]
 
American General in Acquisition
American General has agreed to buy the 55 percent of Western National that it does not already own for $1.2 billion in cash and stock. The deal will make American General the third-largest provider of annuities in the United States. [36.]
 
Insider Trading Charge at Morgan
Federal authorities arrested a 25-year-old junior analyst at J. P. Morgan and charged him with insider trading. The Government said he had made illegal profits of more than $350,000 over a two-month period. [36.]
 
A Strong Coffee Supply Cuts Prices
Coffee prices declined more than 8 percent as supplies flooded into exchange warehouses, a sign that roasters are well stocked at the start of the season of peak demand. Stockpiles in the warehouses stood at 93,682 bags, more than double levels a year earlier. The Green Coffee Association is expected to report on Monday that supplies during August rose as much as 300,000 bags from the 2.335 million at the end of July. [45.]
 
Romania Shelves Helicopter Deal
A $1.4 billion deal by Romania to purchase 96 Cobra attack helicopters from Bell Helicopter and to give the company an assembly plant in Eastern Europe has been put on hold. One of the reasons is that the International Monetary Fund, looking over the country's shaky economy, decided that Romania simply could not afford the helicopters. [3.]
 
Lee Reduces Its Offer for Fisher
The Thomas H. Lee Companies has reduced its offer for Fisher Scientific International to $48.25 a share, from $51, because the scientific instruments maker's profit and market share had diminished as a result of the strike at United Parcel Service. Fisher Scientific said it would accept the reduced offer, which values its stock at about $980 million. [37.]

HEADLINE: 81.99 Rebound in Blue Chips Recoups Part of Week's Loss

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The stock market regained some of the ground it lost in the previous two trading sessions, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 1 percent yesterday. Economic reports indicating that growth remained moderate and inflation tame in August tempered some investor concerns about possible third-quarter earnings disappointments.
Drug stocks like Pfizer, Eli Lilly and Merck were among the issues leading the rebound. In addition, Motorola, whose stock fell more than 8 points in after-hours trading on Thursday, finished higher after a conference call held by the company brightened investor outlook. 
 The Dow soared 81.99 points, to 7,742.97, a 1.07 percent gain, erasing part of the 190.93 it lost the previous two sessions. The blue-chip index was off 79.44 for the week, however.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks added 11.32 points, closing at 923.91, a gain of 1.24 percent.
On the Big Board, gains outnumbered declines more than 5 to 2.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 9.47, finishing at 1,649.33. the technology-laden index is now 6.89 points away from its high close reached on Sept. 9.
After faltering a bit in previous sessions, smaller stocks continued to climb. The Russell 2000 gained 4.16, hitting a closing high of 440.09.
Early in the session, Treasury securities and stocks gained strength from economic reports on retail sales and producer prices. According to the data, prices paid to producers in the United States rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August. The increase, the first after seven consecutive declines, met expectations.
Meanwhile, retail sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, less than the seven-tenths of 1 percent that had been forecast by economists. Analysts said this moderate growth with low inflation suggested that the Federal Reserve might not raise interest rates at its next policy-making meeting on Sept. 30.
But stocks quickly retreated, and the Dow fell as much as 52 points because of concerns about third-quarter earnings, said Jim Benning, a vice president at BT Brokerage.
Shortly before noon, stocks turned higher. But they picked up most of their gains late in the session, aided by some computer-generated buy programs, analysts said.
"There was nothing new that hit the market in the last hour," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Zurich Kemper Investments. "It was just buying on the dip."
Ascend Communications was the most-active issue, with 20.9 million shares changing hands. Falling for the second consecutive day, Ascend closed at 35 1/4, down 2 9/16, amid concerns the company may not meet third-quarter earnings forecasts.
Motorola closed at 69 3/16, up 3 5/16. After the market closed on Thursday, Motorola announced that third-quarter earnings would fall below expectations, hurt by weak sales of pagers in the the world's largest markets, the United States and China, and one-time costs.
But during an early morning conference call with investors and analysts yesterday, Motorola gave the impression that its problems were "localized" within two areas and that its other business operations were performing well, said Jack Geraghty, a semiconductor analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"The longer-term view could be that this is a glitch along the road," he said. Although Mr. Geraghty said the long-term prospects for the company seemed good, he lowered his 1997 and 1998 earnings estimates.
Procter & Gamble led the Dow higher, closing at 133 1/2, up 2.
Among drug stocks, Pfizer gained 2 15/16, to 58 3/16; Lilly rose 4 3/8, to 108 7/16, and Merck added 7/16, to 92 13/16. Also, Warner-Lambert picked up 5 1/4, to close at 133. On Thursday, Warner's chief executive said the company expected to meet analysts' 1998 forecasts as well as see double-digit earnings growth in 1997 because of strong new products.

INTERNATIONAL 3-7
 
Albright's Mideast Visit Ends With Little Gained
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, with undiplomatic bluntness, said she would not return to the Middle East until Israeli and Palestinian leaders had made what she called "the hard decisions." 1
 
Palestinians in the West Bank were as frustrated with Ms. Albright's visit as she is herself. 6 

Funeral for Mother Teresa
The state and military honors at the funeral today of Mother Teresa in Calcutta, her adopted city, were unrivaled in the funeral of any unranked or untitled Indian since Mohandas Gandhi. Shrines to the Albanian-born nun who preached selflessness -- do "something beautiful for God" -- are cropping up on street corners. 1
 
Intimidation in Argentina
In a vicious reminder of the atrocities of the 1970's in Argentina, a former Navy captain who admitted to torture during the military regime said four attackers slashed his face and warned him to stop speaking with journalists. 1
 
Zapatistas March in Mexico
About 1,100 unarmed Zapatista militants from Chiapas arrived in Mexico City after a six-day march protesting the Government's failure to reach a peace agreement with them. "They didn't defeat us. We didn't sell out," one rebel told sympathetic students and poor people. Wearing the masks they popularized during their brief but dramatic uprising in January of 1994, they hope to draw attention to the plight of the Indians. 4
 
Romania Arms Deal Evaporates
A $1.4 billion deal for Romania to acquire 96 attack helicopters from an American company, a deal praised by President Clinton during a visit to Bucharest last July, has fallen apart. Enthusiasm had waned in Romania since it was denied NATO membership, and the International Monetary Fund used pressure on a $430 million loan to argue that health and education were more pressing concerns for the battered economy. 3
 
Chechnya Pipeline Tug-of-War
An agreement announced Tuesday to rebuild a key oil pipeline crossing through Russia and the secessionist republic of Chechnya did not survive the week as Russia threatened to pull out after a bomb attack on some repair workers. Vitriolic insults and threats have since flown back and forth, and Russia announced plans to build a pipeline via another route to ship oil from an $8 billion project in Azerbaijan to the Black Sea. 6
 
Party Congress Begins in China
President Jiang Zemin opened China's 15th Communist Party congress with a two-and-a-half hour speech riven with socialist lingo that almost obscured his plan to sell off most of China's state-owned enterprises. Economic reforms notwithstanding, Mr. Jiang emphasized that the party will retain its monopoly on China's political structure. 7
 
NATIONAL 8-11
 
Gore Finds Himself In Inquiry's Spotlight
The storm over his campaign finance practices has thrust Vice President Al Gore into what his advisers concede is by far the most perilous moment of his political career, leaving his aides scrambling to contain the damage. The growing nervousness results from the announcement last week that Janet Reno, the Attorney General, is reviewing whether the fund-raising activities may have been improper for such a high-ranking official. The inquiry could lead to the appointment of a special prosecutor. 1
 
A Nonhearing on Weld
Senator Jesse Helms asserted his power as a committee chairman and refused to hold a hearing over the nomination of William F. Weld to be Ambassador to Mexico. President Clinton declared the battle "not over" and said he would urge Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, to bring the nomination to the floor for a vote. Some senators were contemplating a move to galvanize public pressure on Mr. Lott to do just that. 1
 
B-2 Confronts a New Enemy
Once heralded as the ultimate Cold War weapon, a radar-evading bomber capable of attacking deep inside the Soviet Union with nuclear weapons, the B-2 is confronted with a different, unforeseen enemy: a coalition of government auditors, members of Congress and arms-control advocates. 9
 
Black and Cuban in Miami
Black Cuban-Americans in Miami find themselves living between two worlds. As Cubans they belong to an immigrant group that has enjoyed tremendous economic and political success. But as blacks they have experienced the discrimination and hardships of their race. And they remain virtually invisible in the city's power structure -- even though they are more representative of an island where half or more of the population is now estimated to be black or mulatto. 8
 
Mars Ship in Ideal Orbit
Early tracking data show that the Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft hit a veritable bull's-eye when it rocketed into an orbit of Mars on Thursday night, officials at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., said. The 1,700-pound Surveyor, launched last November from Cape Canaveral, Fla., is the second American spacecraft to reach Mars this year to start a 10-year campaign of exploration leading up to a return of Mars rocks. 11
 
Jeb Bush Tries Again in Florida
Three years after losing Florida's closest gubernatorial election ever, Jeb Bush, son of former President George Bush, filed as a Republican candidate for governor. Mr. Bush, a real estate developer from Miami, lost the 1994 governor's race to the incumbent Democrat, Lawton Chiles, by 80,000 votes out of 4.2 million cast. His elder brother, George W. Bush, won the governorship of Texas on the same day. (Reuters)
 
NEW YORK/REGION 25-29
 
Therapists Help Patients Cope With Diana's Death
Therapists in New York City and its suburbs report that a number of their female patients have sought counseling in how to deal with the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales. The patients were stunned by the power of their reaction to her death and dismayed that the men in their life hadn't a clue what so moved them, the therapists said. 1
 
Comptroller Opposes Sharpton
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, one of New York City's most influential Democrats, said he would not support the Rev. Al Sharpton if he won the Mayoral nomination. Mr. Hevesi cited what he described as Mr. Sharpton's "willingness to tolerance the bigotry" of Louis Farrakhan and a city college professor who made racist and anti-Semitic remarks. 25
 
Ferry Riders Fear Cutbacks
A series of breakdowns on the Staten Island ferry that have happened in the two months since the 50-cent charge to ride it was abolished with great fanfare has led many of the 27,000 daily passengers to get a sinking feeling that, these days, they are getting what they pay for. 25
 
Library Benefactor Revealed
For two years it has been among the best-kept secrets in New York philanthropy. Only two people at the New York Public Library knew the identity of the donor who in 1995 pledged $15 million -- the largest single gift in the institution's history -- to renovate the Main Reading Room, the heart of the library. Now, the name can be told: Frederick P. Rose, the real estate developer, and his wife, Sandra. 25

San Antonio Cuts Funding
San Antonio's city council agreed in a unanimous vote to reduce the amount it spends on the arts by about 15 percent and cut off all city grants to the Esperanza Peace and Justice Center, a gay and lesbian arts organization whose programs provoked criticism. 17

Mutual Benefit Up for Sale
Six years after the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company became the largest American insurance company ever to collapse, the company has been revived and is expected to announce on Monday that it is up for sale. No price has been established, but investment bankers estimate that the price for the company could be as high as $1.5 billion. 35
 
Insurer to Cut Costs
The Prudential Life Insurance Company plans to squeeze $250 million to $500 million in annual savings from the company's big, money-losing health insurance unit, Prudential executives said. They said the savings would be made by eliminating layers of managers and tightening controls on medical services. 35

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Convention Hall Is Planned

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD

 BODY:
A 72,000-square-foot convention hall will be built on the beach in Wildwood and will replace a hall that was built in 1971, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday.
The $60 million project will be financed by $10 million in low-interest loans from the state's Economic Development Authority and $20 million from Wildwood's 2 percent tourism tax. 
 The Sports and Exposition Authority will pay the balance and operate the convention hall. The authority also operates the Atlantic City Convention Center.
The hall should be completed by 1999, officials said.

HEADLINE: Bonds Break Out of Slump After Tame Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Bond prices rallied strongly yesterday, the first gain in four days, after tame reports on producer prices and retail sales for August suggested that the Federal Reserve might not need to raise interest rates this month to slow the economy.
The 30-year Treasury bond gained 1 10/32, to a price of 97 10/32, pushing the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, to 6.58 percent, from 6.69 percent on Thursday. For bondholders, the day's gain amounted to about $13.13 for $1,000 invested. 
 The Labor Department reported that producer prices rose three-tenths of a percent and one-tenth of a percent when volatile food and energy prices are excluded. Both figures were within expectations, and were "not exactly a harbinger of an imminent upturn in inflation," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, a Canadian firm.
Retail sales for August were another pleasant surprise for the bond market, rising four-tenths of 1 percent instead of the expected increase of seven-tenths of a percent.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "Unequivocal euphoria is the best way I can describe what the mood of the market was like after investors read the results of both the P.P.I. and the retail sales reports."
He said that while the reports did not eliminate the possibility of an increase in interest rates by the Fed, they made it likely that any such move would come later rather than sooner.
Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management, was not surprised by yesterday's gains. "We have gotten past big numbers," he said, adding that economic reports next week could cause some problems, but were not being awaited with the same fears as yesterday's data.
Also yesterday, Argentina, in its largest debt sale ever, sold $2.25 billion of 30-year bonds in an effort to repurchase Brady bonds outstanding. The new issue will now be the country's longest-maturity bond, according to Government officials.
On Thursday, Venezuela took advantage of robust demand for high- yielding securities to sell $4 billion of its 30-year bonds. Investors paid for most of the issue by swapping Brady bonds.
The new Argentine global bonds, whose sale is being managed by J. P. Morgan & Company, were given a 9.75 percent coupon and priced to yield 305 basis points more than a United States Treasury security with a similar maturity. Investors paid for about 75 percent of the new bonds by swapping Brady bonds.

By The Associated Press
The dollar tumbled for a second day yesterday, to its lowest level against the mark since early July, weakening on speculation that the German central bank would raise interest rates soon.
But the dollar continued to rise against the yen, reflecting both the weakness of the Japanese economy and traders' desire to sell yen for the German currency.

HEADLINE: Style;
Tip of the Iceberg

BYLINE: By Holly Brubach 

 BODY:
Economists assure us that the inflation rate is now near zero and holding steady, and we might be inclined to believe them, if we ate iceberg lettuce. For those who do, it's true that the price of a salad has indeed remained constant over the course of the past 10 years. But here is where hidden inflation comes into play: For those of us who have left iceberg behind, the price of a salad has increased exponentially. There was a time when we subscribed to lettuces like Boston and bibb, but before long they were supplanted by other breeds of greens, each more exotic than the one before, and more expensive. First there was arugula, then radicchio, followed by mache and, more recently, mesclun -- each of which made its debut as a delicacy at the top of the charts and has since sunk to the level of ubiquity. It was frisee that ousted mesclun, precipitating its decline, and now mizuna, an upstart salad green from Asia, with darling pointy leaves and a bitter peppery taste, has gone frisee one better. Anyone whose appetite has followed this trajectory from iceberg (stable at an average of $1.19 a pound at D'Agostino) to mizuna (currently $9 a pound at Balducci's) has in effect experienced a 656 percent increase in the cost of a salad. 
 Godiva chocolates, formerly considered the gold standard ($32 for a 1-pound box of truffles), have been topped in status value by Teuscher ($49 a pound): 54 percent inflation. The Jeep Explorer (starting at $28,000 for the standard model) gave way to the Range Rover ($56,000, leather upholstery), which in turn has given way to the paramilitary Hummer ($90,000 with a tire-inflation system): 221 percent inflation. The Viking stove ($3,263 for the 36-inch stainless-steel model, four burners) was outclassed by the Aga ($10,000 -- four ovens, built in Shropshire, England) and La Cornue ($14,800 -- two ovens and two warmers), both of which have been superseded by the Bonnet ($400,000 -- custom-made by hand in France in solid cast iron with an installer flown over to assemble it on site): 12,159 percent inflation.
It's so expensive being rich," Susan Gutfreund once said. And we know what she means, having experienced the hardships of hidden inflation.

HEADLINE: Reveille In New York

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman; Clyde Haberman writes the NYC column for The Times.

 BODY:
The language of New York early in the morning is Spanish. Chinese runs a close second. That is not to say you can't get by nicely in other languages, even English. But at the ungodly hour of 5:30 A.M., the people who keep the city moving tend to be its most recent arrivals, hard-working immigrants without many alternatives.
Perhaps this is a good time for full disclosure. I hate the early morning. I spent two years in the Army trying unsuccessfully to get them to start reveille without me, and the following 27 years have produced no change in atttitude. My eyelids may flutter somewhere around 7 A.M., but the brain doesn't usually kick into gear until closer to noon. 
 So it was an adventure to roam New York at 5:30 A.M., and a shock to see how many people were up and about at that hour. I had expected a nearly empty train as I took the subway downtown to the Fulton Fish Market. Instead, most seats were filled, in the main with young and middle-aged men trying to squeeze a bit more sleep out of the night or talking quietly to one another. Many were on their way to jobs in food markets and diners, places that need time to get rolling before the first customers show up. Spanish and Chinese filled the air, with virtually the only English coming from the conductor announcing the stops.
A few of those workers got off the train with me at the Fulton Street station. I had gone there because of the fish market, centered at the foot of Fulton Street on the East River. It is a great place to start a New York day, particularly if you are a jet-lagged traveler who can't sleep anyway.
There are, you should know, several large markets in Manhattan that get under way as early as 7 or 8 A.M. and are worth visiting. The stretch of 28th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, for example, is the heart of the flower district, where you can walk from one overheated store to another taking in the dizzying scents and colors. But the king of New York markets is the Fulton Fish Market, where a 5:30 A.M. arrival on a weekday is already on the late side. The place has been in full swing for well over an hour.
 But "it's not what it used to be," admitted a vendor who has operated a food cart along the East River for years, selling breakfast fare ranging from Chinese noodles to French toast. "The prices for fish are high," he said, "and you don't see the business that you used to."
 Still, Fulton is an eyeful, an admirable survivor through many decades. It has even withstood the assaults of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a former Federal prosecutor, who vowed to rid it of an alleged mob influence that, frankly, made it all the more exotic to some visitors (perhaps because they wanted to see the source of the fish that Luca Brasi, the Godfather's enforcer, slept with).
 You need to watch your step on South Street, the market's central thoroughfare. If you're not careful, you can be hit from behind by forklifts carrying crates of fish. The pavement is slippery with water and blood. Embers float in the air, from the fires that workers keep alive in metal barrels to ward off predawn chills that can slice into them even in spring and summer.
 On this particular morning, many in the market were Koreans, major wholesale buyers of fish in New York these days. They walked with expert eyes through a giant shed by the river, its stalls filled with tuna, cod and swordfish.
 After making their purchases, they went for breakfast at the handful of nearby restaurants open at that odd hour. Some headed to the Market Bar and Grill on Peck Slip, which was serving bean soup. Many more walked around the corner to a restaurant at Front and Beekman Streets called San, which means mountain in Korean. The dominant smells were of hearty, garlicky Korean soups that had been coming out of the kitchen since 3 A.M. But there was also coffee, thank goodness, for someone whose stomach was not up to kimchi at that hour.
 By then, dawn was breaking over the East River, a pink early light poking through the spidery lacing of the Brooklyn Bridge, which looms over the market. It's one of the great man-made wonders, that bridge, easily reached by walking a few blocks to the footpath that ends near City Hall.
 Maybe a better place to watch the sun rise over New York would be the top of the Empire State Building or the observation tower at the World Trade Center. Better, but unfortunately not doable. Neither skyscraper opens to the public until 9:30 A.M., leaving few places to watch the dawn unobstructed by waterfront buildings on the Brooklyn and Queens side of the East River.
 So the Brooklyn Bridge wins by default. And you can do a lot worse. The world-famous steel suspension bridge, opened in 1883, was once hailed by the critic Lewis Mumford as "perhaps the most completely satisfying structure of any kind" to have been built in America. An endless flow of automobile traffic has somewhat dimmed the allure, but a well-used footpath keeps the bridge people-friendly. Even at dawn, it is alive with pedestrians, mostly Brooklynites slogging into Manhattan for work, briefcases in hand.
 Wall Street is just a few blocks south, and even at that hour it is starting to come alive. By 7 A.M., it is shifting into high button-down gear, many of these masters of the universe having already pummeled themselves into shape with workouts at health centers like New York Sports Clubs, cater-cornered from the New York Stock Exchange at Wall and Broad.
 That's an entire subculture of the New York morning: keeping fit. In fact, it's an obsession. Almost as important as staying in shape, it seems, is making sure that everyone else knows how hard you are working at it. New York Sports Clubs, for example, is at sidewalk level, its windows large enough so that passersby can stand on the street admiring these paragons of higher commitment.
 Much farther uptown, sunrise over New York reveals men and women running by the hundreds around the Central Park Reservoir in parodies of underwear. Many have Walkmen on their heads to shut out the world -- God forbid they should have contact with quotidian life. If they are not running in circles around the reservoir, they're pounding along the city pavement, doing little dances at street corners while waiting for traffic lights to change. At Chelsea Piers, a sports complex on the Hudson River at West 23d Street, golfers can smack balls toward New Jersey as early as 5 A.M. in the summer. In the winter, one group of mainly women works out on Wednesday mornings at the American Museum of Natural History on Central Park West, which opens its doors to members at 7 A.M.: Jurassic gymnasts doing their jumping jacks and power walks by the dinosaur skeletons.
 And you'd better believe that they are running on Wall Street, home of the rat race.
 At 7:15 A.M., the bankers and brokers, the secretaries and mailroom clerks pour out of the IRT subway stop at Broadway and Wall, and stream into the financial district. A few -- very few, I have to say -- stop first at Trinity Church, which is also at Broadway and Wall.
 It is tempting to be cynical. Are these people praying for Divine guidance before going off to make a killing?
 What may be tempting, however, is not fair. God and Mammon have coexisted in the vicinity of Broadway and Wall for more than 150 years. For visitor and native alike, Trinity Church provides a much-needed reflective beginning to the whirligig that is New York's workday.
 Of course, Trinity is hardly the only house of worship open for morning prayers, a category, by the way, that goes beyond churches. This is New York, after all. Don't forget the many synagogues and, increasingly, mosques like the large Islamic Cultural Center at Third Avenue and East 96th Street. But Trinity not only offers a spiritual start to the day but it also is a symbol of New York's roots. That part of Manhattan was the original city. This is actually the third Trinity Church, the first one, completed in 1698, having burned and second having collapsed after a heavy snowfall. This version opened its doors in 1846, an elegant structure that stands as a quiet reminder of how relatively new the skyscrapers that define New York are.
 It can be a jolt to step out of the church at 7:45 and back into the hubbub of Wall Street, whose pace by then has grown only more frantic. But is there a better metaphor for New York's fast pace than Grand Central Terminal (often imperfectly rendered as Grand Central Station)? Between roughly 8 and 8:45 A.M., the Grand Central stop on the IRT subway line is as close as you can get to organized chaos outside a rugby scrum. It is not a pretty sight. But to see how commuting New York starts its day, it is the place to be. Just make sure you stand off to the side to keep from being swept up by the human tide.
 Several months ago, Grand Central was the laboratory for a grand experiment in behavior modification. New Yorkers, you soon discover, are not a conspicuously orderly tribe. On subway platforms, people like to plow into trains before passengers already on board can get off. The results are pileups and delays all along the line.
 Aha! said the Transit Authority, the subway system's manager. Let's see if we can enable one group to leave the train before another pushes in. To enforce discipline, the authority put 30 or so uniformed workers on the Grand Central platform, one at each train door, shooing encroachers away until passengers could get off. It worked. New Yorkers behaved themselves, and order reigned. For the weeks of the experiment, that is. Did things run so smoothly after the experiment ended and the uniforms disappeared? Permit me a New Yorker's right to answer a question with another question. What do you think?
 After half an hour of this underground punishment, you may be ready for fresh air.
 Rockefeller Center is not far away on foot. There, on West 49th Street, you will find dozens of visitors to the city, drawn to the curbside studios of NBC and the "Today" show. Every morning on the hour and half-hour, the "Today" personalities go out on the street and chat briefly with the people, a scene that is beamed live across the United States. That explains why many of these folks, presumably sensible enough back home, do strange things after landing in New York, decking themselves out as London buskers or giant bunnies while holding up signs for the cameras like "Hi Mom, Dad, Suz!"
 One morning at 8, I asked a young couple from Sacramento, Calif., why they were there. Because, they said, they had awakened at 5 A.M. -- 5 A.M. -- to get standby tickets for the Rosie O'Donnell show at the NBC studios. As it turned out, Ms. O'Donnell was not taping that week. So after a quick studio tour by a gracious NBC guide, they hung around to glimpse the weatherman Al Roker and smile at the cameras.
 Oh well, why not? The only point here is that it isn't most New Yorkers' cup of cappuccino.
 Speaking of which, isn't it time for a real breakfast?
 In truth, many working New Yorkers, perhaps most, eat breakfast on the run. What else? A typical routine is to stop at a curbside wagon on the walk between subway and office, and to buy a coffee and a bagel with a shmeer. Shmeer is not as horrible as it may sound. It's a spread of cream cheese, smeared across the bagel. Somewhere along the line, it became shmeer, a Yiddish word that in another context also means bribe. But that's another story. It is mentioned here only to note that without a knowledge of certain Yiddish words -- many of which, for some reason, begin with the "sch" sound -- communication with New Yorkers can be limited.
 It is possible to eat breakfast sitting down, of course. Diners abound, many owned by Greek immigrants and their children. A hot place in this category is Tom's Restaurant, a crowded joint at the northeast corner of Broadway and West 112th Street. Its main distinction for some visitors, other than its proximity to Columbia University, is that it is a fixture on "Seinfeld." You know the diner on the show, where all you see from outside is the word "restaurant" in neon? That's Tom's, though the cramped interior looks nothing like the place where Jerry and his friends shmooze -- another New York word derived from Yiddish, meaning to gab.
 Tom's fare is solid enough. But if you want to see where the elite meet to eat, you must go to the Regency Hotel, on Park Avenue at East 61st Street.
 For $22.50, not including tax and tip, you can get the same bacon and eggs (plus a few frills) that cost $3.35 at a place like Tom's. But the important thing at the Regency is not to eat but to be seen among the Trumps and Tisches. The movers and shakers don't eat much anyway. They're in competition over who will order the least. Ask for juice and granola and you can be sure that someone at your table will go you one better, ordering only wheat germ. But for your $22.50, you do get impeccable service, in contrast to many New York diners, where the service is often highly peccable.
 My wife, Kathy, and I went to the Regency one morning and were shown to a room called The Library, where the only famous person I recognized was Gore Vidal -- and he was in a photo hanging over our table. The Library looks out onto Park Avenue and is perfectly pleasant. The power boys -- there were only a few power girls, I'm afraid -- were next door in the main room, where reservations must be made weeks in advance. Some image-conscious city commissioners, the maitre d'hotel confided, would rather be seen breakfasting in Newark than somewhere in Manhattan other than the Regency's main room.
 What's that? This is all crazy, you say? Of course, it's crazy. But when was that the issue? What can I say except that it's a New York thing?
 If food is still on your mind, the city has many stores that open as early as 8 A.M. and specialize in cheeses and sausages not available elsewhere. Take a culinary shrine like Zabar's, on Broadway at West 80th Street. It is more enjoyable at 8 A.M. than later in the day because you can really appreciate the vast arrays of food there without the usual crowds. Truth is, New Yorkers are not always fun to be around in places like Zabar's. They have a tendency to push and yell a lot, throwing any vestige of good manners to the winds.
 That brings us full circle to a basic point: this can be one hectic city. It is why the early morning is so special. New York may not be asleep at that hour. But it is not fully awake, either, and is more easily absorbed.
 To truly appreciate its grandeur, you can hardly do better than a sunrise ride on the Staten Island Ferry. Granted, the ferry terminal in Battery Park is not heaven, with all the homeless there. But you can take the 25-minute ride to Staten Island and then board the next boat back to Manhattan for free.
 At dawn, the first pink rays of the sun peek over Queens and Brooklyn, slanting across the East River and striking the glass-encased towers of lower Manhattan. On either side of you sits one of the world's great harbors. Off to the left, the Statue of Liberty's torch still burns bright in the melting darkness.
 You have to be fairly jaded not to feel your heart leap at that moment.
 
Breakfast Clubs
 
Market Bar and Grill, 40 Peck Slip (telephone: 406-2742), opens at midnight daily, except Saturdays. There is a full range of short-order specialties, including bean soup ($2.25). Conventional breakfast fare includes two eggs, any style, with toast and bacon, ham, or sausage ($2.75), and a toasted bagel with cream cheese ($1).
 
San, 144 Beekman Street, at the corner of Front Street (267-0086), opens at around 3 A.M., Mondays through Fridays, to serve Korean food to customers of the Fulton Fish Market (the menu is Japanese for lunch and dinner). Specialties include spicy fish soup, kimchi stew and rice cake soup with dumplings (all $6).
 
Tom's Restaurant, 2880 Broadway, at the corner of 112th Street (864-6137), serves breakfast daily from 6 to 11 A.M. A meal of two eggs, any style, with bacon, ham, or sausage, toast, orange juice and coffee, is $3.30; a bagel with cream cheese is $1.
 
Regency Hotel, 540 Park Avenue, at the corner of East 61st Street (759-4100), serves breakfast in the main dining room or in the Library daily from 7 to 11 A.M. The $22.50 breakfast consists of two eggs, any style, with bacon, ham, or sausage; orange, carrot or grapefruit juice; assorted pastries, bagel or toast, and coffee, tea or milk. A bagel with cream cheese is $4.
 
More Early-Bird Specials
The big flea market at Sixth Avenue and 26th Street opens early in the morning on weekends and is considered by many to be the city's best.
Just a few months ago in the Chelsea neighborhood, a sprawling indoor food market offering everything from lobsters to cheesecake began opening its doors every morning in an old factory bounded by 9th and 10th Avenues and West 15th and 16th Streets.
A more venerable institution is the Greenmarket in Union Square, once a speaker's corner for assorted radicals, now the province several days a week of bakers and farmers selling their wares to New Yorkers who cannot imagine dinner without brick-oven rolls on their bread plates or shiitake mushrooms in their salads. CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: John Barracato;
Fires, on Purpose and in Carelessness

BYLINE: By JACQUELINE WEAVER

 BODY:
FOR nearly 40 years, John Barracato has been preoccupied, almost obsessed, he says, with the cause of fires, whether it be arson fraud, arson for reasons of revenge, accidental or the work of a pathological fire setter.
"When you walk into a building where there has been a fire," says Mr. Barracato, "the building talks to you. It tells you what happened." 
 It was this interest and instinct that led him, a few years after becoming a firefighter in New York, to ask for, and receive, training as an investigator in the fire marshal's office. From 1960 to 1976 he served as a firefighter, fire investigator and deputy chief fire marshal with the New York City Fire Department.
Subsequently, he was assistant vice president of the fire and fraud unit at Aetna Life and Casualty, and wrote a book called "Arson."
Today Mr. Barracato is a consultant and is called in frequently to investigate fires or to testify in court. He discussed his work in a recent interview at his home in South Windsor. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What does your work as a consultant involve?
A. I go all over the world -- London, Scotland, Ireland, New Zealand, Australia, South America. Usually it's a case of suspected arson fraud where there were major losses. For instance, I went to some shirt factories down in Mexico City where they weren't sure whether the fires were an inside job or an outside job. They were done by insiders.
Q. Do we have more fires than other countries?
A. We're the leaders in the world. The reason for that is that no one is held accountable. If you just burned down a house and you displaced four other families and the cause of the fire was smoking carelessness, you're not held accountable for any part of it. About five years ago I read where an American was serving 12 years in a Chinese jail for a fire in a hotel mattress attributed to smoking carelessness. Twelve years is drastic, but here nothing happens to you.
Q. What is another common example of a fire caused by carelessness?
A. When we empty an ashtray, we empty it into a cup and pour water on it. Is that extreme? No. That's being careful. I saw dozens upon dozens of fires with people killed from emptying their ashtrays before they go to bed and there are still glowing embers. Embers glow at 600 degrees. Paper ignites at 420 degrees.
Q. What was your training with the New York fire marshal's office?
A. For the first year you got 8 to 10 fires every day. Maybe one or two might be intentional. Most were food on the stove, mattress fires, smoking fires, extension cord fires. You end up seeing every type of fire imaginable. You know the burn pattern.
You also need some basic knowledge in building, in chemistry, in physics, in the psychology of the fire setter. A properly trained fire investigator, before he leaves that fire scene, should be able to determine if a male set it, a female, if it was revenge motivated, juvenile, arson for profit. You can tell by the manner in which that fire is set.
Q. What is the first thing you look for at the scene of a fire?
A. Lines of demarcation. There is a burn pattern on the building that will tell you where to look when you get inside. You work your way in from the least amount of damage to the most damage, following the direction of burn and char. Then you determine if there were any flammables used.
I had a fire in a warehouse downstate where they made all the stage settings for "My Fair Lady." The building was a city block square and all made out of corrugated steel. The building was totally collapsed. I asked for an aerial ladder to be raised 100 feet, climbed to the top, and I could see where the fire started. I told them to pull up just that area with a crane. We not only uncovered the point of fire origin, we found the machine that caused it. The machine had malfunctioned.
Q. What percentage of fires are accidental?
A. Twenty to 30 percent. Most are smoking carelessness fires. The next most common cause is extension cords. They were not meant to withstand the electricity running through them over an extended period of time. People tuck them under rugs, which is the worst thing you can do. The movement of the rug eventually causes the insulator to crack and if the wires connect you get a spark hot enough to light anything.
Q. What percentage of fires are arson fraud?
A. Between 19 and 29 percent. They are more prevalent in any area where the economy is down.
Q. What about the other fires?
A. About 50 percent of all fires are intentionally set for the purpose of revenge. The higher the divorce rate, the higher the revenge fires.
Q. What do you do when you suspect arson?
A. If I think you set that fire, I will go out of my way to see that you are arrested, providing I can prove it. If I can't prove it or if I have even a weak feeling about that fire, I don't call it. I walk away from it because you could ruin innocent people.
Q. What can you tell by the way in which a fire was set?
A. A nonaggressive fire is usually set by a woman or a juvenile under the age of 13. If the fire was aggressive, if flammable liquids were introduced, that's usually set by a male.
Q. Why do juveniles set fires?
A. For the most part they come from single-parent families, they have no male role model, or he's dysfunctional. Usually they are doing poorly scholastically. The child turns to one of the most powerful tools known to man: fire. He gets a lot of attention. Look at all the fire trucks he can make come in there, ambulances, police cars. That's a euphoric feeling.
Q. Many children play with matches. How do you know when it's a problem?
A. There is an age group, usually between 5, 7 maximum. If it goes beyond 7, you might be having a problem. I was at a fire once in a tenement house, in a child's room, a mattress fire. We wanted to speak to the child, but the mother wouldn't allow us to. Four days later we took them all out in body bags.
If it's past the age of 17, he's turning into a pathological fire setter. Now you have a totally different type, one who never stops setting fires.
Q. How can you tell if a fire was set for profit or for revenge?
A. By the manner in which the fire was set. At a house fire, first I determine if the fire was intentionally set with a flammable liquid. If it was an aggressive fire, I have to think first: male. Is it absolute? No. But 90 percent certain. If the flammable liquid was introduced in the interior of the house, the motive was probably profit. If the same fire was started outside, it's usually a revenge fire, maybe drug associated. As a stranger I can't go into your house and pour gasoline, but I will throw a Molotov cocktail.
Q. What about arson fraud?
A. There is almost always financial instability. We had a fire in a shop that only delivered pizzas. But there were no pizza boxes inside. He had stopped ordering pizza boxes 30 days prior to the fire. Then we found out he hadn't been ordering dough or sauce. That was glaring.
Q. What did your study of fire setters show?
A. I interviewed 927 people who were arrested for arson. Females generally set fires for attention or for revenge. If she is seeking attention from a teacher she might set a fire on his desk or in the waste basket and is usually the first person offering sympathy or help in cleaning up.
Q. What about the pathological fire setter, the pyromaniac?
A. They are usually so severely introverted that they can't relate to other people. They turn to the thing that makes them feel good. The fire to them is the female. She never turns them down, never. They'll usually set nonaggressive fires. What makes them so dangerous is that they leave without putting the fire out or warning people. The only good thing is only 3 percent of the fire setting in the nation is pathological.
Q. What about a professional arsonist?
A. Professional arsonists we don't catch. A professional is usually hired by a large business that is not doing well. A torch usually gets 10 percent of the face value of the policy and he usually wants it up front. The average homeowner doesn't have it up front. The professional comes in at night, usually without help, and they're gone the next morning.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Barracato, a consultant based in South Windsor, investigates how fires start, and why. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 4; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1415 words

HEADLINE: Touro Plans Law School Near New Courts

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
WHEN Judge Leonard Wexler of Federal States District Court in Hauppauge taught a course in trial practice at Touro Law Center two years ago, his students asked to hold the class in his courtroom. He agreed on one condition: that they dress appropriately.
"Students generally come to class dressed sloppily," he said. "No one wears a tie and jacket. So I said I expected them to dress up, and not one failed to dress up the entire semester. I was amazed. It just showed their interest." 
 Judge Wexler said the students would invariably arrive early to watch lawyers in action and then critique in class what they saw. And having them sit in the jury box and present arguments from the well of the courtroom "dissipated the strangeness."
It is that enthusiasm and involvement that the dean of Touro Law Center, Howard A. Glickstein, hopes to recreate by moving the school from a former school building in Huntington to a wooded 18.5-acre site that was part of the former Central Islip Pscyhiatric Center. The site is just north of the Southern State Parkway and to the east of Carleton Avenue. It abuts the United States Courthouse and Federal Building Complex, expected to be completed in 1999, and the John P. Cohalan Jr. Court Complex, which includes State Supreme, District and Family Court buildings.
"Nowhere in the United States is there a campus with Federal and state courts and a law school," Mr. Glickstein said. "We want to see if we can find ways of improving legal education and the administration of justice by having a legal institution so close to the courts."
"You would not think of opening a medical school in the woods but rather as part of or next to a hospital," he said. "But most law schools are not even near a courthouse."
Such a relationship would help put Touro Law Center, which is ranked by U.S. News & World Report in the lower one-third of law schools, on the map, according to the dean.
"We opened in Huntington in 1982 and it takes a long time for a school to build a reputation," he said. "What helps is a unique approach, and moving to Central Islip will give us a niche that will help our reputation. People all over the country will be interested in what is going on there."
Mr. Glickstein shrugged off Touro's ranking, saying it was based on the reputation the school enjoys among lawyers and judges across the nation.
"How is a lawyer in Butte, Mont., going to rate Touro?" he asked. "He's never heard of it. Yet if Princeton were to open a law school tomorrow, it would get ranked near the top by people who have no idea who is teaching there. So the system of ranking is flawed."
This week, to further enhance its image, the school will be host to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Supreme Court. She will give a lecture at 6 P.M. Thursday in the law school auditorium. Her topic is "Reflections on Way Paving: Jewish Justices and Jewish Women." It is free and open to the public.
The new building will be designed to allow Touro to maintain its enrollment at 750 students. Anything larger, Mr. Glickstein said, would make the school "too impersonal."
Mr. Glickstein said that, based on the sale of other property to educational institutions recently, he would guess the land would cost the college $15,000 to $20,000 an acre. The building project is expected to take two years and cost $25 million. It is expected to be two stories tall and 150,000 square feet.
A task force set up in March 1996 to suggest future uses for the 87.2 acres used by the former Central Islip Psychiatric Center and for other state purposes recommended in September that the 18.5 acres be used for an "educational institution, ideally one that would benefit from the proximity to the court complex."
A member of the task force, Nancy Manfredonia, the executive director of the Central Islip Civic Association, said Touro's proposed move was "so perfect that I assume it has to work."
"If I were a young law student, that's where I'd be going," she said. "It's a perfect location for the school and I'm ready to celebrate if it happens."
She said that having the law school move to the site would be another plus for Central Islip, which 10 years ago was designated by the state as an economic development zone.
"Within 10 years time we have had a tremendous success story," Ms. Manfredonia said, adding that the master plan calls for developing housing, industry, office space and educational facilities in the community.
The Supervisor of Islip, Pete McGowan, said the law school would "bring more and more people who bring people and create jobs."
"We're not only talking about teaching jobs, but for mom and pop stores the move might mean 50 more sandwiches a day," he said.
He added that the court complex had helped to revitalize Central Islip, which had "come a long way in 10 years -- like day and night."
A 1995 study by Thomas Conoscenti & Associates, an economic consulting firm in Nesconset hired by Touro, found that construction of the law center and a law school would have a positive impact on Central Islip. The two projects would contribute $21 million in income to the Islip economy and $41.7 million to the region. During construction, it would create 437 jobs in Islip and nearly 600 in the region.
Mr. Glickstein said he envisioned a section of the school set aside for a judicial training center for both new and seasoned judges. And courses would be offered for nonjudicial staff as well.
The administrative judge of Suffolk County courts, Supreme Court Justice Mary M. Werner, said she believed it was a "wonderful opportunity to have state and Federal courts across the parking lot from the law school."
"And it's a super idea to have a judicial training center for judges to take continuing legal and professional education courses," she said.
Justice Werner noted that Touro was already very much involved in the legal community in Suffolk. Several state judges are on the faculty and the school is to play host to a program for judges, lawyers and law students that seeks to foster "the concept of civility and professionalism between the bench and the bar."
With the school in Central Islip, Justice Werner said, she envisions Touro students running law classes for pro-se litigants, or people who represent themselves, and "doing exciting and innovative programs because of their proximity to the courts."
When the Federal court complex is completed, all Federal courts on Long Island will move to the site. That includes the courts in Uniondale, which rent a building owned by Hofstra University and which are a short distance from the Hofstra Law School. A spokeswoman for Hofstra University, Valerie Zurblis, said that despite the move the school would continue to maintain a relationship with the courts. And she played down the advantage Touro would have being on the same campus as the state and Federal courts.
"Many law schools are located near courthouses," she said. "Brooklyn Law School is near the Eastern District and New York Law School is near the Southern District. Many law schools are in downtown areas to be near the court system. It's really quite common."
Ms. Zurblis added that the Hofstra Law School already enjoyed a good reputation and was "more competitive with schools outside of Long Island, such as New York University, Syracuse University and Boston University."
But Judge Wexler, who is chairman of the Long Island Courthose Construction Project, said he would have liked to have developed a closer relationship with Hofstra Law School when his law offices were in Uniondale from 1983 to 1986. He said that he had reached out to the school but that "nobody seemed interested."
The immediate past president of the Suffolk County Bar Association, John L. Juliano, said he was working with Touro to develop joint programs with the Suffolk Academy of Law, the educational arm of the Bar Association. He too was excited about the juxtaposition of the school and the courthouses.
"Students will have an opportunity to learn various legal procedures in a classroom setting and then walk across the parking lot and see it firsthand," he said. "It can do nothing but good for the school."
In addition, Mr. Juliano said, the close proximity of the school to the courts would make it more convenient for lawyers to use the school's 250,000-volume library, which is made available to them for a nominal fee, and to take continuing education courses there.

HEADLINE: Police Wage Award Used Suffolk Scale, Rising Over 20%

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
ON a short list of the richest places in the United States, Nassau County and its exclusive villages virtually always rank near the top. Even in less expensive communities, the average household income is reported to approach $70,000 a year.
Now an arbitrator's award that pushes the pay of police officers to historic highs assures that officers in the Nassau County Police Department will earn salaries to match the wealth, making them aristocrats among police forces. 
 Ten months after an award by the same arbitrator ushered in the era of the $70,000-a-year officer in Suffolk, a five-year contract in Nassau will increase total earnings for many officers to about $100,000 in three years, including overtime and other payments. The estimate, offered by several county officials, does not include benefits like health insurance. Superior officers have higher scales.
The higher salaries mean that officers, whose earnings often peak in their final years on the force, will be paid significantly higher pensions, which are based on peak earnings. Officers can retire after 20 years of work.
The arbitrator's award, retroactive to last year, raises the base salary over five years by 24 percent or 22 percent, depending on how the increase is calculated. Officers with seven years' experience will have a base salary of $73,859 by 2000 for a maximum of 154 workdays a year. Under the force's steady-tour system, an average officer works 12-hour shifts three days a week.
County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, who is seeking a third term in November, declined last week through a spokesman to comment on the decision. The spokesman, David A. Vieser, referred all questions on the contract to special counsel Peter A. Bee, who represented Mr. Gulotta in the arbitration.
Mr. Bee said the award, by Martin F. Scheinman of Manhasset, "was not a surprise to me." He said it allowed for increases that were virtually identical to those that Mr. Scheinman decided in Suffolk.
In past campaigns Mr. Gulotta, a Republican, has been endorsed by the Police Benevolent Association, the union for the 2,100 rank-and-file officers. He is expected to win union's endorsement this year.
Mr. Gulotta's refusal to comment on an award with major financial implications for the county contrasts with an otherwise active schedule. This month, for example, Mr. Gulotta was available for photographs that showed him presenting checks to help first-time home buyers make down payments.
His opponent, Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay, offered measured criticism. "The question was not whether the police were entitled to an increase," Mr. Yevoli said. "It was whether the citizens of Nassau County could afford to pay the increase."
The answer, Mr. Yevoli said, was no.
Mr. Yevoli said Mr. Gulotta, the County Legislature and the P.B.A. should meet to discuss cutting costs like overtime. "That's the next big mandate," he said. "The arbitrator's award is binding. Now you have to go to the responsible parties and say there there isn't enough money to pay and now you have to come up with ways money can be saved."
Mr. Yevoli said the county faced a deficit of $20 million to $60 million, even before the decision. Mr. Gulotta says there is no deficit.
Comptroller Frederick Parola said last week that the county would have to pay $9 million retroactively because of the ruling. The money, Mr. Parola added, could be raised through selling bonds.
The P.B.A. sought arbitration after Mr. Yevoli and another Democrat, Supervisor May W. Newberger of North Hempstead, did not ratify a negotiated contract in late 1995, as the old Board of Supervisors was about to be replaced by the Legislature.
The president of the union, Gary DelaRaba, said Mr. Scheinman's award was "actually a little bit better" than the 1995 accord.
Mr. Bee, the county negotiator, agreed that "in general terms this contract was more expensive."
Mr. Yevoli said the differences between the 1995 agreement and the arbitrator's award were slight.
Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove, a Democrat, said the 1995 contract and the arbitration award were excessive. He faulted Mr. Gulotta, saying:
"The County Executive does not aggressively represent the taxpayers in arbitration because he is too close to the P.B.A. The arbitrator made these outrageous awards with his tacit consent.
"Our police in Nassau County do an excellent job, and our Glen Cove police are the best in the state. I have no qualms as far as the performance of the county police. But enough is enough as far as the pay goes."
Mr. Yevoli also objected to the arbitrated salaries. "You need to have a certain amount of courage to be a police officer and it's hard to criticize," he said. "But $74,000 for 154 days? That's an awful lot of money."
Mr. DelaRaba rejected the view that the officers would be overpaid. "We are getting what everybody else in the county-police community is getting, nothing more, nothing less," he said.
In the arbitration, the P.B.A. sought salaries similar to those paid in Nassau villages, where officers earn more than those on the county force. The county argued that the pay should be compared to Suffolk.
Mr. Scheinman said last week that comparisons between Nassau and Suffolk were central to his decision.
The total increases for the first four years in the Nassau contract are quite similar to the total increases in the four-year contract in Suffolk. The Nassau contract awards a 4.5 percent increase in the fifth year, the minimum amount that Suffolk officers would receive in the first year of a new contract, using the comparability approach.
"Over the years," Mr. Scheinman said, "the parties in these negotiations and arbitrations have argued that the most comparable comparable community for Nassau County is Suffolk County. That has been the position the county argued in this case, and I agreed. The police asked for more than Suffolk County."
Arbitration awards are also based on salaries paid in comparable areas and on a community's ability to pay. Nassau's wealth makes that consideration secondary.
A contract provision that the P.B.A. and the county described as the first of its kind requires new officers to have four-year undergraduate degrees to qualify for top pay. The contract also sets pay at $21,000 for the first year, a provision that lessens the cost of hiring.
The contract sets a standard for pay that other police unions will seek in negotiations on Long Island and elsewhere. Police officers in New York City, who earn less than Nassau or Suffolk officers, are excluded from the state board that provides for arbitration in other areas of the state, including Long Island. But city police unions quite certainly will cite the disparity in pay in contract talks.
Just as Long Island schoolteachers have received wage increases from school boards over 30 years that have brought salaries more in line with the high cost of living, officers in both counties and in cities and villages have gradually gained major salary advances.
But in the fiscal crisis of the early 1990's, when state aid to districts decreased and opposition to rising school budgets stiffened, many local boards limited salary increases.
By contrast, increases in county police pay can be offset in county budgets by adjustments in general spending. Nassau and Suffolk have also substituted higher sales taxes for increases in property taxes, a step that has led to higher revenues in recent years as a regional recession has given way to recovery and stronger sales.
The method of police payment and the unwillingness of elected officials and office seekers to criticize the politically powerful police unions have buffered the police from complaints. The reluctance also reflects a perception that the Nassau force enjoys broad public support in a region where the crime rate is low and declining.
Some experts have said the lower rate stems in part from an aging population. But current and former Nassau officials said they sensed that public sentiment was behind the police.
"Generally people are gong to give the police the benefit of the doubt," Benjamin L. Zwirn, former supervisor in North Hempstead, said. "When you dial 911 you want someone to show up quickly who is well trained and capable of handling an emergency."
Police unions have also been successful in protecting state laws that provide for arbitration in contract disputes and base salary decisions on the ability to pay and salaries paid in comparable areas. The laws provide for binding arbitration for police officers, who are barred from striking.

HEADLINE: New Rochelle Celebrates With a Street Festival

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
NEW ROCHELLE celebrates New Rochelle on the last day of summer next Sunday, with a street festival that will focus on the city's many attributes.
The festival begins at noon at Library Plaza in the heart of New Rochelle's, opposite the train station a block from Main Street. 
 Dance troupes, music groups, street performers and jugglers will entertain throughout the day, along with puppet and magic shows, face-painting and hands-on crafts and carnival rides for children.
An international food court will offer foods from China, Mexico, the Caribbean, Italy, Israel and the United States, and the event is sponsored by the New Rochelle Overall Economic Development Corporation.
"One of the primary purposes of the Economic Development Corporation is to raise the profile of our city as an ideal community in which to invest in for the future," Fred Wiener, chairman of the corporation, said, adding that the festival will bring people to downtown New Rochelle, "where they discover just how much the city has to offer."
Melanie Stern, co-chairman of the event, said, "It's a celebration of all the things that make New Rochelle a great place to live, to work and to do business."
"Like New Rochelle," Mrs. Stern said, "our celebration will be a rich mosaic, diverse with something for everyone."
Business, community groups and public service organizations will also be represented. "They will be manning information booths," said Rob Seitz, a businessman and member of the board of the Economic Development Corporation. "The event is a showcase for all the programs the Economic development Corporation runs, including a loan program for women and minority-owned businesses, our new business incubator, which will open soon and our Culture Builds Communities, a program promoting the arts, and our business retention program designed to keep existing businesses in New Rochelle. The festival is a an effective way we draw attention to New Rochelle as a good place to do business."
New Rochelle businesses underwriting the event include Chase Bank, Citibank, Monroe College and New Roc Corporation, developers of the new downtown mall. City government departments, the New Rochelle Chamber of Commerce and the Westchester County Tourism Board were also active in planning and producing the festival.
Further information is available by calling the Economic Development office at 576-5334. PENNY SINGER
