HEADLINE: A Ball Game In Bridgeport's Near Future

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
NOT far from a failed dog track, which previously had been a failed jai alai fronton, and on a site where the real estate developer Donald Trump had hoped to build a gambling casino, a baseball stadium will begin to rise next month near the Bridgeport waterfront.
Assuming the fledging Atlantic League of Professional Baseball Clubs gets off the ground, the new ballpark will be the home of the Bridgeport Bluefish, which would be the city's first professional baseball team since the Bridgeport Bees of the short-lived Class B Colonial League in the late 1940's. Current plans call for the Bluefish to begin play at what will be called Harbor Yard next May when the Atlantic League begins its first season with six or seven teams. 
 The ballpark is viewed as the first component of a sports and recreational complex on the Bridgeport waterfront that will include a sports arena, a new intermodal transportation center, a parking garage and, possibly, a museum for baseball memorabilia. Construction of the 5,000-seat stadium on the site of the former Jenkins Brothers Valve Company plant close by Interstate 95 is scheduled to start this month and be completed by next April, weather permitting.
"Everything is go for our first season," said Mary Jane Foster, who with her husband, Jack McGregor, runs Bridgeport Waterfront Investors and owns one-third of the Bluefish franchise. "We think the ballpark and the team will help reintroduce Bridgeport as the wonderful city that it is."
According to the league's chief executive officer, Frank Boulton, the caliber of play will be on a Triple A level, meaning one step lower than the major leagues. "In a way it will be like the old Pacific Coast League with a mix of young players on the way up and veterans who've already played in the big leagues," said Mr. Boulton, a Wall Street executive who lives on Long Island and has owned three minor league teams, including the Albany Yankees of the Eastern League, which has moved to Norwich. "All the funding is in for the six new ballparks being built -- $83.5 million in public monies and about $25 million in private money."
Besides Bridgeport, teams will be situated in Newark, Atlantic City and Somerset County in southern New Jersey; in Suffolk County on Long Island, in Lehigh Valley in Pennsylvania and in Nashua, N.H., the only location where an existing stadium will be used on a regular basis. Of the $14 million allocated for the Bridgeport stadium, $7 million has been allotted by the City of Bridgeport while the remaining $7 million will be in the form of a state bond issue.
The state money will come from a fund known as Team Bridgeport. In all, the city is expected to receive $125 million for redevelopment in increments of $25 million a year over five years. To date, the State Legislature has authorized the allocation of $75 million. A large portion of that money is expected to be used to build a multipurpose sports arena near the baseball stadium.
Some might also go towards construction of a baseball museum that would house the vast collection of memorabilia owned by Barry Halper, who is a part owner of the New York Yankees. Bridgeport is one of several cities that have put in bids for the Halper collection, which many experts believe is even more comprehensive and extensive than that assembled at the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.
"It would be great having the Halper collection in Bridgeport," Ms. Foster said. "I've seen it, and it's absolutely amazing."
In keeping with a national trend, the Bridgeport baseball stadium, while state-of-the art in most respects, will resemble old-style ballparks in many ways. For example, the red brick exterior will evoke Bridgeport's legacy as a major industrial city. The stadium design was a collaborative effort by Kasper Group Inc., a Bridgeport architectural and engineering firm, and Design Exchange of Newark, Del.
In keeping with another baseball trend, merchandise with the Bluefish's logo and colors -- navy blue, silver and teal -- is already being sold out of the team's offices at 189 State Street in downtown Bridgeport, which stock team caps, T-shirts, jackets, pennants and fountain pens. "Business has been pretty good," said David Fowler, who works in the team office.
Though the Bluefish have a logo -- a tenacious-looking bluefish wielding a bat -- and are selling merchandise, the club has yet to hire a general manager. But Ms. Foster said such a hiring is imminent.
Mickey Herbert, one of the chief executive officers of Phyicians Health Care in Shelton, who owns a third of the Bridgeport franchise, said ticket prices would probably average about $5.50. Seats in the stadium's 20 skyboxes, however, will cost considerably more: $20,000 a year for a 16-seat box.
The Bluefish will bring to five the number of minor league baseball teams in Connecticut. That is believed to be an all-time high. Three of the other teams -- the New Haven Ravens, the New Britain Rock Cats and the Norwich Navigators -- are in the Double A Eastern League, while the fourth, the Waterbury Spirit, is in the independent Northeast League.
But both Ms. Foster and Mr. Herbert believe that the Bluefish will draw primarily from an untapped market: Fairfield County and, to a lesser degree, Westchester County. "We're going after a totally different market," said Ms. Foster whose husband was the founder of the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League. "And it includes one of the wealthiest and most populous counties in the country."
Although the New Haven Ravens play less than 20 miles away, neither they nor the other teams will hurt the Bluefish in terms of attendance, Ms. Foster and Mr. Herbert say. "A rising tide raises all boats," Mr. Herbert noted. "The more teams there are, the more interest is created."
But Charlie Dowd, the general manager of the New Haven Ravens, does worry that the Bluefish will hurt his team at the box office. "There's definitely a concern that they'll have a negative impact on our attendance," Mr. Dowd said. "They will only be 20 minutes away in a brand new ballpark, and they'll have the ability to cut off our efforts to get into Fairfield County."
The Bluefish, like the league itself, would be independent, with no ties to any major league club. Players would be owned by the league but paid by the team owners. Mr. Boulton, the league's C.E.O., said that salaries could range as high as $25,000. Teams will play 140 games, he said, except for the inaugural season when, because of all the stadium construction, the season won't start until May 20 or so and include only 100 games.
Team owners include former New York Yankees Rick Cerone, who owns the Newark franchise, and Sparky Lyle, the owner of the team in Bridgewater, N.J. Former New York Mets shortstop Buddy Harrelson will manage the Long Island team, while former big league managers Jim Frey and Doc Edwards are also scheduled to be involved with the league, Mr. Boulton said.
"It will be affordable family entertainment," Mr. Boulton said. "We'll be competing with the movies and our prices will be in the same range." Mr. Herbert, one of the owners of the Bluefish, said he expected grandstand tickets would cost about $7, but that some tickets might be priced as low as $2.
Michael Freimuth, the Bridgeport's director of economic development, said the stadium would be clearly visible from Interstate 95 and easily accessible. "People driving along I-95 will be able to look right down on the field, and you'll be able to walk to the ballpark from downtown, from the train and bus stations and from the ferry terminal," Mr. Freimuth said. "And the new garage will provide space for between 500 and 700 cars."
All the transportation will be upgraded into a "intermodal transit center" with a cost estimated at $35 million. The Federal Government is expected to pay 80 percent of the cost, with the city and state paying the remainder, according to Mr. Freimuth.
The proposed sports arena would seat between 5,500 and 8,500 spectators, Mr. Freimuth said, and would cost between $35 million and $40 million. It could be used for basketball and hockey by both Sacred Heart and Fairfield universities, "and it could also be used for concerts, trade shows and circuses," Mr. Freimuth said. "And we've already had inquiries from a minor league hockey team and a startup professional basketball league." But he said that construction of the sports arena could be "two or three years away."
Another lure would be the museum housing the Barry Halper collection, which includes more than 1,000 baseball uniforms, including those worn by Babe Ruth and Cy Young, and which has been appraised at $42 million, according to Paul Timpanelli, the executive director of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council.
"We've had extensive discussions with Mr. Halper, and we know that Bridgeport is in the running along with Hoboken and some other cities," said Mr. Timparelli. The Mashantucket Pequots, riding high with the Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard, are "committed to help us financially in getting the Halper collection," Mr. Timpanelli said. "If we get it, we think that in five or 10 years we'll be drawing more people than the 400,000 or so who visit Cooperstown each year. Cooperstown is in the middle of nowhere, while there are 25 million people within 100 miles of Bridgeport."
But the museum, like the arena, is a future project. The ballpark will be the first tangible symbol of redevelopment on the Bridgeport waterfront.
"The ballpark," Mr. Timpanelli said, "will help give people a different perception of Bridgeport."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Celebrating New Age On New Haven Stage

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
ONCE, the New Haven tryout came with the territory of a Broadway-bound show. That meant a few weeks at the Shubert, which opened its doors in 1914.
Over the next six decades -- cresting from the 1940's to the 1960's, diminishing in the 1970's -- the Shubert was the birthing place of a breathtaking galaxy of classics: "Carousel," "Born Yesterday," "Annie Get Your Gun," "All My Sons," "A Streetcar Named Desire," "Mister Roberts," "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum." And seven plays by Neil Simon. 
 For many other shows, already premiered, the Shubert was an essential pre-Broadway nurturing stop. Like "Barefoot in the Park" by Mr. Simon.
Now the road to Broadway, strewn with necessary alternatives, is rougher, lengthier, costlier -- and not frequently taken. So, no one is going to make believe that the glory days of live theater are still here.
But, starting Tuesday, it won't take a colossal leap into a time warp to revisit a golden age where the past is the present.
That's when Mr. Simon's new play, "Proposals" will open at the Shubert, to run through Sept. 28 in preparation for Broadway where it begins previews on Oct. 29. Opening night at the Broadhurst Theater is Nov. 6.
Tuesday night's opening will mark the theater's re-opening, the dawning of a new age for the Shubert, so grandly haunted and informed by a treasured past. Although a wall of fame -- which lists close to 80 years of show titles (except for the theater's dark period, from 1976 to 1983) -- is its everlasting centerpiece, the 1,600-seat Shubert, which now calls itself a "new old theater" is to show off a major touch-up.
So much for the beauty part. But the theater would be neither new nor old were it not for an elaborate "Save the Shubert" plan, involving Yale University, Community Foundation for Greater New Haven and business organizations.
The plan came to pass last year when the theater was on the brink of closing because of a financial crisis. The performing arts center's president, Caroline Werth, describes the renovation as "big, elegant, state of the art changes in a grande dame -- there's even a new boutique."
Now the Shubert "has finally fully blossomed into an exciting range of programs," Ms. Werth said. "Not just theater, but great dance companies and every kind of performance art will find its way into our season. The variety is staggering." The theater will be open 135 nights during the year and otherwise used by community groups. "Our community outreach and education programs have a huge life of their own," Ms. Werth noted.
Given the fearsome business of show business, the Shubert try-out of Mr. Simon's new play cannot signal the revival of the theatrical tradition. "A new process has taken over," said Ms. Werth, referring to extended pre-Broadway tours, the unspoken but undeniable role of regional and institution theaters as try-out centers as well as various play and musical development organizations.
Still, "Proposals" at the Shubert resounds with tradition and the memory of a style that evokes nostalgia in veteran theatergoers who have grown accustomed to a clutter of names and corporations above the title of a play.
"Proposals," like all Mr. Simon's plays since 1972, uses the real solo theater producer -- here, Emanuel Azenberg -- who represents an all but vanished breed, the seasoned man of theater in place of a conglomerate or an invasion of newcomers.
"This is the way it was, old-fashioned try-outs," Mr. Azenberg said after returning from Phoenix, the second stop in the "Proposals" try-out schedule. "And Neil comes in with rewrites every 15 minutes. But the economics are terrifying and it can't be seen as a trend, just a celebration of old times."
Evidently, Mr. Simon's play also evokes warmth and tradition. In mixed reviews, out of town critics have called it "autumnal in mood" and "mellow" as well as "witty and cutting and impossibly wise."
The play takes place in 1957 in the Pocono Mountains. During the New Haven engagement, Dick Latessa is to replace Ron Rifkin in the role of Burt Hines, the owner of a chain of television stores who is recovering from a heart attack. He is being visited by his ex-wife, his daughter, her three admirers, one of their dates and a housekeeper.
The director of "Proposals," Joe Mantello, who is associated with more abrasive cutting edge theater, as an actor ("Angels in America") and as a director ("Love! Valour! Compassion!" "Three Hotels") had another take on a "new old" experience.
"I've never gone out of town before," he said. "This is a crowd-pleasing, old fashioned play. It's very warm and sweet and funny and wistful, not urban or edgy."
Mr. Mantello says has not read the out of town reviews. "We're listening to the audience and to our own instincts," he said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Greenwich, Conn.;
Running Mom and Pop Off Glitzy Greenwich Avenue

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn.

 BODY:
LAST September, when Saks Fifth Avenue opened its store for women in Greenwich, Conn. -- the most elegant and expensive apparel shop in town -- it was a major step in Greenwich's ongoing transition from local to national and international retailing.
Consequently, like other wealthy communities across the country, Greenwich's retail rents and sales of buildings with stores have risen from 20 to 30 percent in the last two years alone, causing some real estate professionals to call the .7-mile Greenwich Avenue and the 180 stores lining it "Rodeo Drive East," after the high-end shopping mecca in Beverly Hills. 
 A walk down the avenue today would surprise anyone who has not visited Greenwich lately. Finch's drugstore has been replaced by Starbucks. Instead of Woolworth's there is Saks. Ralph Lauren, The Gap, Banana Republic, Baccarat, and Henry Lehr & Company, a sportswear store, are some of the stores that have nudged out shops that had been on the avenue for generations.
Rents have risen from $10 to $20 a square foot in the early 1980's to a range of $60 to more than $80 a square foot in 1997. Baccarat, the crystal maker, is paying $81 a square foot for its 730-square-foot shop at Greenwich Avenue and East Elm Street. It replaced a T-shirt store paying rent in the $50's.
"I believe that $100 a foot is doable for a small corner -- just to have a location on the avenue," said Patrick A. Smith, director of leasing north of New York City for the Manhattan-based Garrick-Aug Associates Store Leasing.
Perceptions of conspicuous consumption and skyrocketing prices along a street that had been a bastion of old Greenwich conservatism have generated some apprehension and disorientation.
"Mom and Pop would need $80 million to make it on Greenwich Avenue today," said Bernard Yudain, a longtime resident. "Favorite Shoe Store, Rovens Curtains, all the little service shops are gone. Most shoppers and restaurant clientele are from out of town." Yet there is the recognition that the street is markedly improved as older shops upgrade facades, interiors and merchandise to compete with the new tenants.
Broker buoyancy over record transactions is tempered by uncertainty over whether the new shops will thrive.
"History has shown that even in a recession Greenwich office, retail and residential real estate have held up quite nicely," said John D. Goodkind, a broker in the Greenwich office of Newmark & Company Real Estate of New York City. "Unless we have Armageddon that will continue, but there are the Stamford and Westchester malls to reckon with."
The former is five miles away, the latter 14 miles; both have the familiar collection of upscale chain stores that have now settled on Greenwich Avenue. "Whether this is a fad or Greenwich retailers can support these rents," he said, "you wonder how much there is to go around."
"We had a waiting list of 15 prospective tenants for 200 Greenwich Avenue," said Mr. Smith of Garrick-Aug, referring to the sale on Sept. 4 of a 47,500-square-foot retail and office building brokered by Newmark. Japan Leasing USA sold it for $20 million to RFR Holding LLC, a German investment group in Manhattan.
Brentano's, Shawmut Bank, and Chalk & Vermilion, an art gallery, moved out when their leases expired; Ann Taylor, CP Shades, a California women's sportswear concern, and two unnamed tenants are moving in at rents of $65 to $75 a square foot -- 30 percent higher than the previous rents. "We set an unrealistically high number and got close to our price," said Mr. Smith.
He predicted that there would be a higher concentration of upscale tenants in the two center blocks, close to municipal parking -- and that like Main Street in Westport, rents would increase disproportionately to sales volume. "Eventually," he added, "there will be some sort of correction."
Saks's 35,000-square-foot store was sold to Street Retail, a wholly owned subsidiary of Federal Realty Investment Trust of Rockville, MD., for $12.5 million, or $350 a square foot in 1995.
Federal, the first REIT to enter the Greenwich Avenue market, has bought three additional Greenwich Avenue properties since then, and it is looking for more, according to Harvey Miller, leasing agent for Street Retail.
ITS purchase last year for $9.4 million of the 25,524-square-foot building at 252-260 Greenwich Avenue, where Gap Kids and Banana Republic are tenants, was another example of sales that continue to rocket out of range of their assessments. Saks is assessed at $3.3 million, 252-260 Greenwich Avenue at $3.79 million, far less than the normal 70 percent of market value.
When Greenwich real estate comes up for revaluation in 1999 the results could trigger some tax increases on Greenwich Avenue. The town is not due for its 10-year state-mandated revaluation until 2002, but "there are inequities that need to be corrected," said Harriet Wieboldt, the town's assessor.
"We expect to use income and expense data heavily, and those that have been underassessed will be closely scrutinized," she said. As a hypothetical example, the building in which the D.W. Rogers department store, founded in 1873, has its home at 239 Greenwich Avenue, is for sale at $10 million, but assessed at $3.76 million. The 35,767-square-foot building was purchased by its current owner, Terry Baxendale, for $2 million in 1983. Above the store 21 fully rented studio- to 3-bedroom apartments on three floors, renting for $900 to $1,400 a month, supplement the income from the somewhat outdated store.
"It's a fact of life that diversity is disappearing," said Mr. Baxendale. "I would prefer to be in a shopping area that isn't so appealing. This is becoming a very focused market."
The building's taxes, based on the full sale price, could rise from the current $52,928 to as much as $117,700, according to estimates from the assessor's office.
Mr. Smith does not see tax increases as a negative. "Taxes amount to about 10 percent of a retail tenant's costs and are customarily passed through from landlord to tenant," he said.
Not all local retailers who own their properties are interested in selling. Albert E. Betteridge owns Betteridge Jewelers at 117 Greenwich Avenue, a 6,000-square-foot store that his father took over from Henry Webb Jewelers in the 1940's. He has refused several offers.
"I kind of like what's going on," he said. A retailer of Tiffany's line and a manufacturer of his own jewelry on the premises, he caters to a prosperous clientele.
"My father's customers were Carnegies, Mellons and Rockefellers," he said. "They inherited more jewelry than they bought. Today's Wall Streeters did not inherit. They made their money and they are my customers."
THE one and only local retailing venture to come along in recent memory is the merger of Richard's of Greenwich, a Greenwich Avenue men's store, and Mitchell's, a men's and women's store in Westport. "There's nothing left that's family owned in Westport," said Ross Mitchell.
Two years ago the Mitchells and Ed Schacter's family, owners of Richard's, decided to join forces and create a new Richard's on a 35,000-square-foot Sunoco gas station site at Greenwich Avenue and Fawcett Place. By obtaining the rights to an adjacent parcel of 16,000 square feet, the retailers expect to supply surface parking for 80 cars, and underground parking for 268 cars, of which 126 spaces will be paid for and reserved by the town.
The $20 million project, including a 35,000-square-foot store designed by Herbert Newman, professor of architecture at Yale, is scheduled to go before the Greenwich Planning and Zoning Commission for site plan approval on Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS;
In the Age of the Portobello Mushroom, Culinary Courses Keep Pace

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER

 BODY:
WHAT'S cooking?
It depends where you look in the culinary arts programs at New Jersey's technical and vocational high schools. 
 On Monday, one Bergen County student was starting with the basics: learning where to pour water into a coffee maker almost too high for her to reach. In the same kitchen on the Hackensack campus, other students were putting the finishing touches on a pan-seared salmon fillet and a portobello mushroom risotto.
In Warren County, the sound of the first bell at 8:03 A.M. sets off a controlled frenzy of slicing and sauteeing as student chefs prepare for the first wave of the lunch crowd, which hits at 10:22. During the first week of school, one day's menu included an entree (orange-glazed chicken or Philadelphia cheese steak), a soup (minestrone or chicken with fresh cilantro), mixed vegetables or green beans amandine, roasted potatoes and dessert (cherry crumb pie, devil's food cake or cookies), plus a drink. The price: $1.40.
At Passaic County Technical Institute, where cafeterias staffed by students regularly serve 2,000 meals a day, Tuesday was the first day of business at Chez Technique, a formal restaurant on the school premises. All the tables had been set, complete with flower arrangements and artfully folded napkins. Now, with hands steady or shaky, students were preparing to greet the first customers, and put into practice their first three days of lessons in table service.
In case anyone is confused, we are not talking about old-fashioned home-economics courses here.
The intent of the culinary arts programs -- indeed, of all the programs in the state's vocational and technical high schools -- is to give students both the skills and the attitudes necessary to succeed in a competitive and rapidly changing economy.
"Probably the best reason for accepting kids in this school is the vision they have for setting goals for themselves as far as a career," said Diana C. Lobosco, the chief school administrator at Passaic County Technical Institute.
Some of the culinary arts graduates will go straight to work. Some will graduate with credits that will count toward degrees at Johnson & Wales University in Providence, R.I., or at the community colleges in Hudson and Atlantic counties, for example. Still others will enter four-year universities..
Some students choose culinary arts because they already know they like working with food. "I just love staying in the kitchen," said James Evans, a junior from Paterson enrolled in the Passaic program. "I grew up living with a bunch of women. There was nothing to do but stay in the kitchen."
As a result, he entered high school knowing how to make a first-rate dish of ziti and knowing that he wanted to pursue a career in restaurant or hotel management.
Other students may never have spent time in a kitchen, except to raid the refrigerator. But Joseph Delesky, an instructor at the Warren County Vocational Technical School, says, "It's possible to take someone who has no experience whatsoever, someone who couldn't even make a grilled cheese sandwich, and have them succeed."
Are children really mature enough at 13 or 14 to decide what they want to be when they grow up?
"They're not signing their life away," said John Kolmos, director of curriculum for the Bergen County Technical Schools. "They're exploring alternatives. Do you like handling food? Do you like managing people? What about the hours? Bakers get up three hours earlier than chefs."
And, Mr. Kolmos and other educators note, studying culinary arts does not lock students into one job forever. Everybody eats: toddlers at day-care centers, students in school cafeterias, bankers in corporate dining rooms, patients in hospitals.
Somebody has to cook all this food and staff the supermarkets that serve people who still do their own cooking. Bergen County is confident enough about the growth of the culinary arts that it is spending almost $1 million to transform an old electrical shop into a kitchen that will quadruple the space for food preparation and set up two dining rooms for faculty meals and special events. It is scheduled to open by January 1999.
Pat Cosgrove, district coordinator of the school-to-careers program for the Bergen County technical schools, makes the point that technical-school students acquire skills that are useful in any job. "They learn about working in teams, problem-solving, creative thinking," she said.
They also can't help learning something about the community around them. At Barnert Hospital in Paterson, Bergen County students studied Jewish dietary laws. At the Radisson Hotel in Englewood, they learned how to handle a Muslim wedding reception. (Rule No. 1: no liquor.) In cooking for the Bleshman School in Paramus, students tackle the complexities of feeding the severely disabled; they learn, for example, that food for people with cerebral palsey must be blended carefully so they can swallow it without difficulty.
The instructors know the realities of their field because they used to be in the kitchens themselves. Joseph Delesky, who teaches at Warren County Vocational-Technical High School in Washington, worked in corporate dining for Sierra Food Services. Guy Dunagan, who teaches in Salem County, has a degree from the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., and worked for nine years as an executive pastry chef at the Trump Plaza casino hotel in Atlantic City. Rico Cannataro, who oversees operations at Passaic County Technical Institute's Chez Technique, has many years' experience at the Manor in West Orange.
The restaurant Mr. Cannataro now manages was developed through a partnership between the Passaic County school and the Society of Quality Restaurants of New Jersey, a trade association representing more than five dozen restaurants. School officials like to call the restaurant "a living classroom" where students in crisp white shirts, black bow ties and black vests are trained to be waiters, hosts, maitres d'hotel and captains. (Students also learn about wines, although they are not allowed to taste them because they are not legally old enough to drink.)
On Tuesday, James Evans and Craig Jackson, another student from Paterson, waited on tables for the first time, reciting the day's special (chicken provolone with fresh pasta) taking drink orders, serving and clearing the tables. Was it a flawless dining experience? No. For one thing, some of the floral arrangements on the table were distractingly tall; for another, one diner was served a soda but no glass. But the service was prompt and courteous, and all the diners at a big table received the entrees they had ordered on the first try, something that can't be counted on in a lot of professional restaurants.
At the end of every meal, diners are presented with a bill (of course) with a report card on the back to rate the service. Before Mr. Cannataro can train his students, he has to train the faculty members who dine at Chez Technique to give honest and detailed critiques.
Whether he got them on Tuesday is anybody's guess. After desserts were served -- tiramisu or a puff pastry fruit tart with orange-lemon sauce -- faculty members were practically swooning.
It's not standard practice to review a restaurant the day it opens, but Chez Technique had nothing to worry about.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Beyond the Ivory Tower, a Sabbatical Is a Valued Perk

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
RICHARD F. ZIEGLER, a Manhattan lawyer, just came back from the Rockies. And Mike Phillips, the chief executive of an investment management firm near Seattle, just returned from Europe.
Vacations, right? 
 Better. Sabbaticals.
"It was about two weeks before I really appreciated how long a period I was going to be gone," said Mr. Phillips, who spent a month in England and another in Italy. "Now, of course, it all seems like it was a dream."
Mr. Ziegler just started his three-month sabbatical and spent the first week on a horse ranch in northern Colorado that had no telephones accessible to guests. "So contacting my voice mail was out of the question," he said happily.
Extended leaves, with or without pay, have become a treasured and, over the last 15 years, increasingly common perquisite for long-term, and even relatively short-term, employees.
In a survey of 829 of its members last year, the Society for Human Resource Management in Alexandria, Va., found that 23 percent offered unpaid sabbaticals and 5 percent offered paid sabbaticals. The sample included some schools and universities, at which sabbaticals have long been offered, as well as many companies.
"While unemployment is low, companies are trying new things to attract, motivate and retain talent," said Barry Lawrence, a spokesman for the society.
Though perhaps not as popular as stock options or signing bonuses, sabbaticals can be a carrot to recruit top talent or a reward to keep valued employees.
Mr. Lawrence added, though, that sabbaticals are a mixed blessing for companies.
"They may help attract people, but you can also lose people if they find a new job or career path while on sabbatical," he said.
Conversely, sabbaticals can also help a company ease out deadwood and disaffected or redundant workers. "We believe it can be a so-called downsizing tool," said Burke Stintson, AT&T's senior public relations manager. "'AT&T expects that a number of people will not return, a situation that would ease the need to downsize."
But the company says sabbaticals also offer growth opportunities for workers. Since 1992, about 1,500 AT&T employees have taken unpaid sabbaticals, which offer full benefits and a promise of a similar job when the workers return.
"We see it as a way for some people to better themselves and to bring new skills and perspectives back to our workplace," Mr. Stintson said.
Corporate sabbaticals are rarely as generous as their better-known academic counterparts. At many colleges and universities, a faculty member is entitled to a one-semester sabbatical with pay every six or seven years. Faculty members often extend their sabbaticals by taking a second semester off without pay.
Outside the ivory tower, shorter sabbaticals -- two weeks to three months -- are more common, and the required tenure may be less, sometimes just a few years. Corporate sabbaticals are much more likely to be unpaid, which can make them unaffordable for some employees; companies that offer paid sabbaticals may require that the time be used for community service or another specific purpose.
At the Segal Company, an employee benefits, compensation and human resources consulting firm based in Manhattan, employees are eligible for a one-month paid sabbatical after 10 years. (They get two months after 15 years and four months after 25 years.) Segal was one of the first companies to offer sabbaticals, in the early 1960's, and about 30 people have participated to date, said Robert Krinsky, the chairman and administrator of the sabbatical program.
The time off, though, may be used for any purpose: pursuing a hobby, painting the house or taking a course. Mr. Krinsky said an early participant at Segal was its founder, Martin E. Segal, who went to Paris in 1965 to study painting and reflect on the future of the company.
More recently, a senior consultant, Omar Saldana, visited Colombia to study the health care system there. Another employee, Jonathan Parker, just returned from two months visiting Thailand, Cambodia, England, Ireland and the south of France. In England, he studied local employee benefits programs.
Mr. Krinsky said that whether eligible employees took sabbaticals, and what they did with them, depended as much on their family circumstances as on their work situation.
"The Segal Company program was founded with two basic purposes in mind," he said. "First, a sabbatical should help you gain a new perspective on your work and life and learn some things that could be of use when you return. Second, it provides an opportunity for someone within the firm to have a higher-level position with greater responsibility, filling the position temporarily for the person on sabbatical."
These days, corporate sabbaticals are popular with technology companies like Intel and Apple, which compete fiercely for talent and where many employees work unusually hard. At Genentech, the biotechnology company in South San Francisco, Calif., full-time employees are eligible for a sabbatical of six continuous weeks with full pay and benefits, in addition to their regular vacation time, in their seventh year of employment. Sabbaticals can be delayed until the eighth year if dictated by business needs.
"The sabbatical program is one of several rewards given to employees in acknowledgment of the high level of intensive work and commitment required at Genentech," said Judy Heyboer, the company's president of human resources. In exchange for that commitment, she said, "we give back the incentive of a more significant break than is typically offered."
Using sabbaticals as a carrot can make sense for companies. "The biggest challenge that any company faces is attracting and keeping good people," said Mr. Phillips, whose employer, the Frank Russell Company, the pension consulting and money management firm in Tacoma, Wash., allows 10-year employees to take eight weeks of paid sabbatical. "If you can do that, most of the other problems are manageable. If you can't, the problems proliferate."
"Part of having a people-centered company is recognizing that balance is important in everyone's life," he added. "We don't celebrate 80-hour weeks around here. If fact, we think that the person who has to work like that is, in the long run, not very smart."
Mr. Ziegler's law firm, Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, offers its 130 partners a sabbatical after every eight years' service as a partner. The minimum sabbatical is two months, fully compensated, combined with a month's vacation to yield three months away from the office; partners are permitted to take an additional two months' unpaid leave if they wish and if the firm's workload permits. The firm also offers associates a somewhat shorter sabbatical after four years' service.
Professional partnerships often do not offer sabbaticals, but Mr. Ziegler, who is spending the rest of his time teaching a seminar at Columbia Law School, said his employer's program benefited from the fact that the firm is "among the few major firms that determine partners' incomes purely by seniority, permitting partners to take time off without any anxiety over potentially adverse financial impact."
MR. ZIEGLER said one of the biggest benefits of a sabbatical was simply knowing that a long period of time off was ahead. "The change of pace offered by the sabbatical also, in effect, permits a risk-free, controlled mini-midlife crisis," he said. "It provides an opportunity to drastically change routine, experiment with something different, and then return to what one does best, hopefully refreshed and recharged."
He added that what he has chosen to do with his time -- devising and teaching a course entitled Ethical and Other Challenging Issues in Complex Litigation -- gave him time to reflect.
"I'm able to spend some time reflecting and thinking about -- in a thoughtful, nonadversarial setting -- many of the choices I make now almost automatically in a typical workweek when there often isn't much time to devote to them," he said, adding that the course could improve the firm's standing and thus help with the recruiting of law students at Columbia, "unless I really bomb out in the classroom."
The disadvantages, he said, include the backlog of work that he expects he will find upon his return in November. He is whittling away at it by having his assistant send some work and messages to him at home.
But that has been outweighed by the benefits, Mr. Ziegler said. He added that he was initially uncertain how to explain to clients that he was planning to leave them for three months. "Almost all of them were remarkably supportive, including many in-house counsel whose corporations wouldn't dream of offering such a wonderful midcareer benefit," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard F. Ziegler is spending most of his leave teaching at law school. His Manhattan firm, Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, offers partners a sabbatical after eight years. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA;
No Mickey Mouse Union Protest at the Ice House

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
Some 50 union members began arriving in TriBeCa at 6:30 last Monday morning, a 20-foot inflated plastic rat by their side. They chanted and whistled, awakening neighborhood residents with the din. The reason? To make the point, said the protest organizer, Mike Hellstrom, that "nonunion contractors are rats."
The object of protesters' wrath was the Ice House, a loft conversion at 27 North Moore Street, between Varick and Hudson Streets, a block whose residents include John F. Kennedy Jr. and the actor Harvey Keitel. Mr. Hellstrom, a representative of Local 79 of the Construction and Building Laborers union, said he had chosen the building, where apartments sell for $600,000 to more than $1 million, because the contractor, Sam Strulovitch, has employed nonunion labor to do some interior demolition. 
 "The building and construction trades were instrumental in getting tax incentives for builders downtown," Mr. Hellstrom said, referring to the Downtown Revitalization Plan signed into law in 1995. "But now we're being locked out of a lot of the work being done." While the legislation covers only Manhattan south of Chambers Street, the use of nonunion workers occurs throughout the city, he said, an assertion echoed by Louis Coletti, chairman of the Building Trades Employers' Association, a group of 600 union contractors.
Mr. Coletti estimated that his members' share of city construction work has dwindled to no more than 50 percent from 60 or 70 percent in the 1980's. He blamed lower bids by nonunion concerns that "generally don't pay decent wages." He also said nonunion contractors take safety shortcuts.
Conceding that some subcontractors on the Ice House use nonunion workers, the Strulovitch company's vice president, Bill Van Salisbury, said he thought workers were adequately paid. He said that most were union members, including all the carpenters and electricians, and that no violations had been cited during recent visits by fire, buildings and sanitation inspectors.
Mr. Hellstrom insisted he would not end the protests or take down the rat until the entire Ice House project has been unionized. He pointed to a demonstration this spring in the Financial District, where nonunion workers were helping to convert a 24-story office building at 80 John Street to rental apartments. "We stayed there for 25 weeks," he said. "Finally, the developer agreed to use union labor on his next five projects." BERNARD STAMLER

GRAPHIC: Photo: An inflated 20-foot rat helped unionized construction workers protest the use of nonunion labor on a renovation project in TriBeCa. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
A Master Plan for Copters

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
Irwin Suskind has lived in Brooklyn Heights since the 1960's, in an apartment overlooking lower Manhattan and the harbor. But only during the last few years has he really noticed the helicopters, swooping down from the sky like deafening birds of prey.
"It's like a highway outside my window," he said, noting that television, tourist, business and courier service choppers crisscross the area. "Sometimes, there are more than 30 flying by in an hour." 
 The problem has worsened since last month's eviction of National Helicopter, a tour operator, from the East 34th Street heliport in Manhattan, and the relocation of many of its flights to the Wall Street Heliport. So Mr. Suskind and other members of the Brooklyn Task Force on Helicopters say they hope for big things from the city's Economic Development Corporation.
The E.D.C. will hold its first public meeting at 6 P.M. on Tuesday at the Department of City Planning, 22 Reade Street in Lower Manhattan, to discuss the Heliport and Helicopter Master Plan it recently commissioned from a private company.
"We don't want a plan that's just going to push helicopters from one part of the city to another," said Karen Johnson, the chief of staff for Representative Edolphus Towns and the head of the helicopter task force. "We want a plan that makes sense."
An E.D.C. spokeswoman, Bernadette O'Leary, said the master plan would be "the first comprehensive study of the city's heliports as a system, and not just as individual sites." She said that the plan would provide a framework to reduce "nonessential" flights, referring to Mayor Giuliani's April pledge -- unfulfilled thus far -- to shut the East 60th Street heliport and cut total traffic by 30 to 40 percent.
In addition to the Wall Street, East 34th Street and 60th Street locations, there is an aging heliport at West 30th Street. Ms. O'Leary said that Pier 76, at West 35th Street, was being considered as a possible replacement site, but that it was too early to know just how many heliports would ultimately remain.
That is not good enough for some helicopter foes, like Joy Held of the Helicopter Noise Coalition of New York City, who said she was skeptical of the city's promises. Her group, which seeks an end to all helicopter flyovers, is suing the city to close the 34th Street heliport.
Ms. Held accused city officials of "shunning" group members in connection with the upcoming hearings, and said she had been told that they would not be welcome at a meeting Tuesday morning in Brooklyn led by Ms. Johnson.
Ms. Johnson's only comment was that she thought Ms. Held's goals were unrealistic. "All helicopter flights in New York City are not going to be banned," she said. "We need to have a meaningful dialogue with the city to construct the proper master plan." BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE;
Pennies Under the Bridge: 60-Year-Old Battle Winds Down

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF

 BODY:
A 60-year-old battle is coming to an end. The $1.75 one-way toll on the Cross Bay Veterans Memorial Bridge, the only intraborough toll bridge in the city, is to be repealed in the next few weeks, the Mayor and the Governor's office said.
"It's going out, I guarantee it," Mayor Giuliani said last Tuesday in an interview on a campaign stop outside Continental Post No. 1424 of the American Legion Hall in Forest Hills. "It has been unfair that Queens residents should pay to get to Queens." 
 For more than a generation, residents of Broad Channel have waged a war of pennies, car blockades and civil disobedience to rid the half-mile bridge that links them to the Rockaway Peninsula of what they call "an abomination and an unfair tax." The small island community in Jamaica Bay shares a zip code and a high school with the peninsula, and many residents work there.
"We were a thorn," said Dan Tubridy, a big, cigar-smoking restaurateur who said he had been unfairly arrested six years ago for menacing, reckless endangerment and possession of a weapon (his car) in an altercation with a toll collector.
During his 1993 campaign, Mr. Giuliani, who is now campaigning for re-election, promised the people of Broad Channel that he would do what he could to revoke the toll. Some residents estimate that they spend $1,200 a year on the bridge.
Ending the toll would be the third break given to New York commuters this year. The Mayor has been assiduously courting the boroughs outside Manhattan, home to his base of Republicans and conservative Democrats. If he can deliver on his toll promise, it will be one of great significance to this economically depressed neighborhood, which overwhelmingly supported him in the last election.
The Mayor also suspended the toll on the Staten Island Ferry. And both he and Gov. George E. Pataki are trumpeting their roles in the elimination of the two-fare zone for bus and subway riders.
"It is a terrific thing," Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said of the impending repeal of the bridge toll. "It's a relief for working people of New York, and the same kind of relief will come to Long Islanders."
The Governor, who has 5 of the 14 votes on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, which oversees the bridge, has lent his support to the Mayor's plan.
At the same time, the Mayor, who has four M.T.A. appointees, will support a one-fare zone for Nassau County commuters who transfer to city buses and subways, the Senator said. Mr. Giuliani's office did not return calls concerning the Nassau plan.
Mr. Pataki's spokesman, Michael McKeon, said: "The Governor has asked the M.T.A. to look at eliminating the toll on the Cross Bay Bridge, and we think it makes financial sense to do it."
The M.T.A. board is expected to vote on the matter on Sept. 30. "We have been investigating this possibility at the Governor's request and that of Queens Borough President Claire Shulman," Tom Kelly, an M.T.A. spokesman, said.
More than $6 million was collected on the bridge last year.
"It's politics," Audrey K. Pheffer, the local Democratic Assemblywoman, said of the repeal. "But it's exciting. We've been waiting a long time to not have to pay to get to our own homes." CHARLIE LeDUFF

SECTION: Section 1; Page 47; Column 5; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1598 words

HEADLINE: STYLE NOIR

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
TROUBLE is big business this fall. If urban crime is down, urbane fear is on a roll -- in fashion, movies, books and home design. Hollywood and Seventh Avenue have introduced a sinister new lining to the American dream, and they are escorting it to the bank like a dry-eyed widow with a fat will in her purse.
The products have the hard-edge look that lurks better than ever: noir, pure and blood simple, with its cinematic sense of style, a world of black and white, light and shadow, where only crime is colorful and kisses kill. For people who think it's a hard reboil of the 1950's, noir and its unseen terrors have never been more timely. 
 "People are afraid of random chaos," said James Ellroy, the author of "My Dark Places," a memoir of his mother's murder in 1958. "Car-jackings, serial killers, the proliferation of guns -- they're afraid of all the stuff they see on the evening news."
He added: "People like darkness, and they like touching it. Noir is a way of experiencing it and gaining thrill from it and remaining safe from it at the same time."
The first of a wave of noir-influenced movies, "L.A. Confidential," based on an Ellroy novel and set in 1950's Los Angeles, is to open on Friday with an all-star cast of corrupt cops and Kim Basinger as a Veronica Lake look-alike. Hard on its heels in October is Oliver Stone's "U-Turn," starring Sean Penn as a con man trapped in a small desert town.
Noir's cool voiceover is narrating new tough talk for fashion, too, after the failure of the waif look. Innocence was just too hard to pull off in the 1990's. Tom Ford's fall collection for Gucci features a 40's monkey-fur jacket the color of a Malibu-motel crime-scene swimming pool, a black leather suit in which to answer the postman's second ring and five-inch Saturday night special metal stilettos that look more like handguns than shoes. Fendi and Ralph Lauren are also doing silver metal heels.
Voyeurism, noir's signature viewpoint, informs the ads. Gucci's images have been shot from video monitors to give them the distrusting look of surveillance. Cerruti's new ads are grainy caught-in-car-headlights photos of a couple on the run -- from what and from whom?
"What looks good to our eye right now is harder and more violent," Mr. Ford said. "Our lives are more violent. The last thing you want to look like is vulnerable. Grace Kelly's 50's wouldn't work today."
Home design has made the ransom-note pickup with "Dial M for Murder" black Bakelite-style telephones in the Pottery Barn catalogue and black metal oscillating fans to blow your nails dry before you dial.
Music is also in a dark mood. The pop stylist Carly Simon plays femme fatale on "Film Noir," an album to be released on Tuesday. It includes songs from films like Otto Preminger's "Laura" and sensual standards like "Don't Smoke in Bed." A documentary on making the album, "Songs in Shadow," is to benefit American Movie Classics for the preservation of noir films.
All this is just in time for noir's literary canonization. Eleven classic American noir novels from the 40's and 50's, including Jim Thompson's "The Killer Inside Me" and Cornell Woolrich's "I Married a Dead Man," will stand beside Poe and Faulkner in October in the Library of America series.
Why noir now? Like the boom of the post-World War II 1940's and 50's, the future seems bright. The economy is good, the land is happy.
But seeing is not believing. Nothing understood this better than the style of noir.
"Optimism can be both created and exploited," said Curtis Hanson, who directed "L.A. Confidential," which is set in what Mr. Hanson called "the forward-looking 50's" of his childhood in Los Angeles. Mr. Hanson used songs like Johnny Mercer's "Ac-Cent-Tchu-Ate the Positive" and vocalists like Dean Martin and Chet Baker -- popular today as lounge-culture music -- to convey a postwar America trying to laugh at the threat of nuclear holocaust.
"It's all about looking on the bright side," Mr. Hanson said. "When you can't ignore the negative, you repress it. What speaks to our country more today than repression?"
As the production designer for "L.A. Confidential," Jeannine Oppewall dealt with the deceptively sunny surface of Los Angeles directly. "There's no sun without night," she said. Ms. Oppewall recalls her first few months in Hollywood in the 1970's, when the police knocked on her door one morning.
"Madam, haven't you noticed the dead body in the car parked at the end of your driveway?" they asked.
"Somebody had been murdered and abandoned in a car in front of my house," she said.
" 'L.A. Confidential' was a story that on the surface looked pretty nice and normal but, once you got into the bowels of it, was kind of decadent and decaying," she said.
N OIR'S dark observations of an unseen world larger than the moral universe look uncannily prescient. Only the most gifted cynics, like the creators of the original noir story style, could have written today's headlines of child beauty queen stranglings and spree killers. Street crime may be down statistically in major cities, but the perception of crime -- and of its perversity -- is heightened. Skepticism about the police and the Government breed anxiety despite what should be reassuring official statistics.
"Certainly, we live in an age of cynicism in which people are deeply suspicious about what the Government tells them," said Andrew Karmen, a professor of criminology at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York.
The absence of belief in leadership, he suggests, has created its own kind of modern anxieties. As the future brightens statistically in the news, the shadows deepen in the public consciousness.
"There's a fear that the whole thing -- the good news of the stock market, the low crime rate -- is a bubble," said Charles Bahn, a psychologist at John Jay.
The alternative is to take comfort in imagining the worst.
"Noir confirms our anxieties that the inverse may be brewing beneath the surface," Dr. Bahn said, citing corporate downsizing as an example of cultural paranoia. It is also the topic of "The Axe," a 90's noir novel by Donald Westlake. The killer is middle management.
"The economy is good in The Wall Street Journal," Dr. Bahn said. "How do you square that with being told your job no longer exists? We've added darker motives to daily life. Violence and betrayal in conventional, ordinary relationships -- that's what noir has to offer, the hidden motives of people we deal with on a day-to-day basis."
Noir's stylish cynicism has never looked better as a sales tool.
"What you're looking for," reads the copy at the bottom of a Camel cigarette ad, which features a dark-lidded, 1990's femme fatale behind a martini glass in a shadowy lounge. The copy at the top of the picture is the Surgeon General's warning, in letters as large as the sales pitch. What you may be looking for is a good excuse to smoke. And noir has it -- a kind of armed and glamorous, name-your-poison approach.
"Camel is embracing night life and sophistication and an urban feeling," said Richard Williams, a spokesman for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. "We think urban night life and sophistication are more of an attitude than a geographic location."
It is. It is noir's classic landscape -- the city of night. Where the enemy within lives, not the girl next door.
I THINK AIDS has changed our perceptions of beauty," Mr. Ford of Gucci said. "In the late 70's, who were the most beautiful girls? Patty Hanson, Cheryl Tiegs. They looked like they wanted to be kissed. They were touchable."
But the casual act has become frightening; fashion is dressing the fear. "Now, people still want to look sexy, but there's a danger to it," he said. "The look is, 'Yes, kiss me, but I might kill you, too.' "
If modern life appears to imitate noir's art, the low life of noir has established itself as a respectable genre of 20th-century American art. The lonely, moral vacancy in paintings by Edward Hopper, the absolved grotesques of Diane Arbus's photographs, the lurid triumph of television as a cultural denominator, all touch a noir nerve.
"It's become clear that the noir tradition, whether in novels or movies, really is the dominant style of the American 20th century," said Geoffrey O'Brien, executive editor of the Library of America. "It pulls together all the big themes of the power of money and corruption and sexual obsession -- and a kind of craziness. It has seeped so much into the culture that it's like a vocabulary for people to use."
As pulp literature for the computer age, the next great body of noir is being written on the Internet -- by amateurs. Faceless, amoral, unknowable, the Internet is basically a noir experience, a descending trip to an underworld of tipoffs and titillations, a blind date with paranoia, a mirror world like the final scene in "The Lady From Shanghai," Orson Welles's noir classic: in a mirrored funhouse, what the killer finally stalks is himself.
"Noir isn't crime so much as it's existential dilemma," said Luc Sante, author of "Evidence," a book of archival police photographs published in 1992. "It's about isolation and wide-ranging but unspecific fear -- a kind of fear of being."
Mr. Sante, at one time a fixture on the New York downtown club circuit, now spends half his year upstate.
"One of the reasons I'm not in the city is that the mood is cutthroat," Mr. Sante said. "There's not a lot of peace and love in the air. Crime may be down, but the mood of benevolent fellow feeling is down even further."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
A New Labyrinth For Phone Customers

BYLINE: By LAURA KOSS-FEDER 

 BODY:
YOU may think you're seeing things when your phone bill shows that calls to a friend in a neighboring town are more expensive than calls to your sister on the other coast.
Your eyesight isn't failing, but don't despair: There are ways to save money on your regional phone bills. 
 For a dozen years, regional phone service was a monopoly of the regional Bell companies created by the breakup of the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984. But with the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which was intended to open local and regional service to long-distance companies, a sometimes-bewildering choice of providers and plans is being offered for regional calling.
Long-distance carriers like AT&T, MCI and Sprint have started providing regional service, and the regional Bell companies have responded to the competition with rate cuts.
Consumers will find that it pays to shop around in today's $6 billion residential regional market. While consumers vary greatly in their calling patterns, it is not impossible that a household with moderate phone usage will be able to save 10 to 40 percent on its regional phone bill.
"One of the goals of the Telecommunications Act is to provide competition for local and regional phone service," said Tracy Waldon, an economist with the Federal Communications Commission. "Consumers will ultimately be able to see a drop in these rates, just like they did with long-distance rates." In fact, since the AT&T breakup, which paved the way for competition in the long-distance market, phone rates have come down by 50 percent, Mr. Waldon said.
Regional calls are those placed within one of the country's 199 Local Access and Transport Areas. A LATA can be statewide in a small state; there are multiple LATA's in larger states. (California has 11.) A regional call may be from New York City to White Plains in Westchester County, or from Miami to Boca Raton, Fla. And LATA's are not necessarily based on area code boundaries.
WHEN you set up your phone service, your local carrier is required to ask you to select a long-distance carrier, thus flagging the consumer to the possibility of a choice. But depending on the state, such a warning need not be made regarding regional calling. As a result, many people are not aware that there is now a choice.
"You should check out all the various regional rate plans being offered, especially if you make a high volume of calls," said Eric Strumingher, first vice president and telecommunications analyst with Paine Webber in New York.
MCI announced a plan in June that offers 24-hour flat-rate regional calling with savings of 15 percent to 59 percent over existing regional tolls, depending on location, said a spokesman, Brad Burns. The plan is being offered in all states but Alaska.
In California, MCI's new regional calling rate is 4 cents a minute, which MCI says is 42 percent lower than Pacific Bell's average basic rate. A five-minute evening call with Pacific Bell from San Jose to San Francisco is 52 cents; the same call for MCI customers is 20 cents, MCI said.
The search for cheaper service isn't always easy. The regional plans often vary widely, with a low teaser rate offered for weekend night or late-night calls only. Or there may be fine print noting that a low rate is available only for those who pay a monthly access charge or whose regional bills reach a certain number of calls or minutes.
Such apples-and-oranges pricing is pointed up by Pacific Bell's response to MCI's assertions about its California rates.
"MCI's rates may be a little lower than ours, but these claims are way out of proportion," said a Pacific Bell spokesman, John Britton. "They're comparing their lowest possible rates to Pac Bell's highest rate."
One trouble with the new competitors is that customers often need to dial a cumbersome five-digit code to use a provider other than a local Bell company for regional phone service. This practice varies state to state.
The easier way, of course, is to have customers choose a regional carrier and then allow them to use the current simple dialing method: a "1" followed by an area code and a telephone number, known as "one-plus dialing." Currently, 16 states have one-plus dialing; the other 34 require the use of access codes in some areas.
Each state's public service commission decides when to roll out one-plus dialing. It was mandated by the Telecommunications Act of 1996, however, that when Bell companies enter the long-distance market, they must also provide one-plus dialing for all other carriers that offer regional calling to their customers. Currently, Bell companies are not in the long-distance market.
Another big long-distance company, Sprint, started offering lower regional rates in 1996 in states that have one-plus dialing. These rates vary from 5 cents to 30 cents a minute, depending on location and time of day, said Joseph Mandacini, senior marketing manager.
Again, Sprint and Bell Atlantic make claims and counterclaims on regional services.
In New York State, Mr. Mandacini said, customers who use Sprint's intra-LATA service can save 29 percent over Bell Atlantic's rates, with further reductions expected.
In response, a Bell Atlantic spokeswoman, Joan Rasmussen, said: "They're comparing apples to oranges. Companies can make all kinds of claims, but consumers should check for themselves."
AT&T's One-Rate plan offers set prices per minute for regional and long-distance calls, saving consumers 10 to 40 percent on these calls over their regional Bell rates, said Jack McMaster, vice president for growth markets, consumer markets division. AT&T's regional service is offered in 14 states and in parts of 22 others.
As in long-distance calling, some of the companies are household names, while others are smaller and may offer cheaper services. LCI International, a provider of long-distance service and voice and data transmission services based in McLean, Va., announced plans in July to offer regional one-plus calling in select regions in 23 states, said Roy Gamse, senior vice president for business marketing. The service, he added, could save customers up to 30 percent on these calls. In areas without one-plus dialing, customers must dial a separate five-digit code.
In New York, a highly competitive market, Bell Atlantic offers a variety of plans to customers, depending on their past calling patterns. One Bell Atlantic customer in New York City who makes few calls has an "unlimited regional calling plan" that includes unlimited calls to Westchester and Long Island for a flat monthly charge of $6, coupled with unlimited local calls at $1.63 a month. At another extreme, a Westchester resident without an unlimited plan might pay Bell Atlantic's "basic local services" charge of about $10 monthly, plus $30 for about six hours of calls within the region in a month.
Local phone companies around the country have been gradually lowering their regional rates and these are worth a closer look, Mr. Strumingher noted. While long-distance providers, in some cases, can still offer more competitive regional rates than the local carriers, the gap is narrowing.
But again, the choices can be bewildering: in one Pacific Bell plan, customers receive a 30 percent discount on all calls up to $45 a month, and a 40 percent reduction if calls total more than $45 -- at a charge of $4.50 a month.
 
Searching Out Your Best Deal
So you think you may want to change your regional phone carrier but are totally confused about which carrier to choose?
You are probably not alone. Just remember the days when long-distance service was first deregulated, and you were bombarded with offers from a host of new competitors. Many people didn't know where to turn then, either.
Following are some tips to help you decide which company should provide your regional calling:
* Understand and analyze your regional calling patterns. Do you make most of your calls on weekends and evenings. Are you mostly calling just one or two phone numbers? Are your phone calls lengthy? The answers can help you select a plan that will save money each month.
* Shop around. Ask carriers about their different plans and select the one that best suits your regional calling habits.
For instance, under certain circumstances, Bell Atlantic offers a flat rate as low as $6.28 a month, or 2.1 cents a minute, if you're a New York City resident who makes five hours of regional calls a month. That is only a weekend evening rate, however. An MCI plan, on the other hand, would cost $30 a month, or 10 cents a minute, for the same amount of calls. The advantage is that MCI's offer is a 24-hour flat-rate plan. Smaller carriers are in the market, too.
* Check the fine print. You'll see ads for regional carriers or dial-around services (dialing 1 plus a five-digit code). But some carriers give a low, flat-minute rate in their ads and fail to note that you must pay an access charge or make a minimum number of calls or minimum length of call to get a certain rate.
* Bargain for better deals. When telemarketers call you, ask them if they can do better than the offers that have been quoted.
