HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE CANDIDATE;
For the Ultimate Outsider, the Moment Is Now

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER with LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
He is a minister without a congregation, a politician without a media consultant. He wants to raise New York City's commuter tax, but he owes tens of thousands of dollars in state and Federal taxes. He has long been an anti-establishment street demonstrator, yet he craves political legitimacy.
A man of relentless contradictions, the Rev. Al Sharpton has demonstrated many times over the years that there are only a few constants in his life: his family, his religion, his commitment to civil rights and his desire for attention. Last week, as perhaps never before in his turbulent public career, Mr. Sharpton reached center stage. 
 In capturing 32 percent of the vote in Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary and helping to force a runoff against the front-runner, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, Mr. Sharpton served notice that he is a force to be reckoned with in New York politics.
But serious doubt remains about whether he can broaden his base, evolving from a protest candidate to a mainstream politician who can win the runoff and go on to defeat the popular incumbent, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
For now, Mr. Sharpton is reveling in the spotlight, pivoting from housing projects to television studios, switching easily from I-told-them-so triumph to introspection. A short man with a tall man's gait, he took a half-mile victory walk on Wednesday through Bedford-Stuyvesant, where people flocked from their homes to greet him.
It is no accident, he would be the first to agree, that the campaign song he listens to in his purple campaign van is "I Believe I Can Fly," by the hip-hop artist R. Kelly.
"We really did something that they didn't expect," he said during a post-primary interview. "No matter what happens from here out, we have clearly established a permanent presence in the politics of this city. Anyone running for office will have to deal with the strength that I've demonstrated."
Mr. Sharpton has spent much of his 42 years defying expectations -- and, sometimes, common sense. He began preaching in Baptist churches when he was 4. When still in his 20's, he was creating civil-rights organizations while dabbling in the record business. He has repeatedly led marches protesting racial injustices, in one instance helping to force Mario M. Cuomo, then Governor, to appoint a special prosecutor to handle the case of a young black man who was killed in Howard Beach, Queens.
But Mr. Sharpton has also associated with figures in organized crime -- he denied knowing they were mobsters -- and with organizations that have been accused of operating like cults, including the New Alliance Party and the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church.
He has been a secret government informer, according to Federal authorities, and he has been indicted for fraud and tax offenses, but was acquitted of the charges. He once pleaded guilty to failing to file income taxes and paid a fine, and he is negotiating with state and Federal tax officials over tens of thousands of dollars in back taxes.
He has grabbed headlines and television coverage with provocative oratory, hard-edged street theater and charges that many find indefensible. Mr. Sharpton insists he has matured and, even if he has made some mistakes, critics should look at him in a broader light. "I come with a level of controversy," he said. "Some would say, baggage. I say all politicians have baggage. It's just that some politicians get skycaps to carry their baggage. I have to carry my own."
He contends that detractors who become fixated on a remark that he might have made years ago are ignoring, perhaps willfully, the many ways in which he has changed. "I think some people get locked into a time period of your career because they want to," he said.
 
Seeking Mainstream And Facing Skeptics
Over the last few years, Mr. Sharpton has tried to move, in fits and starts, from agitator to statesman. He ran twice in Democratic primaries for the United States Senate, in 1992 and 1994, and he won points for his restraint and sense of humor.
He has been dogged, though, by some enduring questions: Can he remain a defiant voice of the poor and disenfranchised while also moving toward the political mainstream? Is his support limited, enabling him in the end only to make a strong but symbolic showing in Democratic primaries? Or can he fashion a broader coalition that could actually make him a Democratic nominee?
Mr. Sharpton said last week's primary showed once and for all that he was a serious political candidate.
But many elected officials and political consultants remain skeptical. They say he still has not shown that he can win broad support from Hispanic New Yorkers and make significant inroads among white voters who have long regarded him with deep suspicion.
Two days ago, the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said he would not support Mr. Sharpton, citing his "willingness to tolerate the bigotry" of Louis Farrakhan and Leonard Jeffries, a City College professor who made racist and anti-Semitic remarks.
Another senior Democratic elected official called Mr. Sharpton "a protest candidate" with a limited constituency. "I don't know if there's anything he can do to broaden his support," the official said. "He's pretty well defined with respect to the New York voter. They know who he is. Those who like who he is vote for him no matter what. Those who don't will never vote for him. He can't be anything else. He is what he is."
The official spoke on the condition of anonymity, saying -- as did many Democrats interviewed for this article -- that he did not want to risk antagonizing Mr. Sharpton or his supporters.
The runoff on Sept. 23 presents Mr. Sharpton with his best opportunity yet to show whether he can expand his political base, many politicians say. It will not be easy, as the primary results on Tuesday demonstrated. He attracted about the same number of city votes that he did in two previous primaries, and benefited mightily from Ms. Messinger's poor showing.
He nonetheless pulled off the unexpected -- which is hardly out of character for Mr. Sharpton. Few people have had a higher profile in New York's public life over the last 15 years. Virtually every New Yorker knows who he is, and few people are noncommital. He is, in many ways, a prism through which vast segments of New York's diverse racial and economic mix view themselves and their city.
To supporters, he is a committed civil-rights activist, following proudly in the tradition of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. He has led dozens of protest marches, demonstrating against everything from minor cases of police misconduct to the racial killings of young black men in Howard Beach, Queens, and Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.
He was stabbed in the chest by a drunken white man during a march in Bensonhurst in 1991. He led several hundred people who sat down on subway tracks in downtown Brooklyn in 1987, blocking rush-hour trains on eight lines during a protest over the death of Michael Griffith, who was struck by a car after being chased by a gang of whites onto a highway in Howard Beach.
But to detractors, Mr. Sharpton is an irresponsible opportunist, who has repeatedly fanned the flames of racial discord by inserting himself into charged situations. Critics point to his role in the case of Tawana Brawley, a black high school student from Wappingers Falls, N.Y., who contended in 1987 that she had been abducted and raped over four days by six racist white men.
After a prolonged inquiry, during which Mr. Sharpton and other family advisers successfully urged the young girl and her mother not to cooperate with investigators, a grand jury concluded that the entire affair had been a hoax -- concocted by Ms. Brawley, apparently to avoid a beating from her stepfather for having been away from home for four days. Mr. Sharpton still contends that she was assaulted.
 
Clashing Images And a Quieter Candidate
Critics point to a number of other incidents that, in their view, show that Mr. Sharpton continues to work outside acceptable public discourse.
Just two years ago, for example, during a rally protesting expansion plans by a clothing store on 125th Street, Mr. Sharpton described the owner of the store as a "white interloper" and insisted that "we are not turning 125th Street back over to outsiders." Three months later, eight people died in a fire at the store set by a gunman, after an intense, racially charged campaign to prevent the store's expansion.
Proponents see in Mr. Sharpton a man unafraid to speak his mind, to represent the interests of the poor and powerless more aggressively than more established political and church officials. But detractors view him as a racial incendiary, someone willing to say and do outrageous things, if only they will keep him in front of the television cameras.
For much of this decade, Mr. Sharpton has certainly tried to moderate his image. He has lost weight, trimmed his hair and no longer wears jogging suits with a large medallion with a likeness of Dr. King around his neck. Since he first began running for elective office, in the 1992 Democratic Senate primary, he has generally appeared in public in dark suits and ties.
His conduct and language as a candidate have been, relatively speaking, subdued -- though still lively. He insists that he has changed, in part because of some soul-searching after he was stabbed six years ago. He also credits his family. He and his wife, Kathy Jordan-Sharpton -- a gospel singer and former back-up singer for James Brown -- have been married for 16 years. They have two daughters -- Dominique, 11, and Ashley, 10 -- who attend a private school in Brooklyn. After living in Brooklyn and then moving to suburban New Jersey, the family returned recently to Flatbush.
"I think that I have matured, and I think that I've tried to grow," he said. "I don't think that I've changed in terms of basics. I think I've changed in terms of style and in terms of what I'm trying to project. In the 80's, I was far more concerned about getting my issues straight in the newspapers. In the 90's, I'm far more concerned about getting our message straight in history."
Mr. Sharpton and his allies believe he has already begun to expand his political base. He contended that middle-class black voters had supported him on Tuesday, and that they had not always done so. He also said he had earned some support from Hispanic New Yorkers and liberal whites. "I could not have won Brooklyn by 11 points with just black votes," Mr. Sharpton said.
Gregory W. Meeks, a Democratic State Assemblyman from Queens, said that by emphasizing issues like police misconduct and unemployment, Mr. Sharpton could cross the city's racial and economic lines. "When you talk about economic development throughout the city -- that will reverberate to help expand his base," he said.
And the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has long been a friend and adviser to Mr. Sharpton and who campaigned with him yesterday in Harlem, said he had been expanding his vote total by registering new voters. "People who would not have voted at all have found in him some hope," Mr. Jackson said.
But many politicians are skeptical that Mr. Sharpton can attract large numbers of new supporters. They say that his total on Tuesday -- 126,782 votes -- is not significantly different from his totals in the city when he ran in the 1992 and 1994 Democratic Senate primaries.
Mr. Sharpton is evidently aware that some of his more provocative remarks have hurt his chances of appealing to more white voters. On Tuesday night, he acknowledged vaguely that he had made some mistakes. Asked about that remark later, he cited his reference to the Harlem store owner two years ago as a "white interloper." He apologized, saying he had been wrong to have referred to the man's race, but defending his characterization of him as an outsider.
There was also publicity recently about a libel suit against Mr. Sharpton, connected to the Brawley case. In that case, scheduled to go on trial in November, a former Dutchess County assistant district attorney has sued Mr. Sharpton for slander, for having accused him in 1988 of participating in Ms. Brawley's abduction and rape. The former prosecutor, Stephen A. Pagones, was cleared by the grand jury.
Incidents like these may limit Mr. Sharpton's chance of winning broader acceptance. "To be able to do that, he has to be able to communicate with people who are very skeptical, who think he is very radical," said Mel Miller, the former State Assembly Speaker from Brooklyn who is now a lobbyist. "There's a lot of baggage here."
Ms. Messinger could readily defeat Mr. Sharpton in the runoff next week if a significant portion of Democrats who voted for the primary's third-place finisher, City Councilman Sal Albanese of Brooklyn, were to switch to Ms. Messinger.
But it is also possible, some political analysts theorize, that Mr. Sharpton could pull off an upset victory without finding new sources of support. If the turnout among his core supporters increases somewhat, and Ms. Messinger continues to have difficulty energizing her natural supporters, the contest could be tight.
Mr. Sharpton, ever upbeat, said that even if he remained locked into his total from the primary -- almost 127,000 votes -- he still would have a reasonable chance in the runoff. "If only 200,000 come out in a runoff, the other side has a problem," he said.
"I think that they're going to be surprised, again."

RUTH W. MESSINGER
 
At a backyard fund-raising event on Staten Island:
"So let me just tell you, I need your help as voters and civic leaders, not only to vote yourselves on Sept. 23d and Nov. 4th -- I hope I have convinced you to do that -- but to tell lots of other people to vote, to talk to a member of my staff, to put up a flier in your place of business, and remind people when the elections are. HEADLINE: Judge Has His Own Take On Sentencing Formulas

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
It was one day last spring that Solomon Halberstam, the Grand Rabbi of the Bobov Hasidim, made an emotional appeal to a Federal judge in Manhattan on behalf of an Orthodox Jew about to be sentenced in an insurance fraud case.
Rabbi Halberstam asked Judge Lewis A. Kaplan not to impose a severe penalty on Solomon Sprei because fathers in the Bobov community, like Mr. Sprei, were responsible for finding their children's marriage partners. If Mr. Sprei was imprisoned for too long, "his children of marriageable age will not be able to find spouses for themselves," Rabbi Halberstam said. "They will be as 'living orphans.' Heaven forbid." 
 Under the rigid rules that dictate sentencing in the Federal district courts, Mr. Sprei was supposed to receive three to four years in prison. But Judge Kaplan said he was persuaded, by the rabbi's letter, that "a lengthy term of imprisonment would have dramatic adverse consequences for at least two and probably three of the children." Also citing Mr. Sprei's generous deeds in the community, he sentenced him to only 18 months and ordered him to pay $1.8 million in restitution.
The case, which was appealed by the Government and is pending before the Federal appeals court in Manhattan, has spawned an intense legal and philosophical debate that pits an 89-year-old rabbi and his community's ancient customs against the court's own arcane practice of slotting defendants into formulas and charts to determine appropriate punishments.
The rules, from which a judge can deviate only in extreme cases, were devised in the 1980's to make Federal sentencing more consistent and to take into account a defendant's record and the seriousness of a crime. In this case, the Government contends that the disruption of family life is inherent in the punishment of criminal behavior. It argues in its appeal that Judge Kaplan improperly cited religious factors that could open the door to "whole classes of people" making similar demands -- a view echoed by legal experts.
"I am very surprised that a judge really bought the argument, because once you begin taking these things into consideration then everybody can come in," said J. David Bleich, professor of law and ethics at Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University in New York.
But other experts said the case symbolized the struggle of judges who believe they have been stripped of their discretion by the sentencing formulas.
"I'd have a lot of sympathy for a conscientious Federal judge who did not consider himself bound by them and wanted to substitute his or her own reasoned judgment about what punishment fits what crime," said Michael J. Sandel, a government professor at Harvard University who teaches the popular course called Justice.
Indeed, Judge Kaplan deviated from the sentencing guidelines in one previous case and has said that he would in another. In both cases, he wanted more severe penalties because he felt the formulas did not reflect the seriousness of the crimes.
Court records describe Mr. Sprei, 42, as an unemployed father of six, who was educated at Yeshivas and had no higher education. His family resides in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn with the other Bobov Hasidim, who trace their roots back to the Polish town of Bobov.
In January 1996, prosecutors charged him with 21 counts in a fraud scheme that resulted in losses to insurance companies of about $17 million. Last October, he agreed to plead guilty to two counts, and his defense lawyer and the prosecutor agreed to seek a sentence, as computed under the guidelines, of roughly three to four years.
But on March 13, one day before the sentencing, a lawyer, Andrew J. Levander, claiming to represent Rabbi Halberstam "and the worldwide Bobov Community that Rabbi Halberstam leads," sent the judge Rabbi Halberstam's letter and letters from 36 other family members and friends in the Bobov sect.
They pleaded with the judge to allow Mr. Sprei to avoid a prison sentence, citing his charity to others, his ailing father, and the impact on his children.
"You probably are not familiar with the marriage practices in our community," Mr. Sprei's wife, Sara, wrote.
She described their 18-year-old son's predicament: he was ready for marriage but was suffering from the stigma of his father's arrest. If the judge incarcerated Mr. Sprei, she said, "it will destroy my son's chances for a decent match."
In court the next day, a Government prosecutor, George S. Canellos, said Mr. Sprei's sentence "should reflect the absolute massiveness" of the fraud, according to a court transcript.
But Judge Kaplan said he was concerned that the Government commission that wrote the sentencing rules had not foreseen such a case. "I am persuaded," he said, "that to incarcerate Mr. Sprei for a lengthy period would wreak extraordinary destruction of a kind that never dawned on the Sentencing Commission on a number of these children."
The judge also cited Mr. Sprei's selfless contributions to his community, as laid out in the letters that he said he had read and found "quite moving."
Mr. Sprei apologized for his crime and asked the judge "to find in your heart some way to allow me to stay with my family."
Judge Kaplan said the fraud was too great to allow Mr. Sprei to walk out of court a free man, but he said, "the period of incarceration ought to be related to the ages of the children, whose interests play such an important role in my thinking."
In deciding on a sentence of 18 months, he said he realized that the 18-year-old son would still be adversely affected but perhaps his other children would benefit.
"I selected 18 months with a view to the fact that the next oldest child is 16," the judge explained, "and it is my hope to avoid a serious adverse impact with the respect to the next child."
Mr. Sprei, who is currently serving his prison sentence, could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: Bosnians Vote, But Animosity Is Unrelenting

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Escorted by NATO troops in armored vehicles, buses lurched and rolled out of Sarajevo early this morning. They were taking Bosnian Muslims for a few emotional moments to villages in which they had lived before the war, where they cast ballots and were then hustled hastily away.
In municipal elections today seen as a vital part of the Dayton peace accord, people across Bosnia voted in their prewar towns, many returning for the first time to places they had been expelled from in the bitter conflict among Muslims, Serbs and Croats. 
 In towns like Srebrenica, where several thousand Muslim men were massacred in the summer of 1995 by Bosnian Serb troops, Muslim officials will probably be elected to office, although no Muslims currently live in the area.
And in Drvar, Glamoc and Bosansko Grahovo, near Bosnia's western border with Croatia, representatives of the prewar Serbian majority were also set to be elected to power, although most of the Serbs have been expelled.
Communities that do not accept the election results, which are not expected before Sept. 20, will have sanctions imposed on them, international officials say. But the elections, which were postponed twice, appeared unlikely to alter Bosnia's partition into three antagonistic enclaves or release the grip on power by nationalist hard-liners.
Critics of the vote said sanctions would probably not be enough to force nationalist leaders to abide by the results, especially since many have amassed great wealth in their positions.
The Dayton peace agreement, those critics said, rather than fostering a process to move Bosnia toward democratic rule and a multi-ethnic society, has resulted in a series of NATO-managed events that have so far failed to alter the dismal political landscape.
"What we will most likely end up with are a number of governments-in-exile," said a Western diplomat. "These elected officials will not even be able to visit the towns they are supposed to administer. Power will remain in the hands of those who have always had little regard for the peace agreement or the democratic process."
The 34,000-member NATO-led peacekeeping force sent out heavily armed patrols today, stationed troops in armored personnel carriers at polling places and crossroads and had helicopters buzzing over much of the country. Buses crossing the partition lines between the Bosnian Serb republic and the Muslim-Croat Federation were stopped by NATO troops and passengers were taken off the vehicles and searched for weapons.
Ibro Obhodzas, 56, stood in line at a polling place outside of Pale, the Bosnian Serb stronghold, that had been set up for former Muslim residents. It was the first time since 1992, when he was evicted from his house, that he had been back. Mr. Obhodzas, a former factory worker who spent the war with his wife and two daughters in Germany, returned to Bosnia a few months ago; his family remains in Germany and sends him the money to survive in Sarajevo.
"I feel more like a refugee in my own country than I do in Germany," he said. "The people who have power do not care how we vote. We cannot build the old Bosnia, the Bosnia where people tried to live together, until these nationalist leaders are gone. And that may take years. I just wanted to stand for a few minutes on the soil where I was born."
The deep divide among the three ethnic communities was in evidence today as they wrangled over the voting.
The Bosnian Croats refused, for example, to permit polls to open in the center of Zepce and Tesanj, which once had Muslim majorities. In Sarajevo, where the majority Muslim population hopes to see a common administration for Bosnia, a powerful bomb Friday night blew the front off the Croatian party headquarters. And in Mostar, Muslims at first boycotted the vote after international officials agreed with the Croats not to hold voting in the important central district of the divided city. A Muslim official was reported to have said later that they had worked out an arrangement with the Croats and would take part.
The Bosnian Serbs and the Bosnian Croats, who are supposed to be part of a Muslim-Croat Federation, threatened until late Friday night to boycott the elections.
As in the national elections a year ago, voting today and Sunday was expected to go along ethnic lines.
The Muslim-led Party for Democratic Action, the Croatian Democratic Union and the Serbian Democratic Party have dominated political life in Bosnia since the war started five years ago. All base their appeal on ethnic loyalty rather than any defined political platforms.
Serbs interviewed today reiterated their vows that Muslims would never return home, even if they were elected to run town halls in the Serbian enclave.
Many voiced bitterness at the entrance by the NATO-led peacekeeping force into the power struggle between Biljana Plavsic, President of the Bosnian Serb republic, and Radovan Karadzic, her predecessor, who has been charged with war crimes. Ms. Plavsic, backed by NATO troops, has taken control of the city of Banja Luka and accused Dr. Karadzic and his supporters in Pale of widespread corruption.
"The international community calls this a democratic election," said Vaskrsije Kusmuk, 65, as he stood with his wife, Milena, 60, in front of a Pale polling station. "If this was really a democratic election we would not have these foreign planes flying over our heads and these foreign tanks rolling through our streets."
"We had more democracy under Tito," he said, referring to the Communist former leader of Yugoslavia. "This is a farce."
The Muslims should gain the most, at least on paper, from these elections. The balloting is expected to hand the main Muslim party nominal control of many towns from which Muslims were expelled by Serbs and Croats during the war.
But even in Sarajevo, a city still scarred by war and burdened by tremendous poverty, it was hard to find much enthusiasm for the vote.
Redzep Beganovic, 21, a badly wounded Muslim war veteran, lives with other destitute men in an abandoned boxcar in back of the gutted shell that was once Sarajevo's train station. He said he was embittered over the Government's failure to assist war invalids or provide him with an apartment. "What has this country given me?" he said. "It is time for me to try and get out. There is not one name on these candidate lists that would be worth making the effort to vote for."
About 2.5 million citizens, including 400,000 outside Bosnia, registered to vote for 136 municipal councils across the country. The United Nations said about 35,000 were expected to cross the line between the Serbian and Muslim-Croatian halves of Bosnia to cast their ballots today and Sunday.
The elections have cost the international community $14 million and are part of the terms imposed by the Dayton peace agreement.

HEADLINE: Fast Track on Treaties Leaves Labor in the Dust

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Mr. Clinton Deserves 'Fast Track' " (editorial, Sept. 8) cavalierly dismisses American workers' concern with competition from foreign low-wage labor on the theoretical ground that the competitive effect of lower wages is canceled out by correspondingly lower productivity. This is typically not true for internationally traded goods. 
 Labor productivity in the auto, electronics and other Mexican maquiladora plants is close to, and sometimes above, that of American factories. Yet Mexican Government policies keep wages at a small fraction of what United States workers make. The disparity between wages and productivity causes expanded trade with the third world to erode living standards in advanced economies. That is why we need strong, enforceable labor standards at the core of any trade agreement. Yet our recent trade deals have protected the interests of international investors over those of workers.
You concede that we should protect labor and the environment but wrongly argue that Representative Bill Archer's proposed language for fast track is "a reasonable compromise." Mr. Archer has said that the proposal is aimed not at strengthening labor and environment laws but at weakening them if they inhibit trade.
Those who care about labor and environmental protections are right to oppose a renewal of fast-track authority until such protections are as guaranteed as the property rights of investors.
 
JEFF FAUX
President, Economic Policy Institute
Washington, Sept. 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Fast Track on Treaties Leaves Labor in the Dust;
Secret Talks in Paris

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The premise for giving President Clinton fast-track authority, you say, is that "countries will not negotiate trade accords with Washington for fear of endless revision" (editorial, Sept. 8). Yet for the past two years the 29 industrialized members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have been secretly negotiating the Multilateral Agreement on Investment in Paris, with the United States very much involved. 
 The treaty's provisions will override state and local land use, environmental, economic development and labor laws, giving multinationals free rein in any signatory country. It bans performance requirements like the Federal Community Reinvestment Act and domestic content standards. A foreign company that believes the treaty is violated can sue the host government in a secret tribunal from which there is no appeal. Make no mistake, this is the treaty for which President Clinton needs fast-track authority.
 
ROBERT B. DENNIS
Dallas, Sept. 10, 1997
 
The writer is president of the Dallas Peace Center.

HEADLINE: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER;
The Bargains and the Blowouts

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
Given the steep rise of the dollar in the last several months, much of Europe is now a better deal for American travelers than it has been in years. A fine bottle of French merlot, a pair of Ferragamo shoes in Milan or a night at the new Adlon Hotel in Berlin are all about 20 percent cheaper in dollar terms than they would have been a year ago.
Countries that have locked their exchange rates to the German mark -- France, Austria and the Benelux countries -- have all seen their currencies plunge by about 20 percent against the dollar. Spain and Italy have followed suit. The one major exception is the United Kingdom, where the pound and the Irish punt have kept pace with the dollar. No big bargains there. 
 Even with a stronger dollar, things are far from cheap. In many European countries, prices a year ago were 50 percent higher than those in the United States. And some curveballs have been thrown: Local prices for a one-month Eurail train pass covering all of Europe, available only to non-Europeans, have been notched up to keep its dollar price -- $838 -- just as high as it was last year.
On the other hand, with most of Continental Europe still in the economic doldrums, vendors of leisure and luxury goods have been pressed to offer better buys. Discounting now turns up in some of the most unlikely places. The luxury suite I booked at the Schlosshotel Kronberg, for example, is officially listed at $545 a night, but the price I was quoted on the phone was $375. Why? The hotel had plenty of rooms available -- and sooner or later, the law of supply and demand exerts its force. EDMUND L. ANDREWS

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: STAGE VIEW;
When These Two Chat, an Era Is Speaking

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
JULIE HARRIS WAS SPEAKING WITH THE urgency of a heroine in a Victorian melodrama who recalls being snatched, at the very last minute, from the path of a speeding train.
"Chris saved the day," she said, in that voice that always seems to glow with illuminated italics. "We would have gone down without him." 
 "Oh, please," snorted the hero in question, Christopher Plummer, in his matinee idol's baritone.
"We would have; we would have," Ms. Harris answered. "It was one of those things. We would have absolutely."
The woman who is often described as the greatest of living American stage actresses was recalling the circumstances under which, 40 years ago, during rehearsals for the play "The Lark," she met the young Canadian now widely considered the finest of this continent's classical stage actors. And although Mr. Plummer's suave, roguish persona is a far cry from Ms. Harris's habitually awe-struck air of a pilgrim in the presence of miracles, they share belief that the theater, as Ms. Harris put it, "should be life and death." And after a half century apiece of performing in it, they both still think of the theater as a home, a religion and the place where they are most comfortable.
Whether they like it or not, Ms. Harris, 71, and Mr. Plummer, 67, are among the last of a breed nearing extinction: stars whose identities have been shaped and renewed almost entirely on the stage. They carry with them a perfume of headier days, when Broadway seemed as cosmopolitan as the martini. But they have never stopped working there. And their conversation -- part banter, part love song -- swirls through the decades, equally piquant on subjects as varied as the grandeur of the Lunts, the de-glamorizing influence of Lee Strasberg and the necessary selfishness of actors.
At the time of this reunion, in a hotel suite on Central Park West with a view of Manhattan as an urban dreamscape, they had both been starring on Broadway throughout the spring and summer, Ms. Harris opposite Charles Durning in "The Gin Game" (it has now moved to Chicago), for which she received her 10th Tony nomination (she has won a record five times) for best actress; Mr. Plummer in his current one-man show "Barrymore," which won him his second Tony Award in June.
The immediate topic, however, was the play that brought Ms. Harris her second Tony, "The Lark," by Jean Anouilh. In 1955, the Broadway-bound production, starring the 29-year-old Ms. Harris as Joan of Arc, was about to open in Boston, and the crucial part of the Earl of Warwick had yet to be cast satisfactorily.
"It was like 'A Shot in the Dark,' " says Ms. Harris, detouring, by way of example, to another production she starred in, in 1961, "when Donald Cook had his heart attack and died in New Haven."
"Oh, my God, yes!" interjected Mr. Plummer.
"And Harold Clurman, who was directing, said to me, 'Well, what do you think?' And I said, 'Well, I don't know: someone like George Sanders or Brian Aherne.' And he said, 'Well, we've got Walter Matthau.' And I said: 'Walter Matthau? What a mistake! Can he be a French banker?' And he was marvelous. And he saved the day."
But back to Mr. Plummer's rescuing act. How did he save the day? ("Yes, how did I?" the actor asked avidly.) "Chris saved the day because we had had two Earls of Warwick," said Ms. Harris, referring to "The Lark's" pivotal role of the worldly, sardonic English nobleman that Mr. Plummer eventually won. Both of his predecessors, Ms. Harris recalled, were quite beautiful looking but not "very compelling."
Then, as Mr. Plummer, describing his advent, put it, "this bum came along," having been vetted by Lillian Hellman, the play's adaptor. "Lillian," said Mr. Plummer, assuming the gangsterish posture of the playwright, "who was smoking thousands of cigarettes all at once, out of the corner of her mouth said, 'He'll do fine.' "
So "The Lark" opened on Broadway, on schedule, with the Earl of Warwick properly cast, on Nov. 17, 1955. Mr. Plummer, who had previously played supporting roles with the legendary Katherine Cornell, was singled out by the critic Brooks Atkinson in The New York Times for offering further evidence of "extraordinary gifts." Ms. Harris, wrote Mr. Atkinson, had "an incandescence that illuminates the theater and touches the hearts of everybody in the audience."
The night of the opening, however, Ms. Harris had gone home to bed after the performance feeling, she said, "suicidal" about the evening. Then she got a phone call telling her the reviews were terrific, so she got out of bed, got dressed and went to the party at the Plaza Hotel.
Mr. Plummer said he had no memory of that party. ("Oh, you must have gone, Chris," said Ms. Harris.) But he vividly recalled Ms. Harris as Joan. "I thought she was the cutest thing" -- Mr. Plummer here took a beat, to underscore the punch line -- "in pants," he said. "You rehearsed, didn't you, in part of your armor?"
"Oh, did I, did I?" said Ms. Harris.
"That thing you have done ever since, actually," continued Mr. Plummer, needling gently. "Didn't you rehearse 'The Gin Game' in armor?"
Actually, both Ms. Harris and Mr. Plummer are among the few actors who still could look perfectly at ease on stage in shiny suits of mail; less so, perhaps, in T-shirts and tatters. In an era of mumbling naturalism, they continue to ply their craft with the heroic presence and ringing enunciation that they believe the theater demands. Ms. Harris has said that there should always be "glory" in the theater; Mr. Plummer, that he has spent much of his life "trying to pretend the ordinary doesn't exist."
Their careers, accordingly, embrace mythic performances: Ms. Harris (at 24) as the tortured 12-year-old tomboy Frankie Addams in Carson McCullers's "Member of the Wedding" (1950); or the feckless, divinely decadent Sally Bowles in "I Am a Camera" (1951), John Van Druten's adaptation of Christopher Isherwood's "Berlin Stories"; or a truly transcendent Emily Dickinson in her one-woman show "The Belle of Amherst" (1977).
Mr. Plummer's great conquests have been in the classics, starting with a "Henry V," at the Stratford Festival in Ontario in 1956, that Atkinson described as "magnificent" and, on Broadway in 1982, an Iago that the critic Walter Kerr called "quite possibly the best single Shakespearean performance to have originated on this continent."
Both actors grew up -- Ms. Harris in Grosse Pointe, Mich.; Mr. Plummer, in Montreal -- at a time when the theater still shimmered with glamour, and the stage star was considered more godlike than the mere movie star. Both Ms. Harris and Mr. Plummer had theater-loving parents who took their children to see touring productions. "I inherited the wish from them," Ms. Harris, paraphrasing Laurence Oliver, said of her parents. Of what she was seeing on stage, she said, "That was the world to me."
There were still vestiges of that world in the decade in which Ms. Harris and Mr. Plummer made their names, the 1950's, described by Mr. Plummer as "probably the last kind of golden moment in the American theater."
"Yes," answered Ms. Harris quickly, "because the Lunts were still there. Ruth Gordon was still there." "Louis Calhern," said Mr. Plummer, "Tallu Bankhead." And suddenly their conversation became, as it often did that morning, a volley of names recited with the affectionate certainty of a couple recalling the lyrics of their song. When they described these actors, they more often than not became them, in precise, evocative parentheses. To hear Ms. Harris become Boris Karloff, or Mr. Plummer turn into Ruth Gordon, is, believe me, something.
Here is Ms. Harris on auditioning for the regal acting couple Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne: "Miss Fontanne came down the aisle of the theater. And she said, 'NOW THIS PA-A-RT . . . ' And she was all in mink, with pale harlequin glasses, mink beret. I was like a puddle of water in front of her. And she explained the whole part to me. And finally from the back of the theater came this voice: 'LYNNIE, let her READ, for God's sake . . . ' Which was Alfred, with his vicuna coat over the shoulders.
"I mean, they were stars. You saw what that meant. Now we all shuffle along -- " Ms. Harris stopped in midsentence and hunched her shoulders, providing an instant impression of a bag lady.
Mr. Plummer was taken up early on by another fabled theater couple: the actress Katharine Cornell and her husband, the director Guthrie McClintic. "She was a great personality, not a great actress," said Mr. Plummer, reminding Ms. Harris that the stars of those days were often less than versatile. "And Guthrie knew how to light her."
It was McClintic who took Mr. Plummer, then a green 23, to Paris in 1955 to play Jason to the Medea of Judith Anderson, the great Australian actress. They rehearsed, he recalled, in the bar of the Ritz Hotel while the international hostess Elsa Maxwell held the prompt book. "It was quite a time," he said. "Judith lost her voice."
Ms. Harris gasped in sympathy.
"Because she was put into Sarah Bernhardt's dressing room," Mr. Plummer continued. "A huge room, of course, endless, with those big double doors. They open into an anteroom where La Bernhardt used to come out -- "
"In the intermission," said Ms. Harris.
"Yes," Mr. Plummer said, "to greet ambassadors and kings, while the flunkies would open the doors for her. Well, of course all that had gone, but the doors were still there. And this vast room. And way in a tiny little corner at the end of the room sat a makeup table, with one electric light bulb. And Judith Anderson was making herself up there. And I suppose she got -- well, what do you get? You get terrified. Judith, that tough Aussie, she got laryngitis."
The rasping Medea and her young Jason were roasted in the French press. Late in their run, however, the cast was lunching at the historic Parisian restaurant Le Grand Vefour when "this tall creature got up and started to walk toward our table." It was Jean Cocteau, the self-legendizing poet, playwright and artist, who went straight to Anderson. "He takes her hand in his," said Mr. Plummer, shifting into the present tense, "and says, 'Ah, Madame Anderson, you make life' " -- Mr. Plummer slapped his hand on a coffee table -- "and left. Well, it made her whole trip."
The story of the voiceless Judith Anderson, aside from being the perfect show-business anecdote, with its swing from humiliation to triumph, shows how the grandeur of earlier generations was already waning. "Like Chris said, the big doors didn't open anymore," said Ms. Harris.
This was partly, of course, a consequence of the increasing popularity of film and television. But even within the theater, there were demythologizing forces at work, said Mr. Plummer, citing in particular the Actors Studio in New York, the temple of Method performance run by Lee Strasberg.
"I even felt rather old-fashioned in the 50's," said Mr. Plummer, "because the youngsters coming up would say, 'Oh, come on, be real.' So one went around rather desperately trying to be real. And there was kind of a reverse snobbishness about the grandeur of the theater." He also suspected that Strasberg was "actually beginning, cagily, to train people for the movies, not the theater."
Ms. Harris studied at the studio, while Mr. Plummer attended as an observer, where he noticed one thing especially about the proceedings: "It was never fun."
"That's it," said Ms. Harris, recalling a session with Strasberg (a death scene from "Peer Gynt") that she left with a high fever. "No, there weren't many laughs."
"And isn't that the most important thing in the theater," asked Mr. Plummer, "to have fun as well?"
They paused to consider Strasberg's most famous acolyte, Marilyn Monroe. "Oh," said Ms. Harris, "I keep thinking if only she had been delicately, lovingly handled, she could've been a great actress."
"Yes," said Mr. Plummer, "if anyone needed someone who had a sense of fun, Marilyn did. She should've been thinking, 'Oh, it's not so tough, after all.' "
Glamour aside, Ms. Harris and Mr. Plummer believe that the most significant change for the theater actor has been economic. "There was a string of reality that was going through life," said Ms. Harris. "The New York theater, if you got a foothold in it, could be your livelihood. Now you say, 'No, I can't work in the New York theater.' "
"You can't afford it," said Mr. Plummer, who, like Ms. Harris, has worked extensively in film and television, largely "to earn some money."
"Well, it's not there for you," said Ms. Harris, of the New York theater.
Nonetheless, both said they had never considered leaving the theater, despite the toll it had taken on their lives outside it.
"I think families suffer," said Ms. Harris, who has been married and divorced three times and has one son. "In my life, I never could sustain that. I would have loved to have had more children. But I just found it so difficult to maneuver all of those complicated relationships."
"It is a selfish profession," said Mr. Plummer, who has been married to Elaine Taylor, his third wife, for more than 25 years. "You can't avoid that." Of his only child, the actress Amanda Plummer, he said, "She came from a real broken home, because both her mother" -- the actress Tammy Grimes -- "and I weren't there for her, really."
"But she loves you both," said Ms. Harris.
"She does," said Mr. Plummer. "I don't quite know why, but she does. Maybe it's the best way to love a parent, to love it in the mind's eye and not the real thing."
Mr. Plummer said he never considered having another child. "It would have to be brought up by a nanny, and what the hell is the point of that?"
"I know," said Ms. Harris. "I will always remember Boris Karloff saying to me, 'Only have one child.' "
What is it about being on stage that justifies the sacrifices? What does it feel like, at its best, when everything in a performance is working?
Ms. Harris, describing a moment during her run in "The Belle of Amherst," invoked the image of a flying carpet. "I felt toward the end of the play as if it would never end, and I'd always be floating on this wonderful carpet, talking. And people were listening."
"It's wonderful when you know that you can hold a silence in the theater," said Mr. Plummer. "There are very few times this happens. And when it does, you feel you dare to hold it and hold it, and you feel you could hold it forever. That's, I suppose, the greatest feeling in the theater, that they're so with you that they're silent."
What Mr. Plummer described as "the old-style temperamental star" doesn't, he said, exist much today. "Well, there's no time or room anymore," said Ms. Harris. Asked if she had ever indulged in such histrionics herself, she shook her head, chuckling, it seemed, at the absurdity of the question.
"Oh, come on!" Mr. Plummer erupted, delightedly. "Now, come on! I saw you lose it once."
"Oh, I've lost it," said Ms. Harris.
"Oh, yes, we've all lost it," said Mr. Plummer. "We have to lose it. Because you have to shed some tightness." Actually he said, Ms. Harris had exploded, quite rightly, during rehearsals for "The Lark," over something like a lighting cue that kept going wrong. "I was so glad," he said. "You were so sweet otherwise."
HE ALSO SAID HE WOULD NEVER forget the image of Ms. Harris, as Joan, "when she stood up on her little stool, and she screamed for her soldiers, and the tears ran down her face. And, oh, boy, every night, we stood behind her, bawling."
Ms. Harris, lowering her eyes, said she couldn't remember that.
"I think I told Julie that once during the run," said Mr. Plummer. "She said, 'Please don't talk to me about moments!' And I remember I went away thinking, 'Hey, I could really ruin a lot of great actors by telling them how wonderful they were in certain moments.' "
In fact, a great part of the pleasure of listening to him and Ms. Harris was hearing them describe such moments: Mr. Plummer on Ruth Gordon in "The Matchmaker" or Ms. Harris on Laurette Taylor in "The Glass Menagerie." And while both lamented the de-emphasis on what they consider an actor's most essential asset, a well-trained voice, they said they continued to see transporting performances in the theater. Ms. Harris, who usually devoted her two free nights a week during the run of "The Gin Game" to going to other plays, had seen Janet McTeer's recent performance in "A Doll's House" three times.
"My God, Julie, that's going too far," said Mr. Plummer.
"No, no," answered Ms. Harris, "but I love -- theater is -- I mean, I'm still that kind of audience, I just love it."
Ms. Harris also had rhapsodic praise for the Irish actor Donal McCann, whom she saw in two productions in recent years: Sebastian Barry's "Steward of Christendom," at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and Brian Friel's "Faith Healer," for which she drove from her home in Cape Cod to New Haven.
"I love that play," she said of the latter. "You should do that play, Chris." She paused, and a glint of steel suddenly shone in her voice. "We could do that play. Yeah. It's three parts. You'll probably want to play both men. And you could."
"As long as we know that," said Mr. Plummer.
"As long as we know that," Ms. Harris repeated happily.

PUB-DATE: September 14, 1997
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 3;Page 2;Column 3;Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

LAWSUITS
$3.5 Billion for a Rail Fire
Americans have long been litigious. Still, punitive damages of nearly $3.5 billion awarded in connection with a 1987 chemical fire in a New Orleans railway yard stunned participants and independent analysts alike. "This case shows that our system has turned into the world's richest roulette wheel," said Victor E. Schwartz, a Washington liability lawyer. CSX, which owned the tracks where the accident occurred, was assessed $2.5 billion, even though the National Transportation Safety Board found that it was not responsible for the leak that caused the fire. Some 8,000 people were evacuated from their homes for 36 hours. Questions were raised about the fire's long-term health effects, but no definitive studies have established lasting medical damage. The size of the judgment -- seven times the 1989 payout for the chemical explosion at Bhopal, India, that killed 3,000 people -- may be partly explained by the residents' anger at the storage of toxic chemicals in rail cars in their poor, largely black neighborhood. CSX is appealing. 

THE ECONOMY
Workers Get More Credit
The productivity of American workers grew at an annual rate of 2.7 percent, far more than originally estimated, the Labor Department reported. Some economists have concluded that the country is heading back toward a level of efficiency characteristic of the prosperous early postwar period, but absent for the last 25 years. And what did those busy workers do when they weren't working? They shopped: consumer installment credit climbed in July at a 6.4 percent annual rate, by an unexpectedly strong $6.5 billion, reflecting a bounce in new-car borrowing and credit-card use. Retail sales rose 0.4 percent in August, topping off a three-month summer rebound after a cool spring, but the gain was less than expected. Further, the Producer Price Index for August rose 0.3 percent after falling 0.1 percent in July. It was the first gain in the index since a 0.5 percent rise in December. The nation's deficit on the current account, the broadest measure of international trade, narrowed to $39.03 billion in the second quarter from a revised $39.97 billion in the first quarter.
 
MARKETS
A Chill for Blue Chips
The stock market, after opening the week on a positive note, changed directions on Wednesday and retreated, only to rise just as the week ended. Still, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 79.44 points for the week, closing at 7,742.97, while the Nasdaq composite index edged up 13.56, closing at 1,649.33. Although the latest economic reports were favorably received as showing steady economic growth with little inflation, a surprise warning by Motorola that it would not meet earnings expectations led some investors to sell shares of large multinational companies in favor of smaller stocks.
 
BROKERS
Charles Schwab, Underwriter
Charles Schwab & Company, the country's largest discount brokerage firm, agreed with three Wall Street firms to help underwrite public stock offerings. The deal will allow customers of Schwab's retail brokerage service to invest directly in public stock offerings led by Credit Suisse First Boston, Hambrecht & Quist or J. P. Morgan. The agreement is a big departure from Schwab's traditional business of processing customers' buy and sell orders. As an underwriter, Schwab will presumably put its own capital at risk and take a direct role in helping corporations raise money.
 
CITY KIOSKS
Service Without Attitude
A New York City worker who labors 24 hours a day with no complaints? New Yorkers can now use 37 experimental A.T.M.-like machines to pay parking tickets and property taxes with a credit card or bank card; check building-
inspection records; print application forms for permits, licenses and civil service jobs, and get answers to a host of questions. But New York is no pioneer. From Texas to Pennsylvania and Utah to Maryland, state and local governments are trying to streamline their bureaucracies by using interactive kiosks. In New York the machines are in sites as diverse as the Staten Island Ferry Terminal, Bellevue Hospital Center, the borough halls in Brooklyn and Queens, and 10 check-cashing outlets. They charge $3.50 for each transaction.
 
tHE ENVIRONMENT
Black Gold vs. Green
Despite the objections of Federal environmental agencies, the Clinton Administration approved Conoco's drilling of an exploratory oil well on Federal land in the red-rock country of Utah. Last year President Clinton established the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument to protect the rich wilderness from development. But oil companies' trespasses can have far-reaching effects. Central Park in New York is among the beneficiaries of $900 million that Exxon agreed to pay for environmental good works around the nation, a penance for the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, in which 11 million gallons of oil poured into the pristine waters of Prince William Sound in Alaska.
 
TECHNOLOGY
New Links in Cyberspace
Worldcom, the nation's fourth-largest long-distance phone company, agreed to acquire Compuserve for nearly $1.2 billion in stock. It will keep Compuserve's high-speed telecommunications lines and Internet gateways but sell the on-line subscription service, which has 2.6 million subscribers worldwide, to America Online. In turn, America Online is to sell its Internet telecommunications unit, ANS, to Worldcom. After the cash and asset swap, the imputed value of Compuserve's on-line service is $250 million, which would seem to show that the real value lies in the dull plumbing of cyberspace, not the glamour of the on-line service. Separately, a powerful team of companies is challenging a Microsoft plan, involving the purchase of a TV set-top device, to dominate the Internet via cable television. The challengers would treat the Internet as a premium cable service.
 
TAXES
Credit Cards? Not Yet
By early 1999 taxpayers need not send the I.R.S. a check. They can just tell the agency to dip into their bank accounts. But the Treasury said it had yet to figure out how consumers could pay their taxes with credit cards. Both means of payment were authorized by the budget-balancing tax legislation of the summer, and the I.R.S. likes them because they may encourage people to file electronically. That saves the Government a lot of data-entry work. The problem with credit cards is that the issuers charge fees to participating merchants, and the Government is barred from paying a fee.
 
JAPAN
A New Tax Adds to Trouble
In the second quarter, Japan's economy saw its sharpest contraction since the oil shock of 23 years ago. Economic output fell at a startling annual rate of 11.2 percent, the Government said. The sizable drop, attributed to a sharp increase in the national sales tax, dashed hopes for an early recovery from the nation's long economic slump.

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Sept. 8, reprinted in the Diary column of the Money and Business section on Sunday, showing the amount of leisure time spent on line, carried incomplete labels. The figures applied only to households that subscribe to on-line services or Internet service providers. The figures also represent the aggregate time spent by all members of the household, and were based on survey results, not direct measurements.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
At Fair Lawn Business Park, the Prospect Is Housing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: FAIR LAWN

 BODY:
IN the last 25 years the owners of the 150-acre Fair Lawn Business and Technical Center along Route 208 in this Bergen County community have proposed five projects -- including a million-square-foot commercial complex -- for the remaining 20 acres of their campus.
But none pleased the borough and they were eventually withdrawn, leaving the site in its natural state as a rare patch of farmland used as cornfields. 
 Last month, however, Fair Lawn's Planning Board granted preliminary approval to develop the property into a rental community of 340 apartments, 52 of them for tenants with low and moderate incomes, including 14 units for tenants 62 and older. It is expected to cost as much as $125 million.
Work on the project, now known as Fair Lawn Commons, will start once the remaining local and county permits are obtained, which is expected this fall. It will be developed over the next two years by the center's owners, McBride Enterprises of Franklin Lakes, in partnership with Pinnacle Communities Ltd. and Garden Homes, both based in Short Hills. Financing is coming from PNC Bank in East Brunswick and the partners' own equity.
Edward J. Trawinski, the Mayor of Fair Lawn, said the project will achieve two important municipal goals. Mr. Trawinksi said that it puts land that now generates nominal taxes because of its "farm exempt status" back on the tax rolls, and it also enables the borough to fulfill its obligation under the state's Mount Laurel doctrines.
Those doctrines require municipalities to provide opportunities for developing housing for people making 50 to 80 percent of the median income in the area. Fair Lawn's fair-share obligation is for 52 Mount Laurel units.
Since the program relies in large measure on building market-rate houses to underwrite the affordable ones -- typically in attached-housing projects built at a ratio of four market-rate units to one for low- or moderate-income occupants -- the state's improving residential marketplace is nudging along the production of Mount Laurel units.
"We are seeing a pickup in the number of towns coming in to file their affordable housing plans because they are seeing pressure from developers in their towns or in nearby towns," said Sidna B. Mitchell, spokeswoman for the Council on Affordable Housing, which oversees Mount Laurel issues. If a muncipality's housing plan is approved by the council it is protected from suits by developers for six years.
Ms. Mitchell said that towns were also looking to do rentals because the council in 1994 revised its rules to increase the Mount Laurel credits it gives to towns for such units to 2 from 1.3 per unit when the beneficiary family does not have to be elderly. The added credits seem to be "enough of a carrot" to spur construction, she said.
FOR builders the motivation to put up rental properties is the combination of available financing and a strenghtening demand for market-rate rental apartments. Evidence of that is in the buildings containing some 2,000 rental apartments under way or about to begin along the Hudson River waterfront.
Now the activity is also spreading into other areas of northern and central New Jersey where new construction has been spotty for the last two decades.
"There is more confidence today to move ahead with rental projects," said Nathan Slovin, executive vice president of the New Jersey Apartment Association, a trade group in East Brunswick. "And many are designed to meet Mount Laurel."
Also fueling developer interest, he said, is a law enacted last June that makes permanent exemptions on new apartments from rent control, considered a major barrier to construction. The exemptions were due to expire this year. "In addition," said Mr. Slovin, "the supply of rental housing in the state does not meet the demand."
The alignment of market conditions and municipal objectives were factors in breaking the decades-long logjam on the Fair Lawn site. Its development will bring to a close construction at the business and technical center, which began in the late 1950's as one of the first industrial parks in the state and the nation.
Today, it contains 2.5 million square feet of office research and manufacturing space in 21 buildings. Among them are an 85,000-square-foot office structure for Eastman Kodak and Nabisco's 575,000-square-foot manufacturing plant, from which wafts the sweet smell of baking cookies.
Most of the earlier plans -- like the one-million-square-foot hotel and office complex and another calling for a cluster of office buildings -- centered on commercial development. But the fifth proposal called for a mix of retail space, including a supermarket, and housing.
All were resisted by the borough because of traffic and density issues, said Mayor Trawinski. He said the current plan "represents a compromise between the property owner's rights and the desire of the municipality for controlled growth."
"Rental housing is a reasonable use of the land and provides a reasonable return on our investment," said David F. McBride, chief executive at McBride Enterprises. Now, he added, is a good time to build this project "because there is a need for rentals in this part of Bergen County."
To move the project forward McBride joined forces with Pinnacle Communities and Garden Homes, experienced housing developers. "It is an opportunity to develop luxury apartments in a great area," said Brian M. Stolar, president of Pinnacle. "For-sale housing has also gotten very expensive and for a certain percentage of the population luxury rental housing makes a lot of sense."
He said the partners spent the last year working with borough officials on how best to design the project while addressing such issues as drainage, traffic and density.
FAIR LAWN, as part of its plan for low- and moderate-income housing, designated the site for 300 multifamily housing units, 60 of them for lower incomes. The partners initially proposed 400 units, of which 60 would be affordable. Earlier this year the parties reached an agreement under which the site was rezoned to accommodate the project at its current scale, "which we feel maintains its economic viability," said Charles H. Tint, director of acquisition and land development at Pinnacle.
The partners will also make a number of off-site road improvements, including contributing to the widening of Fair Lawn Avenue, a main roadway abutting the site and extending Pollitt Drive to create a secondary entrance to the project. They will also carve out a one-acre manmade pond, that will double as a detention basin to manage storm water runoff from the site, and will landscape its border with Route 208 to buffer the project from the highway.
All the apartments at Fair Lawn Commons will be contained in 21 residential buildings grouped in seven clusters on both sides of a landscaped central boulevard. Each cluster will front a parking court for convenient access to the apartments.
Each of the two- and three-story brick and vinyl-sided buildings, designed in colonial style by EDI Architecture of Manhattan, will house 12 to 24 apartments. Planned amenities will include a 3,000-square-foot clubhouse, walking paths and a children's play area.
The market-rate units will have one to three bedrooms and 800 to 1,250 square feet of space; some will have car ports. Monthly rents for those apartments are expected to start at $900 for the smaller units and $1,400 for the larger ones. The Mount Laurel units will have the same number of bedrooms but will be smaller. Rents will range from $405 to $945.
Asked if there was any community opposition to the project Mayor Trawinski said: "The night we voted on it not one member of the public was present because by that time all of the borough's concerns were more than adequately addressed."

HEADLINE: Domestic Solutions

BYLINE: By Eden Ross Lipson; Eden Ross Lipson, the children's book editor of the Book Review, also edits The Times's staff publication, Times Talk.

 BODY:

THE WAY WE REALLY ARE
 Coming to Terms With
 America's Changing Families.
 By Stephanie Coontz.
 238 pp. New York:
 Basic Books. $23. 
 THE publication of "The Way We Never Were: American Families and the Nostalgia Trap," Stephanie Coontz's previous book, came in time for that book to serve as fodder in the "family values" debate that dominated the 1992 election. What might have been merely a well-received, clearly written book by an academic became fuel in the sound-bite fires and set the author, a historian at Evergreen State College in Oregon, on the road. The reception of that book perhaps contributed to the accessible tone of Coontz's follow-up, a look at the contemporary American family called "The Way We Really Are: Coming to Terms With America's Changing Families."
Coontz's travels took her to "Oprah" and "Crossfire," on many long plane flights where she often fell into conversation with fellow passengers, to lecture podiums across the country, to P.T.A. forums and drug and alcohol rehabilitation workshops. She listened well and learned a lot about fragmented debate and garbled information, about abrupt intimacy in public places, about fact and fiction in American family life. She has now attempted to "get beyond the rhetoric" and show that "history and social science do have concrete applications and positive lessons" for ordinary citizens.
Drawing on journalism as well as scholarship, she includes almost 50 pages of notes in addition to the modest 177 pages of text. Her book should offer reassurance to people in every kind of family muddling through every stressful stage. Her most important lesson, which she repeats one way and another, again and again, is that "the only way to get past the polarized testimonies for and against 1950's families is to put their strengths and weaknesses into historical perspective." She appreciates the fact of change in American history and constantly emphasizes it, so that, for example, in the chapter explaining "Why Working Mothers Are Here to Stay" she summarizes an important aspect of the industrial revolution as "The Late Birth and Short Life of the Male Breadwinner Family."
Addressing adult uneasiness about and around teen-agers, she shifts the terms of the debate from angry reproach to provocative compassion: "The best way I've found to personally confirm the sociological studies of rolelessness is to ask older men to talk about their life histories." Invariably, she says, they answer their own frustrated questions.
The experience of work has become very different for young people: "The typical job a teen-ager can get today provides neither the self-pride of economic independence nor the socializing benefits of working alongside adult mentors. . . . Work relations seem to have been critical experiences for the socialization of many young men in the past. Such jobs integrated youths into adult society . . . instead of segregating them in a separate peer culture." One telling statistic she cites: As recently as 1940, 60 percent of employed adolescents worked in traditional workplaces, acquiring skills they might use for the rest of their lives. By 1980, that figure had dropped to just 14 percent.
A chapter called "Working With What We've Got" contains a gem of insight about adapting to diversity in family structure. Some elementary school teachers who noticed homework stress in children from single-parent and dual-working-parent families gave students the assignment to read aloud to their parents several nights a week. How much nicer for a child to read to a parent who is fixing dinner than to sit alone with the television set while the parent feels stressed and alone in the kitchen. Another assignment was for a child to do comparison math while shopping with a parent.
That little example is typical of the pragmatic optimism that runs through Stephanie Coontz's book. Just think, she says, "how much we could accomplish if we stopped expecting nontraditional families to fail and started thinking creatively about how to help every family build on its resources and minimize its vulnerabilities." Agreed.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 5, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A review of "The Way We Really Are," by Stephanie Coontz, on Sept. 14 misstated the location of Evergreen State College, where she teaches. It is in Olympia, Wash., not in Oregon.
