HEADLINE: North Korea Famine May Be Killing 15% in Towns, Survey Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
An informal survey conducted for Korean-American organizations has found that about 15 percent of people in North Korea's towns and villages may be dying of starvation and famine-related diseases, an official of the international relief organization World Vision said yesterday.
The North Korean Government was not informed of the survey, which was carried out by ethnic Koreans living on the Chinese side of the China-North Korea border who can travel freely into North Korea. About 400 North Koreans and some Chinese and Russian citizens who recently traveled to North Korea were questioned. 
 They told stories of unclaimed bodies being collected from village streets and coffins being reused to save wood.
The results of the survey are to be made public in New York today by Andrew Natsios, vice president of World Vision, which has relief programs in North Korea.
"Fifteen percent is a huge famine," Mr. Natsios said in a telephone interview yesterday from his home in Washington. "And the thing that's alarming is that those three provinces on the Chinese border where the survey was conducted are ones where the World Food Program has found that people are the best fed."
Mr. Natsios, a former head of United States Government relief programs during famine crises in Africa, said that if these figures are reflective of the national picture, as many as half a million North Koreans may have died of starvation and famine-related illnesses in a population of about 22 million.
"Based on other reports we are getting, these findings seem to be an accurate and not exaggerated description," Mr. Natsios said, adding that food shortages would peak in November, when there should be a fall harvest -- although its size is hard to predict -- and a chance to plant winter crops.
Mr. Natsios, who visited North Korea in June, said the famine's effects were being worsened by the collapse of the national transportation system, which makes distribution of what food there is difficult.
World Vision, one of a handful of American-based private relief organizations working in North Korea, is recommending that Washington press China and Japan to give the North Koreans more food aid. Those organizations are also asking the secretive North Korean Government to allow relief experts and reporters to travel freely in the country, especially to remote areas. "The North Korean Government must be pressed to open the country up so that we can judge its needs," Mr. Natsios said.
"It would be much easier to mobilize resources if they would give us more access," he added. He also recommended that food donations, which the North Koreans are seeking desperately, should come in through the eastern ports and the Chinese border rather than through the North Korean capital, Pyongyang.
"No more food should come through Pyongyang," he said, adding that too much of it is being held and consumed there.
The survey recently conducted along the Chinese-North Korean border covered more than 30 villages and towns in Hamgyong, Puongan and Ryanggang provinces, with the largest number of people surveyed living around the towns of Onsong and Musan in Hamyong.
Of 400 people initially interviewed by Chinese-Koreans, only 33 agreed to complete more detailed questionnaires about local conditions. The rest said they were too fearful of the North Korean Government to divulge information beyond descriptions of life in their own towns.
World Vision officials acknowledge that the survey was limited and often anecdotal, but welcomed its findings as "probably the first of its kind" for North Korea.
The isolated country suffered floods in 1995 and 1996 and a summerlong drought this year. The natural disasters hit an economy unable to function normally, much less in crisis, after years of a bizarre Communist experiment in self-sufficiency that left the country without hard currency to buy emergency supplies or even spare parts abroad.
The collapse of the Soviet bloc further weakened North Korea. Its closest friends now are Cuba and Vietnam, neither of which is able to give much assistance.

HEADLINE: Congo Aid at Risk In Defiance of U.N. Over War Refugees

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Congo, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Four months after winning power through an armed rebellion, this country's new President, Laurent Kabila, is locked in a showdown with the United Nations. The outcome, diplomats say, could critically influence his Government's prospects for survival and will determine how it is seen by much of the world.
Mr. Kabila is torn between the demands of the international organizations and foreign governments that he respect long-established conventions on the treatment of refugees and the investigation of war atrocities, and the demands of powerful African allies who helped place him in power and have no interest in light being shed on these matters. Diplomats say that Mr. Kabila, militarily and politically weak, has opted to satisfy his neighbors. 
 A breakdown in relations with the United Nations would almost certainly spill over into Congo's ties with international financial institutions like the World Bank, and other lenders in the West.
A donors' conference in Paris last month put the new Government on notice that major loans to Congo will be contingent on human rights improvements and a real commitment to democratic elections.
Aid from Washington is already nearly frozen because of huge arrears in debt repayments inherited from the dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko, who was overthrown by Mr. Kabila.
Even before it came to power, Mr. Kabila's movement won a number of commitments from international mining companies for large investments in copper and cobalt production here, but bankers here say little of that money is paid in advance to the new Government, whose revenue is to come from future production.
Returning this week from a brief visit to Rwanda, his biggest military backer during the seven-month war that defeated Mr. Mobutu and put Mr. Kabila in power last May, Congo's new leader gave full voice to the aggressive tack he has apparently decided to take toward the United Nations.
He spoke with undisguised scorn in responding to a warning by the United Nations refugee agency that it would suspend its work in this country because of the summary deportation this month of 700 Rwandans and Burundians, refugees from the city of Kisangani, in what the head of the refugee agency, Sadako Ogata, called a "blatant breach of international treaties."
"We should be very pleased about the departure of the people" of the refugee agency, Mr. Kabila said, "because they are harmful to freedom and well-being of the Congolese people. It would be a good opportunity for the Congolese people to be totally free."
One senior Congolese official later explained Mr. Kabila's language saying that the Government suspected an international conspiracy of sorts to use the refugee issue in the United Nations to destroy Mr. Kabila's Government and replace it with leaders more amenable to the West.
"The history of our country and the United Nations is the history of a failed romance," said Biyoya Makutu Kahandja, a senior Foreign Ministry official. "At independence in 1960 the United Nations banned our own Prime Minister from the radio, and a U.N. peacekeeping force took sides in our civil war. We have reasons to suspect the worst."
Mr. Kabila's Government has been even more assertive in its treatment of a United Nations-mandated investigation into the suspected massacre of thousands of predominantly Rwandan ethnic Hutu who were reportedly killed by Rwandan Tutsi forces during and after Mr. Kabila's campaign for power.
Some of the Rwandan Hutu are known to have been armed combatants, participants in the 1994 anti-Tutsi massacres in that country who allied themselves with Mr. Mobutu's army. But many thousands of the presumed victims were women and children.
After approving the deployment of the investigators under intense international pressure, Mr. Kabila's Government has thrown one obstacle after another in the way of the team, successfully demanding the removal of its original leader, questioning its mandate repeatedly and effectively preventing it from starting its work.
In a recent exchange of correspondence, Mr. Kabila wrote to the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, demanding that any investigation of atrocities be limited to eastern Congo, where the insurrection against Mr. Mobutu began, that it cover only the period before Mr. Kabila took power on May 17, and that investigators be accompanied by Congolese "facilitators."
Later, in what one United Nations official called a "clear provocation," Congolese officials submitted a budget for 24 official "facilitators" that included a $700 daily allowance for each. With the United Nations already considering withdrawing the investigators altogether and referring the matter to the Security Council for possible punitive action, Mr. Annan replied on Aug. 29 in a letter calling the new conditions a "complete surprise," and complained bitterly that "promises and assurances given are being reneged upon."
More recently, the United Nations investigators here have been told by their superiors in New York to try immediately to begin their field work, with the idea that if the Government obstructs them further the mission will simply be recalled.
One member of the investigative mission, Reed Brody, said that when the team tried to buy airplane tickets on Saturday for a destination within the country to begin their work, the travel agent here told them the Government had given instructions that no tickets could be sold to them.
If the investigators pull out, a move many here believe is imminent, Western diplomats say it will prompt a series of actions that will further isolate a Government with huge reconstruction needs, little cash and a dwindling number of friends.
Until now, Washington has been widely seen as the Kabila Government's most sympathetic backer outside of Africa, but senior American officials too have begun to say that enough is enough.
"We very much wanted to give him the benefit of the doubt and to help him," said Bill Richardson, the American delegate to the United Nations. "But when it appears that his Government turns its back on important commitments made to the international community, he leaves us with few options."

HEADLINE: Another Waterway Is Closed in Maryland;
Thousands of Fish Die in Most Recent Outbreak of Microbe Problem

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: DRAWBRIDGE, Md., Sept. 14

 BODY:
Thousands of fish stricken with a microbial affliction thrashed weakly this morning on the surface of Chicamacomico River, leading the state to close yet another waterway to fishing and recreation and adding to the urgency of a festering new environmental problem for the Chesapeake Bay.
It was the third time since early August that Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland had ordered the closure of one of the bay's Eastern Shore tributaries, where sport and commercial fishermen and boaters prop up half the economy and chicken farms and cornfields sustain the other half. 
 The gaping raw sores on the four-inch-long menhaden, which are a common bait fish for crabbers in this area, are the classic symptom of fish attacked by Pfiesteria piscicida, a little-understood microbe discovered only a few years ago that sometimes assumes a toxic form. It has been blamed not only for killing fish but also for rashes, flulike symptoms and even short-term memory loss among some people who have come into contact with it while fishing or conducting research.
Just what causes Pfiesteria to turn toxic is not certain, but chronic problems with the microbe in North Carolina are thought by many scientists to be related to polluted runoff from hog farms. In this part of Maryland, the attention is focusing on chicken farms, whose manure enriches the cornfields that dominate the landscape, drained by ditches that feed directly into some of the affected streams. The nutrients in the manure runoff provide the nourishment for microbes to flourish.
Already, Governor Glendening has stirred a furor in the agricultural community by suggesting that chicken farmers should brace for stricter pollution standards. He said he would appoint a commission to develop recommendations this fall for better regulation of agricultural runoff.
In the meantime, the state's decisions to close a stretch of the Pocomoke River, a section of King's Creek and the Manokin River, and now six miles of the Chicamacomico, have stirred another kind of economic turmoil, because the fishing and tourism industries have paid the price. Pfiesteria hysteria, as it is being called, has dominated the front pages of many of the region's newspapers for weeks now.
"Our two primary concerns must be, first, the health of our citizens, and second, the health of the bay itself," Governor Glendening said in a telephone interview today. "In many ways, Maryland is the Chesapeake Bay, and if we can't find the source of this and contain it, we have the possibility of this spreading year after year."
Even before the state closed the river today, uniformed natural resources police warned boaters and passers-by to avoid the area.
"We're here to advise you it's probably not wise to hang around," one officer told Cindy and John Jacobs, who bicycled by with their son Dennis. They said they were visiting relatives in the area and had been planning to go fishing.
"It's terrible -- look how many there are," said Mrs. Jacobs, gazing at the sick fish from the bridge. "Isn't that sad?"
In their death throes, some of the fish leaped from the water; the dead ones floated downstream. It was impossible to say how many fish would die, but clearly tens of thousands had been stricken since the outbreak was detected late on Saturday. Teams of state officials have been taking samples and shipping them to laboratories for analysis. Until that work is done, it cannot be said for certain that Pfiesteria was at work.
Throughout the region, businesses that rely on tourism said they were suffering from the bad publicity.
Larry Knudsen, proprietor of the River House Inn, which abuts the Pocomoke several miles above the area that the state closed, said a group of elderly guests who visit every year, filling the inn, had canceled this year's trip. Because they usually eat at a fine local restaurant and take a boat tour, he said, the economic loss from their decision alone was probably thousands of dollars.
Many of the Eastern Shore's large poultry farmers say there is insufficient proof to pin the problem on their operations. But some farmers acknowledge that chicken manure may be partly to blame for the fish kills.
"I believe it is a contributing factor," said Frank Morison, a founder and director of the Delmarva Contract Poultry Growers Association, a group of 2,600 poultry farmers from Delaware, Maryland and Virginia. "I've been in the industry for 30 years and done a lot of research," he said. "Wherever the industry sets up shop, there's water quality problems associated with it."
Although many local residents suspect that the heavy output of chicken manure is somehow implicated in the fish disease outbreaks, they are often gentle in their criticism of their neighboring farmers.
"We have never pointed a finger at the poultry industry alone," said Fred Maddox of Maddox & Son Seafood in Shelltown, who began reporting sick fish to state authorities as long as a year ago.
Pollution-control experts point out that there are many sources of excess nutrients pouring into the Chesapeake, from well-fertilized suburban lawns to outmoded sewage treatment plants, and even from the nitrogen in air pollution throughout the vast watershed.
But Judith Stribling, an assistant professor of biology at Salisbury State University and a leader of Friends of the Nanticoke, another river where sick fish have been reported but not confirmed by state authorities, says agricultural runoff is a prime suspect. She suspects that there may be an imbalance between the nutrient chemicals nitrogen and phosphorus, especially when manure is used as fertilizer.
"We have been saying for years that the bay was overloaded with nutrients," she said. "The obvious question is: How much worse is this going to get, and how far is it going to go?"
Governor Glendening said he had called for a meeting of regional governors this week, and that Gov. George F. Allen of Virginia, who has drawn some criticism for his state's less aggressive response to Pfiesteria in its waters, would attend.
Environmental Protection Agency officials have said they are examining how to better control the runoff from agricultural sources nationwide. New regulations and tougher enforcement of rules governing animal feedlots are under active consideration, they said.

HEADLINE: Albright's Trip: No 'Big Steps'

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 14

 BODY:
As a measure of the deteriorating peace efforts in the Middle East, even the Davis Cup tennis team from Morocco -- one of the Arab countries warmest to Israel -- has refused to go to Israel to play.
While security fears were cited as the reason, American officials interpret the decision as a protest against the policies of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and an example of the increasing re-isolation of Israel in even the moderate Arab world. 
 In her first official visit to the Middle East, which is due to end on Monday, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has found herself having to try to restore even the semblance of negotiations toward peace. She has had to try to reduce the swelling distaste and distrust between the conservative Mr. Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. Mr. Arafat is still nostalgic for Israel's Labor Party, whose leaders negotiated and signed the Oslo accords with him on the White House lawn exactly four years ago.
Ms. Albright's delicate task has been to push a deeply divided Israel hard enough to convince it not to damage its own interests. And if Mr. Arafat or Mr. Netanyahu will not take up her challenge to make "hard decisions" needed to restart peace talks, she wants to protect American strategic interests in the larger Middle East from the collateral damage.
She had to warn Mr. Arafat that the United States -- let alone Israel -- would no longer tolerate his use of security cooperation with Israel as a negotiating lever.
She had to support Mr. Netanyahu in his security concerns. But she also had to warn him that they cannot forever be a pretext to keep from dealing seriously with the political issues of real peace and partnership -- or at the minimum, rapprochement -- with the Palestinians.
With the American-built regional coalition against Iran and Iraq fraying badly, Ms. Albright had to go to the Middle East to appear to be trying her best to work as an "honest broker" for peace and to be heard speaking with at least some sympathy for the situation as moderate Arabs and Palestinians see it.
A prolonged collapse of peace negotiations would lead to more radical and fundamentalist pressures on moderate Arab governments, the further isolation of Israel, the undermining of Mr. Arafat by a frustrated and impoverished Palestinian population, a probable increase in terrorism and violence, and a major fracture in the strategic position of the United States in the Middle East.
Ms. Albright had to begin to fix all that in the aftermath of a second suicide bombing episode in recent weeks, when the Israelis needed reassurance about their security. She also had to manage the entire initiative without getting President Clinton into too much trouble with a pro-Israel Congress and Democratic Party at home.
With so much at stake, it is really too early to say whether this much-postponed first trip to the region has been a success or a failure. She herself was relatively honest about the paucity of her achievement, but for once she may have been selling herself a little short.
While she made clear that "big steps" were needed -- from Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat, she was careful to say, not from the United States -- she did manage to arrange a series of meetings on both the Palestinian-Israel and Israel-Syrian negotiating tracks.
Neither is likely to go very far very fast, but they did break the sense of deterioration and stalemate and bought everybody some time. They helped to restore a sense of American engagement and sway. And she was outspoken about the damage done by unilateral Israeli actions like settlement expansion, while decrying the radical Arab terrorism that also threatens every Arab state.
These accomplishments alone produced complimentary sighs of relief from Arab leaders ranging from President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan to less predictable figures like King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and the country's conservative Crown Prince, Abdullah.
Mr. Mubarak said her trip had produced unexpected results and had created new hope for peace efforts, telling her in their meeting that she was being seen "in a new light" throughout the Arab world. Crown Prince Abdullah, who has warned that Saudi Arabia might boycott an American-sponsored regional economic meeting in mid-November in Doha, Qatar, said, "This is what we always looked for and admired, a Secretary of State who is brave and frank at the same time."
Even taking into account traditional Arab chivalry -- King Fahd met her uncharacteristically early in the evening and did not keep her waiting -- Ms. Albright clearly made a favorable first impression.
The public relations-conscious Mr. Netanyahu, too, has moved quickly to make some gestures of the kind she recommended, announcing tonight that he would turn over half of the remaining money he owes the Palestinian Authority and canceling plans for a small but controversial housing project in Jerusalem that he had earlier suspended. And Mr. Arafat has already moved some way, though not nearly far enough, American officials say, to begin to crack down on the militant group Hamas.
The actions are another proof of an old diplomatic adage that when parties are engaged in negotiations, no matter how desultory, they tend to behave more responsibly.
There is a risk that those negotiations could quickly run into the sand, producing another stalemate and possibly further deterioration.
Still, it would be remarkable enough if both parties followed the path of "mutual responsibility" that Ms. Albright laid out for them on this trip -- Mr. Arafat producing enough security cooperation to give the Israelis enough confidence to make the political moves necessary to get into serious final-status talks, while carrying out what remains of the troop withdrawals from the West Bank called for under the Oslo accords.
Those final status talks themselves, to reach a peace settlement, must tackle the most fundamental issues between Israelis and Palestinians. The talks are to define the boundaries of the Palestinian entity, whether it becomes a state or not (and if so, what kind), and the future status of Jerusalem, which both peoples claim as their capital.
But just to get that far, from where matters are today, would be a significant accomplishment for a Secretary of State who waited eight months to visit the region in the vain hope of associating her first trip with a negotiating success.

HEADLINE: Women Losing Ground to Men In Widening Income Difference

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
After nearly two decades in which the wage gap between men and women was steadily narrowing, it is now widening again, piquing confusion and concern among economists and women's groups alike.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median weekly earnings of full-time working women are just under 75 percent of the men's median, down from 77 percent four years ago. 
 "It's a puzzlement," said Francine Blau, a labor economist at Cornell University. "In my head, at this point, it doesn't mean we're actually going backward. It's more a slowdown, a plateau, a consolidation after a period of rapid social change. The concern is what's happened to that robust upward trend we had for so many years, and what's going to happen in the future."
From 1979 to 1993, women's median earnings rose from 62 percent of men's to 77 percent. And in the early 1990's, the narrowing gap was widely trumpeted as evidence of women's greater opportunities, greater education and greater work experience -- trends that were predicted to continue indefinitely, edging women ever closer to pay equity.
"The narrowing wage gap got a huge amount of attention five years ago," said Claudia Goldin, an economist at Harvard University. "But right now, we're a little quiet. Questions of gender and economics are going to be with us forever, and it's all connected to political and social change. The social movements that led to women's advances came in with great force. It was an enormous tide. Now we're coming into a new equilibrium. I see this as a household issue, and the new equilibrium is that all those strollers are still being pushed by women."
While some labor economists suggest tentatively that the turn in the statistics may have something to do with a flood of unskilled women unleashed on the job market by changes in welfare, most warn that it is far too soon to say with any certainty just what, if anything, the earnings data portend.
"There's definitely something real going on, and it's worth worrying about, but we don't have a good explanation," said Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research organization known for liberal views. "I've been wanting to point out to the world that it was happening, but I didn't know why, and I wanted to have some causal information before writing about it."
Most experts caution against any conclusion that the earnings numbers are evidence of growing discrimination against women: They say it is more likely that the numbers reflect changes in the makeup of the workforce, overall economic trends, or statistical flukes, than any real reversal of women's workplace status.
They point out that while one measure of wages -- median usual weekly earnings of full-time workers -- shows a steadily widening gap between men and women since 1993, another measure available only through 1995 -- annual full-time wages of year-round workers -- fluctuates slightly, showing no steady trend. The gap between men's and women's annual earnings is larger than on the weekly earnings in part because the annual measure more fully reflects bonuses and occasional overtime, areas in which men tend to do better than women.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics changed its questionnaire in 1994, so that the later earnings data are not strictly comparable with the earlier years, but that would not account for any continuing drop.
Generally, the youngest working women have come closest to men's pay levels, with those age 16 to 24 earning more than 90 percent of men's wages, those in their mid-careers earning about 75 percent, and those over 55 earning about 65 percent as much as men their age.
"Looking at women over their life cycle, you see that as they get those first jobs, they look pretty equal to men, then when they have their first baby, they start looking less equal to men," Ms. Goldin said.
Though that overall picture remains unchanged, the youngest and oldest women lost ground in the last few years, while women ages 25 to 54 continued to earn about 75 percent of what men their age earned.
The effort to sort out just what the gender gap means is complicated, because it reflects larger economic trends. For example, economists point out, more women may choose to stay home with a new baby during a recession, when wages stagnate and job-hunting becomes harder.
"You're measuring one thing that's changing against another thing that's changing," said Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. "Anywhere from half to three-quarters of the closing of the gender gap was a result of men's real wages falling, so women's wages came closer. Now men's wages are rising again, so to keep closing the gap, women's would have to be rising faster."
Ms. Hartmann is troubled by the widening wage gap because it indicates a concentration of women at the low end of the pay scale.
"There's a growing inequality in the labor market between people at the high end and people at the low end," she said. "Women are losing out because more of them are moving into the losing category of lower skilled workers than into the winning categories of highly skilled workers."
Economists at both ends of the political spectrum suggest that the change may be a result of welfare overhaul.
"Not-married women with children have had an enormous increase in employment, which coincides with the dropping welfare caseloads," said June O'Neill, the Republican-appointed head of the Congressional Budget Office. "These are the least skilled people entering the workforce, and that would have a downward pull on median wages."
Ms. O'Neill said that though she had not examined the data closely enough to offer any definitive analysis, she thought it was more likely that the earnings data reflected welfare changes than sex discrimination.
"Clinton was elected saying he would get rid of welfare as we know it," said Marvin Kosters, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization in Washington. "By 1994, we had a Republican Congress, and a lot of changes at the state level. The movement off the welfare rolls began long before Federal legislation. I'm not saying that's necessarily what's going on here, but it's one thing to consider."
Whether welfare change is the cause, it is true that the group for whom the gender gap widened the most was black women age 16 to 24. In 1996, such women earned 94.9 percent of the median weekly pay of black men their age, down from 101.6 percent in 1993.
When liberals discussed welfare overhaul and the pay gap, they tended to cite such a gap as a sign of the negative social impact of changes in welfare.
"We'd predicted, a while ago, that if welfare reform went fully in effect nationally, and moved a couple million people nationally from welfare to work, it would lower wages for low-wage workers as much as 12 percent," Mr. Bernstein said. "So we shouldn't be surprised if that's occurring. If the point of welfare reform was to lower wages, this is a success. People talked a lot about welfare recipients displacing other workers from their jobs, but now we have to wonder about another kind of displacement, wage displacement, in which the wages for all low-skilled jobs are depressed by all the new women from welfare looking for work."
Though some economists are just noticing the widening pay gap, many women have apparently been aware of the problem for a while. In a nationwide survey of women workers released last week, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. found that equal pay was the top concern cited -- and while 94 percent of the women surveyed said that equal pay for equal work was very important to them, more than a third said they did not get such equity at their current jobs.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
U.S. Says It Could Sign A Modified Treaty on Mines
The United States could sign a treaty banning land mines if it got an additional nine years before removing them from the Korean peninsula, senior Clinton Administration officials said. The major policy shift came after already strong pressure from allies grew with the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales, who had taken up the cause. A1
 
Israel Eases Some Pressure
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said the Government would release another portion of the tax funds it had withheld from the Palestinian Authority, a step that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright sought last week. Israel also announced the easing of restrictions on Palestinian movements in the West Bank, which were imposed after suicide bombings. A1 

Congo in Standoff With U.N.
The new President of Congo, Laurent Kabila, is locked in a showdown with the United Nations over refugees and wartime atrocities. Diplomats say the powerful African allies who helped bring Mr. Kabila to power four months ago are pressuring him to resist. But the standoff could jeopardize the aid that Congo badly needs from world financial institutions. A1
 
Survey of North Korea Famine
An informal survey has found that about 15 percent of North Koreans in towns and villages may be dying of starvation and famine-related diseases, an official of the relief group World Vision said. The North Korean Government was not informed of the survey, which was carried out by ethnic Koreans living on the Chinese side of the border who can travel freely into North Korea. A11
 
Assassination Plot Is Reported
Russian officials said they had learned of a plot to assassinate Anatoly B. Chubais, the main architect of Russia's economic reforms and one of the country's most senior officials. An aide to Mr. Chubais confirmed that the Federal Security Service had received a tip about the plot. He declined to say who would organize such an attack or why. A5
 
U.S. and German Planes Lost
American and German military planes carrying 33 people were missing off southwest Africa and may have collided, officials from both countries said. The Pentagon confirmed that a C-141 cargo plane with nine aboard was missing. A3
 
NATIONAL A12-21
 
High-Tech Sleuthing And the Invasion of Privacy
The world of computer technology and information marketing has turned private detectives into a vanguard of privacy invasion. Perhaps no case provides a better illustration than Texaco's investigation of people who filed claims after a 1992 refinery fire in California. Through commercial databases unknown to most people, law-enforcement computer files that are supposed to be off-limits to civilians, electronic surveillance equipment readily sold in spy shops and simple telephone schemes common in the information underground, Texaco amassed sensitive knowledge about dozens of people involved in the explosion claims, according to court documents, interviews and sworn statements. A1
 
The Value of Friendship
Thomas F. McLarty 3d was pushed out as President Clinton's chief of staff more than three years ago, but in certain circles, Mr. McLarty still wields considerable influence. Given the lofty if hazy title of "counselor to the President" and shunted to a basement office, Mr. McLarty can walk into the Oval Office or the Clintons' private living quarters unscheduled and unannounced. He is blithely candid about the secret of his survival. "I had the good fortune," he said, "to go to kindergarten with President Clinton." A1
 
Pay Disparity Widening
The wage gap between men and women, once steadily narrowing, is now widening again, piquing confusion and concern among economists and women's groups alike. "It's a puzzlement," said Francine Blau, a labor economist at Cornell University. "In my head, at this point, it doesn't mean we're actually going backward. It's more a slowdown, a plateau, a consolidation after a period of rapid social change. The concern is what's happened to that robust upward trend we had for so many years, and what's going to happen in the future." A1

The pilot ejected safely, but four people on the ground received minor injuries and some houses were damaged or destroyed. Stealth aircraft gained fame in the Persian Gulf war for their ability to avoid detection by Iraqi radar and attack heavily defended targets. A12

A Jury's Message to Business
A jury in New Orleans decided that it would send a message to corporate America with its 11-to-1 judgment that the CSX Corporation should pay $2.5 billion of a $3.4 billion award arising from a railroad car fire 10 years ago. Defense lawyers for CSX and other corporations saw the verdict as an example of a runaway jury. But interviews with jurors indicated that the huge judgment was intended to spur change and put big business on notice that it should be accountable for what the jurors regarded as sheer callousness, in this case the parking of railroad cars holding toxic chemicals in a residential area. HEADLINE: New Work Proposed For Shuttles: Salvage in Space

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
BILLIONS of dollars' worth of old communication, weather and spy satellites are circling Earth, dead or dormant and usually adrift. Typically, there is little or nothing wrong with them. They have just run out of fuel.
Space-age garbage?
Not to James C. Adamson, a former astronaut who is the chief operating officer of the United Space Alliance, the company that NASA has put in charge of running the space shuttles. 
 "Space salvage," Mr. Adamson said with the grin of Han Solo, the galactic wheeler-dealer of the "Star Wars" movies.
Most any rocket can carry payloads into orbit, he said in a recent interview at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. But only the winged spaceships, with their cavernous cargo bays, can haul derelict craft back to Earth. If the shuttles "bring a lot of these dead birds back" for refurbishing, Mr. Adamson said, they could be returned to work in space and his company would make a tidy profit. "I'd love to do it," he said.
The potential enterprise signals looming change for the nation's fleet of spaceships. The shuttles are going commercial, slowly for now, then perhaps faster in the years ahead.
On Oct. 1, the United Space Alliance is to present the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, at NASA's request, a detailed plan for privatizing the shuttles. A main agenda item is the return of shuttle flights and services to commercial missions.
Big commercial payloads like communication satellites were banned from the spaceships after the 1986 Challenger disaster, and some experts worry that the return of free-market forces could doom the temperamental shuttles to another catastrophe as economic pressures erode safety.
But many analysts say that the onset of private rigor is already improving shuttle performance and that in time, the process could save taxpayers billions of dollars. The nation's $68 billion fleet of space shuttles runs on an annual budget of $3.15 billion and is now limited to scientific and military missions.
In theory, complete privatization early in the next decade would have the Government spending little or no money on the shuttles other than fees for specific jobs and objectives.
The United Space Alliance has run the shuttles for one year and so far is generally given high marks. The spaceplanes are starting to thunder aloft without the serious delays that marred so many past missions, a testament to good planning and management.
"All the indications are that it's working beautifully," Jerry Grey, policy director of the American Institute of Astronautics and Aeronautics, a professional group of aerospace engineers based in Washington, said of United Space's operation of the shuttle fleet.
"Most NASA people at the beginning were worried. They thought safety would suffer as costs were cut. Now, most seem reasonably happy with how things have gone. The consensus is in that things are moving in the right direction."
Mr. Adamson of United Space is upbeat about commercialization and the prospect of completely privatizing the shuttle effort.
"Here's a program that grew up in cold war days," he said. "We're trying to bend it around. I'm very optimistic. There are lots of opportunities."
The space shuttles, which first blasted into space in 1981, were designed to do commercial work. After their initial test flights, they did so with great regularity, carrying more than a dozen private satellites into orbit. They also made rescues that proved the principle of satellite recycling, at least for craft readily accessible in relatively low orbits.
When the booster engines of two communication satellites failed to work properly in February 1984, stranding them in useless orbits, the shuttle Discovery and its crew flew to the rescue the following November, carrying the satellites back to Earth for refurbishment and eventual return to space.
But the period of shuttle commercial flights ended abruptly in January 1986 when Challenger blew up shortly after launching, killing all seven crew members. President Ronald Reagan, worried that market forces had undercut safety, ordered all large commercial payloads off the shuttles that August.
The commercial idea was resurrected in the early 1990's by Daniel S. Goldin, the current NASA Administrator and a former aerospace executive who has struggled to have the sluggish agency do things smaller, cheaper, faster and better.
The shuttle program was back on its feet but financially bloated, Mr. Goldin reasoned. So he championed the commercial shift as a way to cut costs and free the agency to finance and pursue more futuristic work, like exploring distant worlds and looking for extraterrestrial life.
His ideas were backed in February 1995 by a NASA panel headed by Dr. Chris Kraft, an aerospace consultant and former director of the Johnson Space Center, an agency field installation in Houston.
"The Challenger incident created a safety environment in NASA that is duplicative and expensive," the Kraft panel reported, adding that it actually threatened to undermine safety by adding mazes of red tape.The panel called not only for private shuttle operation but also for an end to the ban on commercial payloads.
In September 1996, NASA signed a six-year, $7 billion contract to turn over most shuttle work to the United Space Alliance. United Space is a joint venture of the Boeing Company, the shuttle's maker, and the Lockheed Martin Corporation, a major shuttle contractor.
Since Oct. 1, United Space, which is based in Houston, has increasingly overseen the day-to-day work of the four-shuttle fleet and by all accounts is running them smoother and less expensively than ever before. Its contract calls for any savings to be divided between the company and the Federal Government, with hundreds of millions of saved dollars expected through the end of the initial contract.
At NASA's urging, United Space is now taking the process a step further by exploring new commercial markets. Last month, it hired Spacetec of Hampton, Va., a technology development and marketing company, to seek potential customers at home and abroad.
The early salesmanship focuses on the shuttle Columbia, which will not be used in building the planned International Space Station, the effort that will occupy the other three shuttles almost exclusively for nearly five years starting in 1998. Columbia, the first shuttle built, is too heavy to carry the heavy components of the outpost.
The envisioned commercial ventures include such varied ideas as advertising on Columbia's exterior and carrying tourists into orbit, though few passengers could probably afford the likely cost of $5 million to $10 million per trip.
A company wish list of other possible jobs includes using the shuttles to generate power, to manufacture goods, to aid mining operations on the Moon, to make educational shows and to loft human remains into orbit.
Glynn S. Lunney, a former NASA official who is now the United Space vice president for strategic and business planning, said the aim was to to do things for customers that rockets cannot do. Mr. Lunney added, however, that the shuttles might play a backup role to regular deployments by rockets.
"We don't know what our role might be in the existing market," he said in an interview, adding that it would "continue to evolve as we go along."
"We're taking a long horizon on this whole enterprise," he said. "We expect that the country is going to operate this system at least until 2010 or 2012."
United Space sees some of the brightest glitter in satellites, a multibillion-dollar industry expected to grow vigorously in years ahead as the world becomes more closely knit economically.
One intriguing idea that plays to shuttle strengths is satellite servicing and retrieval, especially in low orbits of hundreds of miles. It is there that spy satellites, some the world's most costly spacecraft, live and die.
A more ambitious goal is to fetch derelict craft orbiting 22,300 miles above the equator, the altitude at which craft circle Earth in sync with planetary rotation, keeping them stationary in the sky, unlike stars or the Sun.
The United States Space Command, which tracks space objects for the military from Colorado Springs, says 614 satellites populate the areas in and around this geostationary orbit, with roughly half of them dead or drifting uselessly.
Fran Slimmer, spokeswoman for the Hughes Space and Communications Company, the world's largest maker of communication satellites and a part of the General Motors Corporation, said most of the abandoned satellites suffer from a lack of maneuvering fuel rather than from serious problems like bad electronics. Satellites in geostationary orbit depend on fuel to stay precisely in the right spot so the operators of dish antennas on Earth know exactly where to find these beacons in space.
Retrieving the geostationary drifters would require space robots that could fly up from the shuttle's low orbit and carry the targets back down. Experts disagree on whether such work could be economical. But the construction of space tugs is nonetheless being explored.
In the future, experts say, the biggest challenge to shuttle privatization is not finding new markets but increasing the number of flights for the aging spacecraft so operating costs are spread out.
"Today," said Mr. Adamson of United Space, "we fly 7 to 8 flights a year. Without very much trouble I think we could comfortably fly 9 to 10, and with minimal additions, 11 to 12."
The big question is whether that approach courts disaster.
Most analysts agree that the Challenger catastrophe was partly rooted in a push to make the shuttle fleet pay for itself by carrying many Government, scientific and commercial payloads.
The year before the disaster, in 1985, the spaceships nearly doubled their rate of launchings by flying 9 missions, and faced plans for at least 24 a year by 1990. That was the atmosphere on Jan. 28, 1986, when Challenger began its last flight, carrying six astronauts and a high school teacher.
NASA itself is cautiously optimistic about the new push and eager to avoid repeating past mistakes.
"Our goal is to privatize the shuttle as soon as practical," Wilbur C. Trafton, NASA's associate administrator for space flight, wrote on Aug. 25 to the Johnson Space Center, which oversees the shuttles.
But the move, Mr. Trafton stressed, must be "consistent with maintaining or improving safety."
The plan envisions 2002 as the start of the private era. Ultimately, the success of the plan depends on whether the United Space Alliance and NASA can persuade Congress and the Clinton Administration to reverse post-Challenger policies that bar commercial payloads.
The allure is perhaps as great as the risk: turning the shuttle from a Federal hog into a lean, fly-for-profit business.
"We've got a trend that's building considerable momentum," said Mr. Lunney of United Space. "It's not a question of doing it anymore. It's a matter of when and how."

GRAPHIC: Photo: On a past shuttle mission, astronauts maneuvered a retrieved satellite. (NASA/Hughes)(pg. F9)
 
Charts: "A Profit Center, 22,300 Miles Up"
Hundreds of satellites, dead and useless, are in orbits that keep them stationary above particular spots on Earth. Shuttles could make money by retrieving these craft for repairs or refueling and then lofting them back into orbit. Removing obsolete satellites could also clear valuable spots in orbits about 22,300 miles up, where orbiting craft remain in sync with Earth's rotation.

HEADLINE: Private-Suite Concept Is Coming to Broadway

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Skyboxes and luxury suites have all but saturated the sports world, providing cushy retreats for corporate executives and big-ticket fans in football stadiums and basketball arenas, at golf championships and tennis tournaments.
Now, the concept is coming to Broadway. When "Ragtime: The Musical" starts previews in December at the new Ford Center for the Performing Arts in Times Square, 50 tickets a performance, at $125 each, will be available for what the theater's developer describes as "V.I.P. suite service." Those ticket holders will be able to make use of a private suite beneath the theater's lobby where they can check coats, sip free cocktails and make use of uncrowded restrooms. Their seats will be center stage, rows 6 to 12. 
 The $125 price is $50 higher than that for the best orchestra seats at "Ragtime," but it is not a Broadway record. Producers of other shows have offered more expensive promotions. At "Victor/Victoria," the musical that closed this summer, a limited number of seats were available for $145 in the first two rows, with some amenities thrown into the package.
Livent, the Ford Center's developer, runs similar suites in theaters in Toronto and in Vancouver, British Columbia, and is building one in a theater now under construction in Chicago. Garth Drabinsky, chairman of Livent, said the special service would offer patrons "an evening at the theater that was complete, from the moment they walked in to the moment they left."
In recent years, a number of Broadway producers, seeking to attract corporate executives and their often lavish entertainment budgets, have marketed "champagne boxes" with free drinks and other perks, or "preferred" seating in the front rows, at premium prices. But space constraints at most theaters made it impossible to offer amenities in a private environment.
"You've got a certain clientele that is used to being pampered," said John Scher, a producer of "Victor/Victoria," who said he had unsuccessfully tried to offer a similar hospitality suite in the hotel adjacent to the Marquis Theater during the show's two-year run.
"This is long overdue," Mr. Scher said. "There's a higher tier of theatergoers that is used to being pampered at the great restaurants in Manhattan, in the private boxes at the Garden, the Meadowlands. Even the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark has dining rooms next to the private boxes."
Mr. Drabinsky insisted that the $50 price difference for V.I.P. tickets was justified by the perks associated with entry to the 850-square-foot basement room, which will be open before the show and during intermission, and will be staffed by three attendants.
But Paul Libin, vice president of the Jujamcyn Theaters Corporation, which owns five Broadway houses, called it a simple excuse to raise ticket prices. "No one has to pay $50 to hang up their coat and go to a bathroom in the basement," he said. "You're getting the best seats in the house, and you're paying a premium for it."
Others said that the advent of "business class" in the theater might take some business away from ticket brokers. "Business people already buy their tickets from brokers, because they can get better seats than you do from the box office," said Bernard Gersten, executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater. Mr. Drabinsky, he said, "is just cutting out the middleman."
Mr. Scher, who heads the Metropolitan Entertainment Group, said that the economics of Broadway, which are far less lucrative than those of professional sports, are forcing producers to search for every source of added income. "If there are any new theaters to be built in New York, every single one will try to create this kind of space," he said.
Whatever the result, Mr. Drabinsky said, the market for higher-priced seats, suites and perks appears to be a fertile one. Livent sold 2,000 V.I.P. tickets -- enough for 40 performances -- last Wednesday, its first day of sales.
Nicholas J. Verbitsky, president of United Stations Radio Networks, a company that produces radio programming for 3,000 stations, ordered four tickets to a mid-February performance of "Ragtime." "To entertain a station owner or an advertising executive and his or her spouse, for four tickets it's $200 -- that's money well spent," he said.
"You're not standing up getting a Coke at the refreshment stand, you're going to a private area," he added.
"It's supposedly exclusive. And the seats are right down in front. If you called up Ticketmaster, the seats wouldn't be available. And if you went to a scalper, it'd be a heck of a lot more money then $125."

HEADLINE: Welfare's New Face?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The most interesting point in your Sept. 11 front-page article on the changing image of welfare recipients is that state officials of both parties increasingly recognize that it is not so easy to save money reforming welfare. Most welfare recipients are likely at first to land low-paying jobs; thus the need for public investment in supplementing incomes continues. The demand for child care, health care, transportation, training and other services is likely to grow. 
 It is still too early to draw definitive conclusions. We do not know what might happen when the economy slows. But the early evidence shows that the social experiments under way in the states are not so much shrinking the safety net as redefining it. I hope the new definition of success goes beyond declining caseloads to emphasize true integration of the poor into our economy.
 
ANNA KONDRATAS
Washington, Sept. 12, 1997
 
The writer is co-director of the Urban Institute's Assessing the New Federalism project.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against the Mark On Hint of German Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday after the president of the Bundesbank hinted that it might soon raise interest rates.
The Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, said Germany would have less flexibility to raise interest rates after May 1998, when European officials will decide which countries will be part of the planned economic and monetary union. 
 There will be less room to maneuver on interest rates, Mr. Tietmeyer said, suggesting to currency traders that there was a greater likelihood that the central bank would raise rates before then. "The mark's starting to look more favorable on the threat of the Bundesbank raising rates," said Dave Moline, a currency trader at Norwest Bank.
Mr. Tietmeyer's remarks followed a decision by European Union finance ministers this weekend that they would announce in May 1998 the levels at which European currencies would be valued against each other when the single currency, the euro, is introduced. At the same time, they plan to announce which countries will take part.
European Union leaders are trying to avoid unexpected fluctuations in the currencies between May 1998 and Jan. 1, 1999, when the euro is set to begin. That will keep central bankers from making substantial changes in interest rates, or any other moves that could derail the project.
The decision is also heightening expectation that the Bundesbank will raise rates. Countries are expected to bring their interest rates in line with other members' rates.
In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.7629 marks, down from 1.7720 marks late Friday and 7 percent below an eight-year high reached Aug. 6. The dollar's weakness against the mark also helped it tumble to its lowest against the Swiss franc in two and a half months. The dollar was quoted at 1.4470 Swiss francs, down from 1.4635 Swiss francs. The British pound fell to $1.6051, from $1.6059.
The dollar fell against the yen amid concern over the rising United States trade deficit with Japan and as traders look to next weekend's meeting of the Group of Seven industrial countries in Hong Kong.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 120.31 yen, down from 120.96 yen on Friday.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Thorn to Appeal Ruling on Rental Stores

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The British rental company Thorn P.L.C. said today that it planned to appeal a United States ruling about its Rent-A-Center stores that could cost the company $120 million in damages.
A suit said the company, which "rents to own" household furnishings, charged its mostly low-income customers interest rates that exceeded state law. 
 Thorn said a New Jersey Superior Court judge ruled last week that the company owed customers fees and interest paid for furniture and small appliances at its Rent-A-Center stores.
The judge ruled that each customer was entitled to recover 40 percent of what had been paid to Rent-A-Center but that the awards could be trebled under the state's consumer fraud law.
Thorn's shares dropped about 7 percent, or 12 pence (19.3 cents), to 154 pence ($2.47) to rank among the biggest percentage losers on the London Stock Exchange today.
Thorn provisionally estimated total potential damages at $120 million before legal fees.
Thorn said judgments made under New Jersey law had no application beyond that state.
It has 24 stores in New Jersey out of a total of more than 1,400 stores throughout the United States.

HEADLINE: Albright Says She Found 'Tattered' Mideast Situation

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: SHANNON, Ireland, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Evaluating her first official trip to the Middle East, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today, "The crisis of confidence there is worse than I thought -- it's fairly tattered."
She will "stay absorbed" in the issue, she said en route home after her weeklong trip, but added that she had many other world problems to occupy her if Middle East leaders are not prepared to make basic decisions about working together. 
 "The responsibilities of the United States are so large that I can't be occupied with this full time," she said. "On the other hand, I will be available to go when it is necessary and to make a difference if I can."
"Probably more than at any other period of history, the Secretary of State of the United States is called upon to be involved in or part of a host of problems that require his, or, in this case her, attention," she said.
But it is important not to waste time and effort, she added, which was also a kind of warning to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.
"If I can make a difference, I will be there," she said. "I don't have to wait to be summoned by phone. But if there's not enough happening for me to make a difference, then I'm going to concentrate on what's happening in Cambodia, or on our summit with the Chinese, and Bosnia certainly and NATO expansion and meeting with the Russians in New York."
After a not-very-successful effort to keep secret her plans to stop in Beirut, the Lebanese capital, she made an emotional visit there today. She and her party flew from Larnaca, Cyprus, in three American military helicopters with no markings and traveled in an armed convoy flanked by trucks with light machine guns protruding from their roofs.
It was the first such visit to Beirut by a Secretary of State since March 1993, although Warren Christopher visited Lebanese leaders in southern Lebanon in April 1996. Ms. Albright recently lifted the legal ban on the use of American passports to travel to Lebanon, a move appreciated by Lebanon's leaders, while Washington still issues strong official warnings about the dangers of travel there.
In her speech in Beirut today, she stressed to officials and about 70 carefully invited citizens America's support for Lebanon's "sovereignty and territorial integrity" -- despite the Syrian and Israeli troops that have been stationed there for years.
She also made it clear that Washington would not accept a final peace in the Middle East that left Lebanon occupied or divided, although she did not mention Syria or Israel by name. "We respect your vision of a Lebanon that is not beholden to any foreign power," she said.
And she described her effort to revive Israeli-Syrian and Israeli-Lebanese peace talks this way: "Here, too, we have at least agreed to talk further about further talks. In the absence of a peace elevator, we are methodically taking the stairs."
Despite the crisis of confidence she found in the Middle East, she felt she had made a small beginning, she told reporters on her plane. "I said I was going there to give them a reality check," she said. "So I decided to be really unvarnished in the way I stated the case."
She said early steps by Mr. Arafat to move against the infrastructure of terrorism and by Mr. Netanyahu to ease the economic pressures on Mr. Arafat "are useful" and "move in the right direction."
Whatever the leaders think about each other, she said, "the fact is that they must work with one another, and the term 'necessary partners,' I think, becomes the key." One of her main themes wherever she went, she said, was "mutual responsibility for the peace process."
The fight against terrorism is separate and primary, she said. But by mutual responsibility for the Arabs, she said she meant ending "the war of words" against Israel and the habit of going to the Security Council to seek a condemnation of the Israelis at every moment. "It inflames the situation, and frankly it was one of the points I discussed with them when I said the other Arab nations also had a responsibility for the peace process," she said.
At least the parties will be talking again, she said, citing a new round of discussions in Washington on Sept. 23 between Israel and the Palestinians, with a follow-up meeting by foreign ministers. Later this month in New York, she is to hold individual meetings with the Israeli and Syrian Foreign Ministers.
"I'm pleased with some of the things I've seen, but we've a long way to go," she said. "But I am not going to overestimate what's going on here."

HEADLINE: A Promise Is Kept: Mill Reopens

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 14

 BODY:
All in all, this was a very good day for Aaron Feuerstein, owner of Malden Mills and national poster mensch of the nascent American business vogue for having a heart, better known as corporate responsibility.
President Clinton sent congratulations. Thousands of Mr. Feuerstein's employees and their families celebrated the dedication of his gleaming, new $130 million factory in the streets of this old Massachusetts mill town. And best of all, Mr. Feuerstein could announce that true to his word, just 21 months after the heart of his textile plant burned to the ground, he has rebuilt it here and rehired nearly all of his 2,700 workers. 
 "I thank you, God, for most this amazing day -- I who have died am alive again today," Mr. Feuerstein said, quoting E. E. Cummings, and then moved, with his usual theatrical combination of literary erudition and Orthodox Jewish tradition, to a version of a Hebrew prayer: "I thank you, majestic God of the universe, for restoring to Malden Mills and its employees, our life and soul."
The plant, which produces Polartec and Polarfleece, the warm, light-weight synthetic material used mainly in outdoor clothing, is back, at more than 100 percent of its capacity at the time of the fire, he said. Officials say the company's sales are up 40 percent since the fire, in December 1995, its productivity is up 25 percent, and the company plans to bring back the last 70 of its workers within two months.
In late 1995, when American industry was still enmeshed in a period of painful downsizing, Mr. Feuerstein took a dramatic and very public gamble: after a Christmas-season fire and explosion ravaged three critical plant buildings with a total of 600,000 square feet, he promised to rebuild here instead of taking the $300 million in insurance money and moving the plant to another state or even Mexico.
He was also protecting a booming business and a highly skilled work force, but with that pledge, he turned himself into a national symbol, hailed by the White House, unions and the press, of a company's loyalty to its workers.
Today, jubilant attendees at the dedication continued to attribute a broader symbolism to Mr. Feuerstein, this time to his success: It is an example, said Jay Mazur, national president of Unite!, the garment workers' union, of "taking the high road to make the product better instead of the low road of cheapening the product, downsizing the workers and running away to another location."
"Let's hear it for America's number one mensch," proclaimed Robert B. Reich, the former Secretary of Labor, using the Yiddish word for a honorable person.
Mr. Feuerstein's loyalty is not unique. After a January 1995 fire in LaGrange, Ga., at the biggest plant owned by Milliken and Company, the largest privately-held textile company in the country, the owner, Roger Milliken, promised its 680 workers that it would be back in production within six months. He gave them jobs at other plants at the same pay until they returned to the plant that had burned.
Also, economists note, Mr. Feuerstein's commitment to keep his plant and its 2,700 jobs in this northeastern Massachusetts town might not have worked if the company had not already been on a roll, making high-technology, high-performance products for which there is a potent niche demand.
"To understand the Malden Mills story, one has to understand a larger shift in the industry, and the fact that Aaron Feuerstein is a brilliant businessman at understanding that," said David Weil, a textile industry expert at Boston University's school of management.
Mr. Feuerstein, he said, had already managed to refine a high-quality product and maintain great flexibility and speed in filling customers' orders. He also had assembled a highly skilled work force that he had great incentive to keep.
But that, Mr. Weil hastened to add, is not to take away from Mr. Feuerstein's ethically admirable decision to keep his company here.
The driving force behind his decision, Mr. Feuerstein told the dedication crowd, was his conviction that "there was no way that I was going to take 3,000 people and throw them into the street. And there was no way I was going to condemn Lawrence to economic oblivion. No."
Though it was that single-minded tenacity that gained him so much attention, Mr. Feuerstein also serves as an example of how to solicit outside help. Federal, state and local politicians from senators to mayors, union leaders and lenders all helped get Malden Mills, which is an economic anchor of northeastern Massachusetts, through its crisis.
Not everyone could call on BankBoston for money to tide over the company until the insurance settlement came through and be patted on the back and told not to worry by the chief executive officer, Chad Gifford, of that regional powerhouse bank.
But any company owner would aspire to the kind of gleaming-eyed, standing-ovation appreciation that Mr. Feueurstein, 72, is now accorded by his employees.
"The community loves him very much and it's not hype and it's not the upper class, it's the people," said Julio Fernandez, a machine operator. "He treats all the employees with the utmost respect."
And he plans to continue doing so for a long time, said Mr. Feuerstein's wife, Louise. The designated worrier in the family, she expresses concern even now about whether the company's success will continue, especially under the pressure of its heightened visibility. But one thing she knows about her husband: "He has no plans whatsoever to ever retire."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Aaron Feuerstein, chief executive of Malden Mills, raising the flag at the dedication of the company's new textile manufacturing plant in Lawrence, Mass. A fire partly destroyed the mills in December 1995. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Havana Seeks Death Sentence For American

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Cuban prosecutors are seeking the death penalty for an American citizen held in Cuba on charges of working for a "terrorist" group in Miami, diplomats said today.
The diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the American citizen, Walter Van der Veer, had been held since Aug. 21, 1996. 
 In March, Cuba's state television described Mr. Van der Veer as a "highly dangerous mercenary" and "an agent of a terrorist organization in Miami" and said his operations were financed and directed by a Miami-based Cuban exile group, which it identified as the Cuban Liberation Front.
The report said he had smuggled military equipment including incendiary devices into Cuba and planned actions against unspecified "socio-economic, religious and military centers" with the aim of "subverting internal order and the stability of our nation."
In Miami, a lawyer for Mr. Van der Veer, Ellis Rubin, said he would urge the United States Government to intercede on Mr. Van der Veer's behalf.
Mr. Rubin said today that Mr. Van der Veer had been on a charity mission to Cuba on behalf of the Church of the Little Flower in Coral Gables, Fla.
At the time of his arrest, associates described Mr. Van der Veer, 51, as both an anti-Castro commando and a humanitarian worker. But his trip to Cuba had no military aims, they said.
Mr. Rubin said he had not been allowed to go to Cuba to represent Mr. Van der Veer, and said he would appeal to President Clinton and the State Department to monitor the situation.
The diplomats said officials of the United States Interests Section in Havana had been allowed access to Mr. Van der Veer.
No trial date has been set.
Cuban authorities contend that Cuban exiles are organizing and financing attempts to try to overthrow the Government.

HEADLINE: Equity Office Properties to Absorb Beacon

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Equity Office Properties Trust, which Sam Zell had already fashioned into the nation's largest publicly traded office real estate empire, today announced plans to acquire the Beacon Properties Corporation, its nearest competitor, in a merger valued at about $2.9 billion plus debt.
Mr. Zell, a billionaire with a legendary eye for undervalued real estate and companies, called the deal a "one plus one equals three opportunity." He said it would give Equity Office the leverage in crucial markets to negotiate better deals with large tenants and with suppliers of building services and equipment. The more immediate payback would be a $15 million to $20 million savings from closing overlapping administrative offices, he said. 
 The merger would leave Equity, which is based here, as a leading owner of prime office space in Boston, Atlanta, Washington, Dallas, Philadelphia, Los Angeles and San Francisco as well as Chicago. Just over half of its 233 office buildings would be suburban. Equity Office also owns a chain of urban parking garages that can be marketed along with its buildings.
"We view ourselves as the dominant player in a gigantic industry," Mr. Zell said in a conference call with analysts. "Our scale will separate us from everyone else."
Analysts said that the deal spotlighted the growing clout of publicly owned real estate trusts, known as REIT's, and consolidation in the industry as leading investors race to accumulate assets. However, despite Mr. Zell's talk of dominance, Equity Office would still own less than 2 percent of the nation's prime office real estate. Analysts calculate that Equity Office already owns nearly half of the Stamford, Conn., market, but Equity Office's share in the biggest urban markets is under 10 percent.
Still, analysts agreed that the deal was a blockbuster likely to enhance Mr. Zell's reputation as a champion of REIT's. He also controls REIT's that are the largest players in the mobile home and apartment sectors.
Many analysts were surprised not that Mr. Zell wanted the merger but that Beacon, which is based in Boston, would so willingly give up its freedom. It was the fastest-growing REIT in the country during the second quarter of this year and had been performing well. Alan M. Leventhal, president and chief executive of Beacon, which his family built up over two generations and took public four years ago, said the deal began taking shape when he and Mr. Zell met on vacation in New Hampshire in August.
"Our outlook on the marketplace is very similar," said Mr. Leventhal, who will join Equity Office's board along with Edwin Sidman, Beacon's chairman, but will have no direct role in management. At current prices, Beacon shareholders will end up owning slightly more than one-third of Equity Office after completion of the deal, which is expected early next year.
"It's probably a win-win for both companies," said Edward Linde, president of Boston Properties Inc., a major office REIT based in New York that also recently went public.
Beacon's shares jumped $6, to $42.625, in heavy trading on the Big Board following the announcement. Although Equity Office executives said the deal would immediately improve the company's earnings and reduce its debt, investors were nervous. Shares of Equity Office , which had jumped more than 50 percent since the company went public at $21 a share July 8, fell $1.375, to $31.6875.
Under the deal, each Beacon shareholder will receive 1.4063 Equity Office common shares, and Equity will assume $883 million of Beacon debt and issue $200 million in preferred stock.
"It's a very rich price for Beacon, about a 40 percent premium to the underlying value of Beacon's assets," said John Lutzius, an analyst with Green Street Advisors Inc., a Newport Beach, Calif., firm that specializes in real estate research for institutional investors.
Whether the deal pays off or not depends in part on whether Mr. Zell's rosy assessment of the office market is correct. Mr. Zell began buying office buildings for investment funds he managed in the 1980's. His backers included insurance companies like Allstate and large pension funds. The various investment funds were brought together to form Equity Office, which sold just under 16 percent of its shares to the public in the July offering.
Equity Office was wildly popular with investors because rents in many cities have soared. A combination of economic growth and a shortage of new buildings has bolstered occupancy rates.
Mr. Zell said today that he believed rents would have to climb 30 percent to 40 percent more before Equity Office and other building owners start running into serious competition from new building projects. In some key markets like San Francisco and Boston, the barriers to new building are especially high, he said.
"We expect clear sailing for the next few years," Mr. Zell said.
Some real estate experts said Equity Office might be overestimating the value of large-scale operations in its segment of the real estate industry.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
A New York Bank To Stay in the Bronx

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Spurred by a package of city tax incentives, the New York National Bank has decided against moving out of New York and will instead move its corporate headquarters to another part of the South Bronx, where it will also open a new branch, the city announced yesterday.
The privately held bank, the only minority-owned commercial bank in the state, had planned to move its headquarters at 960 Southern Boulevard to Westchester County. But under an agreement with the city's Economic Development Corporation, the bank will receive a maximum of about $448,000 in sales tax exemptions and $75,000 in energy discounts. The bank will also receive up to $195,000 in additional sales tax exemptions if it creates 73 new jobs over the next 20 years. 
 "We are pleased that we have identified a site that will insure our ability to keep our headquarters and back-office personnel here in the South Bronx," said Serafin Mariel, president and chief executive officer of the bank, which has 67 employees.
The bank will invest $1.1 million in capital improvements at its new headquarters, a 30,000-square-foot building, at 369 East 149th Street near Third Avenue, which will also house its new branch.
 DAVID W. CHEN
