HEADLINE: Downsizing Activism: Greenpeace Is Cutting Back

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
After 48 hours of daredevil dangling on ropes from a bridge in Seattle, trying to block outgoing trawlers in a recent protest against overfishing, Greenpeace staff members returned to solid ground, only to be told that the environmental group had just laid three of them off.
Here in Boston last week, a staff member in the group's Back Bay office unhappily carted out a giant Greenpeace sign, no longer needed now that the place was all but abandoned. And in a handful of other cities from Minneapolis to Santa Cruz, Calif., Greenpeace offices had been dismantled or were in the last stages of closing. 
 Around the country, Greenpeace officials say, the world's best-known environmental action group is suffering through the biggest retrenchment it has ever seen in the United States. It is disassembling all 10 of its permanent branch offices and ending the signature door-to-door canvassing that led one critic to call it the Avon Lady of the environmental movement.
It is also laying off about 335 of its 400 staff members, most of them canvassers. The spirit is still willing, officials say, but the finances are weak, and in the face of plummeting membership and a deficit of $2.6 million halfway through the year, Greenpeace is cutting its annual budget in the United States to $21 million from $29 million. The group is also narrowing its focus, planning to concentrate more on campaigns against global warming and forest destruction and somewhat less on toxic waste and overfishing.
"If this is a signal that the public has become so apathetic or uninformed about our environmental devastation, it's tragic," said Niaz Dorry, the Boston staff member carting off the sign for a smaller office in Gloucester, Mass.
Since its grandstanding beginning in 1971, when a dozen protesters in a small boat sought to block nuclear testing in the Aleutian Islands, Greenpeace has weathered many an internal storm, many a tactical mistake and many a cutback.
But the scale of the current downsizing has prompted a new spell of particularly intense soul-searching, and the 170-member board of the United States arm of Greenpeace met in Washington last weekend to discuss what went wrong and what should be done.
Greenpeace International has offices in 32 countries, a worldwide budget of nearly $146 million and worldwide membership of almost 3 million people. Global membership has remained stable while the United States organization's memberships have fallen. Because Greenpeace is expanding its work in Asian and Latin American countries -- work that the United States offices subsidize -- it can no longer afford a financial drain in its American operations, said Kristen Engberg, acting director in the United States.
The United States group's cutbacks have prompted outsiders to analyze what the group's problems say about how environmental organizations in this country have had to change in the last few years as the world has changed around them.
The whales are pretty well saved, environmental historians and top officials in several other national groups say; the Clinton White House is generally friendly to the environment; many more businesses try to respect the environment than ever before, and other national groups have developed highly sophisticated lobbying and outreach methods.
It could well be, some said, that in an era when environmental issues seem to hinge more on complex trade-offs than on an all-or-nothing approach, the time has passed for the classic Greenpeace tactics of telegenic "direct actions" in which protesters rode tiny inflatable motorboats to face down whalers.
Greenpeace, said Rindy O'Brien, vice president of public policy for the Wilderness Society, has tended to look for ways to publicize problems instead of ways to actually solve them. Her comments echoed longstanding criticism by others that Greenpeace is too much of a self-promotion machine.
"I do think the public, in more of the political realm, are looking for solutions rather than maybe extremists," Ms. O'Brien said, "and I think that separates Greenpeace from the other environmental groups."
Four things happened that hurt Greenpeace, said a top official at another environmental group who insisted on anonymity. With an international moratorium on commercial whaling, Greenpeace lost a flagship issue; its tactics became more familiar and so drew less attention; it fell into a debilitating internal debate about its own mission, and it shifted more toward helping local environmental groups behind the scenes, which lowered its profile.
"They ended up with a confused and weak public perception of what they were," the official said. "They're not really a grass-roots organization like the Sierra Club or the Audubon Society. When people stopped seeing Greenpeace on TV and started reading confusing things about it, they drifted away."
But Greenpeace officials say that though they will be narrowing their focus and shifting from permanent branch offices to mobile campaign teams, their basic philosophy and tactics of uncompromising, high-profile protests will remain in force. And they have always sought solutions with industry and government, the officials say, but those efforts never received wide attention.
The cutbacks, Greenpeace staff members say, are mainly a reflection of past poor management, including shoddy record-keeping that allowed membership to drop to about 400,000 from 1.2 million in 1991, and annual United States donations to fall to about $25 million from $45 million. The staff members also say that by dropping the canvassers and the offices from which they worked, the organization can do its work more efficiently.
"The canvass was a costly operation in terms of its administrative and overhead cost," said Ms. Engberg, the acting director. "By having these fixed costs of 10 offices, it gave the U.S. organization less flexibility in how it could spend its money on campaigning."
The canvassers' function was dual: They signed people up for dues-paying memberships, at a minimum of $30 a year for those who wanted to receive the group's magazine, and educated them on current issues and campaigns.
Greenpeace International has been headed for the last two years by Thilo Bode, a bottom-line German economist who has also overseen the streamlining of several offices in other countries.
But the United States group is particularly important, said Ms. Engberg, because each national office sets aside a percentage of its proceeds to be redistributed for work in needier countries. The United States organization, which contributes 18 percent, is one of the four biggest Greenpeace branches, she said.
"It's a very difficult but necessary decision for the health of Greenpeace around the world," Ms. Engberg said.
As Greenpeace's work has stabilized in Western countries, the international organization has focused increasingly on environmental problems in Southeast Asia, China and Latin America -- work it needs American money to help pay for.
The decision to cut back the United States offices was made by the organization's board of directors for the United States, an executive group that could not be overridden at the meeting last weekend of the board of all voting members. The weekend meeting created a committee to plot a strategy for the future of Greenpeace in the United States.
Greenpeace staff members in United States offices also attributed the downsizing to new competition for charity money from social service groups in this period of cutbacks in Government support for the poor.
"We used to compete with other environmental organizations," said Mark Floegel, a Seattle staff member who is being laid off. "Now we compete with the homeless. People who gave $50 a year to Greenpeace now have to decide between that and Save the Children and a homeless shelter."
Other national environmental groups, however, say that their membership and donations have stayed about steady over the last several years. In the period when Greenpeace lost 800,000 members, for example, the Sierra Club has stayed roughly steady at 600,000 and the Wilderness Society at 250,000.
The main explanation, some Greenpeace officials acknowledge, may be that the group was simply not equipped to sustain the membership boom that occurred after French frogmen sank the group's ship, the Rainbow Warrior, while it was trying to block nuclear testing in the Pacific in 1985.
"There's no question our development office made tremendous mistakes," said Dave Batke, a research coordinator in the Seattle office. "Names were not entered when people joined Greenpeace. There was some mismanagement."
Faulty recruitment arrangements may be relatively simple to remedy; what is less clear to both members and environmental historians is whether the tactic of closing branch offices, while keeping its Washington headquarters largely intact, is a good idea.
"If they're going to concentrate on Beltway stuff, they're getting into a crowded market," said Philip Shabecoff, a former reporter for The New York Times and author of "A New Name for Peace," (University Press of New England, 1996), a book on international environmentalism. "I personally think it's a big mistake for Greenpeace. They had their own mission in the environmental movement -- they were kind of the troublemakers, the people who made noise and raised tension on issues, and on top of that they were one of the few national groups that actually went out door to door."
Aside from possible doubts about the decision, staff members in Greenpeace offices around the country have been grappling with the pain of losing jobs that are much more than jobs to most.
"Certain jobs I've had in my life were 9-to-5 jobs," said Mr. Floegel in Seattle. "Greenpeace is a way people identify themselves. It's like if you take a bunch of priests and tell them they're laid off because of cutbacks.
"There's a sense of loss about the work. That's ahead of people's concern for their well-being and how they're going to make the rent."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rise As Investors Await Reports

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday as investors waited for today's reports on consumer prices and industrial production and capacity utilization in August, which are expected to provide more proof that the economy is expanding at a noninflationary pace.
The 30-year bond gained 6/32, to 97 15/32, to yield 6.57 percent, down from 6.58 percent at the close on Friday. 
 Friday's reports on retail sales and producer prices for August, which were not as negative as the market had feared, quieted worries that the Federal Reserve was likely to increase short-term interest rates at its monetary policy meeting on Sept. 30.
Michelle Laughlin, Treasury market strategist at Prudential Securities, expects the market to focus on the Consumer Price Index. "Our forecast of five-tenths of a percent over all, and three-tenths of a percent excluding food and energy, is above the consensus of three-tenths of a percent and two-tenths of a percent, respectively," she said, noting that last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics warned that the index could spike in August because of rising gasoline prices, which were exaggerated by seasonal factors.
She said that an unfavorable index "will not alter our outlook for continued low inflation." Ms. Laughlin said she did not expect the Fed to move, even in November, and added, "The odds are less than 50 percent they will move between now and year-end."
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the light trading yesterday appeared to be a squaring of positions by traders ahead of today's consumer price report.
"The market reached a technical level at the close of trading." Mr. Regan said yesterday, "which would indicate that favorable noninflationary data in the numbers tomorrow will propel the long bond up another half to three quarters of a point in price. That would push the yield closer to the 6.50 percent level."
The price report will be important, but if the other indicators like industrial production and capacity, coupled with business inventories, are in line with expectations, Mr. Regan said, the market may move up.
Other factors affecting the market will be the scheduled release of the Fed's beige book report on regional economic conditions tomorrow, in preparation for the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, and an announcement by the Treasury of the size of its auctions of two- and five-year notes the following week.
"There is some speculation among market participants that there could be a draw-down in the auction amounts," Mr. Regan said. "My opinion is that the Treasury would not like to have a liquidity crunch."
Rates at yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills dropped modestly, with the average for a three-month maturity down 10 basis points, to 4.91 percent, and a six-month down 6 basis points, to 5.08 percent. A basis point is one hundredth of 1 percent.
Kim Rupert, a San Francisco-based economist at Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm, said the bill auction was worse than expected, considering the reinvestment demand from the $44 billion in cash management bills maturing this week.
"It looks as though they are a bit too rich, having gotten expensive over the last few days," Ms. Rupert said. One reason is that the Treasury has reduced the supply of bills by $1 billion.
The following are the results of yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Prison in the Forest;
The Itinerant Jailer Is an Adirondack Plan's Best Booster

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: TUPPER LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 10

 BODY:
In the Adirondacks, Richard Moeller is the prototypical migrant worker, though you might not realize it from his job description. He does not pick vegetables, trap beaver or sell encyclopedias. He is a prison guard.
Each week for the past three years, he has traveled hundreds of miles from home -- as far as Sing Sing Correctional Facility, 250 miles to the south in Ossining -- to watch over some of the state's most violent convicts. At night, he sleeps on a mattress in a rented room, alongside a dozen other men, counting the hours until his days off. All because guarding inmates is among the steadiest, best-paying jobs a man from the North Country can find. 
 But Mr. Moeller, who has three brothers who are also prison guards, has never thought about moving his family out of Tupper Lake to be closer to his job. Life in the city, as he refers to Westchester County and Utica, where he now works, is too dirty and crime ridden, he says. And where else could he afford a rustic, 12-acre spread like the one he owns now?
So it comes as no surprise that Mr. Moeller, 27, and his brothers are thrilled that the New York State Legislature decided last month to build a 750-cell maximum-security prison on the outskirts of Tupper Lake. Along with about 170 other correction officers who live in this village of 4,100 residents, they are hoping the new prison will finally spell an end to their long commutes.
"This is where I want to make my home," he said.
But the prison has touched off a fierce debate over the future of this mountainous region that has pitted neighbor against neighbor, worker against worker, even sibling against sibling. The fight has focused not just on Tupper Lake, but on the entire Adirondack Park, six million mostly pristine acres of public and private land that includes 4,000 lakes and ponds, the source of the Hudson River and the state's highest peaks.
To critics, the verdant North Country has become overly dependent on the penitentiary business, whose latest growth spurt is being fueled by tougher prison sentences established by the Legislature in 1995. Tupper Lake would be the fifth state prison inside what is known as the blue line, the boundaries of the largest American park outside Alaska. If the counties bordering Adirondack Park are included, there are 14 prisons in the North Country, holding a total of nearly 15,000 inmates.
But the critics contend that each new prison detracts from the natural beauty of the place, discouraging efforts to make the Adirondacks a more popular destination for tourists and nature lovers. And they question why the state is building a prison at Tupper Lake even as it tries to prevent development on nearby Whitney Park, 51,000 unspoiled acres owned by the descendents of William C. Whitney, the industrialist who built a fortune on oil, tobacco and New York City streetcars a century ago.
"This does not capitalize on the special qualities of the park," said Eric J. Siy, Adirondack project director for Environmental Advocates, a nonprofit group. "It diminishes those qualities."
But to supporters of the prison, including most of the region's elected officials and many business owners, such critics are out of touch with the hardscrabble reality of the Adirondacks. With double-digit unemployment rates during the long winters, a dying logging industry and downtowns that are pockmarked by vacant storefronts, the region desperately needs the economic lift that prisons can provide, they say.
"If your kids can't find a good job, they leave," said Robert J. Bierwirth, 49, who owns the local McDonald's. "That's why having a prison is held in such high regard. We'd rather have I.B.M. But realistically, a prison is what we can get."
Many business owners said news of the prison gave them newfound confidence in the local economy. With a $130 million price tag, the prison is expected to generate scores of local construction jobs. And when it is completed, possibly in 1999, it is expected to create more than 100 permanent jobs and pump $19 million each year into the economy.
As a result, Mr. Bierwirth has scrapped plans to sell and now wants to expand. A developer is talking about building the town's first indoor mall. And prison guards from other towns have begun inquiring about buying houses in Tupper Lake.
One businessman, Peter S. Day, said he used to oppose the prison on the ground that it would hurt business at the Big Tupper Ski Area, which he owns. But he became a convert a few winters ago when he saw a dozen prison guards at his bar, buying drinks and lunch. They had rearranged their work schedules so they could ski midweek, when the lift lines were short -- a flexibility that was not lost on Mr. Day.
"The Adirondacks have broken a lot of men," said Mr. Day, noting that the average prison guard earns $35,000 a year, well above the local median income of about $25,000. "It's remote. It's inhospitable in winter. There's nothing much here to make a living off of. We need all the help we can get."
The prison will be the state's first maximum-security penitentiary in nine years. Plans call for it to be built on a 100-acre tree farm in an area zoned for an industrial park. It will house as many as 1,500 prisoners, most of whom will be those deemed disciplinary problems and transferred from other prisons.
Its obstreperous inmates will be kept in 105-square-foot cells all day, minimizing contact with guards and other prisoners alike. Meals will be eaten in cells, and even exercise time will be spent in tiny areas attached to each cell.
The prison will employ up to 367 workers, 223 of them guards. Under union rules, all of the guard jobs will be filled by transfers from other state prisons. The remaining 110 to 140 support staff jobs will be filled largely from the local workforce.
Though a few environmental advocates are opposing the prison, others have withheld judgment, saying they might be willing to accept it provided it meets all the region's tough environmental standards.
"This is a major facility that has esthetic impacts, waste-water impacts, water usage impacts," said Bernard Melewski, counsel to the Adirondack Council, a nonprofit group. "We're at the beginning of the process. This is no different from siting any other major industrial facility."
Residents who oppose the prison raise other objections. Some say they fear breakouts. Others complain that "prison glow" will ruin their gloriously starry night skies. Or that prisoners' families will move to town. Or that taxes and electric rates will rise. Or that tourists will stay away.
Some of those opponents say they have been ostracized, occasionally threatened, and had their businesses boycotted by prison advocates.
"There are a lot of people who are afraid to come forth and say they oppose it, because they fear retaliation," said Michael Trivieri, a 34-year-old logger and woodcarver.
Supporters say the prison will barely be noticed, because it will be in a forest, nearly two miles from the nearest main road. "Out of sight, out of mind," said Dean D. Lefebvre, supervisor of the Town of Altamont, which encompasses Tupper Lake, and one of the first advocates of the prison.
People like Mr. Lefebvre say opponents of the prison are a tiny but loud minority consisting mainly of out-of-town environmentalists, residents with stable government salaries, like teachers, and affluent owners of vacation homes who do not understand the struggles of unemployed loggers and small-business owners.
Settled in the mid-1800's mainly by French Canadian trappers, the town has undergone a variety of makeovers. At the turn of the century, logging dominated its economy. By the 1950's, tourism was fueling a boom, and there were 39 bars and restaurants, more than a dozen hotels, four sawmills and a vibrant shopping district.
But the 1960's were the start of a steady slide. The train line shut down. Logging companies moved away and all but one of the mills closed. The population shrank and the state became the largest employer, with about 700 workers at the Sunmount Developmental Disabilities Services Office.
The Northland Hotel is now boarded up; the 330 Lodge is a burned-out hulk. Storefronts are vacant and the weekday traffic is thin.
Most business owners in town want the prison. "Some of that money has to trickle down here," said George Kallasy, owner of the Swiss Kitchen. Asked about opposition, he said, "Some people would complain if Santa Claus gave out $10 bills."
But across the street, Joyce Vincent Moody, owner of the Adirondack Company, among the town's only upscale boutiques, says she is thinking of moving because of the prison.
"It's not what I want to see for my hometown," said Ms. Vincent Moody, 43, the mother of two. "Yes, my business is hurting; we all need something. But the only ones this will help are the Realtors, fast-food restaurants, bars, convenience stores. For the other small businesses, I don't see much coming from it."
Such comments exasperate State Senator Ronald B. Stafford, a Republican of Plattsburgh, who waged a fierce fight in the Senate to bring the prison to his district. Mr. Stafford was among the first legislators to recognize the prison industry's economic potential. Since taking office in 1966, he has brought nine into a district that already had two.
The Senator can speak from personal experience about prison town life: he grew up a stone's throw from Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, where his father was a guard. "I feel fortunate to have grown up there," he said. "Prison towns are great communities."

Map of New York State showing location of Tupper Lake: The Adirondacks are rich with prisons, and set to get another. (pg. B7)

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: How Long Will Good Times Roll?

 BODY:
Steady growth for six and a half years. Low and steady inflation. Unemployment under 5 percent, the lowest level in decades. Productivity -- the amount of workers' output -- rising at the fastest clip in years. Stock markets soaring to dizzying heights.
The economic cheer is unrelenting. The question consuming Wall Street and Main Street is whether the good news is forever. 
 For some, 15 years of nearly uninterrupted growth portends a new world where downturns hardly exist and policy makers can chuck time-honored caution. Some corporate C.E.O.'s, union officials and financial experts call on the Federal Reserve to rev up the economy faster because, they say, the inflation dragon is extinct. But sweet dreams make for irresponsible policy. Good times will not last forever. They will end as they have in the past -- because of a major policy blunder or shock from abroad.
Economists can no more predict the timing of the next recession than they can that of the next crash on stock markets or boom on bond markets. But those who track the economy say that its structure today differs little from that of the recent past. That means the economy will continue to expand by 2 or 3 percent a year, largely reflecting increases in population and improvements in technology. That pace will not excite those who lived through the halcyon days of the 1950's and 60's, but those were years of aberrant growth following the Depression and World War II.
Recessions have interrupted growth throughout the postwar years. In nearly every case the downturn was preceded by a large and visible shock. In the 1960's the shock came from policy makers in Washington. President Johnson made the fateful decision to pay for the Vietnam War without raising taxes. Inflation soared, forcing the Federal Reserve to crack down at the end of the decade. In the 1970's, the shock came from Middle Eastern nations that drove oil prices sky-high and triggered inflation. Once again the Fed clamped down, producing years of recession and stagnation. Only in 1990 was there recession without a strong shock, though some economists believe that the small, short-lived downturn was provoked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
What distinguishes the steady growth of the 1990's from these earlier decades is not the inner workings of the economy, but rather the absence of shocks. Can good luck prevail? There are grounds for optimism. The recent budget deal, however misguided its priorities, commits Washington to paying its bills without much borrowing. Chairman Alan Greenspan of the Fed has set monetary policy on a responsible course. The country cannot fully insulate itself from imploding financial markets in Asia or the antics of Saddam Hussein. But at least the wounds will not be self-inflicted.
In the past, low and falling unemployment rates compelled workers to demand, and win, substantial wage hikes. Yet 78 months into the current recovery, wages, corrected for inflation, are rising more slowly than productivity. That is a needless blow to workers, some of whom have not enjoyed a wage hike, after accounting for inflation, since the 1970's. Fortunately, workers are likely to catch up. Over the long sweep of American experience, the more workers produce, the more they take home.
If wages rise along with productivity, corporate profits will not be affected and companies will have no need to raise prices. But wage hikes are two-edged. If they rise too rapidly, they could lead to price hikes and a Fed crackdown to control inflation, which would slow the economy and drive up unemployment. So the trade-offs built into the fabric of every market economy linger. The boldest new thing about the 90's economy is its uninterrupted luck.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Party Lines Don't Define Debate: Clinton's Foes on Trade Bill Are Democrats

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The textile workers turned out in force, wearing white T-shirts emblazoned with the name of their union. Before them, on easels, colored charts tracked the United States trade imbalance with Mexico and the size of Mexican wages. And at center stage Representative David E. Bonior, the House minority floor leader, railed against the trade policies of his fellow Democrat, the President.
"The Clinton Administration is moving us in the wrong direction," the Michigan Democrat said at the "teach-in" last week in a House office building. "With a lot of talk about building bridges to the 21st century, they are dragging us backward towards 19th century conditions -- lower wages, weaker consumer protection, a dirtier environment." 
 The scene illustrated the difficult political terrain facing President Clinton as he prepared to submit legislation on Tuesday to renew his authority to negotiate trade agreements that Congress can approve or reject but not amend. For Democrats, the looming Congressional struggle over the so-called fast-track trade legislation is as much about the direction of the post-Clinton party as it is about trade. It is so divisive that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore both planned to argue their cases before House Democrats on Tuesday.
The dispute pits Democrats who believe the new global economy is to be embraced as the key to economic growth against those in their party who think globalization threatens to erode the living standards of American workers unless aggressively policed and managed by government.
"I know that we have often disagreed on this," Mr. Clinton told the Service Employees International Union in Washington today, "I just want to say one more time, our analysis is that between one quarter and one third of our economic growth that made 13 million jobs in the last four years came because we are selling more American products overseas."
 Vice President Al Gore and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, who is expected to challenge him for the Democratic nomination in 2000, have staked out opposing sides in the debate. And labor, bolstered by victory in the recent United Parcel Service strike, is organizing a drive against the trade initiative, including television advertisements in the districts of undecided lawmakers.
The Democratic division leaves Mr. Clinton more reliant than ever on the Republicans in Congress, who traditionally support free trade. But Republican conservatives, particularly in the House, are increasingly restive about their leaders' cooperation with Mr. Clinton, leaving Republican leaders pressed to extract favors from the President in return.
While the White House chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, declined to comment, other White House officials said Mr. Bowles had already rebuffed one effort by Speaker Newt Gingrich to trade Republican backing for the trade legislation for Administration support for the party's position on how the 2000 Census should be conducted. Republicans want to ban the use of statistical sampling in the Census, fearful that it could count more minorities and cost them control of the House after the next reapportionment.
The last time Mr. Clinton faced the Congress on a similar trade issue, the North American Free Trade Agreement, in 1993, he won mostly with Republican votes.
But since then, control of Congress has changed hands and the makeup has changed significantly, leading to uncertain vote forecasts. "This is untested," said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, which controls trade legislation. "With the freshmen and sophomores, it's unclear what their position will be."
In the House, Republican officials say that unless Mr. Clinton delivers 80 to 100 Democratic votes, they expect support for the trade measure to diminish among Republicans. Administration officials say they can win if they gain the support of 50 of the House's 206 Democrats. But they admit they are short of that.
Aware of the Democratic discontent, Mr. Clinton last week delayed introducing legislation, as his aides worked to bring over more Democrats, particularly Senator Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader. The White House hopes to use Mr. Daschle to counter Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Bonior, who are expected to be staunch opponents.
Many Democrats want Mr. Clinton to draft a proposal that links labor and environmental issues to trade pacts to prevent developing nations' gaining a competitive advantage over the United States though law wages and poor pollution controls.
But aware that such provisions, if too broadly drawn, could erode Republican and business support, the President instead will try to reassure Democrats that he address labor and environmental concerns in international tribunals, his aides said.
While business groups are poised to counter labor and fight for passage of the legislation, they say that they are waiting to see an actual bill before committing themselves.
"We will be doing TV ads later on in the month after the President submits his proposal to the Hill," said James T. Christy, vice president of government relations for the military contractor TRW Inc., "assuming the President's proposal can be embraced by our coalition."
Organized labor, however, has not been waiting, with John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., declaring last week that "the economic status of the next generation of average-wage Americans will be determined to a large extent by how our government handles trade questions in the coming months."
The unions have been issuing fliers in workplaces and organizing a "Call Congress" campaign. The Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees, has started "speak-outs" against the trade legislation.
But for undecided Democrats the lobbying, such as the advertisements, threatens to put them in a vise -- torn between supporting the President who is at the peak of his popularity and supporting labor, whose financial and organizing support could be crucial in next year's Congressional elections.
One of those Democrats, Representative Nita M. Lowey of White Plains, expressed dismay at the labor movement's intent to run television commercials. "If we disagree on one issue it would be such poor judgment to target the district of a member who would be an advocate on 99 percent of the issues," she said.
Mr. Clinton's support is considered stronger in the Senate. But White House officials said they wanted to be sure they had 60 votes there, enough to break a filibuster that might come from Democrats like Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia or Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina.

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Poor Get Poorer

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Here's why Americans no longer have big families: college.
Suppose you had 12 children --
Ah, but you are laughing. "Twelve children," you are laughing. "Hah hah hah." 
 Well, you are laughing at my grandmother, and if she were here at this moment you would regret giving your laugh muscles such free play. All but 1 of her 12 were boys. A woman who has brought 11 boys to manhood does not do it by being a good sport when people laugh at her.
So suppose you had 12 children, of whom the oldest is about done with high school. You would be studying the college survey just published by U.S. News & World Report.
Having skimmed the contents, you would immediately (1) swear never to have 12 children again, and (2) tell the entire brood, "As of right now, you are all finished with school and will start tomorrow learning honest trades."
U.S. News reports that the price of sending one -- just one child! -- to college for one year -- just one year! -- is now over $20,000 at most of the flossier academies. Add $7,000 for room and board, and go figure:
Twenty-seven thousand dollars a year for four years comes to $108,000. Twelve children at $108,000 a child for four years runs to $1,296,000. Toss in inflation -- and nothing inflates faster nowadays than college costs -- and you can round the number off at $1.5 million, give or take $100,000.
That's why nobody has 12 children anymore. Having one in college is enough to keep Mom and Dad in penury until they're old enough to be wrapped in shawls and kept in rocking chairs.
If they can afford $27,000 a year for college they are probably in a tax bracket that licenses various governments to ravage maybe 50 percent of their salaries. This means they have to earn about $54,000 before taxes just for tuition and board.
That's for one child. For two, it's $108,000 a year. For three -- But let us draw the curtain. If you have tears you are probably shedding them now.
What do colleges do for this kind of money? They certify. As the United States is now organized, people not certified by colleges don't have a lot to look forward to except that blessed happiness that cannot be bought with money.
When seeking work, youth is asked by corporate interrogators, "Are you certified?" If not, alas!
The essential certifying is done by colleges of what is called "higher learning," the highest form of learning being that uncertified people don't go far. The indispensable certificates, called "diplomas," certify that recipients are persons whose parents were willing to face financial ruin in order to have their children certified.
In the past generation or two, too many people have been certified. The employment market is glutted with certified job applicants. Employers can afford to be picky.
"So you're certified, and who isn't these days?" they yawn. They have developed new criteria for weighing individual worthiness within the certified masses.
"Being certified cuts no ice here, kid," they say. "The big question is how much did the old folks pay to get the certifying done for you."
So Moms and Dads now pray that their produce will be acceptable to colleges notorious for their bankruptive tuition costs. Ivy League colossuses and many flossy but small private colleges are now well over $20,000 per annum and, considering the bullishness of the college market, likely to hit $30,000 before today's seventh-graders need certifying.
Applicants for admission to these top-dollar certifiers are so profuse that being accepted to one confers a singularity in a category with the Hope Diamond and the World Series victory of the St. Louis Browns.
Parents pining for poverty dream of having just one precious child accepted by a college that rejects 999 of every 1,000 applications.
These elegant academies, as might be expected, tend to breed killers -- corporation lawyers, merger-acquisition-and-downsizing wizards, Washington string-pullers, etc. The kind of people you don't mess with if you know what's good for you. Killers.
No wonder. After paying those killer tuitions, their parents would probably kill them if they didn't become killers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Concern Develops on Wall St. Over Wide Swings in Stocks

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
With the stock market swinging more wildly this year than it has in a long time, Billie Taylor is a bit more cautious about his investments.
Although he still has 80 percent of his money in equities, he has pulled back from the market, gently tip-toeing away from stocks. 
 "Right now I'm sitting on as high a level of cash as I've had in 10 years," said Mr. Taylor, a 57-year-old retired schoolteacher in Kettering, Ohio. "I'm somewhere on the fence because the pundits say that every time this happens the market's in for a major change."
Like millions of other investors, Mr. Taylor has been watching the increasingly sharp day-to-day moves in the stock market. Ups and downs of 1 percent or more have become commonplace in the stock market's major indexes. So far this year, such fluctuations have accounted for almost 3 of every 10 daily changes in the Dow, more than four times the pace of 1995. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks has shown the same volatility.
And the even bigger swings have been spectacular. The Dow had a 247-point, 3.1 percent, drop on Aug. 15 only to be followed two weeks later by a 257 point, 3.4 percent, rise. And while the market was calm yesterday, with the Dow slipping just 21.83 points, to 7,721.14, it had two moves of 1 percent just last week.
So even though the stocks in the Dow and the S.& P. 500 are having very good years, those 20 percent gains have been coming in an increasingly volatile environment. While this volatility has been rising from very low levels since early 1996, by many measures it is now well above average, flashing warning signals even among seasoned Wall Street strategists.
"Volatility tends to pick up when you get to turning points," said Robert Farrell, a longtime strategist at Merrill Lynch. "Occasionally, high volatility does occur in an up year without a sinister result. But a majority of your high volatility years have been down years."
To be sure, a number of Wall Street analysts remain relatively unconcerned about the increasing volatility. Abby Joseph Cohen, the widely followed strategist at Goldman, Sachs, argues that current volatility is still not particularly far above normal and that the economic fundamentals -- steady growth, low inflation, moderate interest rates -- remain positive and thus dampen the risk of a significant downturn.
Still, many analysts -- while not predicting that a big downturn is necessarily just over the horizon -- are growing increasingly concerned.
"Does this parallel to 1987 suggest market action will play out the same way as 10 years ago?" Gail Dudack, the chief investment strategist at UBS Securities, asked in a recent report. "Not at all. But this is a warning that should be heeded."
For investors, the increase in volatility can have two contradictory effects. It can make some nervous enough to change their outlook and their investment strategy, while others may be lulled into complacency.
On one hand, "volatility makes people think about the market again, and makes them reconsider their positions," said Robert J. Shiller, a professor of economics at Yale University and an expert on investor behavior. "Volatility is a clue that other people are re-evaluating, and so investors have a rule of thumb: when in doubt, imitate others."
On the other hand, increasing volatility as the market is still rising can lull investors. They may see a 200-point fall one day only as volatility that will be followed by a sharp rebound. This means it could take investors longer to see that the fundamental market direction has turned.
Some of this contradictory impact can be seen in the ebb and flow of money into stock mutual funds. Despite the rise in volatility this year, the $150 billion flow into stock funds through August is just 6.6 percent behind last year's record-setting pace and is the second highest ever. And weekly data from AMG Data Services show that in two weeks in August when volatility was high, investors withdrew more money from stock mutual funds than they put in.
One way that Wall Street analysts measure volatility is to calculate how many trading sessions register moves of more than 1 percent from one day's close to the next. By that measure, this year has been more turbulent than most.
The Dow has moved 1 percent or more in 29.2 percent, or 52, of the trading days. That is up from 16.9 percent last year and the recent lows of 6.8 percent in 1995 and 6.3 percent in 1993. And this year's performance is well above the average since 1940 of 17.2 percent, Paine Webber says.
The 29.2 percent figure so far this year is well below the most volatile years since 1940 -- 47 percent for 1974 and 38.3 percent in 1987, years when the market suffered sharp declines. But it is higher than other turbulent periods, like 1990, when investors were rattled by the Persian Gulf war and this measure of volatility jumped to 28.9 percent.
Another gauge of volatility gives more weight to larger percentage moves and measures daily movements over a rolling six months. By this measure, called standard deviation, the volatility of daily changes in the S.& P. 500 is well above the median level since 1940 of 0.72 percent. Current volatility, calculated by this measure, is 1.05 percent.
By this measure, market volatility is also well above that of the 1960's, the era most resembling today. The low-inflation environment is similar, and some analysts point to the strong market then as support for the argument that current stocks are not particularly overvalued. But in only one period -- during 1962 -- from 1957 through 1969 did volatility get as high as it is now.
Analysts offer many reasons for the higher volatility these days. Some argue that the market is jittery because of the high prices investors are now paying for stocks compared with their expected earnings potential, so that even a whiff of unexpected news about a particular company can send certain stocks reeling.
Others say it flows from a surge in computer-aided program trading, which is one reason the stock market has recently made very sharp moves at the end of the trading day.
Experts also cite the shift to allowing price changes of as little as one-sixteenth of a dollar rather than the long-standing one-eighth. And still others say that the rise in volatility is just making up for lost time from the very low volatility of 1993 and 1995.
Ms. Cohen, the bullish strategist at Goldman, Sachs, said that stocks were exceptionally undervalued through the mid-1990's, which helped hold down volatility. But as share prices rose, and stocks have became what she called "fairly valued," investors have turned edgier.
She likened the situation to shopping. "Let's say you go shopping and buy for $50 an item that's worth $100," Ms. Cohen said. "You bring it home and find it has a little ding in it. If you only paid $50 for it, you're not likely to be upset. But if you paid closer to full price, you may be a bit more agitated. That may be a good analogy for our market."
Ms. Cohen acknowledges that the market is more volatile than normal but does not know if that will continue. "What matters to me," she said, "is a fundamental turning point. And I don't see that there is a major fundamental disruption at this time."
Justin Mamis, an analyst who has been tracking and charting the market since the 1950's, suggested that the length of this bull market is starting to tear at the emotions of investors, as some are selling shares at huge profits, while others are trying to get in on the astronomical gains of their neighbors and co-workers.
But whatever the reason, there is little doubt that high volatility has usually been associated with significant turns in the market.
"Our conclusion is that the consistently high volatility, up and down, is indicative of a market in transition," usually downward, said Steven Leuthold, head of the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis.
Tim Hayes, senior equity strategist at Ned Davis Research in Venice, Fla., says volatility "tends to move from relatively low levels before market peaks to relatively high levels after market peaks."
Still, some strategists, like Mr. Farrell at Merrill Lynch, are not sure what to make of this period. "I would treat it as a caution flag," he said, "without implying it's 1929."
Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor of finance at the Wharton School, warns that one of the biggest dangers in the current rise in volatility is that it can whipsaw investors into making bad decisions with their money.
"Volatility is harmful," he said, "if you let it affect your psyche and your long-term goals."
As for Mr. Taylor, the retired teacher, he is content to just wait on the sidelines and let the market run its course. "Sometimes, my Daddy used to say, you need to just lay back in the weeds and wait a while. And that's just what I'm doing."

21.83 Trimmed From Dow
 A late selloff sent stock prices moderately lower yesterday, as the market continued to suffer from fears about profits.

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE CANDIDATES;
No Shortage of Criticism, But Little for Each Other

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
With no idea whether they will actually face each other in a runoff next week, Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton nonetheless sat down for a courtly televised debate last night as if the contest was still on, displaying the occasional flash of disagreement but generally concurring with each other's criticism of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
For the most part, the two Democrats resisted requests by three questioners that they point out their differences and criticize each other. Sitting in the auditorium of St. Francis College in downtown Brooklyn, they said they would not submit to the divisive suggestion of Mr. Giuliani that they spend their time attacking each other. 
 "I take the people that got up and came out and voted for me too seriously to let this degrade into some schoolyard thing of Ruth attack Al, Al attack Ruth," Mr. Sharpton said in his opening statement. "It's about education, unemployment, mass transit, affordable housing, it's not about, Rudy, you dictating a schoolyard fight."
Ms. Messinger agreed that the runoff campaign should not be forced into "name calling and finger pointing."
"I ask Reverend Sharpton not to take the bait, to rise above the Mayor's attempt to divide," she said. "I am not a divider. My whole life has been about bringing people together to solve common problems, to work toward common goals."
The discussion virtually ignored the question that dominated New York political circles yesterday: whether, in fact, there would even be a runoff. Only in response to the first question of the forum did the candidates touch on the possibility that this might be their only head-to-head encounter.
While refusing to say whether he would challenge the results of a recount in court, Mr. Sharpton warned that many voters would take a cynical view of the process if the runoff was canceled. Ms. Messinger declined to discuss the possibility until the tally was completed.
With some coaxing, the candidates did come up with several areas where they parted ways. Without the slightest trace of rancor in her voice, Ms. Messinger said she disagreed with Mr. Sharpton's handling of the Tawana Brawley case in 1987, as well as his refusal to denounce Louis Farrakhan. She also criticized his proposals to raise the city's commuter tax, and his decision not to seek greater productivity gains from the municipal unions.
In turn, Mr. Sharpton said she was wrong to try to balance the budget on the backs of union workers, and said it was important to make commuters pay their share of the city's upkeep. He also said Ms. Messinger should have endorsed the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition in 1988, a year in which she backed Gov. Michael Dukakis for president.
But even their differences were presented in an amiable way. To applause and laughter from the audience -- largely made up of Sharpton supporters -- Ms. Messinger said her main difference was obvious: "I'm taller." Mr. Sharpton predicted that anything short of a fistfight would produce press accounts of their refusal to square off.
A final 20-minute segment in which the two candidates could question each other was dominated by softballs lobbed back and forth: Do you see the Mayor as a divider and a bully, as I do, Ms. Messinger asked, and her opponent quickly agreed. Do you agree that the Mayor has not laid out a plan to deal with record unemployment, Mr. Sharpton asked. Sure enough, Ms. Messinger could not have agreed more.
Mr. Sharpton dismissed Mr. Giuliani's description of him as unqualified by saying the Mayor had no right to criticize his tax problems when the Giuliani campaign itself has been hit by charges of widespread violations of campaign finance laws. Ms. Messinger said that while she considered Mr. Sharpton qualified to run for mayor, she believed her 20 years in government made her the most qualified candidate.

HEADLINE: Whitman Shifts Focus From Car Insurance to Record on Other Issues

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
After six weeks of making automobile insurance the focal point of her re-election campaign, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is now seeking to move the campaign debate onto other issues and away from the one subject that some advisers believe makes her vulnerable to her Democratic challenger.
In what her aides describe as a new phase of her campaign, Governor Whitman is no longer speaking on the campaign trail almost exclusively about high auto insurance rates. In the last week, she has attended campaign events organized to highlight her record on education and crime. And her campaign today presented its first television advertising spot for the general election, and it does not mention insurance. 
 Until now, campaign aides to State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democratic nominee, have said Mrs. Whitman has made it easy for them to focus attention on auto insurance, the one issue that both Republicans and Democrats believe could hurt Mrs. Whitman's candidacy and strengthen Mr. McGreevey's election bid.
Polls show that auto insurance is the most important issue to voters in this race and that the majority of voters do not believe that Mrs. Whitman has done enough to reduce their premiums, which are the highest in the nation.
In the Whitman campaign's new 30-second television spot, Mrs. Whitman is pictured at upbeat, crowded campaign rallies with police officers and union members as an announcer extols her administration's record, saying she has succeeded in cutting taxes, strengthening the economy, reducing crime and putting welfare recipients to work. The campaign will begin broadcasting the advertisement on television stations in New York, Philadelphia and Atlantic City beginning Wednesday.
As Election Day approaches, the Governor's campaign aides said that they had intended all along to move the campaign debate away from auto insurance and onto the Governor's broader record, which they believe will persuade voters to give Mrs. Whitman a second term.
Tom Wilson, the Governor's campaign manager, said the advertisement was created to remind voters about Mrs. Whitman's record and to tell them that the state is moving in the right direction under the Whitman administration. "The Governor has a great story to tell," Mr. Wilson said. "She has a lot of good things to talk about, and we want to keep talking about them."
Over the objections of some of her political consultants, Governor Whitman spent much of the summer, and until just recently, talking almost exclusively about the state's auto insurance problem while campaigning. Her campaign aides worried that she was spending too much time discussing an issue that voters believe she has not handled properly. But Mrs. Whitman disagreed. She contends that it would be a bigger mistake to ignore the voters' top concern in this campaign.
Mr. Wilson said that Mrs. Whitman would continue to address the problem of auto insurance but that the campaign intended also to focus on other issues of concern to voters, like crime, taxes and education.
Mrs. Whitman's decision to stress auto insurance this summer was welcomed by Mr. McGreevey, whose campaign has tried to tap into voter anger over high premiums. His staff criticized the Governor today for trying to move the focus away from the issue that polls show most voters cite as their top concern.
Steven Salmore, a professor at Rutgers University and a Republican political consultant, said that Mrs. Whitman's decision to move away from the issue will cause difficulties for Mr. McGreevey.
"I have a strong feeling that he has lost his opportunity to define this race," Mr. Salmore said. "It is going to be very difficult for him to recover now that the media campaign has begun. He had to come up with a compelling reason to throw her out of office. He picked auto insurance. The question is what is next."
But Mr. McGreevey's campaign aides insist that voter concern over auto insurance is not going to go away.
"She is talking about issues that are outside the Governor's control, such as the national economy and national trends in crime and welfare," said Richard McGrath, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey. "She is trying to hide from her failed record on auto insurance, property taxes and education."
Mr. McGreevey, who is lagging behind the Governor's fund-raising efforts, expects to begin his television advertising campaign next week. Both candidates expect to spend about $5 million on television advertising in the coming weeks to reach New Jersey voters.
New Jersey voters can also expect to see television advertising from Murray Sabrin, the Libertarian Party's gubernatorial nominee. Mr. Sabrin, a college professor, said he had raised $236,000 for his campaign.
The State Election Law Enforcement Commission postponed a decision tonight on whether to grant matching taxpayer funds for Mr. Sabrin's campaign. Gubernatorial candidates in New Jersey who raise at least $210,000 are eligible to participate in the state program. If the commission approves Mr. Sabrin's request, he will also be able to join Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey at two televised debates.

HEADLINE: Fight Over Nomination Clearly Shows Rifts in G.O.P.

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
In their final showdown on Capitol Hill last week, Senator Jesse Helms accused William F. Weld, the former Governor of Massachusetts, of threatening to "begin a war within the Republican Party." Today, Mr. Weld, the non-Ambassador, welcomed the battle, declaring, "To the extent that people are looking at Jesse Helms as the face of the Republican Party, I think that carries a certain amount of freight with it."
The moment, in fact, is more like one combative day in the Thirty Years' War or the Hundred Years' War than Pearl Harbor or Fort Sumter. The ideological war in the Republican Party dates back more than three decades, to 1964, when Barry Goldwater won the Republican Presidential nomination. 
 The spectacle of Mr. Weld's doomed quest to win an ambassadorship to Mexico was one of the most theatrical displays of these deep hostilities. The Helms-Weld fight demonstrated -- as did the coup attempt against Speaker Newt Gingrich earlier this summer -- that the party that was so successful as the opposition is still struggling to adjust to its role as the Congressional majority, and to the reality of a Democrat in the White House.
Their personal collision reflected successful efforts by Mr. Weld and Mr. Helms to use each other to raise their profiles in the party. In quashing the Weld nomination, Mr. Helms asserted his power in the Senate and was cheered by the social conservatives.
By standing up to Mr. Helms, Mr. Weld became a hero for Republicans who are conservative on economic issues but more liberal on social matters like abortion. The ease and humor with which Mr. Weld carried himself and his terse, punchy answers in the news conference today were reminiscent of the banter with reporters of another son of Massachusetts, President John F. Kennedy, and may help Mr. Weld set himself apart from other moderates willing to jump into a field of right-wing Presidential contenders in 2000.
In blocking Mr. Weld's move to Mexico City, Mr. Helms may have inadvertently helped Mr. Weld remain active in Republican politics. As Mr. Weld said in an interview days before he resigned the Governorship in July, "If I get the nomination, obviously it takes me out of national politics."
That, of course, is no longer a possibility. Indeed, at times today, Mr. Weld sounded almost as if he were trying out lines for the stump. He said that Republicans should "get Government back to doing what it does best: defending public safety, educating the citizenry and helping those who cannot help themselves." (It was probably not lost on potential rivals that in the news conference, Mr. Weld emphasized his anti-Washington bona fides, saying more than once, "Washington sure is a funny town.")
"This made him national," said Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton's former political strategist, who has also advised Mr. Weld and Mr. Helms. "He can't win the party's Presidential nomination, but he can be the leader of the political faction" of liberal Republicans.
But many Republican loyalists discount Mr. Weld's national potential, saying they were unnerved to see a prominent Republican standing at a lectern with a White House seal as he ridiculed Mr. Helms -- and spoke warmly of the Democratic President who nominated him.
"I really think he's marginalized himself," said Scott Reed, who ran Bob Dole's unsuccessful Presidential campaign last year. "He stuck it in the eyes of conservatives all over the country, and he has helped Clinton more than he has helped the Republican Party."
Senator Sam Brownback, a freshman Republican from Kansas and a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, who had urged Mr. Helms to give Mr. Weld's nomination a hearing, said: "It raises Weld's name and it raises his profile. But you do that at the expense of making other people very irritated."
Whatever the fallout for Mr. Weld, the drama over his nomination left the Republican Party looking particularly weak, with fractures that go far beyond ideological differences.
"A number of Republicans still don't know what it means to be in the majority," said Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut, a moderate Republican. "They still think they're in the minority. And being in the minority means just blowing up the place." That is not only the view of a lone moderate; Mr. Gingrich has made a similar observation.
Many Republican lawmakers said they were particularly concerned that, with Mr. Gingrich's wounded image and the failure of the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, to become a commanding figure, the party is floundering and unable to find consensus on an agenda of issues. These lawmakers said they were increasingly worried about these conflicts as the midterm elections approach next year.
The predicament was on display at the Christian Coalition convention in Atlanta last weekend, where the lack of a party line was obvious. Some Republican speakers condemned the party's leaders in Congress for working too closely with the White House, while others, like Mr. Gingrich, congratulated themselves for pressing Mr. Clinton into signing a tax-cutting package.
"The leadership has allowed a vacuum to occur where we don't stand for anything," said Representative David McIntosh, a conservative from Indiana. "If we don't solve it by the 1998 election, then we're likely to lose the majority in Congress. The polls show everybody still likes incumbents in Congress, but our base is very depressed."
Ralph Reed, who recently left the Christian Coalition to become a political strategist, warned party leaders in a memorandum that the way for the party to recover was not to simply attack Mr. Clinton.
"Republicans have sometimes acted as if the road back for them is paved with scandals and Congressional inquiries," Mr. Reed wrote.
"This is a mirage. Instead, Republican candidates should treat Clinton's popularity for what it is: an amorphous political phenomenon created by forces beyond our immediate control," he said.
But for other Republicans, their party's challenge boils down to the two men in the spotlight today and finding a home where both Jesse Helms and Bill Weld can co-exist. "The Republican Party must be big enough for Jesse Helms and William Weld if we're serious about competing in national affairs," said Senator Robert C. Smith, a conservative from New Hampshire. "And I believe it is big enough for that."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 17, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article on Tuesday about William F. Weld misattributed a quotation about the future of the Republican Party. It was Senator Gordon Smith of Oregon, not Senator Robert Smith of New Hampshire, who said: "The Republican Party must be big enough for Jesse Helms and William Weld if we're serious about competing in national affairs. And I believe it is big enough for that."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Bordeaux Again Leads a High-Price Parade

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THE official date set for picking white grapes in Bordeaux this year was a remarkably early Aug. 25; mid-September is more the norm for all grapes. But the crop was so precocious that picking in the Graves region, a major source for white Bordeaux wine, began on Aug. 18. The early harvest reflects the magnificence of this year's growing season, which means the grapes and the wine should be superb.
Historians have had to go back more than a century to find an earlier date. Not since 1893, when the harvest began on Aug. 15, had the picking begun so early. Dates for the red grapes this year were early, too: Sept. 3 for merlot and Sept. 8 for cabernet sauvignon and other Bordeaux varieties. There have been years when most picking was done in October. 
 It was an auspicious start to what could be a memorable season for wine. And not just in Bordeaux. Early harvests were the rule all over France, most of Italy enjoyed good growing weather and, despite rain damage in August in some areas, California is harvesting a bumper crop.
These are happy days in wine country. Prices are high, order books are full and figures show that the consumption of good wine is continuing to grow. Prices for futures for the 1996 Bordeaux vintage, announced earlier this year, are in the $300-a-bottle range for wines like Petrus and Chateau Ausone. And some current Burgundy prices are even higher, with Domaine de la Romanee-Conti reaching $600 and more.
California wines like Robert Mondavi Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon and Stag's Leap Wine Cellars Case 23 sell readily for $75, Caymus Vineyards Special Reserve goes for $100, and the rare Diamond Creek Lake Vineyard Cabernet sells out in European markets for $250, says the winery owner, Al Brounstein.
These ultra-premium wines account for only a tiny portion of the wine market, but they reflect a trend toward more expensive wines, a trend that indicates American wine drinkers are coming of age.
The numbers for California wines show what's happening. Sales of varietal table wines -- wine named for the grape from which they are made -- were up almost 11 percent from 1996, according to Impact, a trade publication. This continued a trend begun in the mid-1980's. In 1985, the industry shipped 20 million cases of varietal wines; last year the figure was 77.4 million.
To that must be added 31.5 million cases of imported table wines, much of it meant to cover demand that domestic production, most of it from California, was unable to meet. California vineyards are still recovering from an epidemic of phylloxera, a vine-destroying insect, which has forced the replanting of thousands of acres of wine grapes.
Further illustrating the change in America's wine-drinking tastes is the continuing decline in interest for inexpensive generic wines. In 1985, some 85.7 million cases of California generics, mostly jug wines, where shipped; last year, the figure was 52.5 million cases.
The long-ignored bag-in-the-box wines have given considerable support to the generic category in recent years. They have made substantial inroads in the traditional market for three- and four-liter glass jugs. Each rectangular box holds an airtight plastic bag usually filled with five liters of wine. As the wine is poured through a built-in spigot, the bag collapses, keeping the wine free from air. Five liters is the equivalent of almost seven bottles of wine. Some boxed wines have crossed into the varietal group, holding inexpensive chardonnay and other wines.
Most varietal wines, however, sell far more than all but a handful of the generics. In 1996, the retail value of chardonnay sold in this country topped that of all generic wines combined, according to Impact.
Even if the wine producer is thrilled by high prices, most wine is inordinately expensive from the consumer's point of view -- and not just for famous French wines. It may well be that most American wine drinkers have seen the last of the Bordeaux First Growths and Burgundy Grand Crus -- at least until the economic boom in the Far East slows down.
Call any Bordeaux chateau owner or head of a famous Burgundy domaine, and he or she will probably be traveling in Asia. And selling wine. Some American wine collectors are finding themselves forced to sell their Lafites and Moutons, even when they acquired them years ago at reasonable prices. They find it difficult to drink a bottle of wine that can be sold at auction for $350. Top-of-the-line American wines are unlikely to come down in price, even when grapes are more plentiful, because most of them are deliberately made in small quantities and will never match the demand for them.
What will happen to moderately priced varietals remains to be seen. Many wines that were priced at $8 a few years ago are $12, and the $12 wines are $18 or $20. For all but a small group of consumers, $20 is too much for a bottle of wine for dinner at home. A moderating factor is that discount retailers in this city and elsewhere, generally, even in a time of wine shortages, pare 10 percent or more off suggested retail prices.
Since the overall market for wine is growing much more slowly than the industry would like, there is reason to hope that as grapes become more plentiful in a few years, competition will drive prices of many wines down to more acceptable levels. Thousands of acres of new vines have been planted in California to replace those destroyed by phylloxera, and many wineries are developing vineyards overseas, both on their own and in joint ventures.
But as for now, there is no shortage of little-known and underhyped wines that sell at attractive prices and are equal to wines at twice the cost. The search is unending; it's also fun.
 
Tastings
From Australia, A Special Cabernet
 
PENFOLDS Bin 707 Cabernet Sauvignon 1993, South Australia. About $45. Penfolds bills this rich, luxuriously concentrated wine as the cabernet equivalent to its Grange, Australia's best-known wine. Bin 707 is a blend of fruit from vineyards in Coonawarra, Padthaway and Adelaide Hills. It was first made in 1964, but was discontinued in 1969 because of a shortage of the highest quality cabernet. Since it was brought back in 1976, there has been a 707 every year except for 1981, when the fruit was considered too light. Fermentation is finished in American oak, and the wine is aged in barrels for 16 months. It can be kept in a cellar for a decade.

HEADLINE: Inflation Continues Slow Crawl, U.S. Says

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Consumer prices edged up a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in August, while factories increased output at the fastest rate in nine months, the Government said today in separate reports.
The reports were the latest signs that the economy continues to grow at a robust pace with low inflation. Stocks and bonds rose after the reports, as investors reasoned that the data would allow the Federal Reserve Board to hold interest rates steady when its policy makers meet on Sept. 30. 
 "What we seem to have is a situation where the good times keep rolling," said Robert Dederick, an economic consultant to the Northern Trust Corporation in Chicago. "Production growth is vigorous, and inflation is tame. You can't get much better than that."
The rise in consumer prices, below the gain of three-tenths of 1 percent that Wall Street economists had expected, was viewed as especially benign in light of the economy's overall strength and surging gasoline prices. The rise of two-tenths of a percent in the Consumer Price Index matched the gain in July.
Consumer prices have risen at a 1.6 percent annual rate for the first eight months of the year -- less than half the 3.3 percent increase in 1996. For the last 12 months, prices have risen at a 2.2 percent rate.
In its report, the Labor Department said gasoline prices jumped 5.4 percent last month while food prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Those gains were partly offset by a 1 percent drop in clothing prices as shoppers bought more discounted spring and summer merchandise.
Consumers will probably buy more expensive fall clothing soon, reversing that decline next month, Patrick Jackman, an economist with the Labor Department, said.
Excluding the often volatile categories of food and energy prices, the so-called core rate of inflation inched up one-tenth of 1 percent, down from a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in July. The core rate has also risen at a 2.2 percent annual rate for the last 12 months; if the pace continues, the core rate for 1997 could be the lowest in more than 30 years.
"It's a very comfortable number for the inflation outlook and certainly fits with no Fed activity in terms of policy on Sept. 30," said Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York.
A separate report from the Federal Reserve said factory output rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, pointing to brisk growth with few signs that the economy was overheating after more than six years of expansion. Industrial output grew nearly twice as fast as July's increase of four-tenths of 1 percent. Factories ran at 83.9 percent of capacity last month, the highest rate since September 1995 and up from 83.6 percent in July.
While economists welcomed the inflation data, many said the unexpectedly strong rise in manufacturing output suggested that the economic slowdown anticipated by the Fed seemed unlikely to occur in the third quarter.
That left some wondering how long the rosy situation would last. The economy grew at a 4.9 percent rate in the first quarter and a 3.6 percent pace in the second quarter, rates that economists traditionally believed would fuel inflation.
James E. Annable, chief economist at First Chicago NBD bank, said that if factory output rose so that businesses started using too much spare capacity, they might be forced to raise prices.
"That has not happened yet," he said. "One of the reasons that inflation has been so low is that capacity utilization rates have been historically low."
But a report from the Commerce Department suggested that growth could still moderate later this year. The department said business inventories rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July, slower than June's rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent and the seventh consecutive monthly gain.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Mark As German Rate Isn't Raised

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher against the German mark yesterday after the Bundesbank left a crucial interest rate unchanged and an official at the central bank suggested that a weak mark would not automatically lead to a German rate increase.
The dollar also strengthened against the yen, benefiting from the mark's strength against the Japanese currency. 
 Surging stocks and bonds in the United States gave the dollar a push higher in late trading. The United States markets rose on benign inflation data, with the Dow Jones industrial average jumping 2.26 percent on the day.
In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 1.7700 marks, up from 1.7629 marks on Monday. The dollar rose to 121.25 yen from 120.31 yen. The pound slipped to $1.5954 from $1.6051.
The dollar begin its climb against the mark in overseas trading after the Bundesbank, as expected, left its securities repurchase rate steady at 3 percent.
The dollar added to its gains on news that a Bundesbank council member, Franz-Christophe Zeitler, had said in an interview with a German magazine, Borse Online, that the central bank would not automatically raise interest rates if the dollar climbed toward 2 marks.
"Important for me is less the level, rather the period of time in which the movement took place," Mr. Zeitler said.
Despite the decision by the Bundesbank to leave interest rates unchanged, many currency traders say they expect it will raise rates later this year.
Indeed, the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, on Monday hinted at a rate increase before next spring.
"Talk of German interest rates going up continues to put a cap on the dollar in the short run, anyway," said Earl Johnson, foreign exchange economist at the Bank of Montreal.
By contrast, investor confidence in the Japanese economy and financial markets continues to deteriorate. For this reason, aggressive purchases of mark for yen continued today, and that was the primary reason the dollar showed gains against the yen.
"The turn everyone thought was coming in Japan's economy is apparently not coming at the moment," said Benjamin Strauss, vice president of foreign exchange at Bank Julius Baer.
