HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Tight Market Reveals 'Hidden Space'

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
As if by magic, some of Manhattan's invisible office space is starting to come into view.
Actually, magic has nothing to do with it. Brokers and other real estate executives say that as vacancy rates drop and rents rise, many prospective tenants are seeking to line up deals for office space as much as several years before their existing lease expires and the same space officially goes on the market. 
 But some landlords still appear to be holding space off the market to avoid committing to leases at current rates, in the hope that rates will be sharply higher in the near future.
In a recent report on the state of the office market, Newmark & Company Real Estate noted that McGraw-Hill was scheduled to move into space in 2 Penn Plaza, at 33d Street and Seventh Avenue. The transaction, it noted, "reveals the importance of 'hidden space'; the floors to be occupied by McGraw-Hill at 2 Penn Plaza encompass over 300,000 square feet that was never placed on the market."
James D. Kuhn, the president of Newmark, said the strength of the market allowed Vornado Realty Trust, which owns the building, to secure a new tenant before the old lease expired without the expense of a marketing campaign or a major renovation. "In the early 1980's I was doing as-is deals all the time," he said. "This is the first point in the current cycle where it is easy for landlords to do this sort of thing."
Peter R. Friedman, chairman of the brokerage company bearing his name, said that during the early 1990's, when many corporations reduced their work forces, they faced a quandary about what to do with the excess space, particularly if the lease had only five or six years to run. To attract a new tenant in that recessionary time, the company would have had to offer at least one year of free rent, while being forced to pay brokerage commissions and for remodeling work.
"The reason a lot of this space was held off the market is that it was economically unmarketable," Mr. Friedman said.
For example, the advertising agency holding company WPP Group had 3 million square feet of space in New York, while only needing 2 million, he said. "Only in the last 24 months has it made any sense to try to market that space."
Julien J. Studley, chairman of a brokerage firm bearing his name, said, "A lot of corporations carried excess space because they did not want to take a hit on their books" by taking a financial loss on a sublease. "As the rental value increases," he said, "that space will come to market."
Mr. Studley said some of the office space that was invisible even to real estate specialists would be vacated when new development took place. As an example, he cited the old Alexander's department store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue. "Everybody knows the Alexander's site will be developed," Mr. Studley said. "It will support 1.5 million square feet of retail, office and apartments." He predicted that most of the commercial tenants would move from elsewhere in the city.
Another form of hidden space is in buildings that are not suitable for marketing, he said. "There is the Chrysler Building and 666 Third Avenue," Mr. Studley said. "One is empty and the other is half empty and both need renovation. But they are in good locations and they will come back to the market."
In spite of the improving market, some space is being withheld for speculative reasons, brokers say. "Space is being warehoused by landlords in hopes that the market will tighten more and they will have a precious commodity in the near future," said James Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a brokerage that represents tenants.
As an example, he cited the building at 600 Fifth Avenue, which is part of Rockefeller Center. Officially, he said, about 71,000 square feet of space on the upper floors is on the market. But, he said, there is 190,000 square feet of contiguous space on the second to ninth floors that will become available at the end of 2000. "Why is that not on the market?" he asked. "I guess the attitude is that they can get $35 to $40 a square foot in the building now, but by the end of 2000 it will be worth $50 a foot."
The existence of hidden space, both known and unknown, means that vacancy statistics are at best an approximation, real estate executives say. "Whenever brokerage companies quote vacancy rates they are different because there is no accepted industry standard or benchmark," said Paul N. Glickman, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield.
He said that because of the tightening market, brokers are working in advance to identify what space will become available and to prepare to market it when it does. "We are working with 133,000 square feet of space at 99 Park Avenue," Mr. Glickman said, referring to a building on Park Avenue between 39th and 40th Streets. "It becomes available in the second quarter of 1999 and we are very quietly beginning to market it. Six months ago that was hidden space."

HEADLINE: 'Fast Track' Issue Deserves Fast Action

BYLINE: By Bob Dole and Lloyd Bentsen; Bob Dole, the 1996 Republican Presidential nominee, is the former Senate majority leader. Lloyd Bentsen, the former Treasury Secretary, is a former Democratic Senator from Texas.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
During more than two decades of divided government, Democrats and Republicans have often set aside their differences to take collective action on matters promoting our nation's interests beyond its borders. The next issue that calls for bipartisan leadership is the passage of legislation granting the President "fast track" authority -- a contract between the executive and legislative branches in which the President can negotiate trade deals knowing that the results will receive an up or down vote, without amendments, in return for a commitment that the Administration will consult Congress in the negotiations.
As Senate colleagues from different political parties, we joined in voting to give fast-track authority to every President from Gerald Ford to George Bush. Today, as law firm colleagues, we agree that Congress and the Administration must set aside partisan differences to grant President Clinton this same authority. The United States must act now to take advantage of our status as the most competitive economy in the world to insure our future prosperity. To do that, Congress must decide to compete, not retreat. 
 The United States is, once again, the world's largest exporter. Our current seven-year period of sustained growth, with extraordinarily low unemployment, has been fueled in large part by international trade. More than a quarter of our economic growth and more than 10 million jobs are the direct result of trade.
Without passage of fast-track legislation, however, our success in selling American products to the world will be at risk. Inaction carries a very high price. Although we are currently well positioned to compete, other countries have recently been negotiating trade agreements that will allow them to move ahead of us into developing markets -- even in our own backyard in Latin America.
Since 1992, 20 free trade pacts have been negotiated in Latin America and Asia that exclude the United States. China, for example, has aimed at Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico and Venezuela as "strategic priorities" to develop bilateral trade.
Fast-track authority will allow President Clinton to negotiate agreements to break down trade barriers in areas where the United States is most competitive, like agriculture, telecommunications, financial services and medical equipment. It will allow us to retain our leadership in exports by focusing on developing economies, where the bulk of international growth will occur in coming years.
The coalition that passed the North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade must come together again to pass a fast-track bill this fall. If legislation does not pass in short order, next year's contentious elections may delay passage until the 106th Congress -- and 1999 may be too late. If we don't act quickly to shore up trade relationships in Latin America and Asia, other countries will.
Passage of fast-track legislation is critical to insure that our economy continues to grow at its present rate. In fact, the success of this year's budget agreement depends on maintaining steady growth. As much as any other issue, the fate of the fast-track bill in 1997 will determine whether our budget balances in 2002.
While we are the world's largest exporter, we also continue to import more than we export. The best way to shrink the resulting trade deficit is to persuade other countries to eliminate their trade barriers, enabling us to export even more goods, services and agricultural products. That, in turn, will create more and better-paying American jobs.
Given the public's general ambivalence about trade matters, it would be easy for either party to try to score political points by criticizing responsible proponents of free and fair trade. Criticism is easy. Leadership requires hard work. Our leaders must step forward, now, to do what is right for America's future.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: End of Chicago's Education School Stirs Debate

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 16

 BODY:
As the campus's shaded quadrangles fill with students for the start of the fall quarter -- hints of red dappling the ivy that climbs the neo-Gothic buildings, yellow self-move trucks rumbling along the streets -- there is a void at the University of Chicago this year: For the first time in more than a century there are no doctoral candidates entering the department of education.
The department, founded in 1895 by John Dewey, and once home to Bruno Bettelheim and William S. Gray, creator of the "Dick and Jane" early reader series, has been shut down, its remaining faculty and students told that they have until 2001 to finish and move on. The administrators who closed it argued that its scholarship was unworthy of Chicago's standards in the social sciences, a failing they deemed too costly to correct. 
 At a time when education is edging to the center of the American domestic agenda, the demise of such a pedigreed department has engendered much anger. After the faculty of the division of social sciences voted last November to endorse the recommendation of Dean Richard P. Saller that the department be closed, he and other administrators were barraged with hundreds of letters and petitions from around the country, some accusing them of apathy toward the fate of the nation's schoolchildren.
A common version of the events leading to the decision asserted that the money men, the bean counters, had taken over Chicago, found its education department -- with its modest-earning alumni -- wanting, and chose to kill it off.
"It was portrayed as a battle between good and evil," Professor Saller, a Roman historian who became dean of social sciences in 1994, lamented. "I got all kinds of hate mail."
But in recent months, a more complex discussion has emerged, one which raises questions about the nature of educational research, notably about the links between educational theory and practice, and how they fit into a traditional academic setting. Increasingly, insiders and outsiders are contending that the decline started in the late 70's, when Chicago's education department stopped its day-to-day involvement with teacher training and schools, devoting itself more purely to theory.
"A department of education which terminates all ties to the real world of schooling and focuses only on statistical manipulation of schooling outcomes is getting itself in trouble," said Bert Cohler, a professor of psychology and education here. "We became more and more ivory-towered in the worst sense."
Ivory tower is not generally a dirty phrase at Chicago, an institution that prides itself on offering a kind of cloistered devotion to knowledge. A higher percentage of Chicago graduates go into academia than those of comparable schools, such as Yale and Stanford, and its graduate departments of such disciplines as economics and anthropology are widely viewed as among the very best.
But education has always been a special case, a hybrid field that depends on a give-and-take with ordinary people teaching youngsters how to make sense of squiggles on a page and the world around. On this score, the department's fate is a something of a cruel paradox, because Dewey himself made much of applied research, founding the university's laboratory school where he tested and developed his theories of education and child psychology.
He assailed education that separated school and life and made his mark by rejecting the predominant pedagogy of his day, which involved rote learning rather than learning through experience, now the prevailing pedagogy.
His well-known laboratory school remains on campus but it has evolved into a good private school with few direct links to the university.
Until the 1970's, the University of Chicago had a strong commitment to education. In addition to the department, there was a Graduate School of Education devoted to teacher training, with strong links to the laboratory school both for teacher instruction and research projects.
Philip W. Jackson, who in the 1970's was head of the laboratory school, dean of the graduate school and chairman of the department, said he had 40 full-time faculty members under him with programs financed by the Ford Foundation and other major endowments reaching as far afield as Pakistan and South America.
But in the late 1970's, two things happened: The focus on education shifted away from schools, and research money dried up.
Chicago closed its graduate school of education and consolidated it within the graduate department that was part of the division of social sciences. Several Ph.D. candidates transferred out, and the number of faculty members began to diminish and age -- there were only 15 last year, with 12 of them over age 60 -- and the focus shifted to bring it more in line with traditional social science. Apart from the continuation of small Master of Arts of Teaching programs in the departments of English and mathematics, links with the laboratory school were severed.
Prof. Patricia Albjerg Graham of Harvard, the former dean of the Harvard's Graduate School of Education, said that Chicago's withdrawal from teacher training in the 1970's was not unusual because the dominant intellectual model in education then held that schools themselves had relatively little influence on youngsters.
"Schools of education moved away from schooling," she said. "Harvard stopped training teachers in 1974, so for Chicago to close its school was, in some ways, very understandable. The difference was that once that happened and they found themselves in the social sciences, they couldn't realign their priorities when things changed again. Harvard went back to teacher training in 1983 and now we do loads of it."
But money and prestige played roles in the fate of Chicago's department as well. Professor Jackson, who called this an enormously painful subject for him, said, "Like law and medicine, education looks outward to some world of practice and is plagued by this dual role of serving two masters."
"But law and medicine," he continued, "have extremely wealthy alumni which education does not have. It's very unusual for a university to say, 'Let's get rid of medicine or law.' But getting rid of education can be done."
A number of top universities, including Yale and Johns Hopkins, have dropped schools or departments of education over the years, he said, partly over financing and partly because they did not fit in with classic models of academic research. While Chicago held on, the department found itself increasingly unable to get money for new appointments since education research often appeared to lack rigor in the eyes of the university administrators who controlled the money.
Dean Saller said that when he took over the social sciences division, he was troubled by the frequent lack of peer review for publication in education and the way in which government agencies or foundations sometimes set the research agenda by financing their own pet projects rather than the ideas generated by scholars themselves. He noted that some 20 percent of the Ph.D.'s earned in America are in education, yet the field has failed to live up to its promise.
"Of course I care about public education," Dean Saller said. "My children are in public schools. But we can't let a sentimental concern for children get in the way of hard scrutiny about whether we are producing quality work."
Critics of the department's closing maintain that while the department was declining over 20 years, the administration failed to step in until it was too late.
A university committee has been working since the spring on recommending a future for educational research and teacher training here and some hope that the department can be revived. But the committee's chairman, W. Clark Gilpin, dean of the divinity school, said there was no chance of this, though an interdisciplinary center might be formed to link what he and other administrators said were pockets of fine educational research in other departments and to continue teacher training programs in English and math.
Others, noting that the university finds itself surrounded by a large and troubled public school system, argued that the department had been salvageable. The failure to save it, they say, reflects a lack of commitment to what should be a vital university mission, especially at this moment in American history, even if it requires an adjustment of standards to reflect the messy nature of educational research.
"I consider it a major mistake when a university such as this one cancels its education department," said Wayne C. Booth, a retired English professor and distinguished literary critic. "It should be struggling to restore what was once the best department in the world."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Richard Saller, the dean of the social sciences department of the University of Chicago, shown on the campus yesterday. Dean Saller is at the center of a debate over the closing of the school of education. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
American Express expects travel costs to continue rising next year, but at a less torrid pace.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
EXECUTIVES experiencing sticker shock from constantly escalating travel costs can expect more of the same next year, though there are signs the increases are beginning to taper off.
In a 1998 business travel forecast released this week, American Express predicts overall travel costs will jump 3 percent to 5 percent next year, compared with an expected 7 percent to 8 percent increase this year. 
 Air fares -- which American Express says represent 42 percent of an average company's travel and entertainment costs -- are projected to rise 5 percent to 6 percent in 1998 over 1997 levels, which are the highest ever. This year, according to American Express, the typical business air fare -- a full fare or fare with few purchase requirements -- will climb at least 15 percent; through July it was up 23 percent. American Express attributes any increases next year to upward pressure on airlines' labor costs; it expects carriers' capacity growth to be a minimal 3.5 percent, with demand growing similarly.
Hotel costs, which American Express says total 21 percent of travel expenses, are projected to climb 4 percent to 5 percent in 1998, half the rate of increase expected this year. The company predicts 1998 hotel occupancies will fall "slightly below expected 1997 levels, (but) nonetheless remain at historically high levels." Room supply is expected to increase in 1998, outpacing demand.
American Express is also forecasting a smaller increase in 1998 over 1997 in car rental costs, which constitute 8 percent of total travel expenses; the company says rates will rise 5 percent to 6 percent, compared with 4 percent to 7 percent in the first half of this year. It says dining costs, 14 percent of total travel expenses, will climb 2 percent to 3 percent, the same as this year.
The Air Transport Association, the trade group for the United States airline industry, has confirmed what many business travelers have uncomfortably suspected for months: carriers are flying an all-time high number of passengers. According to statistics announced by the association last week, a record 69.3 percent of seats on planes were occupied by paying passengers in 1996; this year the figure-- known as the load factor -- is one percentage point higher. Load factors 15 years ago were below 60 percent.
One bright spot ahead, according to the association's chief economist, David Swierenga, is that United States airlines will add 175 to 200 planes to their fleets this year, and more than 200 in both 1998 and 1999. If the economy slows, as he anticipates, capacity growth should outpace demand, which should mean lower load factors and more empty seats.
PKF Consulting, a San Francisco company specializing in the lodging industry, issued its 1998 forecast last week. It predicts the average room rate will climb 5.8 percent next year, compared with 7.2 percent in 1997, and that occupancies will vary significantly by city. The bad news for visitors to New York: PKF expects the average rate for a hotel room there to reach $200 by the end of 1998, making the city the first in the United States to achieve this dubious distinction.
 
Rewards for Short Trips
UAL's United Airlines has created a special offer for its frequent fliers to encourage them to use up miles on short weekend trips. Through March 31, 1998, travelers can obtain two tickets for a round-trip flight to a destination 750 miles or less away for 30,000 frequent flier miles, compared to the 50,000 miles such an award would normally require. Frequent travelers in New York, for example, can escape to Chicago; those in Denver, can fly off to gamble in Las Vegas, Nev. Requirements include an overnight Saturday stay, travel with an electronic ticket, and mileage redemption from one frequent flier account.
 
Facts From the Web
The Sabre Group, which runs the Travelocity web site (http:// www.travelocity.com), has teamed up with the guidebook publisher Lonely Planet to begin a new section on the site called "Your Planet." Set to start in November, the section will provide information on international destinations; maps and pictures from Lonely Planet books; tips on traveling off the beaten track; current visa, passport, travel and weather data for more than 220 countries, and a schedule of coming events and activities worldwide. The Columbus Group, a London travel information company, will also contribute to the new section.
 
Awards at Marriott
Beginning Oct. 15, Marriott International, will allow Hertz customers and passengers on United Airlines or British Airways to accrue points in the Marriott Rewards frequent guest program. Airline passengers will accrue between two and three points in the Marriott plan for each mile flown, depending on the type of ticket purchased. Hertz customers will be able to accrue up to 1,000 points for each rental. No hotel stay is required with any of these transactions. United and Hertz customers can ask to accrue points when they book or at the counter when they travel; British Airways passengers must make this request when they reserve flights.

HEADLINE: Japan Says Trade Surplus Is Up Sharply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The Japanese merchandise trade surplus rose more sharply than expected in August, the Finance Ministry announced today.
The surplus soared a seasonally adjusted 51.1 percent in August from July to 1.099 trillion yen ($9.12 billion), the Finance Ministry said. That was almost double the increase expected by economists. It was the third gain in more than five months. 
 From August 1996, the surplus grew 113.6 percent to 742.06 billion yen.
Exports rose 3.3 percent from the previous month. Imports declined 6.7 percent, another sign that an increase in the national sales tax since April 1 is discouraging consumer spending.
"With the effects of April's tax increase still here, there's no sign of a recovery in imports, and I can see exports rising through the year-end," Maki Miyazaki, an economist at Yamaichi Research Institute of Securities and Economics Inc., said before the trade report.
The politically sensitive trade surplus with the United rose 59.8 percent to 350.60 billion yen in August from a year ago. About one-quarter of Japanese exports go to the United States.
United States officials have said that they would raise the issue of Japan's trade surplus at this weekend's meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Hong Kong.
Japan's trade surplus with Asia expanded 27.2 percent, to 520 billion yen, in August from the corresponding month in 1996.
Overall imports totaled 3.238 trillion yen in August, the Government said. Imports were sluggish even as the dollar has lost about 5 percent of its value against the yen since May. That makes American goods cheaper.
Seasonally adjusted figures compare imports and exports from a month earlier, while ironing out differences in the number of working days and exceptions created by Japan's fiscal year.

HEADLINE: Clinton Faces Off With Congress on Trade

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton put his personal prestige on the line today, traveling to the Capitol to fight for new authority to negotiate trade deals in the face of muscular opposition from House leaders of his own party.
Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore appeared before a fractious caucus of House Democrats as senior Administration officials unveiled the trade legislation and then fanned out across the Capitol to sell the proposal at the heart of Mr. Clinton's second-term economic agenda. 
 The measure would grant Mr. Clinton what is often called "fast track" authority to negotiate trade agreements that Congress can approve or disapprove but not amend. Such authority has been held by every President since 1974. But it expired two years ago and Mr. Clinton chose not to push ahead with a vote that would have splintered the traditional Democratic coalition as he headed into a Presidential election year.
Today, however, Mr. Clinton joined the battle, arguing that expanded markets were crucial to continued prosperity. "Today 12 million American jobs are supported by exports," he said at the White House before his meeting with Democrats. "Today at the pinnacle of that strength, America must choose whether to advance or retreat. I believe the only way we can continue to grow and create good jobs in the future is to embrace global growth and expand American exports."
But the President did not mollify hard-core opponents in his party, who argue that American workers are hurt by competition with third world nations that have lower wages and lax environmental standards. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader and a likely primary opponent to Mr. Gore in the year 2000, nearly shouted his opposition after Mr. Clinton left.
Referring to a trip he made last week to the border with Mexico to survey living conditions, Mr. Gephardt said, "The people we met over the weekend are living in subhuman conditions. It is wrong."
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., meanwhile, announced that it had begun airing television and radio commercials against the measure at an initial cost of $1 million in the districts of 13 undecided lawmakers of both parties as well as radio ads throughout California.
While Mr. Clinton had planned to put forth the legislation last week, the White House delayed it as it sought ways to write a bill that could attract more Democratic support without losing Republican votes.
In the end, the bill contained some provisions designed to address objections from Democrats, organized labor and environmental groups. The legislation promised consultations with Congress and listed "workers rights and environmental protection" as negotiating objectives that the United States would pursue through the World Trade Organization.
Administration officials also pledged that the President would use his executive authority to negotiate separate side agreements on labor and the environment.
But the bill largely tracked language favored by Republicans and stopped well short of what many Democrats and labor unions wanted to see -- the placement of labor and environmental standards at the heart of any market opening accord, enforced by the threat of trade sanctions.
In a sign of just how delicate the balancing act is for votes in the Republican-controlled Congress, Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said he thought the bill "provides a reasonable base on which to start" but added that he had some reservations about the labor provisions that had been included in the legislation.
With the vote on the trade bill likely in October, a major question will be whether the Administration's pledges to heed labor and environmental concerns will be enough to sway undecided moderate Democrats. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said the steps the Administration had taken were "encouraging" but that he had not decided what to do. "Obviously, there is a good deal of difference of opinion," he said after Cabinet-level officials briefed Senate Democrats.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, predicted that it would be a "tough job" to pass the bill. "The President will have to participate in that very fully, as we will on our side of the aisle," he said.
Shadowing the trade debate are memories of a similar fight in 1993 over the North American Free Trade Agreement which involved trade with Mexico and Canada and which Mr. Clinton won with mostly Republican votes.
The Administration insisted at the time that it would be a boon to the economy. But an Administration assessment earlier this summer suggested that at most 90,000 to 160,000 American jobs rely on increased exports to Mexico as a result of that pact. In a booming economy that has created 13 million new jobs over the past four and a half years, that figure is hardly significant.
The critics of Nafta point to a United States trade surplus that has turned into a $16 billion trade deficit and say that American jobs are moving out. They also argue that the "side agreements" with Mexico on environmental and labor matters have not brought about reform and will not unless made a central part of trade agreements, with United States sanctions wielded as a threat.
Charlene Barshefsky, the President's chief negotiator, sought to rebut that viewpoint today by noting that the goal of trade agreements is to open rapidly growing markets to United States exports. "It is not realistic to suggest that countries will rewrite their domestic labor and environmental laws for the privilege of buying more of our goods," she told reporters as she made her way around the Capitol.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore met with House Democrats for more than an hour and tried to keep the mood civil despite the sharp differences. Democrats who participated in the closed-door session said more Democrats argued against the trade agreement than for it, and at times, participants said, the tone of the meeting turned testy.

HEADLINE: Senate Shelves Proposals to Restrict Indian Legal Protections

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The Senate backed away today from attempts to strip American Indian tribes of their legal immunity against lawsuits and to force tribes to report their income in order to receive Government benefits.
Under intense lobbying from Indian tribes and some of his fellow Republicans, Senator Slade Gorton of Washington agreed to drop his efforts. He had proposed both provisions as part of the spending bill for the Interior Department. 
 But in exchange, the Senate agreed to hold hearings on the immunity question and to bring it to a vote by next spring. It also authorized a Government study on whether future payments to Indians should be based on need instead of on the current formula based on population.
Across the Capitol, debate on yet another contentious issue in a spending bill put the House of Representatives on a collision course with the Senate and the White House. The House voted 295 to 125 tonight to block President Clinton's drive to establish voluntary national testing on mathematics for eighth-grade students and on reading for fourth graders by 1999.
The Senate voted 87 to 13 last week to rescue the plan.
But the probability of a political showdown with both the Senate and the President over the issue did not dissuade Representative Bill Goodling, Republican of Pennsylvania, from pushing to kill the testing plan on the House floor this evening.
Mr. Goodling's amendment was tacked onto the spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education.
National testing for math and reading was in the 10-point plan for education that Mr. Clinton announced in his State of the Union Message in February. But the idea has drawn opposition from both sides of the political spectrum.
Many conservatives worry that national testing would be the first step toward a Federally imposed national curriculum that would weaken local control of education. Some liberals, including many of the black and Hispanic members in the House, fear that minority and other students in poor school districts will not perform well on national tests and that the test scores will be used against them.
The House was able to put off another bruising fight over spending when the chairman of the Transportation Committee, Representative Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania, agreed to postpone further action on a three-year, $103 billion highway bill until next week.
The Transportation Committee was to vote on the bill on Wednesday. But Mr. Shuster, a Republican, said he postponed the vote after meeting this evening with Speaker Newt Gingrich to discuss the controversial measure.
Republican leaders had threatened to block Mr. Shuster from bringing his bill to the floor because they said it would have broken the balanced budget deal, outspending it by $30 billion over five years.
The debate in the Senate today ended with a victory for Indian tribes, but with a pledge that the fight would be rejoined.
"I have not gained the goal I set for myself," Mr. Gorton said. "But we are going to be able to debate these issues intelligently over the coming year in a way we haven't done in this Congress."
Critics of Mr. Gorton had said his proposals would have limited the sovereignty of American Indian tribes. Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Colorado Republican and the only Indian in the Senate, complained that the proposals "constituted a dramatic departure from existing Federal Indian policy."
Last July, with little debate and no public hearings, the Appropriations Subcommittee on Interior and Related Agencies included the two provisions in the 1998 spending bill for the Interior Department, which includes the Bureau of Indian Affairs. Mr. Gorton is chairman of the subcommittee.
One of Mr. Gorton's proposals would have forced the country's 554 Indian tribes to waive their sovereign immunity from civil lawsuits or lose up to $767 million in Federal money, nearly half the budget for daily operations on Indian land.
"It would have been grossly unfair to haul off and reinstate that Indian tribes can be sued by almost anyone for anything in almost any counts," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who, with Mr. Campbell, led the fight against the provisions.
Indian leaders said that withoutthat legal protection, their tribes could face bankruptcy because of lawsuits and might be unable to operate as governments.
To entice Mr. Gorton to drop his provision on the immunity issue, the Senate's Indian Affairs Committee agreed to hold hearings and to schedule a vote by next May on a bill that would allow lawsuits against tribes.
Mr. Gorton's other proposal was just as vexing to Indian tribes. Through what is called means-testing, tribes would have been denied Federal money if their incomes were above a certain level.
Under current guidelines, Federal dollars to Indians are distributed through a formula based on the population and acreage of the various tribes. But citing the income that many tribes now get from gambling, Mr. Gorton and others have argued that Government aid to Indians should be based solely on need.
Opponents of Mr. Gorton's proposal argued that although there was a perception that Indians were getting wealthy from gambling, only a few tribes were making money.
A report last December by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said about a third of all American Indian tribes were involved in some sort of gaming. But the agency said that 10 tribes had taken in more than half of the $1.6 billion received by casinos on Indian reservations. The report also showed that unemployment on the reservations was more than three times the national average.

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

RUTH W. MESSINGER
 
Appearing in Battery Park in lower Manhattan, she said she had to assume there would still be a runoff, and expressed hope that confusion with the vote count would not lessen voter interest in November. 

"They now have thousands of paper ballots that they need to review and count. And until they say otherwise, there will be a runoff next Tuesday. I am absolutely confident that as we move toward the general election, the vast majority of New Yorkers, who are ready for a change, will want a mayor who will set higher standards for students and teachers, will want a mayor who will grow the economy of this city, and who want a mayor who will pay attention to the quality of life in all neighborhoods will come out to vote."
 
THE REV. AL SHARPTON
 
At his campaign headquarters yesterday while taking a break from discussions with his lawyers over a possible challenge to the Board of Elections if it rules that there will be no runoff between him and Ruth W. Messinger:

I will not be distracted with Board of Elections speculation or other speculation. I will continue to raise the issues of unemployment, bad schools, police brutality and will go forth in this runoff. If the Board of Election interferes with the runoff, we'll deal with it at that time. As of now, our agenda is full steam ahead."

HEADLINE: Poll Findings Hint at Trouble For Whitman Over Insurance

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

 BODY:
Most New Jersey voters say that neither they nor the state have benefited from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's income tax cuts, and now, seven weeks before Election Day, they give her low marks on the issue that they continue to cite as the state's biggest problem: the cost of auto insurance.
These results of a New York Times/CBS News poll underline the volatile nature of the New Jersey electorate, a group whose members overwhelmingly say they have no opinion of Mrs. Whitman's Democratic opponent for governor, State Senator James E. McGreevey, but who also tell poll takers that Mr. McGreevey is more likely than the Governor to bring down automobile insurance premiums. 
 Sixty-seven percent of those surveyed said they disapproved of the way that Governor Whitman has handled auto insurance rates, which are more expensive in New Jersey than in any other state. Asked which candidate is more likely to bring down those rates, 36 percent cited Mr. McGreevey while 25 percent chose Mrs. Whitman.
Mrs. Whitman's promise to cut income tax rates by 30 percent jump-started her 1993 campaign that ousted Gov. Jim Florio, and when she kept that promise a year ahead of time, she stood in the national spotlight. But as the fall campaign begins, almost half of New Jersey residents surveyed said they did not think the tax cut made much of a difference to the state. Asked what impact the income tax cut had on their own lives, two-thirds of those polled said that cut had not made much difference. Only 18 percent described the tax cut as good, nearly matched by the 13 percent who said it had been bad for them personally.
"What this poll says to me is that she has a real race on her hands," said Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia. "This is not the coronation that people expected a year ago."
Auto insurance has dominated the campaign debate all summer. Forty percent of the 901 New Jersey residents polled from last Thursday to Sunday cited auto insurance as the single most important issue that they wanted the next governor to address.
The next issues cited as problems were education (by 13 percent) and property taxes (by 11 percent). Democrats are working to persuade voters that local property taxes have increased as a result of the state income tax cut, and the poll shows their arguments may find fertile ground. Asked how Governor Whitman is handling property taxes, 53 percent said they disapproved while 24 percent approved of what she is doing. The margin of error in the poll is plus or minus 3 percentage points.
But the challenges for Mr. McGreevey are huge. Mr. McGreevey, a 40-year-old former assistant prosecutor who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge Township, N.J., remains relatively unknown to residents outside Middlesex County. Seventy-seven percent of registered voters surveyed said they did not know enough about Mr. McGreevey to offer an opinion of him.
Even so, when registered voters were asked whom they would vote for if the election was held today, Mrs. Whitman holds only a modest lead over Mr. McGreevey. Forty-four percent of registered voters chose Mrs. Whitman, and 35 percent preferred Mr. McGreevey. Fifteen percent were undecided. The remaining 5 percent said they would vote for neither candidate.
Despite reservations over the tax cuts and a preoccupation with auto insurance rates, 58 percent of those surveyed said that over all, they approve of the way Mrs. Whitman is handling her job as Governor.
Mrs. Whitman dismissed the poll's results about her modest lead over Mr. McGreevey. "I've never been a person who polled well," she said. "They've never been accurate in a race that I've been in. I focus on what I hear on the streets."
The poll results on her job performance put her comfortably ahead of where Mr. Florio was at this point in his campaign four years ago, a time when 47 percent of voters said they approved of his job as Governor. Mrs. Whitman defeated him that November by 25,000 votes.
The findings of the Times/CBS News poll are similar to those of other recent independent surveys. In a poll released yesterday by Quinnipiac College, New Jersey voters said they believed Mr. McGreevey would do a better job than Mrs. Whitman on the state's auto insurance problem. They also found that the Governor held a 49 to 37 percent overall lead in the gubernatorial contest.
Mrs. Whitman, who helped make auto insurance a campaign issue by vowing to reduce rates in her annual address to the State Legislature earlier this year, said she did not regret focusing public attention on the auto insurance problem. Although her own party in the Republican-controlled Legislature rejected her plan to reduce rates by giving consumers the option of reducing their coverage, Mrs. Whitman said she believed that "the legislators now understand how critical it is that they have got to address this issue."
Until last week, Governor Whitman has brought up auto insurance regularly on the campaign trail. But now her campaign aides say they are moving into the next phase of the campaign, extolling the Governor's record on other issues. In her first campaign television advertisement, which began broadcasting on New York and Philadelphia stations yesterday, the Governor does not mention auto insurance but hammers on the issues -- crime, jobs and welfare -- that tend to gain Mrs. Whitman her best ratings from voters.
In an interview yesterday, Mrs. Whitman vigorously defended her income tax cuts and expressed frustration about the poll's finding, showing that almost half of the state's residents do not believe that the tax cut has made a difference in the state. "The state has turned a corner, and we're back to where we should have been before," she said. "And that didn't just happen. It happened because of an aggressive program to cut taxes."
Richard McGrath, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey, said he believed that the poll results showed the Governor's failings on the most important problems facing the state: auto insurance and property taxes. "The polls also reveal that the voters realize that Whitman shifted the tax burden onto the backs of homeowners and businesses," Mr. McGrath said. "She did the easy part of cutting taxes. But she opted to make up for the lost revenue with higher property taxes and budget gimmicks that will impose long-term debt on the taxpayers."
Mr. McGrath said that it was not surprising that Mr. McGreevey was not well known to voters outside Middlesex County at this stage of the campaign. Mr. McGreevey faces the challenge of most New Jersey candidates, making their first statewide election bid. Since New Jersey does not have its own major commercial television station, outside of Atlantic City, New Jersey voters get most of their information from New York and Philadelphia television stations that do not offer a steady diet of news about New Jersey or the race.
And the state program that publicly finances much of the race for governor limits campaign spending, prompting most statewide gubernatorial candidates to reserve most of their resources for their television advertising campaigns until the final weeks before Election Day.
Also, not many voters are now paying much attention to the race. The poll shows that only 12 percent of registered voters have said they have been able to "pay a lot of attention" to the gubernatorial campaign so far. Twenty percent more said that they will start paying more attention later this month, while an additional 42 percent said they will not start paying a lot of attention to the race until October.
Although Mrs. Whitman shows some vulnerability on the three most salient issues in the race -- auto insurance, property taxes and education -- the polls showed numerous strengths in other areas. She received high marks for her handling of crime, the state's economy, the environment and welfare.
But she is unlikely to earn many points at the polling booth for her tax cut. Only 16 percent of those polled said their state income taxes had gone down over the last four years, while 28 percent said they had gone up. The largest share, 43 percent, said their state income taxes remained the same.
At the same time, 59 percent said their property tax bills had gone up during the same period.
Professor Sabato attributed this to Mrs. Whitman for not getting more political mileage from her tax cut. He said the poll's finding, showing that voters give Mrs. Whitman little credit for her tax cut, says more about the Governor's failure to communicate effectively her administration's success than signaling a national trend that tax cuts are unimportant to voters, over all.
"It says that she has done an extraordinarily bad job of selling her major accomplishment," Mr. Sabato said. "Normally, a governor uses the tremendous resources at her disposal to communicate the fundamental accomplishments of the term. And she has not done that. And that is unusual. She seems to be good at public relations nationally. I suppose she would have been better off, staying home a good deal more."
But Mr. Sabato said voter concern over auto insurance also shows that voters are generally satisfied with the big issues, like the economy and jobs, and are focusing on minor irritants, like auto insurance. He noted that in Virginia, the only other state with a race for governor this year, a personal property tax on cars is dominating much of the campaign debate.
Mrs. Whitman said she hears the message loud and clear that voters are frustrated over auto insurance and property taxes. "I don't know if that means at the end of the day, they will vote against me," she said. "They just want to make sure that I don't take anything for granted and that I don't think I've solved every problem in the State of New Jersey. I understand that and I hear them, and auto insurance will be the No. 1 focus when this election is over."
 
How the Poll of New Jersey Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from last Thursday through Sunday with 901 adult residents of New Jersey. Of these, 744 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of New Jersey exchanges. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each area of the state was represented in proportion to its population.
For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex and age.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult residents of New Jersey.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus 4 percentage points for registered voters.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Chips With More Memory May Revolutionize Industry
Intel is expected to announce a technology breakthrough that could in some cases double the amount of memory on a chip and increase its speed and efficiency every nine months or faster.
The development, altering the basic physics of chip design in a way that engineers and computer scientists once thought impossible, portends a new level of frenzy in computer building and buying. [Page A1.] 

Goldman Earnings Rise 58%
Earnings before taxes rose 58 percent in the third fiscal quarter at Goldman, Sachs Group. Goldman, the last sizable partnership on Wall Street, is a bellwether for the securities industry's financial performance. [D2.]
 
Clinton to Call for Tobacco Changes
President Clinton, making his first comments on the proposed tobacco deal negotiated by state officials and lawyers for cigarette companies, is expected to call for changes that would help reduce the number of teen-agers who smoke by sharply increasing the price of cigarettes over the next 10 years. [A1.]
 
Marvel Agrees to Settlement
The contentious bankruptcy of Marvel Entertainment might be settled. Marvel agreed to pay creditors $385 million in cash and sell its sticker unit to reach a deal. The comic book publisher Marvel with characters like Captain America filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in December. [D6.]
 
American Home's Diet Drug Woes
American Home Products repeatedly issued warnings of rare but dangerous side effects for Redux, the diet drug, and dispatched 950,000 cautionary letters to doctors and pharmacists before withdrawing it and a similar drug, Pondimin, from sale this week. [D2.]
 
Inflation Remains Tame
Consumer prices edged up a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in August, while factories increased output at the fastest rate in nine months -- seven-tenths of 1 percent. The reports were the latest signs that the economy continues to grow at a robust pace with low inflation. [D4.]
 
Oracle Matches Expectations
Oracle said first-quarter operating profits rose 33 percent, matching Wall Street expectations, on strong increases from its software consulting business. [D2.]
 
Adidas Acquiring a French Concern
Adidas is buying the French sports equipment maker Salomon, forming the largest sporting goods company in Europe and the second-largest worldwide behind Nike. [D4.]
 
Valentine Heads United Network
As expected, Dean Valentine was named president of the United Paramount Network. He had been president of Walt Disney Television and Walt Disney Television Animation, supervising such shows as "Home Improvement," "Ellen" and the Disney afternoon franchise of cartoons. [D9.]
 
Analysts Warm to Oil Company
The Belgian oil and petrochemical company Petrofina has been able to capitalize on the strong American demand for gasoline. The rebounding refining business is one reason analysts are recommending shares of the company, which began trading American depository receipts Sept. 3. In Belgium, the stock has risen 45 percent this year. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Game Broadcast in High Definition
Harris broadcast a major league baseball game live in digital, high-definition television for 300 invited guests, hoping to create excitement about the new technology. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Will Seek Tougher Proposals To Rein In Smoking

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton will decisively reject a proposed tobacco deal negotiated by state officials and cigarette company lawyers and will outline his own tobacco policy in an Oval Office speech on Wednesday, White House officials said today.
Mr. Clinton will insist that his chief goal -- reducing the number of teen-agers who smoke -- can be accomplished only by a sharp increase in the price of cigarettes, by as much as $1.50 a pack over 10 years, the officials said. 
 In his first extended public comments on the sweeping nationwide tobacco proposal announced on June 20, Mr. Clinton will praise the efforts of state attorneys general, plaintiffs' lawyers, health advocates and tobacco company executives in devising a plan to advance important public health goals while settling dozens of tobacco-related lawsuits.
But the President will insist that the $368.5 billion settlement plan does not go far enough to discourage smoking by minors or to help the nation's 45 million smokers end their nicotine addiction, aides said.
While not spelling out a detailed legislative proposal, the President will describe the overriding principles that he believes must guide the nation's approach to tobacco use, aides said. Among the tenets of the President's plan are unfettered authority for the F.D.A. to regulate nicotine as an addictive drug, fundamental changes in the way cigarettes are made and sold in this country and the rapid disclosure of documents that chronicle the legal, scientific and public relations conduct of the nation's tobacco companies in the past 40 years. Mr. Clinton will also call for some form of compensation to be paid to tobacco growers, whose income will decline as the nation's tobacco consumption falls.
According to calculations by economists at the Health and Human Services and Treasury Departments, the number of teen-agers who start smoking drops by 7 percent for every 10 percent increase in price. On that basis, Administration officials calculated that if prices rose by $1.50 over the current average of $2 a pack, the President's goal would be achieved: Reducing the number of teen-age smokers by two-thirds over 10 years.
The price would be expected to rise because tobacco companies would be fined if smoking levels did not decline rapidly enough.
The White House has yet to begin drafting legislation to embody the President's principles, but Mr. Clinton called on Congress today to address the issue soon. He could present his own bill or work with Congress on one.
"We ought to get this legislation through Congress as quickly as we can," the President said at an appearance in which he discussed trade policy. "I would hope that we can get all the parties to the lawsuits involved to agree to it, but we have to do it right."
Congressional leaders have said that action on what is certain to be a complex and contentious legislative package is not likely this year. And the White House does not appear to be in a hurry, calculating that the industry's position is weakening and that tobacco control will be an effective election-year issue in 1998 for the Democrats.
Enthusiasm has waned for the agreement reached in June. That deal would have required five major tobacco companies to pay $368.5 billion, mainly to settle lawsuits filed by smokers and by states seeking to recoup Medicaid payments for smoking-related illnesses. The companies also agreed to restrict marketing, to finance anti-smoking campaigns and to pay fines if smoking among youths did not fall below certain levels. The plan called for price increases of roughly 65 cents a pack over 25 years. But it would have limited the jurisdiction of the Food and Drug Administration.
The two officials who coordinated the Administration's three-month review of the original tobacco settlement proposal -- Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Bruce Reed, the President's chief domestic policy adviser -- are expected to be at the Oval Office event on Wednesday.
Also expected are others supporting Mr. Clinton on this issue, including Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman; the Mississippi Attorney General, Michael A. Moore, one of the central negotiators of the June tobacco accord; Matthew L. Myers, a lawyer for the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids and another architect of the June deal, and Dr. David A. Kessler, the former Commissioner of Food and Drugs and a longtime anti-tobacco crusader. Dr. Kessler's criticism of the original plan helped persuade Mr. Clinton to scrap the deal in favor of a tougher approach.
"What the President has cared about from the beginning is reducing the number of kids who smoke, and this will work," Dr. Kessler said in an interview today. "This is no longer about whether the deal is worth $360 billion or $500 billion or $700 billion. It's about what works, and I think this does."
Tobacco industry officials will not be represented at the White House announcement, said J. Phil Carlton, a North Carolina lawyer who represented the major cigarette makers in the negotiations.
Mr. Carlton said the industry had not decided how it would respond to the President's announcement. But he said he hoped that Mr. Clinton would endorse legislation to conclude the dozens of lawsuits, filed by individual smokers and by 40 states, that threaten the industry.
"If he'll come on out, as I understand he will, and call for Congressional action on national legislation, that would be good," Mr. Carlton said in an interview. "That doesn't mean we can agree to some of the things he may try to add to the June 20 agreement."
The industry's interest in reaching a settlement with the attorneys general has always been to find a single-stroke solution to the potentially ruinous litigation it faces from coast to coast. The June accord would settle most of those suits.
But Mr. Clinton's principles go far beyond the settlement proposal, particularly on the cost to industry of failing to meet specified targets on smoking by teen-agers.

HEADLINE: Fighting Religious Persecution

 BODY:
Conservatives in America have long been part of the human rights movement, but in the past they have largely focused on abuses committed by Communist governments. Today they are broadening their concerns. A small group of activists has succeeded in putting repression of Christians in other countries on the national agenda. This has brought attention to an important, neglected problem, and increased consideration of human rights in American foreign policy. But it has also produced demagoguery among politicians eager to gain points with the Christian right.
One example is a bill that purports to fight religious persecution, but is so poorly designed it would do little to help religious freedom abroad. The legislation, sponsored by Senator Arlen Specter and Representative Frank Wolf, has the support of the Republican leadership and appears to have a good chance of passing in some form. It would set up a new White House office to monitor and classify religious persecution. A finding of certain types of persecution would automatically trigger a variety of economic sanctions, starting with a ban on American exports to abusive government agencies and possibly including a cutoff of all non-humanitarian aid and American votes against international bank loans. The President could waive the sanctions on national security grounds. 
 The office would be required to investigate persecution of Christians and a few other minorities in Communist and many Islamic countries. All other religious persecution would be addressed at the director's discretion. While the bill's authors say it is not their intention, such an unbalanced mandate is offensive to Muslims, Jews and other religious groups that are also subject to abuse. The most common type of religious persecution -- limits on religious assembly -- is not covered at all in the bill. Immediate export sanctions would apply only to the entity directly carrying out persecution. No money, for instance, could go to a specific military barracks that tortured Christians, but it could go to the army or defense ministry responsible, making the sanctions meaningless.
One curious provision would change the rules of asylum and refugee applications in America to insure that people who say they are fleeing religious persecution would get a hearing. This is a welcome acknowledgment that the new rules that became effective in April do not protect refugees and asylum seekers. But the bill might end up filling the refugee quota with those fleeing religious persecution, thus shutting out other applicants. Its changes should apply to those fleeing all kinds of oppression.
This provision reflects the bill's relegation of all other persecution to second-class status. The torture of Christians is heinous, but so is the torture of ethnic Tutsi or union organizers. In most countries where religion is attacked, such attacks are part of a wide spectrum of human rights abuses.
Groups with a special concern for religious persecution are right to demand more attention to the issue. Instead of trying to create a new office in the White House separate from the policy-making process, however, they should work to strengthen the State Department's human rights bureau. If there is a political stampede to approve this bill, Congress must rewrite and broaden it to cover all manner of persecution and all religious groups equally.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
A Player of Few Words Is Ready for No. 1 Speaking Role

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 16

 BODY:
When he began sounding off about things like unfair labor agreements and bad economics two summers ago, everyone associated with Patrick Ewing wondered what had happened to the often reserved and quiet man they thought they knew.
Ewing and the Bulls' Michael Jordan had led a faction of players that failed in its bid to decertify the players union, but the Knicks center had said his piece and made his point clear: beyond his playing exploits, he wanted to make a difference in the league's future. 
 After winning a majority of the vote to become the players association's president over the weekend, he will get his chance. Succeeding his teammate Buck Williams, Ewing will serve a four-year term that runs parallel with his new Knicks pact.
"Buck did the best job that he felt he could," Ewing said as he left the Knicks' practice facility at SUNY-Purchase today. "No disrespect to him, but I'm going to try to be the best leader I can possibly be also."
Ewing's election comes at a very pivotal time for the players association. With the growing possibility that the league will reopen the collective bargaining agreement next year, he could be at the forefront of securing a new deal and coping with a potential lockout. He will have to be outspoken and take charge.
This is the same guy who has spent the last 13 years quietly going about his business in the media capital of the world. He will have to dispel the notion that he has never been a vocal leader in the locker room.
"It doesn't mean anything, what other people think about you," said Herb Williams, Ewing's teammate and a players association vice president. "It's just their opinion. If he was really vocal, then guys would say: 'Well, he's too vocal. He needs to shut up some time.' You never hear that about Mike. I don't see him shouting and screaming at people. I never hear anybody say he's not vocal enough."
Billy Hunter, the players association executive director, said: "Still waters run deep. I don't see it as a problem at all. Patrick doesn't waste words. He's not always running off at the mouth with a lot of rhetoric. He's a very emotional person and I think that also validates his position."
Among the 18 player representatives who voted, Hunter said Ewing won by an overwhelming margin. He beat out Charles Smith, Mitch Richmond, Tyrone Corbin and Chris Dudley. The fact that Ewing was the most high-profile player among the candidates probably did not hurt.
"We had decent leadership with Buck, but I think it's good for a player of his caliber to step in and accept the responsibility," Herb Williams said. "You look at baseball, you look at their top players: Greg Maddux, Cecil Fielder, Bobby Bonilla, Barry Bonds. All their top players are the guys in the union sitting at the table. When you look at us, we have guys like myself and other guys that are not that well known.
"Buck probably could have run again if he wanted to, but I'm not sure he wanted to. He's like me; his career is winding down. When you had an Oscar Robertson and a Tommy Heinsohn, well, we need guys like that to step up to the plate and take responsibility."
There are other dynamics involved. Ewing will have to deal extensively with Commissioner David Stern, whom he penned a letter of discontent to in June after the league suspended Ewing and four other Knicks for leaving the bench against Miami in the second round of the playoffs. Ewing felt the league effectively cost New York the series.
Also, as one of the leaders of the decertification movement -- an effort to avoid what he felt was an inadequate collective bargaining agreement -- Ewing was accused of essentially being a tool of what many perceived to be an agent-led movement. Ewing, feeling his intelligence was being questioned, was furious regarding the perception that his agent, David Falk, was somehow steering his intentions.
Finally, Ewing and others feel that many of their predictions regarding the league turning into a caste system under the current agreement have come true.
"We're concerned about it, but we have to play under this agreement," Ewing said. "Unless the league blows the agreement up, we can't do anything about it. They're going to do whatever they feel is right. We, as players, have to stick together and fight on for what happened two years ago."

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
A Kicker Sues, Saying She Was Treated Unfairly

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH 

 BODY:
In 1993, Heather Sue Mercer left Yorktown Heights, N.Y., believing that her place-kicking skills, which had helped the high school win a state football championship, were good enough to secure a spot on the Duke University football team.
Four frustrating years later, after being told that she was on the team, and then not being given a uniform or being allowed to practice with the team or stand on the sideline during games, Mercer says that there was never a place for her on the Duke team. 
 Mercer, now a senior at Duke, filed a lawsuit in Federal court in Durham, N.C., yesterday against Duke and its football coach, Fred Goldsmith, claiming that the coach did not give her a fair opportunity to become the only female place-kicker on a Division I team. Mercer is alleging that Duke violated Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972, which prohibit sex discrimination in college athletic programs that receive federal funds. She is also suing under North Carolina law for constructive fraud, negligent misrepresentation and breach of contract.
Mike Cragg, the Duke University sports information director, said Goldsmith had not seen the lawsuit and neither the coach nor the university would comment on it.
"I think that people should be aware of what happened to me, and I hope it never happens to anyone else," Mercer said yesterday. "The idea of anyone else going through what I went through for four years is nauseating to me."
Mercer's lawsuit asks for compensatory and punitive damages for emotional distress and for the loss of opportunity to play football at another college or to participate in future amateur or professional athletics. She said any money she might receive from the lawsuit would be used to set up a college scholarship fund for promising female kickers.
Mercer, an economics major who will graduate next May, does not have any more college athletic eligibility. She was on the Duke fencing team while pursuing a place-kicking slot.
In a telephone call from North Carolina yesterday afternoon, Mercer sounded frustrated, angry and hurt when talking about her four years of trying to make the Duke football team.
"I just kept believing that they would see me as a kicker and not someone who often wore a skirt to the office," Mercer said. "Most athletes take it for granted that they have someone around them that supports them. It's tough when you don't have that. But it's worst to be made to feel that you don't even belong. It hurts."
Mercer, 21, was a walk-on player at Duke as a freshman in the fall of 1994 and was given what she describes as a "private tryout" by Goldsmith and members of his coaching staff. Mercer was allowed to practice only with the other walk-on kickers even though, she said, other walk-on kickers were allowed to practice with the team, were issued uniforms and were even allowed to dress for games -- things, she said, that she was denied during her quest to make the team. At one point, Mercer said, Goldsmith told her she could sit in the stands with her boyfriend during home games.
In April 1995, Mercer was selected to the Blue team for the annual Blue-White intrasquad game. She kicked a game-winning 28-yard field goal in the Blue team's 24-22 victory. Mercer said Fred Chatham, Duke's kicking coach at the time, told her she had made the team. But she had not. In the fall, she said, the same pattern emerged.
Mercer said that Goldsmith told her that she would be a distraction to the team if she were allowed to be in uniform and stand on the sideline, even though he wanted her to conduct news media interviews about being the only female kicker on a Division I team.
During the summer of 1995, Mercer said, she wrote a letter to Goldsmith asking him why he was not going to allow her to attend practice that summer. She said he telephoned her at home and asked her why she was interested in football and why she did not want to be in beauty pageants instead.
Finally, this past spring, Mercer said Goldsmith told her that she had no place on the team.
Mercer said that during the summers she attended kicking camps to help sharpen her skills and that no one at any of those camps told her that she did not have the ability to compete at the Division I level.
Mercer attended camps run by Bill Renner, Paul Woodside and Mark Moseley, the former kicker for the Washington Redskins. "She kicks the ball well enough to be competitive with other college kickers," Renner said by telephone last night. Renner, who runs the Fourth Down Sports Kicking Camp, said he thought enough of Mercer's skills to include her on his camp's staff last summer. Telephone messages to the offices of Woodside and Moseley were not returned yesterday.
Mercer said she never considered transferring to another college to pursue her place-kicking.
"It was suggested to me by those close to me, because they knew kicking was a big part of me, and they saw the frustration and hurt that I was going through," Mercer said. "I was never willing to give up. I felt like transferring would be giving up. I was happy academically. If I made it at another school, I would have felt like I had settled for second best, because I didn't make it at Duke."
Asked what she hoped to accomplish with the lawsuit, Mercer said: "At the very least people will know what happened down here. Everybody always thinks that everybody gets a fair shot at making the team. Maybe they will understand better what happens to somebody who is a little different when they try to accomplish something. I hope it changes some minds.
"Place-kicking is not about the size of your leg or whether you're male or female or you weigh 200 pounds. It's whether you can get the ball through the uprights with accuracy and consistency. Girls can do that."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Thailand Ponders Reform In Midst of Economic Crisis
A draft constitution stressing government accountability and civil liberties has become a flash point in Thailand, fueled by the nation's economic discontent. This frustration with the Government reflects an emerging social conflict in a nation where the political structure has not modernized along with the country's rapid growth. A6 

Space Junk Just Misses Mir
The Russian space station Mir narrowly avoided disaster when it almost collided with a United States military satellite, which had been taken out of service in 1994. The three crew members aboard Mir had sealed themselves into the Soyuz re-entry capsule to make a fast getaway in case of a collision. NASA officials estimate that about 10,000 pieces of junk are in orbit; the satellite had been used for a few months and then discarded. A14
 
Cold War Converts to Drug War
A screening system, partly based on a technology developed to detect Soviet warheads during the cold war, will soon be deployed to detect narcotics being smuggled across the border from Mexico, the Clinton Administration's drug policy chief, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, announced. "There is no question that this will work," he told reporters. A5
 
U.S. Seeks Mine Compromise
The Clinton Administration scrambled to reach a compromise on a treaty to ban land mines, hoping to avoid international censure. Details of the new American position were not yet public, but other countries seemed opposed to amendments other than possibly agreeing to a delayed timetable. A6
 
A Bomb Explodes Near Belfast
A bomb exploded in a town west of Belfast, disrupting the Northern Ireland peace talks in which Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, is taking part. Protestant political leaders blamed the I.R.A. for the blast, which damaged a police station, and demanded that Sinn Fein be expelled from the talks. The I.R.A. denied responsibility. A14
 
Protest Over Bosnia Elections
Several senior officials working for the organization that administered the elections this weekend in Bosnia have threatened to resign because of the body's failure to annul votes cast for the ruling Serb Democratic Party in Pale. They say the party should not have been allowed to field candidates in the local elections because it is run by Radovan Karadzic, who is charged with war crimes. A14
 
Bodyguard in Crash Is Alert
Trevor Rees-Jones, sole survivor of the high-speed crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, has recovered from serious injuries and was described by a doctor as "perfectly conscious." French prosecutors hope he will be able to recall the crash and shed light on the role, if any, played by photographers pursuing the Princess and her companion, Emad Mohamed Al-Fayed. A12
 
NATIONAL A16-29
 
Reno to Replace Leaders Of Election Finance Inquiry
Attorney General Janet Reno, embarrassed by missteps and discord in the Justice Department's campaign finance investigation, will replace the top Federal prosecutor and F.B.I. agent in charge of the inquiry with more experienced personnel. The reshuffling is an attempt to get control of the agency's most important investigation, one that has created serious internal tensions, demands for the appointment of an independent prosecutor and accusations that she has refused to seek such a counsel to protect the White House. Clinton to State Tobacco Policy

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
ROTH, ARTHUR THOMAS

 BODY:
ROTH-Arthur Thomas, ninetyone, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, September 17, at his home of sixty years in Rockville Centre, New York. He will long be remembered in American banking circles for the extraordinary innovations he successfully brought to commercial banking as CEO of the Franklin National Bank before retiring in 1968, and more locally for his dynamic role in spearheading the phenomenal economic growth of Long Island following W.W. II for which the press dubbed him "Mr. Long Island". His family however will remember him as a loving husband, father and grandfather whose generosity, warmth, strength, and will to do the right thing is deeply impressed on them all. His many acts of community and church leadership and his widespread philanthropy speak for themselves. He leaves his wife of 67 years, Genevieve, and his daughter Mrs. Carol Madigan of Oldwick, New Jersey, and son, Donald Arthur Roth of E. Setauket, N.Y., their spouses John P. Madigan, Jr. and Mrs. Patricia Roth, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. He will be interred at the Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York, on Saturday, September 20, following a 9 AM Mass of the Resurrection at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre. Visitation will be at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, on Thursday and Friday between 2 and 4 PM and 7 and 9 PM.
ROTH-Arthur. EAB mourns the death of Arthur Roth, a great banking innovator and a great friend, and extends its condolences to the family. Edward Travaglianti Brendan J. Dugan EAB Office of the Chairman
