HEADLINE: With a Nod and a Wink

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
WHEN Marcel Duchamp put a bicycle seat on the wall and called it art, the world of decorating changed forever.
It is reassuring to remember this every so often, amid the angst over what fabric will spiff up that impossible 10-year-old sofa and the nagging suspicion that fine furniture is only for connoisseurs. Decorating was once a tortuous match game. Now, it is just as tedious to hunt and gather the right pieces to achieve the ever-elusive personal style. 
 Minimalism may be nobody's idea of fun, but it sure made the job easier.
It's time to spread a wider net. Two Manhattan designers who have done so are Kevin Roberts and Timothy Haynes. They hold that a Louis XVI settee and a skateboarding teen-ager can coexist in the same living room, that one can demand ease even while yearning for elegance. Welcome to a style of decorating that one can live with and even love.
The rules of decorating have never been more relaxed, but that, too, can be a challenge: if anything goes, where to begin?
Mr. Roberts and Mr. Haynes don't get their rules from a pattern book. They learn from the scale, proportions and lines of painting and sculpture, from the character of architecture and the wisdom of other cultures (Mr. Roberts started as an anthropologist).
O.K., so they're professionals. It's their job to stockpile experience and have clever ideas. But what makes them stand out as leaders of a new interior design direction is the way they honor both the esthetic high ground and the reality of daily use. "I had very stiff grandparents who liked formal rooms that we were never allowed to enter," Mr. Roberts recalled. "I learned early that the only houses that make sense are houses that get used."
So the first thing he asks a client is, "Where are you going to flop?"
In three projects, Mr. Roberts and Mr. Haynes faced typical hurdles: giving a rented loft in Manhattan personality; making a hallway kitchen less of a drawback in a tiny Upper East Side town-house apartment, and lending spaciousness to a period house in Cambridge, Mass., with small rooms and low ceilings. The standout interiors they put together share one thing: an easy elegance.
So where does Marcel Duchamp come in? "The freedom to take furniture out of context and let it stand like sculpture came straight from the Dada movement," said Mr. Roberts, whose second rule of thumb is, wherever possible, to allow each piece breathing space. He prefers classics, whether pedigree or plain beat up, so treating an armchair like a piece of sculpture is not as precious as it sounds. Breaking the lock step of sofa, chair and coffee table can also be practical, he insists. He lets the dynamics of life decide where the furniture goes.
Mr. Roberts, the decorator of the team, uses an old French upholsterer's trick to give a fine chair multiple lives: he'll take a Jacobean armchair, for instance, and put green velvet on the front and a green and white check on the back, making it interesting from any angle, whether at a dining table or a computer terminal.
"There's no wrong spot," he says.
In the Cambridge house one day, Mr. Roberts stepped into the breach as a dry cleaner's van sat idling outside. He ran around searching out the dirty laundry. He and Mr. Haynes, the architect, treat their clients with the old-fashioned courtliness of a young Ogden Codman humoring his client Edith Wharton.
"I find it helps keep things in perspective," Mr. Roberts said. "When clients get hysterical about a delayed schedule, I'm the one reminding them that none of this is about life and death, but about making living pleasant." And good humor can be as easy as placing a classical bust in the kitchen for a hatrack.
Mr. Roberts fondly remembers when the house of Joan and Elon Kohlberg in Cambridge was "a dark, dinky little dollhouse." The front rooms are so small that 12 paces mark off the living room. So the designers did something radical without tearing out a single wall. They treated the front half of the house -- living room, dining room and entrance -- as a continuous space by using the same wallpaper and placing light-color furniture throughout.
"You can trick yourself into seeing the rooms look bigger," Mr. Roberts said. He pointed to another artful device for fooling the eye: eliminating rugs and using only furniture with legs (wrought-iron garden tables can look especially lyrical) makes the space flow. To soften the bare floors of the living room, he covered a huge ottoman in an Oriental-rug pattern that cleverly alludes to the real thing. "Whenever I come over, that's where the kids are," he said, referring to the two Kohlberg sons.
Mr. Roberts and Mr. Haynes agree that no matter how modest the home, creating a sense of architecture is worth the effort. They take their cue in this from Edith Wharton, whose 1898 manifesto, "The Decoration of Houses," is often credited with upgrading interior design from upholstery to an art and avocation.
Bland architecture may be the curse of post-World War II dwellings. Still, there's hope. "Without good bones, you are lost and there's no Band-Aid," Mr. Roberts said, "but good bones are easily gotten. All you need is one good wall."
At the Kohlberg house, five-foot-high wainscoting in the kitchen and white-painted wood paneling in the dining room were low-key, hard-working additions. They add architectural interest and create informal backdrops to sophisticated pairings of the incongruous: a Roman bust on a Deco console; a Chinese chair alongside a painted Swedish chest.
And in the 3,500-square-foot Manhattan loft, the designers created an illusion of columns by hanging 10-foot-tall curtains of green Thai silk.
 ONCE you've seen how other people live, it opens you up to considering ways of doing things that might never have occurred to you," Mr. Roberts said. He described a mountaintop plantation house without walls he once visited in Jamaica where the clouds passed through the living room, and a cozy haven of a bedroom tucked under the gables of a Swiss house overlooking Lake Geneva. He carries his wide vocabulary of images to the most pedestrian job sites.
The idea of hiding a banal kitchen in the loft behind a beautiful screen came from grand 19th-century apartments in Paris. "When plumbing was added to these perfect rooms," Mr. Haynes said, "they dealt with it very casually."
And sometimes, "the solution to a problem is exactly what makes a place special," he added.
The tiny town-house apartment of Elizabeth Tops and Arnie Lizan on the Upper East Side seemed to have an insoluble defect: the only way to get to the living room was through a kitchen.
So the design team made the most of the awful truth and turned the kitchen into an illuminated manuscript by covering the walls with exotic wallpaper -- saffron yellow with a Gothic-style fretwork pattern. The result is so bright and unexpected that visitors pass through dazzled, without noticing the dishes in the sink.
Wallpaper has many uses. The designers employed it to great advantage in the loft, where they fabricated the kitchen screen in a jiffy by stapling a foliage print from Zuber to a makeshift wooden frame. "It made the whole place feel like the trees outdoors had been drawn in," Mr. Haynes said.
And the designers use panoramic wallpapers to make tiny spaces, especially foyers and dens, look bigger.
"They give a tremendous sense of quality," Mr. Haynes said. "We use them a lot in new construction. It's a great way to get beyond wallboard."
The designers have heard the talk about a return to luxury, but they aren't buying it. "The 80's are over for good," Mr. Haynes said. "People don't want to recreate the luxuries of the past, but they do want some glamorous things." It's what sets grown-up homes apart from dorm rooms.
Consider the antique sconce. For the loft, Mr. Roberts bought two over-the-top, four-foot-tall sconces that epitomized his idea of luxury -- something that is part gorgeous, part useless. Mirrors, when they have lost their silver, can still convey faded glamour.
Paint is the most economical luxury of all. Walls of Granny Smith apple green make a fashion splash in the loft and make its white 1960's armchairs pop.
There are stunning pieces in the tiny town-house apartment -- a reproduction 17th-century English sofa and Marie Antoinette armchairs with tapestry seats. But in Mr. Haynes's view, the layering of saturated color is what invests the room with theatrical richness. He points to the contrast of Cognac velvet against a pale, chalky green wall and an Esteban Vicente painting splashed with reds and golds.
"It's not about the antiques that happen to be there," Mr. Roberts said of this apartment and also of the team's design approach. "But in the end, it's the composition that makes all the impact."

HEADLINE: New York Arts Council Wins 15 Percent Increase

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
While the National Endowment for the Arts is struggling to survive, its state counterpart, the New York State Council on the Arts, has quietly won an increase of nearly 15 percent in its budget from Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature.
The 37-year-old state arts council emerged from the raucous budget fray in Albany a few weeks ago with a budget of $40.8 million for this fiscal year, up from $35.7 million last year. While other states' arts agencies received increases this year, New York, which has the largest budget of any state, increased its arts budget by a greater percentage than many other states. 
 Though the most ardent arts champions say the increase is still insufficient, veterans of previous budget battles said they were satisfied. Coming on the heels of a $3 million increase last year, they said, the current rise means that the arts council's budget has grown by almost a third in two years. It also shows that the council itself is finally rebounding, they said, from the budget reductions and downsizing of the New York City and State fiscal crises of the mid-70's, and the recession that hit the state during the administration of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. During the recession of the late 80's and early 90's, the council's budget was cut almost in half, as was its staff.
"We're clearly on our way back at last," said Reba White Williams, an art historian and a member of the council's 10-person, unpaid board.
The increase is due partly to the strong economy and budget surplus in Albany but also to months of low-key, persistent lobbying by arts groups.
"It's not just enough to have a budget surplus," said Jonathan Katz, who heads the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies in Washington.
In New York, arts supporters credited the increase to advocacy in the State Senate by Roy Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, who is chairman of the Senate Special Committee on the Arts and Cultural Affairs; in the Assembly by Paul A. Tokasz, Democrat of Buffalo, the new chairman of the Assembly's Tourism, Arts and Sports Development Committee; and in the Pataki administration by Earle Mack, the New Jersey real estate developer, who was appointed by the Governor to head the council 16 months ago. Mr. Mack, a major supporter of the ballet, succeeded Kitty Carlisle Hart, the beloved performer now in her 80's, who stepped down after serving through five administrations.
Because Mrs. Hart was greatly admired, the nomination of Mr. Mack, who was a financial supporter of Mr. Pataki's campaign, was greeted suspiciously by many artists and arts organizations. But he has since earned significant respect.
"Getting the budget increases was nothing short of miraculous," Mrs. Hart said of her successor.
The New York council has distributed more than $900 million in grants ranging from hundreds to many thousands of dollars since it was established by the Legislature in 1960 at the behest of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. Mr. Rockefeller made public support for the arts one of his priorities.
Last year, panels of artists in 15 disciplines sifted through more than 4,000 requests for grants, awarding 2,869 grants to more than 1,300 museums, cultural heritage groups and performing arts companies throughout the state.
New York arts groups receive more money from the National Endowment for the Arts than groups in any other state, but the state council gives more money to the groups than the endowment does. Last year, the endowment awarded about $17 million to New York-based groups, less than half of that awarded by the state council.
"We wouldn't have today's rich network of Off and Off Off Broadway theaters were it not for N.Y.S.C.A.," said Robert Marx, the director of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, who was the director of the council's theater program between 1976 and 1982.
Mr. Marx noted that the national endowment was patterned on New York's arts council and drew some of its early staff from it.
But the state council, he added, has rarely been subjected to the political pressures that have battered the national endowment, insulation that Mr. Marx attributes mainly to New York's more liberal political climate and to Mrs. Hart's stewardship.
Mrs. Hart said it was easier to rally support for the arts in New York than in Congress because of the arts' obvious importance to the economy. "You'd have to be living in a tree not to understand what the arts mean to New York," she said.
Unfortunately, Mrs. Hart and Mr. Marx agreed, Governor Cuomo did not share his Republican predecessor's commitment to the council. When fiscal retrenchment was necessary, many areas of public spending were cut, but the retrenchment for the council was particularly severe. "If we at N.Y.S.C.A. made a mistake," Mr. Marx said, "it was in failing to prepare for the day when money would be tight and Rockefeller would no longer be governor."
Suddenly the arts had to compete in Albany for a share of a shrinking budget. While the Republican-dominated Senate traditionally protected arts money, the Assembly, long a Democratic preserve, favored giving the limited state money to social welfare projects.
Norma P. Munn, who heads the New York City Arts Coalition, which represents small as well as larger institutions, credited Mr. Tokasz and Mr. Mack with having helped persuade the Assembly to become a real partner in obtaining money for the arts. "They were both enormously helpful," she said.
Mr. Mack said that a key to his strategy was underscoring the arts' importance to the state's fiscal health. During his first week on the job, Mr. Mack dined with Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, to discuss how to emphasize the arts' economic impact. A result was a joint study by McKinsey & Company that concluded that Government arts support is a low-risk, high-yield investment that recovers several times its cost in taxes and generates billions of dollars in economic benefits.
Also, when Mr. Mack calls, Albany tends to listen. A major campaign contributor to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Mack also gave $25,000 to Mr. Pataki's 1994 campaign and helped organize a major fund-raiser. Though somewhat shy and deliberately low key, he manages to find common ground with upstate and city legislators.
The major budget battle behind him, Mr. Mack is now raising private support to supplement the $350,000 Albany has given the council for an arts technology conference next March and rebuilding the council's staff. He also got a small increase in the honorarium for the dozens of New Yorkers who serve on the council's grant-making panels. "Now they'll get $100 a day instead of $75," he said.

HEADLINE: Brother (or Sister), Can You Spare a Dime for a Boom-Era Economist?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The better the economy, the worse things seem to get for economists.
Fifteen years of expansion interrupted by just one brief downturn in the early 1990's have helped to erode the market for the people in American corporations who study the economy for a living. "If your job is forecasting recessions, you've got a pretty sleepy job," said Paul Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. 
 That was just one reason that the annual meeting of the National Association for Business Economics, which concluded here today in this city known for celebrating good times, was such a sedate affair.
Sustained prosperity, corporate downsizing that has made research expendable and a backlash against the economic fraternity's inflated forecasting claims have all combined to make the life of a business economist tougher than ever. Indeed, for a lot of economists these days, job insecurity is not an abstract principle but a day-to-day reality.
Much of the program at the meeting was given over to self-improvement panels on topics like "successful job switching," "hot career opportunities" and "how economists can play a role in their firm's decision making," and corridor talk often began with old friends telling of new jobs or the search for them.
Among the missing was Alison Lynn Reaser. A former economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, she lost that job in the takeover by Wells Fargo & Company. She landed at Barnett Banks in Florida but is now uncertain of what will happen after its acquisition by Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C. Ms. Reaser had signed up to attend the meeting here but could not make it because of a freeze on travel by Barnett, a friend said.
"Hundreds of economists are in the same boat," said Ken Ackbarali, a Los Angeles consultant who lost his job in the Wells Fargo takeover of First Interstate.
John H. Ortego was left behind in Albany when his one-time employer, the Key Corporation, moved to Cleveland. "I have joined the army of the self-employed," said Mr. Ortego, who just resigned his latest post as an economist in Buffalo with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
While banks and industrial companies have been trimming economics departments for years, the employment distress in this field has never been so acute. And the contrast with the 1980's -- which started with a deep recession and saw record Federal budget deficits amid a booming stock market and the end of high inflation -- could not be starker.
"We were in nirvana as economists in the early 80's," said Bernard M. Markstein, who set up a consulting business in Phoenixville, Pa., after losing a job at Meridian Bank just before it was taken over by Corestates Bank.
Now, cost-conscious senior management finds little use for predictions from in-house experts when a wide array of forecasts, none of them particularly more trustworthy than another, are readily available.
"Forecasting," Mr. Markstein acknowledged, "is not what we do best."
Not that they don't keep trying. The National Association for Business Economics consensus predicts that the economy will grow 2.3 percent next year. And slightly more than half of the respondents are forecasting a recession in 1999. But even the experts do not put much stock in those predictions. "There was a lot of money to be made" in forecasting, especially of interest rates, said William Dunkelberg, an economics professor at Temple University and chief consultant to the National Federation of Independent Business. "Now we know we can't do that."
That explains why the association, which has seen membership decline 10 percent over the last decade, is searching for a new identity.
"We are less and less an association of traditional members doing macroeconomics forecasting in a corporate center economic unit," said C. Mark Dadd of AT&T, the current president of the association. To reflect the new reality, the group just changed its name from the National Association "of Business Economists" to the National Association "for Business Economics."
Its new mission is to help members apply their economic skills to specific corporate problems rather than make grand but dubious pronouncements about the entire economy.
This somewhat humbler ambition seemed especially striking when set against the opening address on Monday by Jack Guynn, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, who declared the stellar performance of the economy to be a triumph of national economic policy making rather than favorable circumstances and improved corporate competitiveness.
"The conventional explanations," he said, "do not recognize the central role of the monetary policy the Fed has made over the past 17 years and the more recent contribution of improved fiscal policy."
At other sessions, one speaker after another concentrated on practical ways for economists to "add value," enhancing their careers by filling such specialty niches as litigation analysis and transfer pricing or adopting strategies for turning themselves into executives.
In the end, several economists noted, they are victims of the very market forces that the profession so often exults. And with the market changing, economists must change, too.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The latest move by China toward capitalism: Is it real?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
KARL MARX envisioned the withering away of the state as the final stage of the socialist revolution. But it is unlikely he had in mind today's China, where President Jiang Zemin just broadened the definition of "public ownership" to include publicly held private companies and announced that the vast majority of state-owned enterprises would soon be left to the fate of the free market.
What Mr. Jiang meant is not yet clear. "Everybody's calling it 'privatization,' which may not be the case," cautioned Robert Dernberger, director of the Center for Chinese Studies at the University of Michigan. "All we really know is that Jiang made it politically correct to sell shares" in all but a handful of enterprises. 
 But Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development, thinks he sees the writing on the wall. "They've reached the conclusion that state ownership won't work; China is now committed to free markets," he concluded.
China has been experimenting with its own eclectic mix of capitalism and socialism since 1979. The first step was the liberalization of agriculture, replacing communes with long-term land leases. That permitted peasants to keep the proceeds from their extra production, nearly duplicating the incentives of private enterprise while maintaining state ownership of land. And it paid off: while farm output grew by 5 percent annually from 1978 to 1995, the portion of the work force on farms fell to 53 percent from 72 percent.
In the second wave of near-capitalist reforms, small, community-owned industrial enterprises were permitted to blossom, absorbing much of the labor freed by productivity gains in agriculture. "Special economic zones" -- free markets, by another name -- were created in southern coastal cities. And their success induced some 90 other cities to demand partial exemption from Beijing's rules on labor, taxes and foreign investment.
Strikingly, though, the growth of free enterprise did not come at the expense of the socialist sector. Always viewed by the Communist leadership as its political base, state-owned industry has been coddled with Government orders and capital.
Thus, while the portion of gross domestic product generated by the state fell to just 34 percent in 1994, from 78 percent in 1978, both employment and output in Government enterprises actually grew. Today (as in the early 1980's) roughly one Chinese adult in five works for the state.
But the state sector is hardly healthy. Since the mid-1980's, managers have been granted freedom to produce what they want and sell it for what the market will bear -- as long as they maintained the "iron rice bowl" guarantees of employment and minimum living standards. The catch, argues Harry Broadman, a senior economist at the World Bank, is that enterprises rarely confronted a "hard budget constraint."
State enterprises got to convert the fruits of their successes into wages and bonuses, but were bailed out with loans or direct subsidies when they failed. Indeed, the neither-fish-nor-fowl character of the state enterprises produced much the effect that "perestroika" had in the last days of the Soviet Union: managers routinely played the system by taking out loans they could not repay, counting unsalable products as inventory -- or simply sold off assets to meet expenses.
The big difference, Mr. Sachs argues, is that China could carry its state sector because the business sector outside the state was so large and growing so rapidly. Why, then, the latest, seemingly radical pronouncements on reform?
One possibility is that President Jiang is bluffing in hopes of getting managers to shape up. But there are reasons to believe Beijing no longer has the room to reverse course that it had in the 1980's.
Wing Thye Woo, an economist at the University of California at Davis, predicts that "asset-stripping by managers will accelerate" once they discover "this is their last chance to steal." Hence, a reversion to direct state control would mean a serious loss of face for the leadership -- or worse, charges of corruption.
Equally important, Mr. Dernberger of the Center for Chinese Studies suggests, a subsidy-as-usual approach no longer represents a safe political alternative. While it may be possible to sustain the iron rice bowl for urban industrial workers, half-measures will not narrow the growing disparity in living standards between the socialist north and the capitalist south.
Besides, Mr. Sachs argues, the chance of unrest once state enterprises are left on their own has been exaggerated. He estimates that no more than 3 percent of the work force would lose jobs in a rapid restructuring -- a modest number compared with unemployment in the transition economies in Russia and its former satellites.
Indeed, Mr. Broadman sees this as the moment for China's canny, survival-oriented leaders to seize the day. "With the economy booming," he said, "they can afford the hard decisions."

HEADLINE: Federal Agency Is Proposing Regulation for Mortgage Brokers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The mortgage broker initially told Erick and Barbara Barbosa that their interest rate on a 30-year loan for the $78,000 house they were buying in North Miami Beach would be 8.75 percent. At closing, he told them it had jumped to 9.5 percent because interest rates were rising.
"I was amazed at how fast it went up," Mr. Barbosa said. 
 Several weeks later, the Barbosas learned from their lawyer that interest rates in general had not increased at all -- that, for a consideration, the broker had steered the Barbosas to a lender charging a higher rate.
With the number of transactions like that increasing each year, the Housing Department today announced that it was proposing a regulation to require mortgage brokers to declare in writing whom they represent -- the buyer, a lender or both -- when a buyer seeks the broker's help.
"Too often consumers think the brokers are working for them," Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo said at a news conference with the Barbosas. "In reality, they are working against them."
Mortgage brokers are a relatively new element of home buying, playing a major role only in the last decade. In theory, a broker shops around to find a buyer the best possible deal and receives a fee at closing as part of the settlement, usually a small percentage of the mortgage or a flat sum.
Jan Hix, president of the National Mortgage Brokers Association, said her group how has 52,000 members, and according to Housing Department data, they were involved in half of the country's 3 million mortgage transactions last year, handling about $333 billion in deals.
Mr. Cuomo said the new regulation is needed because "a small number of bad brokers are scamming the system" by driving up purchasing costs for home buyers, costing them thousands of extra dollars over the term of the mortgage.
The Barbosas, who sued the broker and renegotiated their mortgage as part of a settlement, the terms of which they would not disclose, said the higher interest rate would have cost them $18,000 over the term of the mortgage.
Under the proposed rule, which must survive Congressional review to go into effect, a mortgage broker would indicate all sources of fees and what exactly those fees will be.
By refusing, Mr. Cuomo said, the broker would be presumed to be in violation of the 1974 Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act for charging excessive fees. That is punishable by penalties of up to a year in prison and a $10,000 fine.
Ms. Hix said she "did not think much" of the proposal, since her association adopted a similar -- but voluntary -- guideline for brokers three months ago. She also said the association had not received a single complaint over broker practices and she was unaware of any complaints filed with state real estate boards.
"We have already taken steps to address this issue," she said in a telephone conference call with reporters. "We have a model disclosure form, urging members to describe how they are compensated."
While implementation of the regulation could take several months, Mr. Cuomo said the department had set up a telephone number for prospective mortgage buyers to call with any questions about brokers. It is 1-800-217-6970.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing Dropped by 4.8% in August

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Housing construction unexpectedly dropped in August as builders started projects at the slowest pace this year, though the broad economy shows few signs of losing its steady-growth, low-inflation rhythm.
Housing starts fell 4.8 percent last month to an annualized 1.363 million, Commerce Department figures showed today, suggesting that a decline in mortgage rates had yet to rekindle demand for new homes. Permits for new construction also dropped, and July's total of housing starts was revised lower, showing a decline of almost 5 percent. 
 A separate Federal Reserve report signaled that labor shortages had yet to translate into rising consumer or industrial prices. Bond investors welcomed the news as further evidence of slower growth that would keep inflation in check and give the Fed little reason to raise borrowing costs.
In the housing report, all regions of the nation reported fewer starts, with the Northeast accounting for the greatest decline. Last December was the last time new construction came in this low, falling to an annual pace of 1.353 million.
Builders are cautious because the number of prospective buyers is declining, though sales have yet to slow. "The demand for homes seems to still be there, but in the past three weeks there has been a considerable slide in traffic," said Lori Steiner, vice president of Dominion Homes. "It could be because people are busy getting their kids back into school, but we're watching that trend."
Even so, the pace of new-housing starts for the first eight months of the year -- 1.449 million -- remains close to the eight-year high of 1.476 million recorded in 1996.
The Federal Reserve -- in its latest regional economic outlook, known as the beige book -- said that "with a few exceptions, prices for goods are said to be moving very little, if at all, at the manufacturing level for inputs or finished goods, and at the retail level." Labor shortages, though widespread, "are not translating into generally higher wages," the Fed survey said.
Those findings suggest that the central bank is in no hurry to raise interest rates. Its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee next meets on Sept. 30.
While growth continued in all 12 Federal Reserve districts, "some districts note signs of slowing in selected sectors," the survey said. "About half the districts say their overall pace picked up in July and August while the others report continued moderate growth."
The regional-outlook survey is based on reports from the Fed's 12 district banks. It is published eight times a year. The latest edition was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, with the information collected before Sept. 8.
Also pointing to subdued growth and low inflation, new figures from the American Bankers Association today showed an almost 4 percent rise in late credit-card payments in the second quarter, while the Labor Department said that import prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in August.
The Commerce Department report suggests that the "housing market has topped out," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, and unless low mortgage rates start it back up, "it looks like it's going to subtract from third-quarter growth."
Mortgage rates, a key ingredient in whether people buy homes, continued to decline in August, though by the end of the month they had again risen a bit.
The average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage was 7.48 percent in August, down slightly from 7.50 percent in July. That put the average principal and interest payment on a $100,000 loan at $697.85 last month, down from $699.21 in July.

HEADLINE: With or Without U.S., Latin Trade Group Is Marching Forward

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 17

 BODY:
After years of backstage rivalry between Brazil and the United States over which country's vision will shape the rules of trade in this part of the hemisphere, a high-level economic conference here has emerged as a coming-out party for Mercosur, a Brazilian-led South American trade group.
Leaders who spoke before the World Economic Forum, a business-financed research group that met last week in Sao Paulo, acknowledged the advances Mercosur had made in promoting regional trade. They also noted that the United States had done little to advance President Clinton's 1994 pledge at the Summit of the Americas in Miami to create a "Free Trade Area of the Americas from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego" by 2005. 
 "I don't want to rule out the Free Trade Area of the Americas," President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina said in his opening address to the group, "but charity begins at home."
The Brazilian Foreign Minister, Luiz Felipe Lampreia, also noted that trade was soaring among the four Mercosur members -- Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay -- and that the alliance was signing accords with the European Union and the Andean Pact, a trade group in western South America.
"Mercosur is not a stage toward a Free Trade Area of the Americas," he said. "It is an end in itself."
Mr. Lampreia said that Brazil now buys 30 percent of Argentina's exports and that Argentina sells more to Brazil than to the United States. In just a few years, Mr. Menem said, Argentina's trade with Mercosur countries has grown fivefold, to 20 percent of its total trade.
President Clinton's so-called fast-track authority -- the power to negotiate trade deals that Congress can accept or reject but not amend -- expired three years ago. The White House announced last week that the fight was on to restore it, and on Tuesday Mr. Clinton forwarded a bill to the House. Administration officials are arguing that Mercosur and other regional trade groups will make deals that exclude the United States unless the President can negotiate new trade agreements without Congressional involvement.
The President's special envoy for Latin American and Caribbean affairs, Thomas F. McLarty, visited the Sao Paulo meeting and indicated Washington's qualified acceptance of Mercosur, which he described as one of "many paths to achieving a Free Trade Area of the Americas."
He avoided the question of Mercosur's role in any future Free Trade Area of the Americas. But the growth of Mercosur appears to have posed more urgent questions for Washington than whose trade pact will prevail in 2005.
"Americans must be aware that trade liberalization is taking place at a very fast pace in the Americas," said Alvaro Garcia, the Chilean Economic Minister, "and any country that is not part of that is losing out."
Mr. Garcia said Chile had signed free trade agreements with Canada and Mexico, and had also joined Mercosur as an associate member. As a result, companies from those countries can compete on more favorable terms for Chilean contracts than American companies can.
Mr. Garcia noted that recent privatization contracts had gone to Canadian companies because United States concerns would face an 11 percent tariff on equipment they brought in.
In an allusion to the United States and the Miami meeting, Mr. Garcia added, "The only actor that's been absent until now has been the host of the summit."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rise Somewhat on Congenial Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were mostly higher yesterday, buoyed by weak housing-start figures for August and a friendly Federal Reserve report on business conditions.
Still, ebbs and flows in trading were prevalent throughout the session, as advances were often stymied by investors' seemingly balking at the higher prices that resulted from Monday's sharp rally and the consolidation of those gains by others investors. Many in the market are waiting for figures beyond Monday's Consumer Price Index to justify any further moves higher. 
 Stephanie Davis, fixed-income analyst at Technical Data of Boston, said: "Today's data did not provide any fresh incentives for the market. The market politely accepted yesterday's rally off of C.P.I. data, and sentiment remains bullish as we await the next big move." That may not come until next week's report on durable-goods orders, she said.
The 30-year bond rose 7/32 to a price of 99 26/32 to yield 6.39 percent, down from 6.41 percent on Tuesday.
Bond buying gained impetus early in the session when the Commerce Department reported that new-home construction fell 4.8 percent in August to an annualized 1.363 million units. That was lower than the 1.450 million some economists had expected and the lowest monthly pace of the year.
Some analysts said that the housing statistics should be considered an aberration until proved otherwise. Others, however, said that the weaker August housing starts had not been signaled by traditional indicators like interest rates, personal income and consumer confidence and home-mortgage applications. Rather, they were signaled by falling residential-construction contracts.
"At this juncture," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "virtually all market participants are expecting the Fed to keep monetary policy unchanged at its Sept. 30 Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Indeed, the economy's forward momentum has not yet produced any corresponding lift in inflation, and until there is a translation from strong economic growth to increasing inflationary pressures, Fed policy will likely remain stationary."
The Fed last raised short-term interest rates in March, when the target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, was increased to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent.
Yesterday afternoon's release by the Fed of its beige book report on regional business conditions caused bonds to advance further into positive territory, as investors got a glimpse of what the Fed will have in hand when its monetary-policy committee meets on Sept. 30.
The report indicated that continuing economic growth would create little wage or price pressure. "While in reality, the beige book was for the most part a verbal description of the economic data already released over the past few weeks," Mr. Fine said, "the market found it reassuring nevertheless."
Also yesterday, the Treasury announced the size of note auctions next week, which were left unchanged, with $15.5 billion of two-year securities being sold on Tuesday and an $11.5 billion offering of five-year notes Wednesday. In when-issued trading ahead of the sales, the two-year issue was offered at a price to yield 5.78 percent, and the five-year at a price to yield 5.96 percent.

HEADLINE: An Old School Inflation Fighter;
Fed Official Resists Notion of a New Era in Economics

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Inflation is almost nonexistent despite steady growth and an unemployment rate hovering near a quarter-century low. Companies are chalking up ever-higher profits. Millions of investors are basking in the glow of the longest, strongest bull market on record. Even curmudgeons like Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, are increasingly optimistic that the economy is undergoing a transformation that should yield more good times ahead.
So who would dare to rain on the parade? 
 Larry Meyer might, for one. Mr. Meyer, one of Mr. Greenspan's fellow governors on the Federal Reserve Board, has emerged as one of the most outspoken and influential of those disputing the notion that the economy has entered a new era in which old rules about the interplay among growth, unemployment and inflation are becoming less reliable and less relevant.
In doing so, Mr. Meyer is subtly but unmistakably challenging some of the views held by Mr. Greenspan, whose thinking so dominates monetary policy that it is rarely questioned in public by other Fed officials.
Yet at the same time, Fed officials said, Mr. Meyer's role as an intellectual foil for Mr. Greenspan has helped invigorate the debate within the central bank over some of the most critical issues of the day.
And they said that by articulating the cautious, traditionalist view, Mr. Meyer was acting as a powerful anchor at the Fed. That gives Mr. Greenspan greater leeway to show Congress and the public that the central bank takes seriously the possibility that the economy's ability to grow faster without inflation has been permanently improved by factors like corporate America's huge investments in technology.
Laurence H. Meyer, 53, is a Bronx native who joined the Fed last year largely unknown to the general public but with a reputation as one of the nation's most brilliant economic forecasters. He says that the economy's stellar performance of late may require tweaking some rules that have long governed interest-rate policy, but by no means invalidates them.
Reduced to its simplest form, his argument is that there is little evidence so far to overturn what has long been a central tenet of policy making at the Fed: If the economy grows faster than around 2.2 percent a year for a sustained period when unemployment is low and factories are running near full tilt, it will eventually ignite inflation, threaten the continuation of the expansion and require raising interest rates to cool things off.
Just today, in a speech in Pittsburgh, Mr. Meyer emphasized that the Fed could not afford to ignore the lessons economists have gleaned from the past in assessing whether the present has changed so much that it promises a rosier future.
"There are limits," Mr. Meyer said. "They may not be the old limits that disciplined policy in the past. But even if the limits are new, they must be respected. Overheating is a natural product of expansions that overtax these limits. Recessions typically follow overheating. Good policy must therefore balance regularities and possibilities."
As a sparring match, the intellectual face-off between Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Meyer is not much. There is no animosity between the men, and their statements on the subject are directed at answering the most vexing question to face policy makers in years, rather than at each other.
Their debate is couched in the dense reasoning and cautious language used by Fed officials whenever they speak publicly. And despite their differing perspectives, Mr. Meyer has voted in lockstep with Mr. Greenspan on whether and when to change interest rate policy, and seems likely to continue doing so.
But Mr. Meyer is the only member of the Fed's policy making body other than Mr. Greenspan to have spent his career dissecting the business cycle and rooting out clues to incipient inflation. And he is the only one to have delivered a series of carefully constructed defenses of the rules and equations that economists have long used to track inflation risks from strong growth and declining unemployment.
"Larry Meyer is somebody who's worthy to challenge Chairman Greenspan's breadth and scope of knowledge on monetary policy," said Allen Sinai, an economist at Primark Decisions Economics. "He provides a check on the power that Chairman Greenspan may hold over the Fed in terms of his knowledge of the nitty-gritty and his presumed forecasting power."
Some analysts believe Mr. Meyer is consciously positioning himself to become the Fed board's most determined inflation fighter in an effort to vault himself over the central bank's vice chairwoman, Alice M. Rivlin, as the leading inside candidate to succeed Mr. Greenspan.
But Fed officials said that was unlikely, and Mr. Meyer has told colleagues he does not consider himself to have any chance at the job.
Still, Mr. Meyer's willingness to stake out a clear position is one manifestation of how the conundrum over what is happening to the economy has upset the traditional roles within the Fed. Mr. Greenspan, a Republican who was long viewed as a dogmatic, uncompromising inflation fighter, has emerged in the last year as far more pragmatic and patient in assessing possible changes than either his supporters or critics would have believed a year ago.
Mr. Meyer and, to a lesser extent, Mrs. Rivlin have been far more cautious. They were both appointed to the Fed last year by President Clinton, who had suggested not long before he nominated them that he was intrigued by the argument that the nation's potential to grow faster without worsening inflation was higher than most mainstream economists believed.
In speaking up, Mr. Meyer is reflecting growing frustration among many prominent economists that the speculation about a New Age Economy -- fueled in part by Mr. Greenspan's public flirtation with the idea -- has simply gone too far.
"Whatever one calls it, this new view of the economy has spread with a rapidity rare in the annals of economic thought," Paul Krugman, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, wrote in a recent article in The Harvard Business Review. "There is only one problem: when you think about it carefully, you realize that the new paradigm simply does not make sense."
In many ways, Mr. Meyer has been preparing for this debate his entire career. After receiving a B.A. at Yale University in 1965 and a doctorate in economics at M.I.T. in 1970, he went on to teach at Washington University in St. Louis. In 1982 he founded Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a consulting firm that soon became known for its sophisticated computer forecasting model of the American economy.
When he joined the Fed, he was initially taken aback at the power of the platform he had been given; he still winces when recalling how even his banal public statements moved the financial markets. But he has appeared increasingly comfortable lately in using his position to advance his argument -- both to the public and to other Fed members, who communicate remarkably little among themselves outside their eight meetings a year on monetary policy.
While Mr. Greenspan closely studies a combination of long-term historical trends and immediate indicators of what is happening in the real world -- one recent favorite of his has been the rate at which people voluntarily leave their jobs -- Mr. Meyer tends to put more trust in broad formulas.
In particular, Mr. Meyer remains a defender of a concept known as the nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment, or Nairu. It holds that if the rate of unemployment falls below a certain level and stays under the line, that wages, and ultimately prices, too, will begin to rise. And if the economy continues to grow faster than what many analysts consider its "speed limit" -- 2.2 percent or so annually -- such an increase in inflation is almost unavoidable.
Mr. Meyer, like many other economists, long pegged the Nairu at about 6 percent. With unemployment now running below 5 percent and no signs of inflation in sight, he has lately lowered his estimate to around 5.5 percent. Still, even though the level may be flexible depending on changes in labor markets and other long-term factors, he insists that there is no reason to believe that the concept is any less valid than it has ever been. The same is true, he said, of the Phillips curve, an equation that economists use to predict how fast inflation will accelerate as unemployment falls.
"It is possible that the Phillips curve and Nairu is simply the wrong analytical framework, but I doubt it and am not aware of another model of inflation dynamics that is ready to take its place," Mr. Meyer said in his speech today.
The implication is that Mr. Meyer believes that the economy has been growing well above its noninflationary potential -- a trend that if continued would ultimately create inflationary pressures.
Mr. Greenspan, by contrast, has long expressed doubts about Nairu, and has stressed recently the need for policy makers to be flexible in how they assess the economy.
"We are constantly evaluating how much we can infer from the past and how relationships might have changed," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech at Stanford University earlier this month. "In an ever-changing world, some element of discretion appears to be an unavoidable aspect of policy making."
The implication drawn by many analysts from Mr. Greenspan's position was that he would need some firmer evidence that inflation was on the verge of accelerating before he decided to raise interest rates -- and that formulas like Nairu by themselves did not provide that evidence.
Mr. Meyer, while willing to concede that some fundamental changes may be under way in the economy, strongly suggests that the biggest factors in explaining the current lack of inflation may be temporary, including the strong dollar, the reduction in the growth rate of health care costs, declining computer prices and low energy and food costs.
"Uncertainty about the source of the recent performance might be viewed as so great that the best course for monetary policy is a reactive posture, waiting for clear signs that inflation is rising and only tightening in response to such evidence," Mr. Meyer said. "I agree that the current uncertainty encourages caution, but not to the point of paralysis."

HEADLINE: Strong Dollar Taking a Toll On U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Fears that a strengthening dollar could undermine the growth in earnings of American companies in the third quarter have sent the stocks of some large multinational corporations reeling in recent weeks.
Shares of Eastman Kodak, Gillette, Coca-Cola and Polaroid have all been hit hard because of the impact of the dollar's rally. Earnings from abroad are reduced when they are converted at higher rates into dollars; at the same time, a stronger dollar can make American exports less competitive by raising their price in foreign currencies. 
 But many analysts contend that the declines and investor concerns may be overdone, which might help explain the stock market's recent volatility. Yesterday, things were calmer, with the Dow Jones industrial average off just 9.48 points, to 7,886.44.
The dollar has been strong for some time, these analysts note, and thus its impact has already been factored into earnings forecasts. Also, not that many companies beyond the major multinationals receive a large part of their revenue from overseas operations. And of those that do, some use hedging to minimize the risk of losses from currency fluctuations.
Such companies also tend to offer brand-name products that are not easily copied and are in high demand, which can help offset upward moves in the dollar.
"The true currency impact is not going to be more than a few cents," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. As a result, Ms. Cohen said, she has not changed her operating earnings estimate for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index this year even in the face of the dollar's rally.
Analysts also argue that much of the selling tied to a stronger dollar may actually be a response to the high prices reached by popular blue-chip stocks in comparison to their promised earnings. In other words, the dollar has been an excuse to get out.
"The dollar has been doing what it's been doing for a while," said Melissa Brown, director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities. "The market was due for a pause or a little bit of a correction -- not because of the dollar, but because of the overvaluation, because of the quick move up without a corresponding move in fundamentals.
"But I think something gets blamed for it, and the dollar was a good thing to blame," she said.
So far this year, the dollar is up 4.5 percent against the Japanese yen and 14.9 percent against the the German mark. The rally against the yen has been very volatile, with the dollar up as much as 9.8 percent before a sharp slide in May. It has rebounded some since. Against the mark, the dollar moved higher all year, rising as much as 22 percent, until a recent slide that has seen it fall 5.8 percent.
But what has focused most of the recent investor attention on the dollar was the sudden collapse this summer of Southeast Asian currencies and the consequent jump in the dollar. Against the Thai baht, the dollar is up 48 percent since July 2; it has also risen 19.4 percent against the Malaysian ringgit.
These moves have had their impact. But often the companies that have been hurt do not hedge -- or hedge only minimally -- against sudden swings in the dollar's value.
The most recent casualty was Polaroid, which does only a little hedging. Polaroid's stock fell 6 percent Tuesday after it said that a stronger dollar would hold third-quarter earnings to less than analyst estimates and would reduce profits. "The dollar just moved too quickly for us," Nancy Childs, a spokeswoman for Polaroid, said. Hedging, she added "didn't help us in this quarter." Yesterday, Polaroid shares stabilized, slipping only 1/16, to 51 15/16.
The stock of Kodak, which has abandoned the hedging for which it was well known in the 1980's, has plunged 13.9 percent since the company said on Monday that its share of the United States film business was slipping and that the rising dollar would hurt profits. Yesterday, its shares fell 5/8, to 56 3/8.
Kodak had similar dollar problems earlier this year. That announcement knocked the stock down 10.5 percent in a single trading session, on March 21.
But other companies having dollar problems do not seem to be paying such a price with investors. The Chrysler Corporation hedges some exposure to the yen by purchasing parts made in Japan for use in the cars it sells there, said Van Bussmann, a Chrysler economist.
But, excluding Australia and New Zealand, Chrysler has seen sales in the Asia-Pacific region decline by 22 percent through the end of August as the rising dollar increased the price of Chrysler's cars, he said. Yet, its share price rose 3/16 yesterday, to 37 1/4 -- a level less than half a point below its 1997 high.
And Microsoft is purposely risking a hit from the strong dollar, but has not been penalized as much as other companies. Microsoft shares are down 10.9 percent from their 1997 high, and yesterday fell 3 3/16, to 133 3/16. But they are up 61 percent for the year even as the company delays the introduction of the newest version of its Windows software.
Since the currency crisis in Southeast Asia, Microsoft has been selling its software products to local distributors in their home currencies, enduring any losses from the dollar's rise, said Orlando Ayala, a Microsoft senior vice president. He said that the company took a similar approach after the Mexican peso devaluation at the end of 1994 in hopes of keeping its market share. In that case, he said, Microsoft was able to maintain 40 percent sales growth in the region in 1994 and 1995.
So while some companies have been hit, the overall picture of expectations for the S.& P. 500 has not changed significantly.
According to earnings estimates gathered by the First Call Corporation, operating earnings for the S.& P. 500 are expected to grow 12.4 percent in the third quarter and 13.5 percent in the fourth quarter. Estimates have declined modestly in recent weeks but that is a normal trend as the reporting period approaches.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 3694 words

HEADLINE: Clinging to Its Past, Europe Is Warily Awaiting the Euro

SERIES: CHANGING MONEY: First of two articles

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: MOSBURG, Germany

 BODY:
Franz Schmid is old enough to have suffered his share of European upheaval, and now, as the century wanes, he is convinced that the Continent is on the brink of another disaster, one that will wipe out all he has slowly built from the ruins of Hitler's war.
A retired hairdresser with a solid house beside a Bavarian brook, Mr. Schmid experienced the inflationary chaos that gave Hitler his start. He was drafted into the German army and captured on the Russian front. When he put his life together after 1945, rising early, never taking a vacation, it was the rock-solid German mark that measured his passage to a modest affluence. 
 His conclusion: play with currencies and you play with fire. So, like about 60 percent of his fellow Germans, he is alarmed by a plan to ditch the world's second-largest reserve currency, the mark, and use a new money to change Europe. "The mark is part of us," Mr. Schmid said. "What do we need a worthless new money for?"
But several European governments -- including Germany's -- appear ready to scrap their national currencies and replace them with a single money, the euro, by 1999. They are set to impose the currency on restive, sometimes openly hostile, citizens, for whom union has become synonymous with stagnation and sacrifice. The political risk is enormous.
That risk is being taken with a bold aim: to forge greater European unity in an attempt to arrest the continent's relative decline in an American-dominated world. "There is nothing more political than money," said Richard Descoings, director of the French Institute of Political Studies. "Once each person has a euro in his pocket, the money will unite us as Americans are bound by the dollar."
But this has been a lousy decade in Europe. Unemployment is at levels not seen since the 1930's. Over the past five years, growth averaged little more than 1 percent, less than half the American level. The globalization embraced by the United States has struck fear into the European soul; war in Bosnia has shaken the continent.
For some time now, Europe has labored under a dread conviction that Asia is rising, America roaring along, while the old Continent sleeps amid its predatory ghosts.
The euro is potent medicine for this malaise. Each country that joins the common currency will surrender part of its national sovereignty by turning over key economic decisions to a European Central Bank in Frankfurt. This bank will set interest rates and impose a fiscal discipline so strict that a profound reshaping of Europe's costly welfare state appears inevitable.
In the United States, too, there is a broad push to reshape welfare programs. But Europe is a customs union, not a country, and the cuts in spending required by adoption of the euro result from the planning of faceless central bankers rather than an election in which one vision for the future has trumped another.
Skeptics worry that the architects of the euro are inviting disaster by imposing a single economic policy on diverse countries with vastly differing traditions, national identities and economic philosophies. But supporters insist that this surrender of national sovereignty is the only way for Europe to challenge the United States' global economic power, closing the American century with an act of European emancipation.
"The euro has come to be seen as a thing imposed by an elite," said Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the French Finance Minister, "but it is the only way to make Europe strong in the decades to come."
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, already in the history books as the helmsman of German reunification, thinks he has a vision that will immortalize him a second time: end a bloody century -- in which Europe twice ripped itself to shreds and the United States twice came to its rescue -- by creating a single money in a market of 372 million people. Which will usher in a united Europe with a united Germany at its heart.
To reassure his fellow Europeans once and for all about his country's intentions, Mr. Kohl stands ready to sacrifice the country's best-loved symbol, the mark. It is an extraordinary political step -- akin to suggesting that the surrender of the American flag might somehow be in its people's interest. The euro will rise or fall with Germany, which accounts for 25 percent of the European Union's total output.
The outcome remains very much in doubt. The euro is to become Europe's money on Jan. 1, 1999. Will it bring strength or chaos, unity or renewed outbursts of European nationalism, as a Frankfurt bank becomes the scapegoat for massive unemployment?
 
Love, Hate and the Euro
Feared as Currency, Favored as Strategy
Faces at the European Commission in Brussels tend to light up at the euro's potential to spur Europe's economy. But Mr. Schmid, the retired hairdresser, sees folly where so-called Eurocrats see fortune.
His fears are those of the average German burgher. He has given some of his savings in marks to his son, Toni, to change into dollars. He equates the dollar's 20 percent appreciation against the mark over the past year with the mark's looming demise.
Franz Schmid was 12 years old when, in 1923, inflation reached more than two billion percent. To buy $1, 4.2 trillion marks were needed. In the same year, the young Adolf Hitler was arrested after he tried to lead a march on Berlin.
His family ruined, Franz was sent to work as an apprentice to a barber, only to be drafted into Hitler's army just as he had acquired his first hairdressing salon and was beginning to make his way.
Poland, France, Russia: Mr. Schmid invaded them all, an ordinary German swept along in a tide. Then, in 1944, he was captured by the Red Army and taken to a prison camp in Siberia. On carts in summer, on sleds in winter, he carried corpses out to woods where the wolves ate them. Only his skills in cutting Soviet officers' hair saved him.
A second lesson in the vagaries of money awaited him on his return to a devastated Germany in 1947. His life savings -- a bank deposit of 1,500 Reichsmarks -- were worthless, devoured by the inflationary financing of the war. Dollars alone, sent by two sisters who had emigrated to New York, bought him food until a new currency, the Deutsche mark, was introduced on June 20, 1948.
"The new currency was hope, the first hope, really," Mr. Schmid said. "I got married eight days later, and the photographer asked for 100 marks, and that seemed a staggering amount. But with time, the mark became part of us. It was stable. Germany without the mark is not Germany! I feel I'm about to lose my money for the third time."
Mr. Schmid is now 86. But almost one-third of Germans are over 55, and even many younger people grew up in homes where old, devalued Reichsmark bills were kept as symbols of money's vulnerability. It is, at the root, fear of chaos that leads 60 percent of Germans to say they oppose the euro project.
"It is amazing how deep the trauma goes," said Hans-Georg Gerstenlauer, the European Commission's representative in Berlin and an enthusiastic supporter of the euro. "I remember my parents talking repeatedly about hyperinflation, and they were infants when it happened."
During an interview, Hans Tietmeyer, president of the Bundesbank, talked repeatedly -- almost obsessively -- about the "sustainability" of monetary union: that is, the question whether Germany's low inflation and solid currency can be enduringly extended to the European Union. He repeatedly expressed concern that the euro might be blamed for the continent's economic woes. He seemed to be fighting his own doubts.
In the end, Germany fears the euro as money but favors it as strategic salvation. This country is, on some levels, is still trying to persuade wary neighbors that its nationalism was buried with the Third Reich.
"We are looking for a different identity because nationalism is really taboo," said Walter Hasselkus, the German chief executive of Rover. "That identity is Europe."
 
The Case for the Euro
Unshackling Europe To Take On the U.S.
The economic logic behind the plan is simple. "What," asked Jean-Claude Trichet, governor of the French Central Bank, "would the single American market be without a single money in Texas and California?"
In other words, the European Union's single market in goods and services is incomplete without a single currency and will be invigorated by having one. Over 60 percent of the trade of European Union states is with other countries in the union: the euro will simplify and stimulate this trade.
Like many European executives, Horst Teltschik, a member of the executive board of BMW, the German auto maker, sees the case for the new money as self-evident: "We export one-third of our production to other European Union countries, "and we've suffered a lot from exchange rate fluctuation. The euro will eliminate that risk."
For example, since BMW bought the British Rover auto company three years ago, sterling has appreciated more than 10 percent against the mark. As a result, the new Rover dealerships opened by BMW in Germany are having difficulties. "We should raise Rover prices to match the mark's level," Mr. Teltschik said, "but we can't, so for now we take losses."
Of course, companies trading between New York and Phoenix do not face such fluctuations. In this sense, the euro is intended to make Europe more like America. Corporations including Siemens and Unilever have made clear that they believe they will benefit greatly from the change.
Executives say that business will be spurred by easier corporate planning, pricing and billing. European financial markets will be opened up to new competition; inefficient policies will be less sustainable; pressure will rise on countries to make their economies attractive to business. The dollar will at last have a real rival.
The union's economy is roughly the same size as America's; it accounts for 20.9 percent of world trade, more than the United States' 19.6 percent; its population is bigger by about 100 million people, providing the largest single market in the world.
Why, therefore, should the euro not eventually make strong inroads into the dollar's international dominance, expressed in the fact that the dollar is the currency for close to 60 percent of international trade and 80 percent of financial operations?
Imagine oil priced in euros rather than dollars. Imagine the United States no longer able to assume that its deficits are automatically financed because the world wants dollars. Imagine Europe one day showing the same "benign neglect" for the euro that America does for the dollar because the domestic European market will be so big.
Such visions are by no means shared by everyone. "A German racket to take over the whole of Europe," was what Nicholas Ridley, a former British Industry Minister, once called the euro. The remark was revealing of a corner of the British psyche. Abstruse and abstract, but as intimate as the coins in a pocket, the euro beams a spotlight into the diverse recesses of the European heart.
Up to now, Britain, Denmark and Sweden have indicated that they will probably not join the planned "first wave" because of their reservations about the project. To these countries, the economics look too risky and the politics of a formal abandonment of national sovereignty too sensitive. But they may join later.
The United States has its doubts as well, although European integration has been in the American interest for more than 40 years. It has provided a steady opening of markets on which American corporations from I.B.M. to Toys 'R' Us have thrived. It has been a bedrock of America's postwar emergence as a European power.
"Important as monetary union is," said Lawrence H. Summer, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, "we sometimes have an impression of an introverted Europe, of navel-gazing."
Richard C. Holbrooke, a former Ambassador to Germany and Assistant Secretary of State for Europe, was blunter: "Almost a decade has gone by since the Berlin wall fell and, instead of reaching out to Central Europe, the European Union turned toward a bizarre search for a common currency. So NATO enlargement had to fill the void. Tell me, would you leave your money in German marks if the mark is going to become the lira and you can move to the dollar?"
Italy, however, is eager to dissolve itself and its lira into Europe as soon as possible. "We've always had a healthy inferiority complex here about tall, blond people," said Luigi Spaventa, a former Budget Minister. "For us, it's the euro or Africa." In Portugal and Spain, where a decade of membership in the European Union has been synonymous with the end of dictatorship and the advent of prosperity, the euro is similarly coveted.
France is ambivalent. It cares little for the franc. Moreover, in the heady days of the Cold War's end, it was France that exacted a commitment from Germany to adopt the euro as a condition for reunification. The strategic desire to harness German economic power inalienably to French political ambitions remains. But the cession of sovereignty that the euro entails raises the specter of an end to "La France."
In Britain, the ripples of Mr. Ridley's remark have not entirely faded. Tony Blair's Labor Government has called for a sober look at the euro. But unease persists about loss of sovereignty to a bank in Germany and the less flexible economic model of continental Europe. The Conservative Party has torn itself apart over the issue.
To attempt to marry such diversity by creating a European money may appear the folly of this fin de siecle. "Kohl wants the euro for the history books," said Denis Tillinac, a French writer. "But why must we pay for his obsessions? You can share a home, you can even persuade people to eat together, but you can't force them to make love."
 
The Case Against the Euro
In Monetary Policy, Can One Size Fit All?
The political theory in Paris and Bonn is that you can. As Norbert Walter, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt, put it, "Why not try to be great?"
Perhaps the answer is because it can be dangerous. Historically, monetary union has usually followed political union. The Federal Reserve was not established until 1913. Europe has opted to do things the other way around.
There is no European government, and peanuts would be a kind description of Europe's budget. Paltry would be an overgenerous portrayal of Europe's foreign policy. As the Bosnian war illustrated, political Europe is still as feeble as it is fragmented. The projected expansion of the union in the next century to bring in Poland and other Central European countries could cause yet more fragmentation.
By minting a money without making a government, and by surrendering control of monetary policy to a central bank while shunning the creation of other federal institutions, European states are heading into largely uncharted territory.
"This is the first time in history that the creation of a single money on a territory is not being accompanied by political centralization," said Olivier Klein, a French economist. "But money corresponds to a state power. And that is why we will have to move toward a more federal political structure in Europe."
Yet many European voters appear to despise the very federalism that the euro seems to promise. A recent cartoon in the daily Le Monde shows a despondent Frenchman. "Funny," he says, "We seemed to have more fun before Maastricht!"
Herein lies the paradox of the euro, a project sometimes suggestive of a journey begun so long ago that nobody can remember why a certain destination was chosen.
"We are going a new way in Europe," Mr. Tietmeyer, the Bundesbank president, said. "I don't see a readiness for a European superstate with one tax system, one big central budget, one security system. I have to accept that. So the basic question is whether there is enough common ground for monetary union."
The planned European Central Bank will -- if the euro is broadly adopted -- set a single monetary policy from Rotterdam to Rome, from Berlin to Barcelona. National room for economic maneuver after Jan. 1, 1999, will be limited.
Thus, if Italy hits a recession as the Netherlands booms, Italian authorities will no longer be able to lower interest rates to stimulate activity. They will not be able to devalue the lira.
Italians are unlikely to migrate en masse to Amsterdam for jobs, as Americans might move to a booming Arizona from a depressed Vermont. Europeans, in general, do not like to move.
Nor will a European federal budget transfer resources to Italy, as the United States Federal budget transfers money to depressed areas through Medicare and Social Security payments.
Nor, finally, will there be room for generosity in national budgets, because of the new fiscal discipline: no deficits larger than 3 percent of output. This has been the Bundesbank's draconian condition.
Europe, in other words, had better be a truly convergent economy, more or less responsive to the same economic medicine from Helsinki to Lisbon, or there will be tensions that will find a readily available target in the European Central Bank.
"How will a Europe with the euro deal with regional recessions?" asked Paul Krugman, a professor of economics at M.I.T. "I would put the odds of a collapse at one in four."
It is easy enough to imagine, for example, the invective of a group of newly unemployed French citizens told in mid-1999 that the government is essentially powerless because of decisions made in Frankfurt. Rather than uniting Europe, an unstable euro in a depressed continent might easily spur new nationalisms. Currency speculators would be quick to seize on instability.
"One can certainly imagine potential disasters in the one-size-fits-all approach to monetary policy," Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, said in an interview. "I am feeling nervous for the whole of Europe."
 
Germans and the Euro
Reclaiming Berlin, Learning From Bonn
Toni Schmid, the hairdresser's son, works for the Bavarian state government. He is nervous, too. But unlike his father, he may be more willing to accept the euro, however reluctantly. He sees that giving up the mark is the price for a united Europe to which Germany is irrevocably harnessed, a Europe whose economic policy is largely set by a bank in Frankfurt.
A member of the postwar generation, Mr. Schmid sees the euro as shaped less by the direct trauma of Nazism than by the angst of being German in the aftermath of the Holocaust. Born in 1950, he was a member of the first generation of Germans to go abroad after the war. Everywhere, the mark was the finest money. In Western Europe it was admired, in Eastern Europe coveted.
But respect was not the only thing encountered outside Germany. There was the realization, in Mr. Schmid's words, "that you were not normal." Your fathers had started the war and butchered millions of people. You had not chosen those fathers, but there it was. You were different.
On a visit to Ireland, Mr. Schmid recalled befriending a couple. He was French, she British. On parting, the woman said to him, "You know, it's really strange, I never thought I would have a German friend." The remark stuck in his mind.
And there, perhaps, lies the root of Germany's euro dilemma: a strong, much-loved money, the mark, on the one hand; an uncertain identity, a bad history, on the other.
A half-century after the war, the country, whole again, stands squarely at the center of Europe. Its economic domination is clear enough. The German economy is almost a third bigger than France's.
But Germany also has its doubts. And it knows -- especially since reunification -- that its allies need constant reassurance. Indeed, the euro was given a decisive push by unification. It was the most convincing reassurance, the most sweeping sacrifice, that Mr. Kohl could offer his neighbors.
There is a telling symmetry in the fact that the scheduled readoption of Berlin as German capital -- the return to the Reichstag and the Brandenburg Gate -- is set to coincide with the adoption of the euro in 1999. The reunification with Germany's past will thus be tied to the abandonment of the mark, the very emblem of German postwar strength. Put another away, Berlin will be reclaimed but with the lessons of Bonn.
"If you give away the mark you give away respect," Toni Schmid said, "and most Germans hate the idea. But Europe has been sacred for 50 years. No political party can say no to it. That is why Germans are not yelling."
Mr. Kohl is gambling that he can win over people like Mr. Schmid to his vision of aEurope where morale and growth can return to France and Germany, and where, perhaps, a new European identity can be born.
It will also be a place where interest policy reflects the interests of all European states.
The Bundesbank's insistence during much of the 1990's on high interest rates to tame the inflationary pressures of German reunification imparted a crippling blow to the economies of other European countries, which had to apply the same interest rates as the continent entered recession. The euro's image was thus battered.
The challenge facing the German Chancellor is therefore enormous, and German history offers a cautionary tale. The last German leader to embark on such far-reaching change was Bismarck, who declared the creation of the German Empire in 1871. His united Germany, bringing together 18 states, grew out of the customs union, or zollverein, between German states established in 1834, just as the euro seems set to emerge from European customs union.
Within 19 years of German unification, however, Bismarck was ousted. Mr. Kohl, who reunited Germany in 1989, has been in power 15 years. The vote he faces next year will hinge on the politics of the euro. Like Bismarck, Mr. Kohl may yet find that his countrymen's memory is short. "Kohl wants to be a European saint and he is ready to pay with the mark," said Toni Schmid. "But to many of us, the price looks too high."
