A10)
 
Chart: "The Euro: A Primer"
In the Maastricht treaty of 1991, members of the European Union agreed to requirements and a timetable for abandoning national currencies and creating a common money called the euro.
 
WHO QUALIFIES
 
Countries must meet strict limits on several criteria, primarily:
 
DEFICITS -- must not exceed 3 percent of gross domestic product, unless the deficit declined substantially and continuously, approaching 3 percent.
DEBT -- must not exceed 60 percent of total output unless it is approaching that level at a satisfactory rate.
INFLATION -- must not exceed the average of the three countries with the lowest inflation by more than 1.5 percent.
 
THE SCHEDULE
 
MAY 1998 -- European leaders decide which countries qualify. The bilateral exchange rates of the national currencies of those countries will then be set.
JAN. 1, 1999 -- The euro comes into existence, at fixed ratios to the national currencies, and becomes the instrument for issuing debt and making intergovernmental payments.
1999 TO 2002 -- National currencies continue to exist and are used for cash transactions. Euro notes and coins may be issued at any time between 1999 and 2002. National currencies go out of existence in 2002. (pg. A10)
 
Map/Chart: "The Euro Zone"
Not all European Union members are adopting the euro in 1999. Some may not qualify; others will wait. This will create a two-tier European Union. Map shows those in the euro zone and those outside: expected to qualify, improving chance of qualifying, waiting until later and will not qualify. 1996 population in millions, and gross domestic product in billions of U.S. dollars. (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Senate Republicans Criticize Clinton's Effort on Trade Accords

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's stance on international trade encountered intense opposition from important Senate Republicans today, only a day after it was denounced by House Democratic leaders.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who heads the Senate Finance Committee, told the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, that the Administration's proposals were "in deep trouble" and stood no chance of passage. 
 "The present proposal does not seem to have very widespread support on either side of the aisle," Mr. Roth added. "What you have here before us is not going to develop the kind of coalition we need if we're going to be successful enacting legislation."
The dispute is over President Clinton's desire for authority to negotiate trade agreements that Congress can approve or disapprove but not amend. The Administration has hit fierce opposition over two issues, workers' rights and environmental standards. Mr. Clinton had wanted so-called fast-track authority to negotiate on those issues in trade agreements.
But organized labor and environmental groups have expressed fears about hastily negotiated trade deals that might hurt American workers. The labor unions and environmental groups have complained that American workers lose in competition with their counterparts in developing countries, where wages are far lower and environmental standards are likely to be more lax.
So Mr. Clinton on Tuesday pledged to negotiate separate side agreements on labor and environmental issues and to negotiate global agreements on those matters through the World Trade Organization and other international groups.
It was not clear today how much the President's shift softened the opposition of those Democrats and labor interests who want to see workers' rights and environmental standards at the center of any international trade pact and enforced by the possibility of sanctions.
What was clear today is that the Administration's proposals have angered some Republicans. One, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, said the changes proposed by Mr. Clinton could put Congress in the position of having to vote yes or no on right-to-work laws, which bar mandatory union membership.
And Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, told Ms. Barshefsky and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin that he would not allow the fast-track legislation to become "a vehicle for special-interest agendas, no matter how passionate their proponents may be."
Ms. Barshefsky told the Senators that the fast-track legislation was needed unless the United States was willing to "cede our leadership role with respect to the global economy."
This evening, an Administration official familiar with the fast-track issue said the President and Ms. Barshefsky would continue to work with both Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill.
"We see this as a first step in a long -- hopefully not too long -- process," the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
Every President since Gerald R. Ford has had fast-track authority. Mr. Clinton's expired two years ago. Anticipating that the issue would divide Democrats, he chose not to press for it as he headed into his re-election campaign.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Starts of Housing Decline As Inflation Stays in Check
Housing starts unexpectedly dropped 4.8 percent in August, to an annualized 1.363 million, as builders began projects at the slowest pace this year.
A report from the Federal Reserve showed that labor shortages have not translated into rising consumer or industrial prices. Both are further evidence of slower growth that will keep inflation in check and give the Fed little reason to raise interest rates. [Page D3.] 

Traders bid up Treasury prices in response to the economic data. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.39 percent from 6.41. [D15.]
 
Fleet Takes a Different Approach
Fleet Financial is taking a different route into stock trading and investment banking than other banks. Its $1.6 billion acquisition of Quick & Reilly Group shows it is betting that adding a discount brokerage firm with a national reach is cheaper and less risky. [D4.]
 
Tobacco Makers Object to New Plan
The nation's cigarette makers reacted bitterly to President Clinton's new tobacco policy, saying that it demands concessions that go far beyond a costly and groundbreaking plan they reluctantly agreed to in June. [A30.]
 
Georgia-Pacific Splits Company
Georgia-Pacific is putting its 5.8 million acres of timber into a new operating group and spinning it off to shareholders. [D7.]
 
Lucent Offers a New Strategy
Lucent Technologies announced its long-awaited data networking strategy, sending its shares up modestly. The company introduced telecommunications products and said that it intended to acquire at least one smaller company that could help it offer a full line of networking gear. [D2.]
 
S.E.C. Accuses Six of Fraud
The S.E.C. accused six people of defrauding a Swiss bank of $3 million and Lehman Brothers of $6.5 million. [D4.]
 
No Deal Yet for U S Airways
U S Airways and its pilots are far from reaching a cost-cutting agreement that the company says is a precondition for the airline's future growth. [D8.]
 
Turbulence for European Currency
The move to forge European unity with one currency, the euro, is meeting both approval and skepticism. Skeptics worry that the architects of the euro are inviting disaster by imposing a single economic policy on diverse countries. But supporters say the surrender of national sovereignty is the only way to challenge the economic power of the United States. [A1.]
 
Yamaichi Workers Arrested
Japanese authorities arrested five current and former employees of Yamaichi Securities and banned the firm from underwriting Government bonds as they investigated accusations that the brokerage house made illegal payoffs to a corporate racketeer. [D15.]
 
Bad Times for Business Economists
The annual meeting of the National Association for Business Economics was a sedate affair because the attendees have a pretty sleepy job. [D3.]
 
China's Latest Capitalism Move
China has been experimenting with an eclectic mix of capitalism and socialism. And although it is not yet clear what President Jiang Zemin envisions for public ownership of companies, it is another move toward free enterprise. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
Latin Trade Group Growing
Trade is soaring among the four Mercosur members -- Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay -- and the alliance is signing accords with the European Union and the Andean Pact, a trade group in western South America. [A7.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 35; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 930 words

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
www.mideast.com.war?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I spent last week following Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on her Middle East tour. Here is what was being talked about outside the corridors of diplomacy.
Tel Aviv -- "Explain one thing to me," I ask one of Israel's top financial officials. "Why doesn't the breakdown of the peace process devastate Israel's economy?" (Growth in 1997 will be about 2.5 percent; in 1996 it was 4.4.) The answer is that Israel today has two economies: the old economy of oranges, tourism and textiles, and the new information economy of software and high-tech exports. "The information economy is highly resistant to violence," he explains. "Almost all the exports go outside the Middle East, and most of these information technologies are small and light, or exported by modem. All the key inputs come from brains and human capital; no embargo can stop them. Smart global investors understand that. Bombing affects the old economy, not the new one. But this new economy was stoked by Israelis who came back from Silicon Valley after the Oslo peace. These knowledge people are highly mobile. The only economic threat is if the conflict makes daily life so unpleasant, the best brains leave. It could happen." 
 Damascus, Syria -- "So what's the talk of Damascus?" I ask a Syrian reporter, as Ms. Albright's caravan pulls into town.
"There is a big debate in the Government over whether to let the Internet into Syria," he says. The state intelligence services, which refuse to allow any Syrian to have a cell phone, are said to be arguing over who will get to be the Internet provider. Syria, though, has just allowed AT&T credit-card calls from the press room at the Sheraton. Good news: Syria is slowly updating its economy. Bad news: It's just entered the 1980's.
Alexandria, Egypt -- While Ms. Albright is meeting with President Hosni Mubarak, a Mubarak spokesman strides over to me. I am sure he wants to talk politics. The first words out of his mouth are: "Have you seen our Web site? We've had seven million hits in only 10 months. It's got news, a press digest. You have to see it." Three years ago there was no Internet provider in Egypt. Today there are seven. For the first time ever, an Egyptian diplomat boasts to me that the Egyptian stock market was the hottest in the world last year. He jokingly offers me the services of his stockbroker son. Suddenly there is more to talk about than just Arabs and Jews. As Egypt gets more open, the demands for more transparency at home begin to mount. The As-Sha'ab newspaper just ran a series alleging gross corruption by the powerful Minister of Interior and his sons, and so far the Government is letting the investigative journalism go on.
Abha, Saudi Arabia -- "So what are people talking about here?" I ask an official while Ms. Albright is meeting with gulf foreign ministers.
"Venezuela," the official says, without hesitating.
"Huh? Venezuela?" I ask.
"The Saudis think Venezuela is cheating on its OPEC quotas, and this year, for the first time, Venezuela surpassed Saudi Arabia as the biggest oil exporter to the U.S. The Saudis don't like that. They want America dependent on their oil, not on Venezuela's. It's a national-security thing for them."
Jerusalem -- Think about this: Israel's Yediot newspaper just went to Moscow and bought Russian spy satellite photographs of new Scud missile bases in Syria. Then Yediot hired a private U.S. expert on satellite photos to analyze the pictures. Then last week Yediot published the package as a scoop, without ever quoting a government official. Good news: In today's global market you can buy anything. Bad news: Syria is still preparing for another war.
Amman, Jordan -- Lead story in The Jordan Times on the day after Ms. Albright visits: a speech by the Crown Prince on Jordan's need for global competitiveness. The hottest new Web site in Jordan is http:// www.arab.net/gid/welcome.html. This is the home page of the Jordanian intelligence service -- the first in the Middle East to have its own Web site. An official handout says: "The site offers an interesting glimpse of the history, doctrine, responsibilities and viewpoints of the General Intelligence Department." Hottest new restaurant in Amman: "Books @ Cafe," an Internet cafe where you can sip coffee and surf the Web on a computer. In the morning Jordanian housewives come in to shop on the net; in the evening it's the students who gather to schmooze. Try the banana cream pie. It's made by the wife of an Israeli diplomat in Jordan. When Islamist opponents of Israel found that out, they posted it on the local Jordanian Internet, and called for a boycott until the pie was ousted. But the boycott fizzled, the cafe is packed, and the pie is still a favorite.
Jerusalem -- Ms. Albright is gone. I return here to get a look at the Jewish settlers trying to lay claim to the Ras al-Amud Arab neighborhood in order to really kill the peace. I use my fancy new Israeli-made Tadiran telephone to ask the religious philosopher Moshe Halbertal for his analysis. He takes me down into the volcano still lurking just below the thin layer of globalization in this region: "At the end of the Second Temple days," he says, "the great Jewish historian Josephus describes the unfolding of the Jewish revolt against the Romans that led to the destruction of Jerusalem and the Temple. A determined group of Jewish zealots, mobilized by a megalomanic sense of their role in history, pushed the Jewish people at the time into a struggle they did not want to participate in. Ultimately it destroyed them."

HEADLINE: Messinger Appears Victor in New Count

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
By a margin of just 658 votes, Ruth W. Messinger appears to have broken the 40 percent barrier needed to avoid a runoff with the Rev. Al Sharpton for the Democratic mayoral nomination, the Board of Elections announced early this morning.
Mr. Sharpton immediately said he would file suit today in state and Federal courts, seeking an injunction to force the board to proceed with the runoff, which had been scheduled for next Tuesday. 
 According to the nearly complete count, released at 12:15 this morning, Ms. Messinger had 40.16 percent of the 411,811 votes that had been tallied. Ms. Messinger had 165,383 votes, or 658 more than the 40 percent threshold, compared with 131,888 for Mr. Sharpton. A third candidate, Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn, received 86,619 votes.
"As of now, there will be no runoff," said Daniel DeFrancesco, the executive director of the board.
Providing there are no more problems with this tentative count -- the 10-member Board of Elections will gather in Manhattan this afternoon to certify it -- the results should finally bring Ms. Messinger a successful if sputtering end to her bid to become her party's nominee against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
There were no victory celebrations at Ms. Messinger's headquarters last night upon learning that, contrary to what the board said only after hours the polls closed last Tuesday, she had achieved the 40 percent of the primary vote needed to secure the nomination. Ms. Messinger's aides said that, given the tumult of the past week, she would not discuss the result until the board made a final decision.
But her press secretary, Leland T. Jones, embraced the decision and presented Ms. Messinger as her party's nominee.
"Ruth very much looks forward to the general election campaign against Mr. Giuliani," Mr. Jones said. "His record is replete with failures: the sorry state of the city schools, widespread unemployment, police brutality, unabated homelessness, poverty and hunger and, of course, Mr. Giuliani's repeated violations of the city's campaign finance law."
Mr. Jones was referring to contributions that exceeded city limits, and that the Republican Mayor was forced to return by the city's Campaign Finance Board
Mr. Sharpton displayed no anger toward Ms. Messinger over the result. "I'm not blaming Ms. Messinger on this problem," he told a roaring crowd of supporters in Queens last night, his eyes brimming with tears. "Ms. Messinger didn't count the votes. If she did, she would have won the first night. So, don't blame her."
And Mr. Sharpton signaled that he would use the result to raise his political stature in the city, invoking the rhetoric of Jesse L. Jackson: "I raised hope in this city. I raised promise in this city. I made people who had given up try all over again. I will not sell out the dream of the people."
Mr. Sharpton, eager not to be seen as acting to undermine Ms. Messinger if she does become her party's nominee against Mr. Giuliani, said in an interview that his suit would be aimed not at Ms. Messinger but at a Board of Elections that he argued was so inept that it had effectively disenfranchised his supporters, who were seeking to help him become New York's second black mayor.
Ms. Messinger's tiny margin provides her a shaky platform from which to begin her fall campaign against Mr. Giuliani, several Democrats said. It also places her in a tricky political situation with Mr. Sharpton and his supporters, whom she will need at her side.
Several Democrats said a critical decision for Ms. Messinger now is whether she decides to join, or at least endorse, Mr. Sharpton's legal challenges to the Board of Elections and the election result.
Ms. Messinger's aides said no decision had been made. During the last few days, they have rejected the suggestion of other Democrats -- most recently, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- that she pre-emptively join Mr. Sharpton in calling for the runoff to proceed, no matter what the outcome of the count.
Mr. Sharpton demurred when asked whether he expected, or wanted, Ms. Messinger at his side when he and his lawyers go to court this morning to file his suits. "How she responds, that's up to her conscience," Mr. Sharpton said. "She's not the target."
Significantly, though, one of Ms. Messinger's black supporters, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem, said that he supported Mr. Sharpton's action. Mr. Rangel said he understood how the back and forth of the past week could encourage suspicions among Mr. Sharpton's supporters.
"Sharpton supporters have every reason not to have confidence in the electoral system as managed by we professional politicians," Mr. Rangel said in a telephone interview from Washington. "I think good people and reporters and everybody would say you want a good count. It's not going to be a suit against her. It's not going to be alleging fraud."
Referring to what he described as widespread inefficiencies at the Board of Elections, as well as the apparent close margin of the race, Mr. Rangel said it seemed essential that the board be forced to do the count again. "He's entitled to a decent count," the Congressman said.
The Elections Board, usually an undisturbed outpost for political appointees, finally finished the count early this morning after lumbering through another day in the spotlight during one of the more embarrassing episodes in its history. Elections workers were dispatched from across the city to Brooklyn, which was the last place where votes were left to be counted. At one point, three dozen workers were seen plowing through piles of envelopes, containing absentee ballots mailed in before the primary as well as affidavit ballots filed in polling places where machines were broken.
"We're whipping people to death here," said Mr. DeFrancesco, the board's executive director.
Even then, things did not go well for the agency. At one point in the evening, the number of votes left to be counted actually increased from earlier in the day. Board officials attributed that to a faulty estimate of how many ballots were left.
The scene at the board's headquarters on Adams Street in Brooklyn looked like a set from a 1940's movie. The election clerks, seated at folding tables, went through a long and convoluted procedure, first checking each sealed envelope against the spiral-bound master list of voters, then stamping the box under each person's name to indicate that a paper ballot had been filed.
From there, the ballots were handed over to a second set of clerks, whose job was to open the ballots and transpose the vote, by hand, onto a tally sheet. From there, the tally sheets finally found their way into the 1990's, as a clerk entered the results into a computer.
The Board of Elections is made up of 10 members named by the Republican and Democratic leaders of the five counties. Each is paid $125 per day of work -- such as today, when they will certify the results -- up to $12,500 a year.
The selection of workers for the board is unusual, according to the Federal Election Commission, in that merit is one factor that is generally not considered. Instead, the selection is purely a result of political patronage, something no one even attempts to hide. "My mom was a district leader so I got this job," said Daisy Rivera, 40, a registration clerk from the Bronx who spent her day opening envelopes.
As the counting continued, Ms. Messinger sought to hold Mr. Giuliani responsible for the board and its problems. She repeatedly described it as a mayoral agency under his command, even though it is not, and said Mr. Giuliani should have ordered the Board of Elections to stay open until it finished the count.
"Let me tell you, if he funds it, he runs it," she said. "It's under his control, it's his dollars."
"I don't believe he cares when the Board of Elections finishes this count," Ms. Messinger said, speaking on the radio program of David N. Dinkins, the former Mayor. "But the people of this city do."
Mr. Giuliani mocked Ms. Messinger for what he said was an inaccurate description of the board. "Ruth Messinger has been in city government for 20 years," he said. "There isn't a person that knows city government that doesn't know the fact that it is not a mayoral agency." The Republican Mayor said her comment "reveals the irresponsibility of her and her campaign."
"To suggest that it is a mayoral agency," he said, "when I am sure she knows that it isn't. Maybe she forgot in the excess of wanting to blame things on other people."
For Mr. Sharpton, it seemed appropriate that his final stand should come in Brooklyn.
And as it seemed clear that Ms. Messinger was getting her 40 percent, Mr. Sharpton left no doubt about his unhappiness. Speaking at a rally at the New Greater Bethel Ministries in Cambria Heights, Mr. Sharpton noted that the city's Campaign Finance Board had awarded Ms. Messinger $320,400 for her runoff campaign, pointing to the incongruity of one arm of the city financing an election while another nullified it.
"You have people on one side of the city handing out checks and you have people on the other side saying, 'We haven't counted yet!' " Mr. Sharpton roared to appreciative howls from his audience. "There's something wrong."

Chart: "Counting the Votes: Why It Takes So Long"
The results of last week's primary were still being counted as of last night. By law, the city can take up to 25 days to determine the final count. Here's how the votes were counted.
 
ELECTION NIGHT: UNOFFICIAL COUNT
 
MACHINE VOTES COUNTED
At each poll site, an election worker and two inspectors (one Democrat, one Republican) write down the vote count from each machine.
 
MACHINE VOTES AND PAPER BALLOTS GIVEN TO POLICE
A police officer from the local precinct retrieves the results, which are called to Police Headquarters in Manhattan.
 
POLICE ENTER MACHINE VOTES
At Police Headquarters, the numbers are typed into a computer system and then sent to The Associated Press.
 
OFFICIAL COUNT
 
MACHINES RETURNED
Usually within four days, the 6,824 voting machines are returned to borough warehouses and organized by Assembly district.
 
MACHINE VOTES RECOUNTED
Within two to four days, a Board of Elections team (one Democrat, one Republican) is assigned to each Assembly district. They recheck the totals from
each machine for the official count.
 
VALIDATING PAPER BALLOTS
Affidavit ballots are verified to make sure the voter is properly enrolled and registered. Absentee ballots postmarked the day before the election, and delivered up to and including the seventh day after the election, are checked to make sure the voter didn't vote by machine.
 
PAPER BALLOTS COUNTED
Once the 7-day period has passed, the verified paper ballots are counted and certified.
 
ALL RESULTS TOTALED
The machine and paper ballot results are totaled and certified by the Commissioners of Election as the official election results.
(pg. B3)

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Clinton Says He Won't Sign Treaty Banning Land Mines
Applause broke out in Oslo as about 100 governments, including the United States, agreed to submit for formal ratification a treaty to ban land mines. But a few hours later, President Clinton said the United States would not sign it in December. A1 

Mr. Clinton, who called for a ban on anti-personnel land mines in front of the United Nations in 1994, bowed to military leaders who argued that such a ban would put American soldiers at risk. A8
 
Latin America Celebrates Trade
South American leaders at the World Economic Forum in Sao Paulo celebrated the rapid growth of trade involving their countries conducted under the auspices of Mercosur, a regional group led by Brazil. But amid elation over recent agreements with Andean Pact countries and the European Union, pointed jibes were made about President Clinton, who pledged at a summit meeting in 1994 in Miami to create a "Free Trade Area of the Americas." A7
 
Protestant Joins Belfast Talks
David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, the largest Protestant political party in Northern Ireland, agreed to join formal peace talks on the province's future. Other Protestant political leaders are expected to follow. Mr. Trimble said foremost on his agenda would be trying to have Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, expelled from the talks. A11
 
Swiss Get Holocaust Fund List
A list of 12,000 names of aging Jews in eastern Europe was handed over to the Swiss Ambassador in Washington, according to Swiss officials. The list represented a first step toward insuring that money from a fund set up by the Swiss Government, industry and banks actually gets to the Holocaust survivors it was set up to help. Payments of around $1,000 a person are expected for the survivors, whose average age is almost 80 and many of whom subsist on meager pensions. A13
 
12 Die in U.N. Helicopter Crash
A United Nations helicopter crashed in central Bosnia, killing all 12 passengers, including Gerd Wagner, a German diplomat who was deputy to the civilian administrator of the Dayton accords, United Nations officials said. The passengers were all officials trying to help Bosnia conduct elections. Four other Germans, five Americans, a Briton and a Pole also died, while the four Ukrainian crew members survived. A15
 
Israeli Right Faces Fissure
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked that three recently installed Jewish families move out of a house in an Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem while allowing a group of Jewish students to remain there. The compromise offer was refused, however, by the wealthy American owner of the house, who asked the Israeli Supreme Court for a restraining order against any forced evictions. A3

Security Adviser Opposed Access for Political Donor
A former White House national security adviser told Senate investigators that officials of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Department of Energy and the Democratic party lobbied heavily to make sure that Roger E. Tamraz, a big-money campaign contributor and controversial oil promoter, obtained an audience with President Clinton despite warnings that he had a "shady and untrustworthy reputation." A1
 
H.I.V. Research Criticized
One of the nation's most prestigious medical journals has thrown a harsh spotlight on research the United States has been conducting on H.I.V.-infected pregnant women in Africa, Thailand and the Dominican Republic. An editorial in the journal likens the research -- in which some women are given placebos -- to the notorious Tuskegee experiment, in which poor black men suffering from syphilis were left untreated. A1
 
Christian Coalition Politics
A 40-minute tape of Pat Robertson, chairman of the Christian Coalition, addressing about 100 members of statewide branches offered a rare glimpse into the coalition's political objectives. It also cast new doubts on the insistence by the coalition, the nation's largest and most influential organization of religious conservatives, that it does not engage in political activities. A24
 
Clinton Outlines Tobacco Policy
President Clinton demanded tough penalties on cigarette makers if smoking by teen-agers did not decline dramatically over the next decade. He also said he would not accept any dilution in Food and Drug Administration authority to regulate nicotine as a dangerous drug. The nation's cigarette makers reacted bitterly, saying that Mr. Clinton's demands go far beyond a costly and ground-breaking plan they reluctantly agreed to in June. A30
 
Magnetic Field Found on Mars
In its first major discovery, the American spacecraft that went into an orbit of Mars last Thursday has solved one of the planet's longstanding mysteries: Mars does have a magnetic field. Its magnetism may be weak, compared with most other planets, but is considerably stronger than scientists had suspected. A33

In the first independent evaluation of Cleveland's groundbreaking school voucher program, a Harvard University study has found that the program was very popular with parents and raised the scores of those students tested at the end of the first year. A16

The Defense Department, alarmed by a spate of dramatic and often fatal airplane crashes in the last four days, has for the first time ever ordered each of the armed services to suspend training flights for 24 hours to give aviators and ground crews additional safety lectures. A23

HEADLINE: Chrysler Building Lures 20 Bidders With Romance and Profit Potential

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
An unprecedented number of investors, real estate moguls and foreign companies have joined the bidding for the Chrysler Building, the landmark Art Deco skyscraper on Lexington Avenue at 42d Street that serves as a monument to the industrial age.
Sales of office buildings in a hot real estate market have often drawn a half-dozen prospective buyers. But according to real estate executives and some of the bidders themselves, as many as 20 groups submitted offers on the Chrysler Building on Monday: they include Jerry Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties, Steve Witkoff, Steven Roth of Vornado Realty Trust, Argent Ventures, Willow Funding, Paul Reichman, the Canadian developer whose empire collapsed in the early 1990's, Bernard Goldberg of Gotham Hospitality, and a handful of foreign investors. They see the Chrysler Building as a trophy worth having. 
 "It's funny to see these hard-headed businessmen responding to the romance of the Chrysler Building," said Mary Ann Tighe, executive managing director of Insignia/ Edward S. Gordon Company, a real estate broker. "It's the romance of industry. Instead of gargoyles, it has hubcaps."
The romance surrounding the 77-story skyscraper, which is expected to sell for more than $200 million, has captured some imaginations as much as its potential for profit. Still, any buyer will have to invest an additional $100 million to restore the 67-year-old building to its original grandeur and to update its air conditioning and electric systems, people familiar with the deal said. Built in 1930, the Chrysler Building is clad in stone and stainless steel, with shiny ornaments that evoke images from the automobile industry.
The fate of the building has been uncertain since spring, when its owner, Jack Kent Cooke, died. A consortium of nine Japanese lenders led by Fuji Bank, which holds a $250 million mortgage on the property, then began a foreclosure action. The two sides have a tentative agreement to sell the property to the winning bidder.
"The building has generated strong interest from people all around the world for reasons that are not purely economic," said Warren Heller of Jones Lang, Wooton, which is conducting the sale for Fuji. "This seems to be a building people are extremely anxious to own and are prepared to go to unconventional lengths to make that happen."
The sale includes the nearby Kent Building and several other structures.
Mr. Heller refused to discuss any details of the sale, but real estate executives said the bids range from $150 million to about $200 million. Any buyer would also have to come to terms with the owner of the land beneath the building, Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. Real estate brokers say that no one would complete a deal for the property without an extension of the land lease at a reasonable rent.
The Chrysler Building was built by Walter Chrysler, the auto maker, in the midst of a three-way race to be the tallest building in the world. The Chrysler Building surpassed 40 Wall Street after a spire was installed atop the tower, but it lost the top spot a few months later to the Empire State Building.
One of the Chrysler Building's most striking features is its Art Deco lobby, which combines African marble and chrome steel. A Chrysler showroom once occupied the first two stories. Some prospective buyers have speculated that the skyscraper's larger, lower floors could be used for office tenants, while the smaller, tower floors could be converted to hotel rooms or boutique space for law and architectural firms. Mr. Goldberg of Gotham Hospitality has proposed converting the entire building to what he calls the Hotel Chrysler.
Any prospect would be expensive.
At least one potential buyer who reviewed the building's prospectus decided that the price was too high.
"The effort involved did not justify what we thought we could get out of it," said Mortimer B. Zuckerman, chairman of Boston Properties, a real estate investment trust, and publisher of The Daily News. "It's a humongous undertaking."
A prominent New York real estate developer who is bidding on the property, and who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Chrysler Building could be a profitable venture, despite the tens of millions of dollars it could cost in renovations. He discounted talk that the romance of the building had blinded buyers to the economics of the deal.
"It's a beautiful-looking building, but nobody is going to spend the pile of money needed here because they've fallen in love with it," he said. "It's got to be completely retrofitted. But it's in a great location. We think the bones are good and we can do something with it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Chrysler Building, at Lexington Avenue and 42d Street. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)(pg. B10) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Field for Interim CUNY Chief Is Narrowed to Four

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
A committee of trustees of the City University of New York has narrowed its search for an interim chancellor to four candidates and will interview them tomorrow, according to several people familiar with the search process.
The candidates include two former college presidents, Edmond L. Volpe, the longtime president of City University's College of Staten Island, and Alice Chandler, the president of the State University of New York at New Paltz for about 15 years and a former acting president at City College. 
 The short list also includes two CUNY professors, Ira Bloom, a professor of political science at Lehman College and a former vice chancellor, and Steven M. Cahn, a professor of philosophy and former provost at the university's graduate center.
The committee, which reviewed 17 names at a meeting on Monday, bypassed several CUNY presidents, including Allen L. Sessoms of Queens College, Kurt R. Schmeller of Queensborough Community College and Gerald W. Lynch of John Jay College of Criminal Justice.
The search committee, headed by Ronald J. Marino and working with CUNY's chairwoman, Anne A. Paolucci, agreed to try to forward two or three names to the full board by next week, along with their recommendation. Dr. Paolucci has said she hopes the trustees can appoint an interim chancellor at their Sept. 29 meeting.
The chancellor's post became vacant this week after the departure of W. Ann Reynolds, who accepted the presidency of the University of Alabama at Birmingham after growing disagreements with the university's trustees.
Several trustees have said that they want the interim chancellor to be more than a place-holder and to upgrade standards and help decentralize the university while they conduct a national search for a permanent chancellor. They have also said they want someone who is familiar with CUNY but who will not be a candidate for the permanent position. The interim chancellor is expected to serve at least a year, until a permanent chancellor is chosen and arrives on campus.
Herman Badillo, vice chairman of the board, who is not a member of the selection committee, said yesterday that he could not comment on the candidates, but that he thought they should be asked their positions on issues like remedial education, grade inflation and testing.
He called the interim chancellor's job "a suicide mission" and said the person has to be tough and be willing to "clean the stables."

HEADLINE: Turf;
Where a Celebrity's Name Isn't Worth a Dime

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
IN the mirrored entryway illuminated only by distant tall towers twinkling through the drawing-room windows, velvety-black shadows darted from side to side as real estate agents searched for a light switch. It was a scene that revealed Marlene Dietrich's empty apartment at its most glamorous. As every star knows, when one grows older, the lights must get dimmer.
In daylight, the apartment is not as romantic. With its scuffed parquet floors and dated appliances, traces of burnt-down cigarettes and the slightly bizarre use of smoky mirrors, it becomes a house in need of TLC, a two-bedroom handyman's special for sale in a prewar Park Avenue building. 
 When it first came on the market in July -- it was used only occasionally by relatives since her death five years ago -- Marlene Dietrich's 12th-floor apartment was priced at a cool and simple million dollars. Yet, only a week later, the price was dropped -- with a jolt -- to $625,000. This week, brokers for Sotheby's International Realty jubilantly confirmed that an offer for the full $625,000 had been accepted.
But experts say the selling price is probably just what it would have been if the apartment had been owned by . . . anybody at all. In fact, a two-bedroom apartment in the same Park Avenue building, on the much-lowlier and less valuable second floor, but in mint condition, sold in the nadir of the real estate recession for $645,000. And the potential buyer of the Dietrich apartment, an unmarried executive in her late 50's, told her agent that the apartment's history had piqued her interest but, in the end, did not influence her decision.
So how much does a celebrity name really add to the price of a property?
Not much, the country's top brokers say.
"Someone buying a house wants to see themselves living in the house -- not anybody else, even if that somebody else is somebody famous," said Alan Jacobson, a partner in Wimbish-Riteway Realtors in Miami Beach, who this month put Sylvester Stallone's house overlooking Biscayne Bay on the market for $27.5 million. (The larger-than-life statues of Rocky and Rambo in the garden are not included in the price but "may be negotiable," the realtor said.)
Madonna's apartment, too, is on the market -- and has been there since the beginning of the year. A 6,000-square-foot duplex at 41 Central Park West, in the prewar dowager known as Harperley Hall, the apartment comes with its own beauty parlor on the second floor, next to the steam room. Nevertheless, the price has just been dropped, from $6.75 million to $6.25 million.
"I've yet to see a house that belonged to a celebrity sell for more because of it," said Nick Coates, a partner in Coates, Reid & Waldron in Aspen, Colo. "Martina Navratilova's got a house for sale; it's been on the market for two years."
Cher's house in Aspen, an adobe bungalow with a lot of charm, sold about a year ago, for $3.1 million, Mr. Coates said. "And we didn't get a nickel more because of it," he added. "Of course, they all let it be known who owned the house -- I don't think it hurts the value -- but it doesn't make a darned bit of difference."
Frank Symons, who heads Sotheby International Realty's office in Beverly Hills, Calif., agrees. In Beverly Hills, Bel Air and Holmby Hills, the areas where he does the most business, sales are "driven only by price -- there's no added value to celebrity," he said, adding that Barbra Streisand's house on Summitridge Drive in Beverly Hills took five years to sell.
Edward Lee Cave, whose New York City real estate business caters to the wealthy, including celebrities, said: "Provenance is much more important for art and jewelry than it is for houses. An apartment that a celebrity lived in is different from a painting owned by a celebrity or a famous collector."
Both Mr. Cave and Alan Rogers, the managing director of Douglas Elliman, pointed to the sale of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' apartment at 1040 Fifth Avenue in early 1995, as "the exception that proves the rule." Although the $9.5 million sale of the huge, terraced, 14th-floor apartment was generally interpreted to be wildly above market, the two men agreed that the price was only about 20 percent more than the market then -- and might be a fair price for the same apartment in today's much hotter market.
"If a beaten-up chintz sofa goes for 100 times its real value, or a Kenneth Jay Lane necklace for 50 times retail, then Mrs. Onassis' apartment traded at an astoundingly fair price," Mr. Rogers said, referring to the record-setting $34.5 million auction of Mrs. Onassis' belongings, a media event in which a $500 set of fake pearls went for $211,500. "Do you want to buy Paul Newman's apartment? It's for sale -- and it doesn't cost any more than anyone else's."
Madonna's broker, Roger Erickson, a senior vice president of William B. May Real Estate, adamantly refused to discuss her apartment, at her request. But he did comment on the phenomenon of celebrity sellers.
"There's so much emotion in real estate," he said, "and the celebrity element can add an extra kick to the emotional impact of a new listing and draw even more people than it might otherwise do. Right at the beginning, you want to get as much action as you can -- and maybe you'll even get a higher price.
"But if the place doesn't sell right away, for whatever reason, any celebrity benefit starts to wear off."
Besides Madonna's apartment, Mr. Erickson is also handling John McEnroe's penthouse at 200 East End Avenue, a remarkable apartment with spectacular views of the East River and a chrome-trimmed pool table in the living room. The penthouse has been on the market, with several different brokers, for at least a year and a half and has an asking price of $1.18 million.
To make a difference in the price, an owner "would have to be a legend, like Jackie Kennedy or Princess Diana or maybe Elvis," said Dolly Lenz, a broker at Sotheby's who is a bit of a legend herself -- mainly for selling 24 multimillion-dollar condominiums in a day on one of her frequent trips to Hong Kong. "To make a difference, you'd have to be a legend. Or an icon. Or a god."
Ms. Lenz said the imprimatur of a run-of-the-mill celebrity doesn't make a difference, and cited as an example Andrew Lloyd Webber's $7.9 million apartment in Trump Tower, which has been on the market for years. "Robert Redford's penthouse is on the market at 955 Fifth," she added. "It's a very sweet little two bedroom, asking $3.95 million, and nobody's snapping it up because it's his. Don King's house isn't selling. Meryl Streep sold her place at 271 Central Park West, where Robin Williams lives, for a normal amount. Then there was O. J. Simpson's at 200 East 65th. That, they kept a secret. The people who eventually bought it didn't even know whose it was."
Then, of course, there is always the one true exception.
"Take Barbara Hutton's place in the Casbah in Tangier," said John Prince, the vice president of international operations at Sotheby's realty. The fact that it had been owned by the heiress was "really the only thing going for it," he said.
"Sotheby's owns the Cecil Beaton archive and used a glamorous picture of Barbara Hutton sitting in the house on the cover of the brochure," he said. "And it worked. It did the trick."
Even if celebrity cachet doesn't increase a price, a ghastly occurrence can drag it right down. "If someone was killed in a place, like where Henry VIII chopped one of his wives' heads off, that would not be good," Mr. Prince said.
Donald Trump agreed. "Leona Helmsley's place in Greenwich had a history of about eight people living there, all of whom went to jail or committed suicide or went bankrupt," he said. "When I heard she bought it, I said I wouldn't take it for $10,000 -- and look what happened." Ms. Helmsley went to jail.
In any case, if you're looking for celebrities, it might be wiser to move in next door to one.
"People like to be where a celebrity is, rather than where a celebrity was," Mr. Prince said.
Mr. Jacobson in Miami Beach said, "If you can live next door to Stallone or Madonna, perhaps you might pay more, because if these people live there, you might figure it's a good investment."
Like all the other real estate agents interviewed, Mr. Jacobson said he manages to weed out the sightseers. Still, he said he has shown the $27.5 million Stallone house about 20 times in the three weeks it has been on the market.
When the potential buyer is unknown, he asks for letters of credit from a bank or other forms of financial identification. But in some cases, the person seeking to check out the celebrity's house might be a bigger celebrity than the one selling it.
"If it's a Hollywood star, it's not someone we're going to ask for references," he said. "If it's the president or the prime minister of a country, the same thing."
"It's actually amazing how many people there are who can afford this property, for whom $27 million is just a drop in the bucket," Mr. Jacobson said, adding, "These are not the type of people to be awed by celebrity."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
JOYCE, DR. TIMOTHY

 BODY:
JOYCE-Dr. Timothy. Founder and former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Mediamark Research Inc. died on Saturday, September 13. Dr. Joyce was internationally prominent in media and market research for nearly four decades. He developed Target Group Index, a survey system for measuring consumer behavior of media audiences which is still widely in use today. Dr. Joyce is survived by his wife, Helen, a son, Nicholas, a daughter, Rachel Frosh, and a grandson, Alexander Frosh. Memorial Services are being held at the McGraw-Hill Auditorium, 1221 Avenue of the Americas, 2nd Floor, New York, at 4:00 P.M., on September 25th. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Network for Organ Sharing, 1110 Boulders Parkway, Richmond, VA. 23225. The officers and employees of Mediamark will truly miss Timothy and extend their deepest condolences to the members of his family.
JOYCE-Timothy, Ph.D. The officers and employees of Roper Starch Worldwide mourn the passing of our Vice-Chairman, Dr. Timothy Joyce on Saturday, September 13. He was a true pioneer in the media/market research field and we will long remember his unparalleled wit, keen intelligence and loyal devotion to his friends and colleagues throughout the world. The research industry and we, in particular, will miss him dearly. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Helen, his son Nicholas, and daughter Rachel Frosh. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 25, at the McGraw-Hill Auditorium, 1221 Avenue of the Americas at 4 P.M.

ROTH, ARTHUR THOMAS

 BODY:
ROTH-Arthur Thomas, ninetyone, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, September 17, at his home of sixty years in Rockville Centre, New York. He will long be remembered in American banking circles for the extraordinary innovations he successfully brought to commercial banking as CEO of the Franklin National Bank before retiring in 1968, and more locally for his dynamic role in spearheading the phenomenal economic growth of Long Island following W.W. II for which the press dubbed him "Mr. Long Island". His family however will remember him as a loving husband, father and grandfather whose generosity, warmth, strength, and will to do the right thing is deeply impressed on them all. His many acts of community and church leadership and his widespread philanthropy speak for themselves. He leaves his wife of 67 years, Genevieve, and his daughter Mrs. Carol Madigan of Oldwick, New Jersey, and son, Donald Arthur Roth of E. Setauket, N.Y., their spouses John P. Madigan, Jr. and Mrs. Patricia Roth, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Visitation will be at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, on Thursday and Friday between 2 and 4 PM and 7 and 9 PM.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Auction Houses Courting Youth
Just as museums are trying to appeal to younger audiences, so too are major auction houses. In years past, officials at Sotheby's and Christie's said, they had not generated enough business from the young, contemporary collector who bought brash, avant-garde art. Now these auction houses are addressing the problem, each in its own way.
Christie's is rethinking its approach to selling and marketing contemporary art. Starting next year, it will segregate art made between 1970 and the present into a department separate from the one that handles modern masters like Jasper Johns, Willem de Kooning and Robert Rauschenberg. The new department will hold sales of art made only within the last 30 years. 
 Sotheby's, by contrast, has actually bought a piece of the art world that caters to this younger market. Last week, it announced it had purchased 50 percent of Deitch Projects, the SoHo gallery started by Jeffrey Deitch that represents artists like the 80's star Jeff Koons and the Japanese photographer and performing artist Mariko Mori.
As part of the deal, Mr. Deitch will manage the new 20th-Century Art Gallery Program for Sotheby's. Essentially, he will oversee the Andre Emmerich Gallery, which Sotheby's bought last year and which will focus on 20th-century masters. (Mr. Emmerich will be a senior adviser.)
Mr. Deitch will also continue to run two spaces in SoHo: Deitch Projects, at 76 Grand Street, and another gallery, opening Nov. 1, at 18 Wooster Street, between Grand and Canal Streets. Deitch Projects will show primarily the work of emerging artists, and the Wooster Street space will exhibit more established contemporary artists.
For Mr. Deitch, the deal offers financial muscle. It also plugs him into Sotheby's worldwide network of contacts. "This gives me a structure to play on a much bigger stage," Mr. Deitch said. "I have a wide circle of active collectors who I am personally involved with, so I will be able to help with major consignments and private sales. My first priority, however, will be building the galleries."
Diana D. Brooks, Sotheby's chief executive worldwide, said the deal would give the company more expertise in 20th-century art. "The field is so large, it's overwhelming," Mrs. Brooks said. "We're better served by having someone from the dealer world who can provide us with his own vision." Although neither Mr. Deitch nor Mrs. Brooks would disclose the financial details of the arrangement, sources close to the deal, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Sotheby's investment was in the neighborhood of $1 million.
 
'The Warhol Look'
Bloomberg News, the financial data company, is becoming a new patron of fine art in New York. In June, it helped pay for the Public Art Fund's installation of several sculptures by Keith Haring on Park Avenue and at the Doris C. Freedman Plaza, at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street. Now it is sponsoring "The Warhol Look/Glamour Style Fashion," opening at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Nov. 8, during New York's fashion week, and running through Jan. 18.
"It was Warhol who said business was going to be the art of the 80's," said David A. Ross, the Whitney's director. "We know Bloomberg is interested in pop culture, so we approached them." The show, organized by Mark Francis and Margery King, curators at the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, traces the artist's work from the 40's through the 80's. The Whitney announcement came right after the Metropolitan Museum of Art said that Michael R. Bloomberg, the founder and chairman of Bloomberg Financial Markets/Bloomberg News, had joined its board. "Our television and radio stations cover a lot of cultural events," Mr. Bloomberg said. "We get the same kind of upscale audience that goes to museums."
At the Whitney's annual benefit party, which coincides with the Warhol show, Bloomberg will supply video screens and monitors for the museum's Madison Avenue facade and its interior. They will show reels of vintage Warhol film, as well as live coverage of the party.
 
Doors Close in Chelsea
It was inevitable. Despite the explosion of new galleries in Chelsea, one had to be the first to close. That doesn't make the "For Rent" sign a welcome sight in the window of 521 West 21st Street, where the five-month-old Paolo Baldacci gallery closed last week. A show by the abstract painter Alan Uglow had been scheduled to open yesterday. "I was shocked," Mr. Uglow said. "I'm not sure what I'm going to do with the work, since some of it was made specifically for the space."
Mr. Baldacci said he couldn't afford the gallery. "I have a gallery in Milan, and I couldn't be in two places at once," he said. "Despite all the good work, the economic results were not up to my expectations." Before moving to Chelsea, Mr. Baldacci had a gallery for five years in the Fuller Building, at 41 East 57th Street, where he showed Italian modern classics and some contemporary American artists.
Rent there was too high, "and there weren't enough American collectors interested in Italian art," he said. "In the last two years, I shifted more toward young, contemporary artists, but it became impossible to do while running two galleries."
 
Weekend Art Walk
The second annual Chelsea Art walk is this weekend, when 40 galleries and 35 artists' studios will be open to the public. There will also be guided tours given by Winston Wachter Fine Art, the Upper East Side gallery that helped organize the festival. The event is sponsored by Tag Heuer, the watch manufacturer, which commissioned Herb Ritts to photograph Olympic athletes; these works are on view at D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22d Street, where there is also an information desk with schedules, maps and brochures.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Slip As Traders Take Profits

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The four-day rally in Treasury securities ended yesterday as investors took profits.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond lost 2/32 , to a price of 99 24/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, remained unchanged at 6.39 percent. Since last week the price of the long bond has increased 2 27/32 , with bondholders gaining nearly $28.44 for every $1,000 invested in bonds. 
 Investors focused on the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's September survey of regional business conditions, which suggested that the manufacturing sector may be slowing. The report bolstered bonds and overcame a report of a trade deficit that was sharply wider and a weekly jobless claims number that was surprisingly lower.
The regional Fed's report gave market participants little reason to think that the central bank would raise short-term interest rates when its Federal Open Market Committee meets on Sept. 30.
"I'm afraid we're going to see more days like today for the next couple of weeks, where there is high volatility, but little movement," said Christopher A. Low, a senior economist with the HSBC Group in New York. "We probably won't have any significant data until the employment report early next month."
Reviewing yesterday's economic data, Mr. Low said that "the weekly unemployment claims was the first report on tap and was consistent with strong employment growth; the report was quickly followed by a bigger-than-expected trade deficit, which did not signal bonds should trade up or down, but did whipsaw the market."
The market rose after the Philadelphia Fed survey seemed to confirm the market consensus about a slowing in manufacturing. Traders took particular note of two of the survey's components. The employment index fell to a reading of -3.0 in September from a gain of 14.2 in August, and the prices-paid index reading slipped to 15.1 from 16.1. Over all, the Philadelphia Fed index dipped to 20.4 in September, from 24.3 last month, a steeper drop than what economists had expected.
In the weekly jobless claims report, claims fell by 5,000, to 306,000 for the week that ended Saturday, the lowest level in a month and a half, according to the Labor Department.
Bonds were also under pressure from the Commerce Department's July trade deficit report, which showed the deficit widening to a larger-than-expected $10.3 billion from a revised $9.54 billion in June.
Robert Kapito, a senior portfolio manager at Blackrock Financial Management and Compass Capital mutual funds who oversees more than $50 billion in bonds, said that after years in the shadow of a soaring stock market, bonds are back. He cited the inflow of $6.5 billion into bond funds in August, the most in three years.
Mr. Kapito said several factors make Government bonds attractive now. Yields are attractive compared with those of bonds from other countries, especially from the large capital markets of Germany and Japan, where the yields of 10-year securities yesterday were 2.16 percent and 5.50 percent, respectively, compared with a Treasury issue with the same maturity yielding 6.10 percent.
"This is keeping U.S. bond investors at home and attracting foreign money into U.S. bonds," he said.
Mr. Kapito also cited the strength of the dollar, as well as a shortage of bonds relative to demand. With the United States reducing its deficit spending, fewer bonds are being issued. He forecast yields on Treasuries dropping to a range of 6 percent to 6.25 percent on the long bond by the end of the year.
In when-issued trading for next week's Treasury auctions, the new two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.79 percent, and the five-year at a price to yield 6 percent.

HEADLINE: At Whirlpool, 4,700 Workers To Lose Jobs

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The Whirlpool Corporation announced today that it would dismiss 4,700 employees -- just more than 10 percent of its work force -- and take a $350 million charge against earnings as part of a plan to improve profits.
The reorganization plan will affect mainly its European operations, where Whirlpool has run into strong local competition, made marketing missteps and, more recently, faced adverse exchange rates in Italy, its European manufacturing hub. The company said it also planned to seek strategic alliances or other alternatives that will get it out of money-losing joint ventures that make refrigerators and air- conditioners in China. 
 "We're addressing the realities of the marketplaces in which we operate," said David R. Whitwam, chairman and chief executive of the appliance giant, which is based in Benton Harbor, Mich.
Mr. Whitwam stressed that the revamping did not represent a retreat from the company's global expansion, which began in 1989. Indeed, in addition to the retrenching, Whirlpool also said that it would assume control of Brasmotor S.A., the profitable Brazilian appliance company that has been its longtime partner in South America, by paying $217 million to increase its stake to 66 percent from 33 percent.
To cover the cost of that investment and reduce its financial risks, Whirlpool will sell $1.6 billion in receivables and other assets and operations of the Whirlpool Financial Corporation, its finance subsidiary, mostly to the Transamerica Corporation. Whirlpool projects that the deal will bring in $300 million after it pays off associated debts. Whirlpool had announced in July that it was considering its options for its finance arm.
The moves to cut losses in China and Europe were long overdue from Wall Street's perspective. Investors sent Whirlpool's shares soaring 14.2 percent, up $8.0625, to a 52-week high of $64.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"They really cracked the whip," said Nicholas Heymann, a consumer products analyst at Prudential Securities, which raised its recommendation on the stock to a buy.
Whirlpool's moves came just months after Electrolux, its largest European rival, announced a reorganization that will cut up to 12,000 jobs and close 25 plants.
Whirlpool's write-off will come to $3.38 a share and will be taken in the current quarter. The sale of Whirlpool's finance operations, expected in the fourth quarter, should add 53 cents a share to earnings.
The result would be a slim net profit for the year. Without such special charges, analysts expected earnings for the year to be $3.18, according to Zacks Investment Research. Whirlpool earned $111 million, or $1.48 a share, on sales of $4.2 billion in the first half of the year.
Whirlpool said that the job cuts would take place over three years and that the annual savings from the reorganization would reach $180 million in 2000. Roughly half of the job reductions are expected to be in Europe. As many as 800 jobs could be eliminated in the United States, not counting employees of Whirlpool Finance.
"It's our goal to grow our commercial finance business, and this is a big expansion for us, especially of our base in Europe," said William McClave, a spokesman for Transamerica, which is based in San Francisco. The deal with Whirlpool calls for Transamerica to continue providing a range of financial services over 10 years.
Whirlpool's global drive had once been viewed as a well-executed plan to expand out of its market-leading but stagnant North American appliance base. An interview with Mr. Whitwam published in the Harvard Business Review in 1994 was titled "The Right Way to Go Global," and the company's stock rose to $74 early that year. Mr. Whitwam said that Whirlpool was prospering because it was not just operating overseas but making sure that new technology, manufacturing skills and other assets were shared among countries.
But problems were already growing, both at home, where second-ranked General Electric was stepping up its efforts, and in Europe, where Whirlpool had been slow to consolidate manufacturing plants it had acquired and where demand was too sluggish to raise prices. Meanwhile, Whirlpool's rapid buildup in Asia was draining cash.
Whirlpool's stock tumbled below $50 in 1994 and hovered at that level for three years as setbacks undermined each hint of recovery. The company took a $240 million write-off at the end of 1994 in a reorganization aimed at eliminating 3,200 jobs, including 1,200 in North America.
Whirlpool was not the only appliance maker struggling with attempts to extend its geographical reach. Maytag, which invested heavily in Europe, finally gave up in 1995, swallowing a $135 million loss on the sale of its operations there.
Mr. Whitwam said that the restructuring announced today reflected Whirlpool's conclusion that high unemployment rates and low levels of consumer confidence pointed to poor market conditions in Europe for a long time to come.
In China, Mr. Whitwam said, Whirlpool decided to stop making refrigerators and air-conditioners because there was severe overcapacity and other manufacturers planned even more production.
"There won't be equilibrium for years," Mr. Whitwam said, but Whirlpool intends to continue making washing machines, where it has the leading market share, and microwave ovens, where it has the third most popular brand.
"We'll sell 2.2 million appliances in Asia this year, up from 40,000 four years ago," Mr. Whitwam said. "We'll sell more next year and will be doing it profitably."

HEADLINE: China Turns Another Corner

 BODY:
The centerpiece of this week's Chinese Communist Party Congress was President Jiang Zemin's call for the sale, merger or closing of the vast majority of China's state-owned enterprises. His declaration exceeded expectations and signals the boldest economic transformation attempted by Beijing since the early 1980's.
Regrettably, Mr. Jiang and his party colleagues showed no parallel interest in political liberalization, the key to consolidating a market economy and relieving chronic tensions between China and the United States. 
 Mr. Jiang emerges from the conference with his personal authority strengthened and his chief party rival, Qiao Shi, nudged into premature retirement. Next month he will try to enhance his diplomatic prestige with a long-sought state visit to Washington. The chances of a successful meeting would be improved by a good-will gesture like an amnesty for political prisoners, including the democracy advocates Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan.
Even after two decades of market liberalization under Deng Xiaoping, China's 305,000 state companies still account for more than half of urban employment, though a far smaller share of total output. Overstaffed, inefficient and obliged to provide a full range of welfare benefits to their employees, these enterprises had threatened to exert an increasing drag on China's future growth potential. They now absorb 90 percent of business credits provided by the state banking system, and the special privileges enjoyed by their managers also made these companies seedbeds of official corruption.
Despite artful language casting the move to shareholding and market relations as appropriate to "the primary stage of socialism," Mr. Jiang's initiative sharply challenges the party's guardians of Marxist ideology, something he had been conspicuously unwilling to do during the long and delicate transition of power occasioned by the frailty and death of Mr. Deng.
That Mr. Jiang now seems to feel confident enough to embrace accelerated economic reform leaves room for hope that he will go further and reopen the issue of political reform, off-limits since the 1989 blood bath in Tiananmen Square. In a modestly encouraging sign, China's officially controlled press permitted a slightly broadened range of political debate in the weeks leading up to this week's Communist Party Congress. Chinese leaders traditionally use these congresses, held every five years, to unveil major shifts in ideology, leadership or economic structure.
Mr. Jiang's privatization plan calls for the vast majority of state-owned firms to pass into the market, leaving only about 500 of the very largest in government hands. Many of the details, including the timetable, have yet to be filled in. What is most important is that government monopolies not give way to private monopolies and that privatization not become a smoke screen for handing over public assets cheaply to the well connected.
Shutting down these state enterprises carries social and political risks. That partly explains why it has been put off so long. There is likely to be a jump in unemployment and considerable suffering as workers lose their present entitlements to company-provided schools, health care, pensions and other social benefits. Worker protests are already on the rise in China and could grow, all the more so since Chinese citizens still have no real political outlet for their grievances.
Beijing can partially mitigate these problems by moving quickly to build a universal government-guaranteed safety net to replace benefits now provided mainly to employees of state enterprises through their workplaces. But it is unlikely to achieve lasting stability until it recognizes the virtues of decentralizing political as well as economic power and unleashing the civic as well as the productive energies of its people.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fall For a Third Week

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell unexpectedly in the latest week, the Government said today, providing more evidence of a persistent tightness in the labor market.
 The Labor Department said initial claims for state unemployment compensation slid by 5,000, to a seasonally adjusted 306,000 last week, the lowest since the week of Aug. 2. It was the third consecutive week to show a drop.
 
 Wall Street economists had expected a surge in first-time claims to 320,000.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Construction of Rentals Is Surging

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
Capitalizing on the steady demand for new rentals in Manhattan, developers will start leasing 227 apartments next month in a building rising at 33d Street and First Avenue, once the site of a gas station.
Called Eastbridge Landing, the 22-story building, at 577 First Avenue, will have studio to three-bedroom apartments, as well as a few larger units and penthouses. It will also have 10,000 square feet of medical office space on the ground floor along with an 80-space parking garage. 
 Ten more rental projects with some 2,500 new apartments are expected to be completed in the city by early 1999, according to estimates from Feathered Nest, a residential brokerage firm in Manhattan that is the leasing agent for Eastbridge Landing.
The vacancy rate for apartments in luxury buildings in good locations throughout Manhattan is under 1 percent, most brokers agree. That, along with rising rents, which increased about 10 percent on the East and West Sides the first half of this year, is fueling the construction activity.
"There will be adjustments in the rents according to the supply and demand," said Corinne R. Pulitzer, senior vice president at the Charles H. Greenthal Residential Sales Corporation, a residential brokerage. "But with the current lack of supply for luxury rentals, and assuming the economy remains healthy, new projects should rent quickly."
Ms. Pulitzer said the demand is coming from young professionals and families, as well as people selling their condominiums and co-ops to take advantage of the strong sales market. Those people are aware that "if they sell high they will have to buy high" and are opting to rent, she added.
At the same time, given the scarcity of development sites and the greater availability of financing, "construction has and is going forward on parcels that are ready to go, and in areas that until recently would not have been considered by the lending community for upscale housing," said Andrew J. Singer, chairman of the Singer & Bassuk Organization, a real estate financing firm in Manhattan. "That in turn," he said, "is expanding the definition of prime neighborhoods."
The developers of Eastbridge Landing bought the old gas station site last year from Mobil Oil in a sale that drew many bidders.
Construction is to be completed by March, said Trevor Davis, president of Davis & Partners, which is building Eastbridge Landing in a joint venture with Aby Rosen and Michael Fuchs, who own the RFP Holding Corporation. Both companies are based in Manhattan. The partners declined to give the purchase price, but the total cost is $45 million; financing is coming from American and European banks.
"It is a great location with easy access to midtown in a well-established predominantly residential neighborhood," Mr. Davis said, noting that the project would be the first rental built in the area in years and that none are planned within a six- to seven-block radius of the site. In terms of new luxury rentals on the East Side, "the playing field is not crowded," he added.
The partners have also renovated four adjacent four-story brownstones with 30 rental apartments and 6,000 square feet of street-level retail space. At that project, known as Eastbridge Landing Annex, the 11 unoccupied one-bedroom apartments have been leased, as have the storefronts.
Eastbridge Landing is in Kips Bay, the area between 30th and 34th Streets and First and Third Avenues. Ms. Pulitzer said that while the area, near New York University Medical Center and Bellevue Hospital, "may not have the same cachet as the Upper East or West Side, it is a solid family neighborhood."
The studio to three-bedroom apartments at the building, designed by the Manhattan architect Costas Kondylis, will have 525 to 2,500 square feet of space. Early estimates of monthly rents range from $1,750 for a studio to $7,800 for the top three-bedroom. Rents for the larger units and penthouses, with 2,500 to 3,500 square feet, may start at $7,000.
Mr. Davis said tenants will also have the option of combining apartments.
Mr. Davis said Eastbridge Landing, which offers views of the East River, will have the same focus on "quality and service" that proved successful at 300 East 64th Street, which he and his partners completed last year and where all 103 units were rented out in 16 weeks.
Amenities at the new building, faced in brick with stone and concrete details, include a health club and an outdoor landscaped garden. Tenants will have to pay for a parking space in the garage, but those prices have not been set, Mr. Davis said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Gap Widened to $10.3 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Driven in part by a mounting deficit with Japan, the nation's trade gap widened sharply in July, to $10.34 billion, the biggest since January, from $8.29 billion in June, the Commerce Department reported today.
Lower exports and higher imports both contributed to the surprisingly big rise, which economists attributed to statistical problems as well as the strong dollar, the weak economies of many trading partners and unflagging American growth. 
 The $5.2 billion deficit with Japan -- the biggest in two years -- captured political attention here and in Hong Kong where officials are gathering for this weekend's meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank.
"Slow growth and the fact that the Japanese market is still too closed to imports are reasons why our trade imbalance with Japan is large," complained William Daley, the Commerce Secretary. He called the persistently large gap between the two countries "upsetting" and said it would be "unacceptable" for Japan to try to export its way back to prosperity.
The latest widening of the deficit provides ammunition to those opposed to the Clinton Administration's attempt to win so-called fast-track authority for the President to negotiate unamendable trade agreements. Critics of fast-track power generally equate deficits more with lost jobs than with the benefits of lower-cost goods.
After dipping in June, imports rebounded 1.1 percent in July, to a record $87.7 billion, led by a 6.4 percent advance in vehicles, parts and engines, reflecting, in part, an end to production delays at auto assembly plants in Canada. But motor vehicles imported from Japan jumped 10.5 percent to bring the seven-month total to $20.9 billion, nearly nine times the value of vehicles the United States has sent to Japan this year.
Figures for trade between individual countries are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation.
Exports, meanwhile, retreated 1.4 percent from June's record peak to total $77.38 billion, with industrial supplies and materials -- especially shipments of nonmonetary gold -- the largest factor.
While trade data often swing sharply from month to month, analysts said they took little comfort that July's widening deficit might have been exaggerated by seasonal or statistical factors.
"There's hardly anything you can say that's good about trade prospects," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities.
He said that the Japanese "just don't have any more levers to pull" that would raise their demand for American goods or reduce the reliance of their companies on overseas markets. He said he was not, however, convinced that Japan's economy was as bad as was indicated by this week's report that showed a contraction at an 11.2 percent annual rate during the spring quarter. His doubts were widely shared by senior American policy makers.
The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said today in Seattle that the United States was seeking "a better understanding of what's happening economically in Japan."
Janet L. Yellen, the President's chief economic adviser, said in a speech in New Orleans on Monday that what was important was not the size of nation's trade gap -- the amount by which imports exceed exports -- but the volume of trade, which implied "openness" to its benefits.
She also said that "there is a big difference between borrowing in order to invest -- as the economy is doing now -- and borrowing in order to consume, as we did in the 1980's."
Analysts acknowledged today that the country is indeed investing substantially but noted that the Government's report still showed net imports of consumer goods in July.
As American officials resumed their grumbling about the deficit with Japan and China, which have been repeatedly switching places as the biggest and second-biggest surpluses with the United States, a business-backed research group outlined a new strategy for disputes with Asian countries.
"Back away from unilateral sanctions and bilateral trade battles," advised the Committee for Economic Development. "Instead settle disputes where possible through the World Trade Organization, which is proving fair and effective."
The deficit with China, the department's report showed, climbed to $4.7 billion from $4.3 billion, while Japan's $5.2 billion deficit was up from $4.1 billion in June.
As for Western Europe, the deficit soared so much -- to $4.3 billion from $800 million -- that analysts, noting similar leaps in July 1996 and 1995, suspected flaws in the statistics. "Something is rotten in Denmark -- not to mention Germany, France, Italy and the United Kingdom -- with respect to these trade flows," said Joseph Liro, economist at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities in New York.
