HEADLINE: The Cries of Welfare States Under the Knife

SERIES: CHANGING MONEY: Second of two articles

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BENEVENTO, Italy

 BODY:
At the end of a dim corridor full of yellowing files spilling their forgotten contents onto dusty shelves sits Dr. Mario Maddaloni, the Italian state's inquisitor in this depressed southern town.
His mission is to cut the waste in Italian welfare, saving the state money by rooting out phony invalids. The disabled of Benevento account for an astonishing 21 percent of the population. The culture of dependency is deep-rooted. But if Italy is to balance its budget and qualify for the euro, that culture has to change. 
 Dr. Maddaloni has already interviewed about 800 local invalids. Of these, more than half were found to be making false claims and lost their benefits. It was wrenching work, the doctor said, because many of the people coming to the office needed the disability pensions to get by.
"But we have to do this," he said. "As long as we waste public money, we will pay more taxes. And Italy will get left behind -- a car with a beautiful wheels, a nice paint job and a lousy engine."
Throughout Europe, the euro, like globalization, has proved unforgiving of the inefficiences of what Germans call the Vaterstaat -- the consoling Father-State, always there when needed. It is forcing a radical reconsideration of the model of European society -- one that is treacherous politically because it has been decreed by central bankers rather than demanded by voters.
The euro requires countries to cut their budget deficits to 3 percent of total output this year if they are to qualify for the new European money on Jan. 1, 1999. That can only be achieved through cutbacks in the Continent's welfare state. Italy's budget deficit stood at 12 percent as recently as 1992. The euro is shaking Europe like a massive electric shock.
Even in countries whose public finances were less messy than Italy's, the euro is posing a basic question: how much of the welfare state should be sacrificed for it? If European nations give radically different answers, tensions will jolt the single-currency zone.
In Germany and France -- with respective unemployment rates at a record 11.6 percent and 12.6 percent -- the debate on how to shift from the expensive subsidizing of inactivity to stimulating jobs is already politically explosive. If welfare reform is pushed too hard, there could be social upheaval, as there was in France in December 1995, when strikers virtually shut down Paris to protest proposed changes to social security.
The debate is particularly volatile because it is envenomed by a sense that Europe's social model is under assault from a more vigorous United States.
As Jacques Chirac, the French President, made clear by declining to don cowboy boots at the meeting of leading industrialized nations in Denver in July, he does not want to be an extra in Bill Clinton's global theme park. "We have our model," Mr. Chirac said, "and we plan to stick to it."
But is that model compatible with the euro? France has advanced social protection but also record unemployment, high taxes, labor-market rigidity, low growth and a rapidly aging population. It, and countries like it, will almost certainly find the small budget deficit demanded by the euro's fiscal discipline hard to sustain. It is also likely to need different monetary policies from states that have chosen to sacrifice some social security for jobs and faster growth.
"If countries give radically different answers to the challenge of reforming the welfare state," said Hans Tietmeyer, president of the German Bundesbank, "we are going to have problems in the euro zone."
In Britain, for example, social security spending accounts for about 13 percent of total output, compared with 20 percent in Italy and 23 percent in France. Britain seems set on a radically different course from its Continental neighbors. It is a course that borrows much from the American conviction that reduced taxation, deregulation, labor-market flexibility and a dwindling safety net are the route to success in the jungle of the global economy.
"People look across the Channel and they do not like what they see," said Kenneth Clarke, former Chancellor of the Exchequer. "Confronted with the euro, they ask, why should we be locked into failure? Continental Europe is overregulated and sclerotic, and the key to recovery there is structural change."
British growth was double the French rate last year and, at about 3 percent, will be well above French rates again this year. Unemployment has plunged to 5.8 percent, from 10.4 percent in 1993, as the economy has benefited from lower taxes and the birth of a shareholding culture.
In the Netherlands, consensus has achieved what the Thatcherite revolution did in Britain, bringing unemployment down to 6.5 percent from more than 10 percent a decade ago, without accentuating inequalities as much as in Britain. Growth, as in Britain, has surged. But in both countries, to varying degrees, job security and welfare protection have been sacrificed.
Europe thus offers various economic models, whose differences will be laid bare by the euro. The currency will test the sustainability of different systems even as it exposes them.
A common currency will reveal, for example, that the same brand of Scotch whisky can vary in price by 50 percent, depending on whether it is bought in Spain or Germany. It will also reveal the relative attractiveness of different European economic environments in terms of tax levels, costs of labor, onerousness of welfare, and incentives to business.
"If we get the euro," said Bruce Kasman, a vice president of J.P. Morgan in London, "inefficient policies will be much less sustainable. You are going to see the same kinds of competition as between states in America. There are going to be huge pressures on countries to provide policies conducive to investment."

Italy Fights Its History
A System Corrupted By Cold War Politics
In Italy that pressure is particularly intense. More than 10 percent of Italians -- six million people -- are officially disabled. They will cost Italy more than $33 billion this year in disability pensions.
Many do have physical handicaps. But many are the healthy beneficiaries of a bygone system. Before the cold war ended, $33 billion was considered a reasonable annual investment in Italian political stability.
For decades Italy produced "invalids" at a remarkable clip. The politician, usually Christian Democrat, who arranged for the payment of a disability pension won votes. Particularly in southern Italy, where jobs were scarce, to be disabled was to gain a passport to money or a job.
It was a costly setup. Budget deficits and national debt spiraled. But the system helped keep the Christian Democrats in office and the Communists out. Italy did not go the way of neighboring Yugoslavia or Albania. Social security meant geopolitical security.
Now, however, a political age has given way to an economic one. Over Germany's border with Poland it is no longer the Warsaw Pact that threatens; it is workers making one-tenth of German salaries. Yesterday's esteemed political client in Italy is today's resented financial burden. It is the euro, not the politburo, that obsesses Europe.
"The euro is my frontier," said Enrico Michele, Undersecretary of State for the center-left Government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi. "Either we make it or this Government falls. And to get there, we have to negotiate reform of a distorted pension system. The welfare state is part of the European idea and cannot be completely dismantled. It must, however, be changed."
Michelangelo Bergamini is leading the campaign for change. As a senior Treasury official, he has been asked to lead a sweeping inquiry to unearth the fraudulent recipients of disability pensions.
Such is the labyrinth of Italy's state-run pension system -- costing more than $190 billion a year, or about 15 percent of total national output -- that there are three separate categories of invalid, each paid by a different state entity.
Mr. Bergamini was asked to start by investigating the 1.4 million cases handled by the Ministry of the Interior. The number of people receiving these pensions has doubled since 1985; pensions cost the Interior Ministry about $8.8 billion in 1996. Over an 18-month period that is to end on March 31, 1998, Mr. Bergamini's inquisitors, operating throughout the country, are interviewing 150,000 of the 1.4 million "invalids" to examine whether their claims are real.
"We are well into the program," Mr. Bergamini said, "and up to now we have found that one in four of those inspected was a false invalid. We have found blind people who were not blind and people miraculously cured of rheumatoid arthritis. In the most extreme cases -- say a blind man working as a bus driver -- we are bringing criminal cases."
Mr. Bergamini's agent in Benevento is Dr. Maddaloni. He works in a crumbling palace. There are typewriters but no computers. Just outside town, there are still people living in the mobile housing they were given after the 1980 Naples earthquake.
The bureaucracy of Italian welfare had assumed fantastic proportions before the current attempt at reform began. Under a 1980 law, for example, a person with a peptic ulcer causing "grave digestive disturbance" could claim a disability level of 51 percent to 60 percent. Diabetes of "medium gravity" would confer 31 percent to 40 percent disability. Different ailments could be added -- like roulette chips piled one on the next -- to increase one's degree of disability.
The degree was critical. Until 1992, a 35 percent disability level was enough to qualify a person for one of the numerous jobs in the public administration and state companies reserved for invalids. In the south, the postal service was a preferred haven.
A politician would send somebody to a friendly doctor who would certify a disability. And the reward would be a flood of votes. "Whoever governed from 1960 to 1990 had to have clients," Dr. Maddaloni said. "Welfare was the means."
The level of disability needed to qualify for a monthly pension is now 74 percent. The pension is quite small -- about $250 a month -- but a very useful cushion for poor families in places like Benevento.
At 100 percent disability, the situation changes. Authorities may approve a further $450 a month, supposedly to pay for a full-time nurse. There is no verification of the employment of such a nurse. Remarkably, more than 60 percent of the 1.4 million people now under investigation by Mr. Bergamini enjoy this additional benefit.
 
Italy Eyes the Prize
So Much to Change, So Little Time
Mariano de Luca, president of a Benevento invalids' association, is furious about Mr. Bergamini's campaign. He pointed to the man sprawled on the sofa and urged him to speak. "Say something, Pasquale, say something!" he hollered. No response. "Something, Pasquale, you must say something!"
From Pasquale di Fiori there emerged a groan. The sound slipped from lips contorted into a grimace. His hands writhed with the effort; his body was clearly a vessel he did not control. The sound, a crescendo, was a call from a distant place.
Satisfied, Mr. de Luca turned away. "You see what the Government is doing," he said. "Pasquale can't walk. He can't talk. But the Government calls him a false invalid! So they won't give him the disability pension he deserves. The euro is being used to justify an Italian witch hunt."
Mr. di Fiori has twice requested the extra $450 payment for 100 percent disability and been refused. The authorities argue that his parents can look after him. But to Mr. de Luca, the case suggests that the excess of abuse has been replaced by an excess of reforming zeal.
But Mr. Bergamini remains tranquil in his mission, convinced that Italy should break with its former culture and become a truly modern state with the euro as its currency.
Already this year, his investigation has saved about $150 million, an amount expected to double by the end of the first phase of his inquiry next year. Moreover, the number of invalids -- which had been growing more than 10 percent a year in the 1980's -- stopped rising last year.
Eventually, it is clear, Italy's entire pension system will have to be reviewed. The three categories of invalid will have to be grouped into one and a rigorous inspection of claims carried out, officials said. Resistance from labor unions is certain to be intense.
All this bodes ill. It is the sheer extent of these needed reforms that causes Arrigo Sadun, an Italian economist, to think that Italy is misguided in its haste to adopt the euro at its planned outset on Jan. 1, 1999.
"There is no question the Germans are right," he said. "Government spending is not yet under control. We Italians are going through a one-shot, unsustainable adjustment. Italy is not ready for the euro."
Still, the strides Italy has made so far are staggering. Nowhere is it more obvious that the euro is fueling profound economic adjustment in Europe.
Inflation has come down to a projected 2 percent this year, from 5 percent two years ago, and is now below the German level. The critical budget deficit figure may be as low as 3.2 percent this year. The national debt -- more than 120 percent of total gross domestic product -- remains way above the 60 percent target set for the euro, but it is also coming down.
"The euro has been the means to modernize our country," said Giuseppe Zadra, president of the Association of Italian Banks. "Without that external constraint we would have been too lazy to do it ourselves. If we do not make it now, it would be a disaster."
But Hans Zehetmair, culture minister of the German state of Bavaria, is among those unimpressed by Italy's efforts. "When you see how creative the Italians are with bookkeeping," he said, "then I say no, we will not allow this to make the German people suffer. Italy cannot come into the first wave of the euro."
 
Britain Keeps Its Distance
An Ex-Basket Case, And Proud of It
While the euro has been the agent of change in Italy, Britain transformed itself several years ago and as a result has profound doubts about a common currency. Britain's economic culture is now so profoundly divergent from that of Continental Europe that it is not easy to imagine Britain operating with the same money as its European Union partners.
Britain is an important economy. More than 60 percent of its trade is with other European Union countries. The City of London has by far the Continent's largest securities and capital market. A euro without that market will obviously be incomplete, and a Britain without the euro may face exclusion from a powerful club.
Yet, to travel around Britain today is to be plunged into a world to which Germany and France seemingly have scant relation. The attractiveness of soccer-club shares or building-society shares is the stuff of casual pub conversations. Shareholding has become a kind of national sport.
This radical change struck Walter Hasselkus when he moved from Germany to Britain two years ago to take over management of Rover, which had been acquired by BMW.
Old images of conflict -- the miners' strike, auto strikes -- inevitably lingered in this German executive's mind from the days when Britain was Europe's basket case. But what he found, he said, was "an acceptance that competitiveness is an absolute must."
"It is amazing, absolutely amazing," Mr. Hasselkus continued, "to see the brutal change of ideological direction here. Britain is very, very far from the social-market model that has served Germany well, and I think we in Germany have to be very careful not to knit the social safety net closer than we can afford."
Olivier Cadic, a French businessman, recently moved part of his electronics business, Info Elec, from France to Britain precisely to escape charges and constraints that he could not afford.
In Britain, he can hire and dismiss easily, and social security taxes add only 10 percent to his wage bill, compared with 50 percent in France. "We can employ people here," Mr. Cadic said, "but in France it has become prohibitive to hire. The French system seems to be conceived so that unemployment can go up."
For Mr. Cadic, Britain has realized, as France has not, that the world has changed. For a long time, the devloped world enjoyed a virtual monopoly -- of knowledge, of capital, of the most important goods, of military strength. That domination has now been seriously eroded. The knowledge and means exist for things to be made anywhere. This is the challenge that globalization poses.
Eddie George, governor of the British Central Bank, thinks Britain can comfortably live alongside the euro zone for an indefinite period, preserving sterling as its currency, just as Canada preserves its currency alongside the United States. And he sees grave dangers in joining the euro before France and Germany have undergone reform.
"If some European areas are ready to lower minimum wages and achieve a flexible labor market, and others are not," he said, "how can the euro work?"
 
France Sits in Concrete
Anglo-Saxon Model As Gallic Bugbear
Yet in France, the very word "flexibility" -- also favored by Mr. Tietmeyer of the Bundesbank -- is taboo. It is seen as a code word for replacing Gallic solidarity with marauding American capitalism. France wants the euro, but unlike Italy it seems unprepared to change to accommodate it.
"An extreme free-market approach may work," said a senior official at the French Finance Ministry. "But it is not for us."
Ed Balls, an aide to the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, worries about what he sees as an effort in Paris to caricature the Anglo-Saxon model as an excuse not to change. "Look," he said, "America has created 30 million jobs since 1979. Surely we can borrow something from this. I say to the French, 'Our model is not perfect but nor is yours. Let's try for dynamism without cruelty.' "
To look at a pay slip from Eric de Cardonnay's BDM decorating company in the Normandy town of Bray-et-Lu is to understand something of France's absence of dynamism. In its way, it is as alarming as the number of invalids in Benevento -- and as rich in ominous implications for the economy of the euro zone.
When Mr. de Cardonnay started his company in 1977, there were five lines to a salary slip. Now, after various taxes and charges have been listed, there are 29 lines stretching over two full pages.
At the end of this labyrinth, the cost to Mr. de Cardonnay of employing a worker at a gross monthly salary of 10,111 francs ($1,699) ends up at 15,306 francs ($2,572), or an additional 51 percent. The worker ends up with net pay of 7,882 francs ($1,324).
The charges to Mr. de Cardonnay amount to a grand tour of France's welfare state, one that cossets but also appears to stifle.
There are taxes for family allowances, for a fund offering low-cost housing loans, for unemployment insurance, for work accident compensation, for pensions, for the improvement of security on building sites, for professional training, and even for reducing the social security deficit -- an estimated $7.2 billion this year.
Indeed, the charges are so numerous and diverse that this entrepreneur has given up trying to remember what all the acronyms stand for. All he is sure of is this: "These charges are simply uncontrollable. They go up all the time."
That, in turn, creates difficulties. Having expanded steadily through the 1980's, BDM faced a crisis at the beginning of this decade caused by a combination of rising labor costs and falling revenue. Mr. Cardonnay decided he had to lay off six of his 21 workers.
For 18 months after the layoffs, he had to continue paying an amount equivalent to most of the six workers' salaries, so they could be retrained for other jobs. This so-called conversion training has in practice proved largely ineffectual.
"Anyone who has gone through that will never hire again," Mr. de Cardonnay said.
BDM's experience is anything but uncommon. Increasing costs and constraints on dismissals keep entrepreneurs from hiring and expanding. Unemployment rises.
With it, the pressure builds on the welfare state funded by the charges. Taxes must rise further to compensate. The pay slip must grow longer still. The circle is vicious.
"If costs for employers in America were the same as in France," said a leading French banker, "perhaps 25 percent of Americans would be unemployed."
The dangers to the euro in this French situation are clear enough. Unemployment brings anger, and it can take nationalist forms. Already the extreme-right National Front has become the third-largest party in France, with 15 percent of the vote. It constantly attacks the euro as a German plot to take over Europe.
If unemployment continues to rise and change continues to be resisted, the euro may simply prove a catalyst to disaster. It will be the symbol -- weak and untrusted -- of a stagnant Continent. The state budgets behind the money will be overstretched. Germans will want their mark back. The inquisition at Benevento will have been in vain.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rubin to Press Central Banks to Disclose Financial Data

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 18

 BODY:
In the Clinton Administration's first major response to the Southeast Asian currency crisis, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said today that the United States would press governments and central banks around the world to disclose more financial data that most nations routinely keep secret.
The American initiative, which could meet considerable resistance from Asian nations whose currencies have been under attack, stems from the discovery that Thailand's central bank kept secret data that would have warned international investors of the country's impending crisis. 
 But several Asian leaders have disagreed and argued that the crisis was precipitated by currency speculators, many of them from the United States, and it is likely that they will oppose disclosure requirements that could embolden such speculators to make new assaults on the value of their currencies.
"Let me be absolutely clear," Mr. Rubin said in a speech this morning, on his way to Hong Kong for the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. "The United States has a profound interest in the restoration of financial stability in Asia."
The I.M.F. has tried to help restore order to the Asian financial markets in recent weeks, and is reviewing whether it missed signs over the last few years of Thailand's huge bank-debt exposure.
Today's announcement has echoes of Mr. Rubin's actions after the Mexican peso crisis of 1994-95. At the time, he pressed the Group of Seven leading industrial nations, and then much of the third world, to agree to tougher disclosure standards, an action he believed would have helped avert the Mexican crisis. If foreign investors had known the extent of Mexico's economic troubles, he argued at the time, they would have stopped pumping cash into the country -- and imposed fiscal discipline on Mexican political leaders.
Mr. Rubin conceded today, however, that the post-Mexico changes did not go far enough.
"Our concept was right," he said. "But as time goes on, you learn. There are many things we did not cover" in those rules, he said, "that we now should include."
Among them are statistics showing commitments to buy or sell currencies in the future, figures that the central banks of many nations consider state secrets.
Central banks periodically report the levels of their reserves of foreign currency, which helps investors assess whether the countries can sustain current exchange rates and protect against devaluations. But the disclosure rules do not require them to disclose whether they have committed themselves to use those reserves to buy or sell other currencies -- say the yen or the dollar -- in the future.
In short, the governments have to report their assets, but not their liabilities. It is a little like telling a credit card company that you have $1,000 in the bank to pay your monthly bill -- but neglecting to mention that you have already committed $900 to pay the mortgage.
Thailand kept that data secret for much of this year. When its currency came under attack, it discovered that its reserves were worth much less than the world thought. That precipitated a crisis that spread to Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines.
With the Thais, many leading speculators suspected that the country's central bank was essentially overstating its available reserves, and would be forced to drop the fixed exchange rate between its currency, the baht, and the dollar. But other investors, with less savvy or less sophisticated research, were left in the dark.
No country would be compelled to follow the new disclosure rules. But if Mr. Rubin succeeds in getting a number of countries to agree to fuller public disclosure through the International Monetary Fund, the pressure on others to follow suit would be great. Investors could reward countries that disclose more, and charge higher "risk premiums" to those that refuse to go along.
Mr. Rubin's proposal will also include forcing commercial banks to report details of their nonperforming loans. Japan's banks kept these figures secret for much of the first half of the 1990's, then suffered huge losses when the facts came out. The country is still trying to recover economically.
"Making these disclosures is often difficult in the short run, and the temptation is to avoid doing so," Mr. Rubin said. " But it builds credibility in a nation's financial system and avoids much more difficult problems in the long run. The reality of life is that things get out sooner or later."
Mr. Rubin has made clear in recent days that he is worried about a world backlash stemming from the Asian crisis, one that would reverse a decade of progress toward greater openness in financial markets. Both Thailand and Malaysia, for example, tried to clamp down on currency traders to prevent them from selling the local currency, and from selling stocks in their markets. Thailand's market has declined 37 percent (and nearly 55 percent when translated into dollars) so far this year.
While the United States directly aided Mexico in 1995 -- lending it $12 billion that has since been paid back -- its only aid to Thailand has been through the I.M.F. program to promote stability there. But the effect on the American economy may prove considerable since Thailand and its neighbors are greatly reducing their purchase of foreign-made goods. That is damaging to American companies. Developing nations in Asia accounted for more than a fifth of all United States exports last year.
As Mr. Rubin headed to Hong Kong and then to China, where he is to meet the new leadership team emerging from the Communist Party Congress ending in Beijing, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright described for the first time her vision of the role of international economic issues in American foreign policy.
She argued today that leadership in opening markets -- including giving President Clinton new fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements -- was critical in bolstering American influence.
"The best course for our nation is not to curse globalization, but to shape it, to make it work for America," she said. "It would be foolish to get up from the table and leave the game to others. For we are competing very, very well."

HEADLINE: United Cuts Travel Agency Commissions

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
United Airlines has cut travel agency commissions to 8 percent from 10 percent for all tickets sold in the United States, saying yesterday it did so to save $80 million to $100 million annually so that it could "survive and succeed" in the global marketplace.
Gerald Greenwald, United's chairman and chief executive, said the new fees reflected the airline's "larger objective of keeping all of our costs under control." 
 "The quest to cut costs isn't a one-shot exercise; it's a way of life at United," he said. "There is a new and more intense level of competitiveness that all airlines must now confront in the marketplace."
United, a subsidiary of the UAL Corporation, said the change would have no effect on ticket prices for passengers.
The 28,500-member American Society of Travel Agents promptly denounced the cuts, which take effect today, as "deplorable and shortsighted." It also said that it "is already exploring all options, legal and otherwise, and is determined to take the strongest and most prudent course of action available."
Steve Loucks, a spokesman for the association, said it had not had time to calculate the travel agents' potential losses in the event other airlines follow suit. None had by last evening, and telephone calls to several airlines' corporate offices seeking comment were not returned.
United's announcement follows the imposition on Feb. 9, 1995, of what has since become the standard 10 percent commission on domestic fares, with a $50 limit. That earlier cap was initiated by Delta Air Lines, also as a move to cut costs. The maximum commission on United's domestic flights will continue to be $25 for each one-way ticket and $50 for a round-trip ticket. The airline will have no maximum for international tickets bought in the United States.
The 8 percent rate, United noted, is identical to the rates of Delta and American Airlines on some routes. Most other airlines continue to pay 10 percent.
The Delta cap two years ago set off a furor among travel agents, who held meetings and protest rallies to denounce Delta and the other carriers that soon followed Delta's lead. The carriers that did not go along were Trans World Airlines, Southwest, America West, Midwest Express and Alaska Airlines.
Yesterday's reaction from travel agents was more subdued, perhaps because most agents had not yet learned about United's decision late in the day. Those who had were not pleased.
"First they cut service to the bone," said Joe Galloway, the owner of Trans-Continental Travel in Houston. "Now they're cutting commissions of the people who sell 80 percent of their seats and interface with their customers at least 80 percent of the time."
Despite dire predictions that the Delta caps would force thousands of travel agencies out of business, the number of agencies has increased to 33,727 as of June 30 this year, Mr. Loucks said, compared with 33,411 at the time the caps were imposed. Moreover, travel agency sales hit $100 billion last year for the first time, up 6 percent from 1995.
But some travel agents say the industry avoided calamity only because of a steadily improving economy that has led to record numbers of airline passengers.
In addition, some agents began charging fees to all but their most loyal clients, while others put greater emphasis on booking cruises, hotels, rental cars and tours. "What also blunted the effect of the caps," Mr. Galloway said, "was that the average price of tickets has gone up."

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE INCUMBENT;
Mayor Removes the Gloves And Laces Into Messinger

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
Unleashing a formal assault on his newly named Democratic opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began the general election campaign yesterday by ridiculing Ruth W. Messinger for opposing his plan to regulate sex businesses in New York City, and vowing to highlight differences between them every day until the Nov. 4 election.
Having been assailed for weeks by the five candidates in the Democratic primary, Mr. Giuliani made it clear that he would no longer sit back and take the criticism now that Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, has been certified by the Board of Elections as his opponent in the general election. 
 In truth, Mr. Giuliani has never been sparing in his criticism of Ms. Messinger, but yesterday marked the beginning of the formal critique of her record that his aides said he has long been eager to inaugurate.
Addressing an invited group of supporters and midtown business leaders in what was billed as his first campaign speech, Mr. Giuliani used a series of sarcastic asides to repeatedly belittle Ms. Messinger for stating in 1995 that adult businesses can actually invigorate the quality of life of some neighborhoods in the city.
"You think it lends character to the city," he said, as if directly addressing Ms. Messinger in regard to sex shops. "There are people who think that, and they are entitled to think it. I think it destroys the character of the city, and there are people who are entitled to think that. And let's see who thinks that more, people on your side or people on my side. That's what an election is about, right?"
He also made a withering reference to her prediction that his adult zoning plan, which became law in October 1995, would never hold up under constitutional scrutiny. In July, a five-judge appeals panel approved the law, upholding an earlier lower-court decision. The law is now on appeal to the state's highest court.
"It was decided not by Ruth Messinger, but by a judge, which is the way we do it in America," Mr. Giuliani said, producing raucous laughter and applause from the audience of about 200 supporters in the New Victory Theater in Times Square.
In a letter to the City Planning Commission in July 1995, Ms. Messinger opposed the Mayor's plan to drastically limit the number of sex businesses in the city by stating, among other reasons, that such establishments have "invigorated" the quality of life in gay neighborhoods like the West Village.
"The proposed adult establishment zoning text could well result in the closing of most of the gay-adult-oriented businesses of Christopher Street, as well as those in other predominantly gay neighborhoods of the city," she wrote. "This could have profoundly detrimental consequences for the gay community, not to mention an important part of our city's economic and tourism-industry base."
Leland T. Jones, Ms. Messinger's spokesman, said she was trying in the letter to make the point that in some neighborhoods sex businesses fit in well while in others they cause problems, which he said argues against the Mayor's broad-brush approach.
Under Mr. Giuliani's law, such businesses may not operate within 500 feet of one another and must stay at least 500 feet from homes, schools and churches, which will eventually mean that only about 30 of the current 180 sex businesses will be allowed to remain.
In contrast, Ms. Messinger proposed limiting sex shops to one per block and restraining their signage, but not restricting them to certain parts of the city.
Mr. Giuliani's decision to begin his campaign on the issue of sex zoning reflects his conviction that the various aspects of his quality-of-life effort are so popular with the city's middle class, particularly outside Manhattan, that any opposition to it is by definition a liability to his critics. For instance, he contrasted the Times Square of several years ago, which he said was patronized only by "the sick and the perverted," with its current, more family-oriented character, which he said was the result of his zoning law. He strongly implied that Ms. Messinger had stood in the way of the new Times Square.
In fact, the cleanup of Times Square began several years before Mr. Giuliani entered office, and has proceeded independently of his zoning law. Ms. Messinger proposed regulating sex shops in a far less restrictive way -- a proposal that went nowhere -- and has supported the changes under way in Times Square. But the Mayor said the issue illustrated the vast differences in their respective worldviews.
"This may be the first, very stark difference of opinion on quality of life," Mr. Giuliani said, "but there'll be many, many differences of opinion on taxation, on what's needed for proper policing in New York City, on what's needed for economic development. You'll be hearing a lot about that, too."
He also warned that the general election campaign would be nothing like the Democratic primary, in which the opposing candidates generally refrained from attacking one another in their zeal to criticize Mr. Giuliani. Parodying the lack of rancor in Monday night's televised debate between Ms. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton, he said that voters could expect a far more spirited exchange of views.
"Since I've been asked all the questions so far, I thought it might be useful to start asking the questions the other way," he said. "And to illustrate that the general election campaign will be very different than the primary. This will not be attacking people. It won't be trying to avoid issues. This is going to be, like, really issue oriented."

HEADLINE: On Long Island, Critics Upset About the High Cost of Police

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 18

 BODY:
For years Long Island's police officers have been among the nation's best compensated, with high salaries, short work schedules and generous fringe benefits.
The resulting costs have imposed an increasing burden on local taxpayers, and the issue is now provoking public debate. 
 Here in Nassau, the police budget accounts for 72 percent of the proposed property tax levy in County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta's budget for 1998. In neighboring Suffolk, 79 percent of the county property tax is designated for the police.
Beyond Long Island, county police costs are far less, because of lower pay and smaller police forces. In Westchester, for example, the police budget equals 4 percent of the county property tax levy. But Westchester has only 235 county police officers, compared with 5,800 in Nassau and Suffolk.
And police costs on Long Island will increase under the latest labor contracts. In late August, an arbitrator granted the Nassau police a compounded raise of 24 percent over five years, paralleling an earlier award to Suffolk police of 18.7 percent over four years. By contrast, another arbitrator gave much less to the lower-paid New York City police: 13.3 percent over five years.
Base pay for an experienced Nassau officer, which was nearly $60,000 under the old contract, will rise to $73,859 in the year 2000. But the total cost -- with overtime and benefits like shift differentials, clothing and equipment allowances, health insurance and pension contributions -- now approaches $100,000 per officer. Under the new contract, it will reach $120,000.
"You end up with an agency where virtually every sworn member gets an executive-level salary," said Michael J. Butler, a lawyer and a retired Nassau police captain who studies police compensation and management. "Cops and former cops are my friends, colleagues and clients," he said. "They provide quality service, but we're taxpayers, too, and the costs sound out of control."
Citing the latest contract award as exorbitant, critics are calling for an overhaul of the laws and procedures governing police arbitrations. The rising criticism is unusual, considering the political sensitivity to police issues in the suburbs, where crime rates are low and on the decline.
Concern about crime helped fuel the migration from the city to Long Island, where the police have long enjoyed wide support from the public and elected officials. Police unions exercise great political clout, through candidate endorsements, campaign contributions and lobbying for legislation.
The debate has taken on partisan overtones. County Executive Gulotta, a Republican running for re-election, has steadfastly declined to comment on the police contract. But his Democratic challenger, Lewis J. Yevoli, the Oyster Bay Supervisor, has accused him of giving in to the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for political gain.
"We have TV commercials and billboards saying 'Tom Gulotta is tough on crime' -- paid for by the P.B.A.," Mr. Yevoli said. "Who are we kidding here? They gave $100,000 to his last campaign. What will contributions buy you? Probably the most lucrative contract in the nation. No knock on the cops, but taxpayers simply cannot afford this."
Even a Republican, County Comptroller Fred Parola, said: "Obviously this was an excessive decision. Our police do a great job, but there is already some backlash on the part of taxpayers who see this as inordinate."
Like most Long Island police raises over the years, the latest awards exceed the rate of inflation, raises for other government workers and the wage norms in private industry. Besides high pay and benefits, police contracts on Long Island generally require less work than at other police agencies.
Although officers often work 12-hour shifts in Nassau, for example, the total time worked averages 1,552 hours per year. Converted to a conventional 5-day, 40-hour week, that is equivalent to working 39 weeks and being off 13. Private-sector employees typically work about 45 to 46 weeks, with the remainder off for vacation, holidays and sick time.
Officers are entitled to retire at half pay after 20 years on the job, receiving pensions that with normal life expectancy will exceed $1 million. Those with disabilities like a heart condition get three-fourths pay, tax free. In addition, officers receive termination checks for unused sick leave and other credits that now top $100,000 and under the new contract will hit $200,000.
"Those golden parachutes are real budget time bombs," Mr. Butler said.
Long Island's high compensation draws hundreds of applicants for every opening. In Nassau, 32,000 applied for the last examination, in 1994. In Suffolk, dozens of lawyers took the police test. The pay here also draws officers from New York City; about a third of Nassau's new officers are hired from there. Even ranking city officers are willing to transfer and start over as rookies.
But the Nassau P.B.A. president, Gary Dela Raba, defended the gains won by his members.
"You've got no scandals here, no corruption," he said. "We've drug-tested close to 1,400 cops and caught only one violator. We're professionals. This contract puts in the first college requirement in the country. We've made schedule changes to cut down overtime and sick time. Gulotta's getting the biggest bang for the dollar here."
Mr. Dela Raba also noted that Long Island is a high-income, high-cost area, with electricity and tax bills among the nation's highest.
Each contract gain becomes a target for unions at the smaller police forces on Long Island -- some of which outdo the county police. The law requires arbitrators to consider comparable pay.
"We're going to keep leapfrogging with each other till doomsday," the Suffolk County Legislature's presiding officer, Joseph Rizzo, said. He has urged the State Legislature to amend the arbitration law to limit raises to the rate of inflation.
Mr. Parola, too, favors revising the arbitration law. "Obviously the deck is stacked," he said. "The law has to be revisited" to give more consideration to things like inflation, ability to pay and the job market.
"The cops are great, and you can't blame them or their unions," said Thomas R. Suozzi, Mayor of Glen Cove and a Democrat. "But you can blame the legislators who won't change the law and the County Executive for not negotiating more aggressively."

HEADLINE: Ancient Indian Site Challenges Ideas on Early American Life

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
Earthen mounds at an ancient American Indian site in Louisiana have been found to be the earliest known remnants of human construction in the New World. The discovery challenges traditional ideas about early American cultures and suggests that pre-agriculture, pre-ceramic hunting societies were more socially complex than previously thought.
The mounds, begun about 5,400 years ago, predate other similar public architecture at Indian sites by nearly 2,000 years, archeologists said in a report being published today in the journal Science. 
 The new findings could transform thinking about the progression of economic and social development in ancient societies, especially about the nature and abilities of bands of hunter-gatherers who once inhabited the Mississippi and Ohio River Valleys. They show that agriculture, permanent settlements or wealth from trade were not necessary conditions for the mobilization of labor for ambitious construction projects.
"It's a rare and wonderful case where one piece of research fundamentally changes our whole picture of early American life," said Dr. Vincas Steponaitis, an archeologist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill who is president of the Society of American Archaeology and an authority on Indian mounds.
Dr. Bruce D. Smith, an archeologist and specialist in early American agriculture at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, also praised the research. "It's a surprising find, this early date," he said. "But it makes a lot of sense."
The investigation of the mounds at a site known as Watson Brake near present-day Monroe -- a city of about 55,000 people in northern Louisiana, 100 miles east of Shreveport -- was conducted by a team of archeologists and other scientists led by Dr. Joe W. Saunders, a professor of geosciences at Northeast Louisiana University in Monroe.
The existence of the mounds, whose purpose is not known, was first brought to the attention of archeologists in the 1970's by Reca Bamburg Jones, who lives on a nearby farm.
In their journal report the scientists described Watson Brake, in the flood plain of the Ouachita River, as the place where hunter-gatherers apparently returned each spring and summer to feast on the fish and mussels in the river, the turkey, deer and raccoon in the woods and the edible plants, many of which would later be among the first domesticated plants in eastern North America. The site was full of animal and fish bones and the seeds of goosefoot, marsh elder and other plants, the scientists said.
Even though the people did not settle permanently at the site, they left a permanent mark there: the mounds. The 11 mounds and connecting ridges form an oval-shaped earthen enclosure about 900 feet in diameter. The largest of the dome-shaped mounds is 25 feet high; the others are less than 15 feet high, and the connecting ridges are no more than 3 feet high.
Charcoal and decaying vegetation in the soil were analyzed in several different dating tests, at the University of Texas at Austin and the University of Washington in Seattle. From these tests it was determined that the mounds were built from 5,400 to 5,000 years ago.
Previously, the earliest known mounds were those at Poverty Point, also in Louisiana, which were built 3,500 years ago. Among the best known and most impressive mounds were those erected in more recent times by Indians known as the Hopewell culture, from 100 B.C. to approximately A.D. 400 or 500, and the Mississippian culture, from A.D. 1000 to 1500. Thousands of these sites are scattered through much of the Eastern United States.
But nothing about the new findings explains the purpose of the mounds, one of the nagging mysteries in American archeology. Did they have religious significance or a ceremonial function?
No human burials have been uncovered at Watson Brake or many other sites. People may have lived on top of the lower mounds, but not the higher ones. Perhaps, Dr. Smith of the Smithsonian said, mounds were ways for a hunting people to define their territory or celebrate themselves.
In a separate article in Science, Dr. Saunders observed, "I know it sounds awfully Zen-like, but maybe the answer is that building them was the purpose."
Dr. Saunders said in a telephone interview that he was just as surprised as others that the Watson Brake mounds were "so large, so complex and so early," and added, "We generally had believed that mobile hunting and gathering people would not have the capability to plan and organize such construction."
For a long time, archeologists assumed that mound building was linked to agriculture, and most of the sites were, indeed, from periods after the Indians had begun to cultivate crops. The people at Poverty Point were not yet farmers, but showed signs of thriving from extensive trading networks.
Such thinking stemmed from the conventional view that societies emerged from the hunter-gatherer stage by settling in permanent villages and domesticating plants and animals. And, as they thus gained wealth and surplus food, they could afford to devote time and labor to monumental architecture. Also, with agriculture and a settled life presumably came more complex social and political structures, including the leadership skills and organization to undertake such engineering projects as mound building.
Or, as Dr. Steponaitis remarked: "Mounds are, in effect, fossilized labor. They are the remains that mean that some social mechanisms were in place in a hunter-gatherer society that made it possible to mobilize labor on a large scale."
Dr. Smith said the findings at Watson Brake seemed to support an emerging concept in which climate change that occurred in the eastern part of North America 7,000 to 5,000 years ago made the river valleys richer sources of food, which mobile hunter-gatherers returned to seasonally, and thus began a gradual transition to a more sedentary life.
Several archeologists said the existence of elaborate mounds at Poverty Point and Watson Brake showed that the early Indian cultures in what is now the United States were probably developing independently of societies in Mexico and Central America. Mound building appears to have been widespread in the Mississippi and Ohio Valleys long before there is evidence of it in Mexico.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Archeologists last spring examined a ridge connecting ancient Indian mounds in northern Louisiana. Seated at right was Reca Bamburg Jones, who lives on a nearby farm and made the site known to scientists. (Joe Saunders for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Take No Action On a Realignment Vote

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The magic number is 7.
That's not a combination of victories and losses that would clinch a division championship for somebody. It's the number of teams baseball's planning strategists would ideally like to have change leagues in their quest to realign the major leagues for 1998. 
 The owners did not act on realignment on the final day of their quarterly meetings today. In fact, they postponed their self-imposed deadline to adopt a plan, pushing it back from Sept. 30 to Oct. 15.
John Harrington of Boston, chairman of the realignment committee, said his group still had a half-dozen plans under consideration but did not provide details to the owners. However, a member of the committee said that now that the radical plan of a 15-team switch is dead, seven was the target number.
He didn't cite teams, but the key to achieving that number appeared to be persuading the Houston Astros to move to the American League.
Drayton McLane Jr., the Astros' owner, has steadfastly stated throughout the realignment debate that while he would like to be in a division with the Texas Rangers he does not want to move. He reiterated that position after the meeting today.
"Houston has been in the National League since 1962," he said. "We have strong ties and sentiments in the National League. We feel that's an important part of our franchise. We're not a candidate."
But if the planners want the Astros to move, they will very likely offer a financial inducement. Compensation became a topic of conversation during the meetings, and Harrington said it was possible the San Francisco Giants could be compensated for any possible economic loss as a way of overcoming their objection to having the Oakland Athletics join them in the N.L.
Oakland, Anaheim and Seattle are prepared to switch to the National, and Kansas City and Milwaukee have indicated similar interest, the Royals to be in a division with St. Louis, the Brewers to be with the Chicago Cubs.
Montreal and Florida are the two N.L. teams that would accept a move to the A.L. Philadelphia previously expressed a willingness to join them, but today, the Phillies' chairman Bill Giles said the club plans to stay where it is. The Phillies didn't want to be the only original N.L. club to change leagues.
The move of the three A.L. West Coast teams would create two four-team divisions made up of all of the major leagues' eight western teams. Except for Peter Magowan of the Giants, who aired his objections during today's two-hour meeting, the owners like that part of the realignment plan.
The players association, on the other hand, doesn't want to strip the A.L. of a West division and could throw up a roadblock to realignment. The union has to approve any plan the owners adopt.
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, stressed today that he and his aides have been in constant communication with union officials about their plans, but that doesn't mean that any plan they adopt will gain the union's approval.
If the Astros agreed to move -- any team asked to change leagues has veto rights -- the major leagues could look like this next season:
National League (16 teams):
East -- Mets, Braves, Phillies, Pirates.
Central -- Reds, Cubs, Cardinals, Royals (or Brewers).
West I -- Dodgers, Padres, Giants, Rockies.
West II -- Angels, Athletics, Mariners, Diamondbacks.
American League (14 teams):
East -- Yankees, Red Sox, Orioles, Blue Jays, Marlins.
Central -- Indians, Tigers, Devil Rays, Expos.
Midwest -- White Sox, Twins, Rangers, Astros, Brewers (or Royals).
This picture, however, is not as simple as it looks. If the Expos are going to move, they want to be with the Blue Jays, who want to remain with the Yankees, the Orioles and the Red Sox. But the Marlins are apparently conditioning their prospective moves on being with those same three teams. Furthermore, the Marlins and the Devil Rays don't seem to want to be in the same division.
Selig said the meeting was shorter today than he had anticipated. Asked why the owners didn't stay longer and debate the pros and cons of the various plans, he said: "That's an impediment to the process. We know where each club is, what they want, what they don't want. We're trying to be accommodating. There's no perfect plan, but we have a better understanding of how maybe we can get to the end of the line and solve the problem."
Driving the desire for realignment, he explained, was the schedule, which, he said, has grown more unwieldy each season.
"This schedule is inflexible," he said. "A schedule that terrorizes individual clubs and their fans is not very helpful to anybody."
 
Public Ownership Now Possible
 The owners approved public ownership of teams, meaning clubs may sell stock in a minority percentage of their ownership. No rush to the stock market is expected, however. To go public, a team would have to issue a prospectus and annual reports with financial disclosure that clubs have always been reluctant to provide.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Ted Turner to Contribute $1 Billion to Benefit U.N.
Ted Turner, the billionaire founder of Cable News Network who has made a career out of defying expectations and shocking the public, last night announced that he is making one of the largest charitable donations ever: $1 billion to benefit United Nations agencies. Mr. Turner said the gift would be used to establish a not-for-profit foundation to benefit United Nations programs aiding refugees and children, clearing mines and fighting disease. A1 

Chinese Leader is Purged
Qiao Shi, a major rival of President Jiang Zemin, was ousted from his No. 3 position in the party hierarchy during the Communist Party conference in Beijing. Mr. Jiang also saw to the appointment of a clutch of allies from Shanghai onto the party's powerful Central Committee. A6
 
10 Die in Egyptian Attack
Spraying gunfire and hurling a bomb, at least two assailants attacked a tour bus in Cairo and killed 10 people, 9 of them Germans. Egyptian officials insisted the attack was not the resurgence of an Islamic militant campaign but rather a singular act of lunacy. They arrested two men, one of them a recent escapee from a mental institution, to which he had been committed in 1993 after murdering two Americans and a Frenchman. A3
 
Agreement in Jerusalem
The Jewish families who recently occupied a house in an Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem left after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel reached an agreement of sorts with the American owner of the house. Ten Jewish religious students acting as guards and maintenance men replaced the departing families. Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, declared the move "a trick, no more than that. A5
 
Taliban Takes Key Town
Afghanistan's radical Taliban movement captured the town of Hairatan on the border of the former Soviet republic of Uzbekistan. Uzbeki television reported 10 missiles from the fighting had landed in Termez, on the Uzbekistan side of the border, raising fears among Western analysts that other countries might intervene. A7
 
Public Executions in Chechnya
Thousands of people gathered in Friendship Square in Grozny to watch a Chechen firing squad publicly execute two men. Chechen authorities said the executions, carried out in gleeful defiance of Russian demands that capital punishment be stopped in the breakaway republic, were conducted in accordance with Islamic law. A8
 
Wales Votes for an Assembly
The people of Wales voted by a surprisingly narrow margin to accept a British offer to set up their first elected assembly in nearly 600 years. The Scots voted resoundingly last week to create their own, considerably more powerful parliament. A9
 
NATIONAL A18-29
 
Campaign Donor Testifies That He Sought Access
Roger Tamraz, an international businessman with an unsavory reputation who gave $300,000 to Democrats for last year's election campaigns, testified that he had donated the money expressly to pry open the doors of power. Quick with one-liners, Mr. Tamraz was the first large donor to testify in the seven weeks of hearings by the Governmental Affairs Committee, and he was by far the most colorful witness yet. A1
 
Teamster Aides Plead Guilty

A1
 
Mounds Show Complex Society
Earthen mounds at an ancient American Indian site in Louisiana have been found to be the earliest known remnants of human construction in the New World. The discovery challenges traditional ideas about early American cultures and suggests that pre-agriculture, pre-ceramic hunting societies were more socially complex than previously thought. A26
 
U.S. AIDS Cases Fall
The number AIDS cases diagnosed in the United States dropped last year for the first time in the history of the epidemic, a trend that Federal officials attributed to aggressive new therapies that keep infected patients healthier, as well as the possibility that fewer people are becoming infected in the first place. A26

Scientists have found a genetic link to age-related macular degeneration, an incurable eye disease that strikes 25 percent of Americans over the age of 65 and is the major cause of vision loss in the elderly. A21

HEADLINE: Fitness, Not Medicine, Increases Life Expectancy;
Income Affects Health

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 12 news article reports that Americans' life expectancy is increasing. Should we be elated? It all depends on what the yardstick is. Do we give the Olympic gold medal to the first-place finisher, or to the one who did better than last year? 
 While life expectancy in the United States has indeed increased, it has done so for the entire century. Japan, however, has led the pack since 1977 and does so while spending only about 6.5 percent of its gross national product on health care. The United States, near the bottom of all the rich countries in life expectancy, spends about 15 percent of its gross national product on health care.
The major cause of our dismal showing is the widening income distribution between rich and poor (front page, Sept. 14) and men and women (front page, Sept. 15). No other factor has been shown to influence a nation's health more than measures of income distribution: a country with a more unequal income distribution than another country will have a lower life expectancy.
 
STEPHEN BEZRUCHKA
Seattle, Sept. 15, 1997

HEADLINE: Poor N.J. Drivers Save Under Insurance Plan

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 17 news article on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's auto insurance proposal for New Jersey reports that most drivers would not save more than $100 to $200 on their premiums. However, according to a study by the Joint Economic Committee of the United States Congress, the average savings for a New Jersey motorist who chooses to forgo pain and suffering coverage -- one of the options under the Whitman plan -- would be $342. Low-income drivers would save the most. 
 You also report that experts believe that auto insurance in New Jersey will always be expensive because it is the most densely populated state. Auto insurance rates correlate with many factors, including the percentage of claims in which there is lawyer representation. In New Jersey, 92 percent of those injured in auto accidents who make claims against other drivers use attorneys. This is the highest percentage in the country -- the national average is 52 percent.
Another reason auto insurance rates are the highest in New Jersey is that the Legislature there has passed a law mandating a benefits package that is five times higher than New York's.
 
LESTER BRICKMAN
Professor, Benjamin N. Cardozo
School of Law, Yeshiva University
New York, Sept. 17, 1997

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Accounting Firm Merger To Create an Industry Giant
Two of the world's largest accounting and consulting firms, Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse, are expected to merge their practices worldwide, forming the largest accounting firm, with revenues of $11.8 billion. 

 The combination is the latest chapter in the continuing consolidation in the accounting industry, which has been set in motion by fierce competition and slow growth in the core business of auditing corporate clients' books. Both firms needed to find a partner or face the risk of being left behind as the larger accounting firms became even more powerful. Page A1.
 
Campaign Aides Plead Guilty
Three top campaign aides to Ron Carey, the president of the teamsters' union, pleaded guilty to funneling illegal contributions to his re-election drive as part of a broad scheme that they said involved officials of the Democratic Party and the President's re-election campaign, and included improper cash payments by leaders of other major labor unions. A1.
 
Rubin Pushes for More Information
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said that he would tell the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund this weekend that the United States wants other nations to disclose more financial data than they routinely do. The push follows on the heels of the discovery that Thailand's central bank kept secret data that would have warned investors around the world of the country's impending financial crisis. D5.
 
Tobacco Unit Changes Its Focus
Philip Morris has named a new tobacco chief for the United States who is an expert on retail sales and distribution, areas that analysts say are the right ones for the company to focus on to sell cigarettes in an environment where tobacco companies may be bound by harsh advertising restrictions and Federal regulations. D2.
 
United Clips Commissions
United Airlines has reduced travel agency commissions to 8 percent from 10 percent for domestic travel to save $80 million to $100 million annually. D2.
 
Wireless Settlement Near

Europe Is Preparing for the Euro
Italy is cutting the waste from its welfare system and other European countries are taking similar action as they try to meet the requirements for the euro, the planned single currency. The euro requires countries to cut their budget deficits to 3 percent of total output this year if they are to qualify for the new European money on Jan. 1, 1999. A1.
 
Stocks Continue to Rally
The stock market rallied after reports showed again that the economy is growing at a moderate but sustainable pace. The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with technology issues, and the Russell 2000 index of the stocks of smaller companies both hit new highs. Trading volume has been increasing lately and on the Big Board yesterday it topped 576 million shares. D13.

Newspapers Battle in Puerto Rico
An old-fashion newspaper war -- perhaps the last and most raucous one -- is brewing in Puerto Rico. The battle among three dailies in the Spanish-speaking American commonwealth includes charges, countercharges and dirty tricks. A18.
 
Japanese Retailer in Bankruptcy
A Japanese supermarket chain, Yaohan Japan, which expanded globally and was one of the first multinational retailers to enter China, has filed for bankruptcy court protection. D2.

HEADLINE: Manila Journal;
People Power 2: A Sleeping Giant Is Awakened

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: MANILA, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Corazon C. Aquino, former President of the Philippines and champion of the "people power" uprising 11 years ago, sat in her car the other day and honked her horn.
Church bells chimed and people stood in windows and doorways shouting and banging on pots and pans in a Philippine ritual of protest called a noise barrage. 
 And from all around the political landscape in the last few weeks, from churchmen, lawyers and business groups, came the catcalls: "warlord . . . dictator . . . dark ages . . . selfish and immoral . . . tentacles of evil . . . a mad dog gone berserk."
Why all the noise?
It appears that President Fidel V. Ramos, a former general known for his complex game plans, has roused the ghosts of dictators past.
Apparently trying to keep opponents off balance and avoid becoming a lame duck, he has allowed his backers to try to change the Constitution and keep him in office after his single six-year term ends next June.
It is a question of fierce debate here whether Mr. Ramos really wants to hold on to the presidency -- as Ferdinand E. Marcos did by declaring martial law in 1972 -- or is simply trying to keep control of the political agenda.
Some political analysts dismiss the idea that Mr. Ramos would seize power through martial law, and the President himself has denied that he would do so.
But whatever his motives, he has succeeded in rousing the nation against him at the end of one of the most successful administrations in Philippine history, a time when the country has just begun to emerge from decades of economic ruin.
He is discovering the high price that Filipinos place on the chief legacy of his predecessor, Mrs. Aquino: the restoration of democracy.
In a region where stability and economic growth are the highest values and where democratic openness tends to take a back seat -- in countries like Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia -- the Philippines stands apart for its dedication to freedom.
"The moment you start talking about extending anybody's term, the Marcos ghost starts to rise," said Paulynn Sicam, a newspaper columnist. "I wrote in my column: 'We'll survive any President, but no President can survive us.' We took Marcos out. We can take out anybody. We know what our power is."
All around the city, people are reveling in a re-creation of the symbols of their democratic triumph of 1986, when huge crowds supporting a military mutiny blocked tanks and drove Mr. Marcos into exile in Hawaii, where he died in 1989.
They are tying yellow ribbons to trees, lighting candles and throwing buckets of yellow confetti from tall buildings as groups of marchers pass by with signs reading, "No to Cha-Cha," the popular nickname for Charter Change.
"My fear is that the same thing is happening to President Ramos that happened to Mr. Marcos -- that he is beginning to believe that he is indispensable," said Rafael Khan, a lawyer, who attended a rally today. "He must respect the rule of law."
On Sunday -- the 25th anniversary of Mr. Marcos's declaration of martial law -- Mrs. Aquino and her most powerful ally, Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila, plan to hold a mass demonstration on the Luneta parade ground that recalls the brave protests of "people power."
"It's exciting all over again," said Narzalina Lim, chairwoman of the program committee for the rally. "So much deja vu."
In fact, the political situation holds almost no similarity with 1986. One of the leaders of that peaceful uprising, Mr. Ramos has repeatedly demonstrated his allegiance to democracy, first by defending Mrs. Aquino from a half-dozen coup attempts, then with a notably open and consultative style as President.
The chief parallel in the two situations is the miscalculation by Mr. Marcos and Mr. Ramos of the country's political mood. Mr. Marcos seemed to think that Filipinos could be bullied; Mr. Ramos underestimated their fear of dictatorship.
"Why is there a hate campaign against all of us?" the President asked this month. "Why have we become demons all of a sudden?"
Mrs. Lim said the rally on Sunday would include at least four of the country's proliferating potential candidates to succeed Mr. Ramos.
Among them will be Vice President Joseph Estrada, who may be most responsible for all of the turmoil over succession. Mr. Estrada is a former movie star who is viewed as Mr. Ramos's most likely successor because of his broad popularity.
His candidacy is dreaded by the political establishment, which sees him as a blustering lightweight incapable of carrying on Mr. Ramos's legacy of economic reforms. A strong motive behind the movement to change the Constitution is a belief that Mr. Ramos is the only person who could beat him.
One of Mr. Estrada's most formidable assets is his off-the-cuff charm. At a recent open forum, a young man told him, "My mother says she will leave the Philippines if you are elected."
Mr. Estrada responded with a broad smile. "Then tell her to start packing!" he exclaimed.

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1285 words

HEADLINE: Battle of What May Be the West's Last Big Dam

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DURANGO, Colo.

 BODY:
Two years ago, the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund objected to a $700 million water diversion project planned for the Animas River here and proposed a $264 million alternative.
This summer, Ute Indian leaders, the project's proponents, reluctantly bent to Washington's budget-cutting mood and announced a $257 million plan. 
 Then the defense fund countered with a new proposal for a $115 million dam.
"Double-crossing" was the adjective used by editorial writers for both of Denver's dailies to describe the way environmentalists moved the goal posts on what may be the West's last big water project.
Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Republican Senator from Colorado and the lone American Indian in Congress, joined the fray, saying: "The enviros have never been interested in a compromise. They just simply want to stop development and growth. And the way you do that in the West is to stop water."
The wrangling in Durango over what is now a medium-sized reservoir project highlights the death throes of a dam-building and water-diversion culture that in this century built 600 dams and reservoirs across the West. Cheap, subsidized water allowed the growth of great cities and the growth of cheap food to feed the new populations. Without piped water, Los Angeles might still be a provincial coastal town, and Las Vegas might be a gas station in the desert.
But with the growth of environmental opposition to tinkering with the West's natural plumbing, the number of new dams slowed greatly in the 1970's and then finally stopped in the 1990's.
"Big subsidized water projects are on their way out," said Robert B. Wiygul, a lawyer for Earthjustice Legal Defense Fund, the new name for the Sierra Club's fund. Rejecting the "double-crossing" label of the Denver newspapers, he said, "The idea that we should embrace the first compromise thrown out by the proponents is just outrageous."
The West's water paralysis is most evident in this southwest Colorado town, just north of the Southern Ute Indian Reservation and the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation.
In 1868, Kit Carson negotiated a deal with the Utes: they would give up claims to Colorado's western half in return for a permanent home in the new territory's far southwest corner. This dry, semi-desert reservation land was arguably the worst in Colorado for farming, but the 1868 treaty stipulated Government aid. Later, courts ruled that this assistance included water.
With Indian water rights a low priority to white settlers, the water wheel moved slowly. In 1938, a Bureau of Reclamation office opened here to study a diversion project. In 1968, Congress authorized the project. In 1988, President Ronald Reagan signed a law needed to go ahead.
But, while the Indians waited, political gridlock turned the project into a bonanza for water lawyers, political lobbyists, fish biologists, civil engineers and authors of environmental impact statements. If the $77 million that has been appropriated since 1988 for the project had been given directly to the 3,300 Utes who live here, each Ute would have received a $23,000 check.
Instead, no earth has been turned, and no end is in sight to the legal and bureaucratic jousting.
"In 1990, the endangered fish came up and bit us," Sam Maynes, a water lawyer for the Southern Utes, said of an environmental lawsuit. The new slimmed-down version of the project would divert only 14.5 percent of the Animas River's annual flow, presumably not enough to disturb two rare fish species -- the Colorado squawfish and the razorback sucker.
Although the Bureau of Reclamation has written an environmental impact statement that fills four feet of bookshelves, environmentalists say that a new statement would be be needed for the smaller alternative, "Animas-La Plata Lite," as it is universally called here.
These arguments seem otherworldly to Judy Knight Frank, chairwoman of the Ute Mountain Ute tribe, an impoverished people who survived until 1994 on water delivered by trucks.
"That squawfish -- and I take offense at that name -- seems to have more of a right to live than I do," said Ms. Frank, who presides over a tribe where unemployment is about 50 percent and household income hovers around $9,000. "The environmentalists don't seem to care how we live."
Sage Remington, director of a Ute splinter group opposed to the project, counters that the project was never intended to pipe or channel water to Ute Mountain Ute lands, which start 25 miles west of the reservoir site.
The reservoir, which would be on the northern border of the Southern Ute lands, is largely seen by Indian advocates as "a bucket." Instead of having abstract "paper water," or water rights on a deed, they would have "wet water," stored in a reservoir like money in the bank.
Water could be sold to Durango, a booming tourist town that experienced water shortages in the summer of 1996. Or water could be sold to non-Indian farmers. Historically a nomadic, horse-riding people, the Utes today largely disdain farming. Most of the tribe's income comes from a horse track, a casino and coal-bed methane gas royalties.
Mr. Remington has proposed an alternative way to settle his tribe's water claims: buying land and accompanying water rights on the open market. But critics say that under Colorado water law, this agricultural water could not be converted easily to other uses.
The hidden agenda behind the water fight, tribal officers and environmentalists agree, is that a reservoir filled with "municipal and industrial" water would allow the Southern Utes to mine their enormous coal reserves. When gas royalties run out, a coal slurry pipeline would allow the Utes to ship their low-sulphur coal -- 400 million tons lies near the surface -- to coal-burning power plants in the Four Corners area.
But, when environmentalists talk about strip mining and air quality, Indian leaders talk about mining royalties and high-paying jobs.
"Why do these people keep telling us what to do?" Ms. Frank, the Ute Mountain Utes chairwoman, asked angrily. "We are going to be on welfare, and the country is going to be taking care of us. Is that what they want?"
With feelings high here, the debate has not always been civil.
Last year, when the water project's price tag seemed to approach $1 billion, environmentalists derided it as "a white elephant wrapped in an Indian blanket." One white opponent formed a one-man group, Stop Campbell's Animas La Plata, or Scalp.
On the other side, Jeff Morrissey, a former mayor of Durango, lost his temper last fall when he saw a young woman park her car emblazoned with a bumper sticker that criticized Animas. He yelled out a crude remark and was cited for disorderly conduct.
Durango and water politics have changed since the late 1970's, when Mr. Morrissey was the Mayor here.
Rafters and trout fishermen now have a voice in the future of a river that flows through town. In the 1990's, the number of tourists who went down the Animas on commercial raft trips has tripled, hitting 30,000 in 1995. This summer, the Colorado Wildlife Commission, a state group, designated the river stretch below Durango a "Gold Medal Stream," an honor reserved for less than 2 percent of Colorado's 9,000 miles of trout streams.
Nationally, what 30 years ago would have been a run-of-the-mill Western water project now finds itself in Washington's spotlight, appearing on one Congressman's "pork" list and on an environmental group's "endangered rivers" list.
"That combination of national environmental organizations and fiscal conservatives is just deadly," Mr. Maynes said. In 1968 he had watched from the galleries, full of hope, when Congress authorized the project.
