HEADLINE: What Makes Ted Turner Give? Others' Examples.

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
A soaring stock market, the end of the cold war and the examples set by such disparate figures as Mother Teresa, Jacques Cousteau and Diana, the Princess of Wales, inspired Ted Turner to pledge as much as $1 billion over 10 years, but possibly less, to support United Nations programs.
In a telephone conference call yesterday with several reporters, Mr. Turner, the unpredictable founder of Cable News Network, discussed the motives underlying what may turn out to be the largest single pledge in philanthropic history. He also described in general terms the structure of his planned gift, although United Nations officials and Mr. Turner's financial and philanthropic advisers agreed that specific arrangements had yet to be decided. 
 Mr. Turner said he would give away grants totaling a billion dollars worth of Time Warner stock valued at current prices or $100 million a year for 10 years, whichever is less. That means that if the stock price falls, Mr. Turner, who is vice chairman of Time Warner, could wind up giving away less than $100 million a year. On the other hand, if the value of the stock increases, he said, he would still limit his gift to $1 billion.
There were some early indications that giving away the money might be far more complicated than either he or the United Nations anticipated when he announced the donation in a speech on Thursday at the annual United Nations Association dinner in New York.
Secretary General Kofi Annan, who yesterday called the pledge "a wonderful gesture," said he thought the money would go into a fund at the United Nations and be managed in accordance with the organization's rules. But Mr. Turner's spokesmen said that Mr. Turner wanted to create an independent, private foundation whose board would work with United Nations officials to decide where the money would go.
Spokesmen for both Mr. Turner and the United Nations agreed that the United Nations can accept direct gifts only from governments and that Mr. Turner's gift would not be used to defray the organization's operating costs. Nor would it help pay off the debt that the United States owes the United Nations, though Mr. Turner said yesterday that he had toyed with the idea of "buying the U.S. debt and presenting the bill to Congress." (Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said yesterday that agreement was near on a deal in which the United States would pay nearly $1 billion that it owes to the world organization.)
Mr. Turner did not say, and his aides did not know, whether he would put the total value of the stock into the new foundation all at once, which would make it one of only 35 American foundations with assets of $1 billion or more, or add $100 million each year to the pool of foundation funds. Because Mr. Turner plans to give the money away over a 10-year-period, what could be a billion-dollar gift must be somewhat discounted because the later portions will be worth less as forces like inflation erode the gift's value.
Peter Bahouth, the executive director of Mr. Turner's private family foundation, which will give away $26 million in fiscal 1998, said Mr. Turner had told him yesterday that he wanted to insure that the new foundation would be able to accept donations from other wealthy donors.
Mr. Turner said that the foundation would not bear his name and that very few people knew in advance of his plans. Secretary General Annan told reporters yesterday that although Mr. Turner had been talking about a gift "for quite some time," the media executive told him only Thursday afternoon that he was going to announce the pledge that night. Mr. Turner said that on Wednesday night over dinner, he had discussed the idea with his wife, Jane Fonda, and that she had cried with joy. "Jane thinks it's terrific," one of her spokesman said today.
John C. Whitehead, a former Deputy Secretary of State and executive director of the United Nations Association, said that skepticism from some philanthropy experts about whether Mr. Turner would really make a billion-dollar gift was unfair. "Americans should be saying, 'Isn't that wonderful that the guy is giving away a third of his net worth to an organization he believes in.' "
President Clinton welcomed the gift through a spokesman, and Ms. Albright praised the "extraordinarily generous" act, but added that it would not affect the United States' demands for reform at the United Nations.
Mr. Turner's pledge, said Sara Engelhardt, president of the Foundation Center, a New York-based group that monitors giving, puts him among America's most generous donors, especially in international affairs, where donations tend to be smaller and constitute only about 10 percent of total American giving. These include such benefactors as Walter Annenberg, who has given away more than a billion dollars, mostly for education; Charles F. Feeney, who quietly gave away $610 million and put $3.5 billion into a charitable foundation, and George Soros, the financier who has given away close to $1.5 billion and whom Mr. Turner identified yesterday as the philanthropist he most admires.
Mr. Turner said that he was also inspired by the good works of Mother Teresa, Jacques Cousteau and Diana. Asked why he gave to charity at all, Mr. Turner replied: "Well it's just say 'yes.' " The end of the cold war, he added, means that "war has become impossible" and that the world should concentrate instead on solving social and economic ills. "We live in an interconnected planet," said Mr. Turner, one of the nation's largest landowners.
Mr. Turner said, "I've been learning how to give. It's something you have to keep working on, because people like money the way they do their homes and their dogs."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
For years, religious leaders have lamented the absence of any major television series that took religious life and spiritual struggles seriously. The popular blend of therapeutic wisdom and supernatural gimmickry of "Touched by an Angel" and its knock-offs was not what they had in mind.
Now reviewers are hailing "Nothing Sacred," the ABC series about an edgy, dedicated Roman Catholic priest that debuted Thursday. Faith and doubt, fidelity and ambiguity, the questioning of both church and self, they argued, were woven winningly and realistically into a well-written, well-acted drama of a young pastor and the motley staff trying to hold together an urban parish. 
 If some conservative Catholics objected to the series and were even calling for a boycott of its sponsors, wasn't that all the more evidence of its strengths?
There is little question that "Nothing Sacred" is a cut above the vacuity, violence and sexual fantasy of much television entertainment. But if the realism and complexity of "Nothing Sacred" breaks out of the framework of most religious programming, it may not break out as far as some admirers seem to think.
Yes, Father Ray, with his temper tantrums, working hormones and occasional profanity, contrasts with Bing Crosby's crooning Father Chuck, the good-guy priest in "Going My Way" and "The Bells of St. Mary's." But to what extent is Father Ray simply a liberal good-guy priest?
There are stereotypes and then there are stereotypes. In "Nothing Sacred," the Rev. Gregory Coiro of the Los Angeles archdiocese points out, "the heroic priest is the one who bucks the church, and, by sheer coincidence, just happens to buck the church on all the issues -- sex and abortion -- where Hollywood is bucking the church."
Father Coiro, the diocesan director of media relations, has been reviewing the scripts of "Nothing Sacred," at ABC's request, for inaccurate or offensive material, although the network does not necessarily follow his recommendations.
Neither Roger Cardinal Mahony of Los Angeles nor the Catholic bishops generally has expressed a public opinion on "Nothing Sacred," but Father Coiro's personal view is that the series "is not a fair depiction of the priesthood."
"The basic premise," he said of the pilot broadcast, "is that the only good Catholic is a bad Catholic."
The Rev. Ellwood Kieser, a priest of the Paulist order who has produced feature films about Dorothy Day and Archbishop Oscar Romero, does not agree.
"I like it," he said of the series. "I don't think it is perfect, but conflict is of the essence of drama, and so is surprise and shock. A priest struggling with his faith, his celibacy and the bishop's office is dramatic" -- and not unrealistic, he said. "Saints have had tensions with authority, and so have had most priests."
Father Kieser did underline "things that stretched credibility" on Thursday night's broadcast. "I don't know many priests who would tell a woman no more than to follow her own conscience in regard to an abortion," he said, "and who would so distance themselves from what the church teaches."
He also found implausible a sermon in which Father Ray calls for a moratorium on confessing sexual sins. "Some people need to confront their sexual sins," Father Kieser said.
There were other lapses, puzzling in a program that ABC announced was written by a pseudonymous Jesuit. Moderately well-informed Catholics, even dissenters, realize that their church does not treat abortion primarily as a sexual question like contraception but rather a question of taking life, on the level of issues like capital punishment, limits in warfare and euthanasia. Not Father Ray.
Catholic bishops do not order priests to give Sunday sermons on topics like Thomas Aquinas's proofs for the existence of God, and Father Ray's snippet of a sermon was less Aquinas anyway than 19th-century popular theology.
But Father Kieser, who believes "Nothing Sacred" should be on at 10 p.m. instead of 8 ("It's an adult show"), has high hopes anyway.
"The press and the network really beat the drums on how controversial this program is," he said, recalling the flap over nudity on the first episode of "NYPD Blue."
"That series turned out to be good," he said, and this one features "some lovely twists, and realistically pulls us into the theological world."
Ultimately, of course, the appearance of a program like "Nothing Sacred" poses a challenge that conservative Catholics probably sense instinctively without quite articulating. That is the question of control.
Suppose that the opening episodes met absolutely everyone's standards, dramtically and theologically. Who's to predict the series' course if ratings are low? Will Father Ray announce he is bisexual? (An H.I.V.-positive priest is already written into a future script.) Will Sister Maureen start celebrating Mass? Is a network the newest claimant to theological authority?
Once upon a time churches could count on deference, sustained by public protectiveness about religious sensibilities. The groups threatening an economic boycott of the new show's sponsors would like to demonstrate that such a time has not passed. But as long as so many faithful, of whatever religious group, get their theology from the media rather than the pulpit, religious leadership will be hard-pressed to control how their own tradition is presented.
The long-awaited serious religious programming, in other words, could turn out to be a two-edged sword.

HEADLINE: Mexican Drug Dealer Tried to Buy Way Out, General Says

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Six months before his apparent death in July, the billionaire Mexican drug trafficker Amado Carrillo Fuentes sent his top lieutenant to negotiate with the Mexican Army for protection from prosecution, the country's disgraced former anti-drug chief, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, testified on Thursday.
General Gutierrez is on trial on drug and other charges. His testimony and documents that have surfaced in recent weeks offer new details about the last days of one of the world's leading drug traffickers. They suggest that Mr. Carrillo was trying to lessen his role in the drug business and wanted to make huge payoffs to buy peace for his family. 
 Mexican officials did not accept the offer, though the details of the negotiations, and why they ultimately fell apart, remain a mystery.
Responding to the general's testimony, the army's senior prosecutor acknowledged today in an interview that the trafficker's top lieutenant met with five generals from the army's General Staff in January.
The prosecutor, Gen. Marcial Macedo de la Concha, asserted that the generals did not know until weeks later that they had met with a representative of Mexico's top trafficker.
But other sworn testimony in General Gutierrez's trial, and army intelligence documents published earlier this year, indicate that in January military officials heard a proposal from Mr. Carrillo in which the trafficker pledged to minimize the violence associated with the drug trade and "act like a businessman, not like a criminal."
In exchange, Mr. Carrillo wanted to keep half of his immense fortune and to receive assurances that he and his family would be protected from anti-drug operatives, the documents indicate.
Events since that January meeting suggest that the trafficker's offer was eventually turned down, but it remains unclear who made the decision and why.
In early February, Mr. Carrillo began traveling outside Mexico, visiting Cuba, Chile and, some officials say, even Russia during the first half of this year. In Chile, Mr. Carrillo made real estate and other investments aimed at establishing a residence there. In early July, the American and Mexican Governments announced Mr. Carrillo's death from complications of plastic surgery.
Throughout this decade, Mr. Carrillo had carried out his smuggling operations with extraordinary license, moving hundreds of tons of Colombian cocaine into Mexico in planes and boats and north into the United States. He traveled throughout Mexico freely.
American officials have estimated that he paid as much as 60 percent or more of his billion-dollar revenues to the police, politicians and generals in Mexico to buy protection.
In 1996 Mr. Carrillo's top lieutenant, Eduardo Gonzalez Quirarte, a Guadalajara businessman, established friendly contacts with General Gutierrez, then the commander of a military region encompassing much of central Mexico. As a result of those contacts, General Gutierrez was arrested in February.
During General Gutierrez's trial, evidence has emerged that Mr. Carrillo succeeded in bribing other generals, but the details are sketchy.
The events suggest that starting in late 1996, at a time when his fame had spread worldwide, Mr. Carrillo lost his influence with Mexico's security forces. In early January he barely escaped a raid by army anti-narcotics troops on the wedding party of Mr. Carrillo's sister in the western state of Sinaloa. He managed to flee his mother's ranch hidden in a farm truck.
It was in that context that Mr. Carrillo's representatives met with the top generals in the Mexican Army. General Gutierrez testified on Thursday that Mr. Gonzalez Quirarte had met on three occasions with generals from the army's general staff, twice in December and again on Jan. 14.
Military intelligence documents published by the magazine Proceso in July appeared to shed light on details of the Jan. 14 meeting. Among the papers was one dated Jan. 14, indexed by army officers as a "document of exposition of hypotheses about an offer from a narcotics trafficker." The document appears to refer to Mr. Carrillo by his initials, A.C.:
"A.C. does not intend to surrender. A.C. wants to negotiate with the Government, to make a pact."
The document says he requested:
*That he be allowed to act.
*Peace for his family.
*50 percent of his possessions.
The document says he offered:
*To collaborate to get rid of unorganized narcotics trafficking.
*To act like a businessman, not like a criminal.
*Not to sell drugs in Mexico.
*To sell the drugs outside the country. U.S. and Europe.
*To bring dollars to help the country, its economy.
*Not to act violently, not in rebellion.
"If the pact is not accepted, he will take his offer, with its 'benefits,' to another country," the document says.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN FINANCE: THE HEARING;
Witness Says Clinton Aide Asked Him to Shred a Fax

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
An unemployed businessman from Florida testified today that a few days before last year's Presidential election, he was asked by Harold M. Ickes, then the top political officer in the White House, to donate $1.5 million to help President Clinton and then, a few hours later, to shred a fax that described the request.
The businessman, R. Warren Meddoff, said Mr. Ickes got his name from a business card Mr. Meddoff had managed to slip to the President at a fund-raising dinner. Mr. Meddoff said he had written on the back of the card, "I have a business associate that is interested in donating $5 million to your campaign." 
 No suggestion was made that money ever changed hands. After Democrats researched Mr. Meddoff's background, they decided not to pursue Mr. Ickes's request for money. Mr. Ickes has said that he made a mistake in talking to Mr. Meddoff, and has denied in a sworn statement to the Senate committee investigating campaign finance practices that he ever asked for the fax to be destroyed.
Republican Senators on the investigating panel, the Governmental Affairs Committee, said the Meddoff case was another example of reckless Democratic fund-raising last year. Democrats challenged Mr. Meddoff's credibility.
The story Mr. Meddoff told sounded a bit like an Elmore Leonard novel about small-time wheeling and dealing. Basically, it went like this:
For seven years, Mr. Meddoff had been in "extensive daily contact" with William R. Morgan, a Texan whom he has never met face to face. Mr. Morgan had a scheme to make a fortune selling pre-World War II German bonds, and Mr. Meddoff was supposed to get a cut.
In 1995, Mr. Meddoff, a former Republican county official in Florida, wrote to Mr. Clinton and to Bob Dole, then the Senate majority leader, and offered them $5 million if the United States Government kept its hands off and the bond deal went through. He never heard back from the President and got a routine cold shoulder from the Dole staff.
Last October, Mr. Meddoff told Mr. Morgan that the Danish company he then worked for in Florida was paying for him to go to a fund-raising dinner for Mr. Clinton in Coral Gables and they decided that Mr. Meddoff should renew the $5 million offer. That was when he gave the President the business card.
A few days later, Mr. Ickes, then the deputy White House chief of staff, called Mr. Meddoff from Air Force One. Mr. Meddoff told Mr. Ickes that Mr. Morgan had authorized him to offer an initial contribution of $5 million and an additional $5 million a month for 10 months, for a total of $55 million.
Mr. Meddoff also told Mr. Ickes that the contribution had to be tax deductible. Direct political contributions cannot be deducted.
The week before Election Day, Mr. Ickes called Mr. Meddoff back and said he needed $1.5 million immediately, according to Mr. Meddoff's testimony, and also sent a fax listing three tax-exempt organizations to which Mr. Meddoff could donate. One of the organizations was Vote Now '96, an obscure organization that promoted voter registration in black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
A few hours later, Mr. Ickes called back again, said the fax had been sent by mistake and told Mr. Meddoff to shred it. Mr. Meddoff did not do so. Mr. Ickes kept a copy of the fax in his files and gave it to the investigating committee.
The story more or less ends there. Mr. Morgan, Mr. Meddoff said, wanted a letter from someone official thanking him by name for the donation and saying it was in support of the President. By that point, the evidence showed, the Democrats had researched Mr. Meddoff's and Mr. Morgan's backgrounds and had decided not to deal with them further.
When the letter they wanted was not forthcoming, Mr. Meddoff said, Mr. Morgan decided not to make the contribution.
It is illegal for money to be filtered into political campaigns through tax-exempt organizations.
Lanny J. Davis, the White House spokesman on campaign finance matters, said today that Mr. Ickes had sent the names of groups whose work might benefit the President indirectly.
Mr. Davis said higher voter turnout in black neighborhoods, for example, could be expected to help Mr. Clinton on Election Day.
Democratic Senators said Mr. Meddoff's tale was not credible; they noted that Mr. Morgan lives in a rented house, has tax liens against him and clearly does not have anywhere near the resources to give the amounts of money he was talking about.
Senator John Glenn of Ohio, the ranking Democrat on the panel, noted that Mr. Meddoff had never made a dime from his relationship with Mr. Morgan and suggested that Mr. Meddoff had been conned.
Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, the chairman of the investigating committee, agreed that Mr. Meddoff's tale was "bizarre and difficult to comprehend."
Still, Mr. Thompson, a Republican, said, he could not understand how Mr. Ickes could talk about millions of dollars with "someone that he does not know, who is purportedly dealing on behalf of someone else whom he does not know."

HEADLINE: Timothy Joyce, 63, a Pioneer in Market Research

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Timothy Joyce, a pioneer in the field of magazine readership research, died on Sept. 13 in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.
Mr. Joyce had long been suffering from hepatitis, said Alain Tessier, a friend and business colleague. 
 Mr. Joyce was born, raised and educated in Britain, receiving a Ph.D. from Cambridge University, and he began his career in market research in London. In the 1960's, as a director of the British Market Research Bureau, he developed a survey system for measuring a magazine's total audience, which included pass-along readership and reading done on airplanes.
In 1972, Mr. Joyce introduced the more extensive magazine readership survey methodology to the United States, when he joined J. Walter Thompson, the advertising agency, as a research director.
The survey system Mr. Joyce helped devise and championed seems common sense today, but it was considered a significant advance at the time. It was a research method that was particularly in step with changing social trends as more and more women were entering the work force, doing more of their reading outside the home.
In 1977, Mr. Joyce returned to London to become media director of J. Walter Thompson there. Two years later, Mr. Joyce returned to New York to become a founder of Mediamark Research Inc., a magazine readership research company.
In 1979, Mediamark was the upstart challenger to the American giant in the field of magazine readership research, Simmons Market Research Bureau.
Mr. Joyce left Mediamark in 1991 to work with A. C. Nielsen to develop a system of measuring media markets using point-of-sale scanning technology, called Homescan. At the time of his death, Mr. Joyce was the vice chairman of the research company, Roper Starch Worldwide.
A former president of the Market Research Council, Mr. Joyce was elected to the professional group's hall of fame in 1995.
Mr. Joyce is survived by his second wife, Helen, whom he married in 1988. His marriage to his first wife, Barbara Joyce, ended in divorce. Mr. Joyce is also survived by a son, Nicholas, of Bristol, England, and a daughter, Rachel Frosh, of London.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. Contract in Need Of Change, Stern Says

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 19

 BODY:
The labor peace that Commissioner David Stern worked so diligently to keep in the National Basketball Association two years ago may be threatened again as early as next spring.
Stern and Deputy Commissioner Russ Granik acknowledged today that the league would strongly consider reopening the collective bargaining agreement signed between the players and the owners in August 1995. Between exorbitant salaries and loopholes around the salary cap, Stern is apparently willing to go back to the bargaining table to fix the economic disparities between the teams in his league. 
 The league can reopen the talks at its option, without the players association's approval. Though no action can be taken until April, one of the worst-case scenarios involves a league-imposed lockout to begin the 1998-99 season.
"We remain eternal optimists in the face of reality," Stern said during an informal news conference at the annual league meetings. "In some ways," he added, "the current collective bargaining agreement is a vast improvement over former agreements -- in terms of 50 different loopholes, balloon payments and salaries to untried rookies for the long term."
But the agreement has also led to a culture of rule-bending by teams and players hamstrung by the salary cap. Given the recent refusal of a $103 million contract extension by Kevin Garnett in Minnesota, the league is particularly concerned about players spurning major dollars for paltry, one-year deals that often lead to a long-term contract with a team now over the salary cap.
Stern and Granik said the recent victory in arbitration by the veteran center Chris Dudley was a prime example of their concern. "I think the Dudley decision is a particularly damaging one with the way we had hoped the new salary cap system would have worked," Granik said.
An arbitrator ruled two weeks ago that Dudley could move from Portland to New York in a sign-and-trade deal consummated by the teams in August. Dudley opted out of a contract worth three years and $13 million in Portland and turned down multiyear offers from other franchises to sign a one-year deal with the Blazers with the notion that they would trade him to the Knicks.
The league argued that an alleged unwritten agreement between Dudley and New York -- in which the Knicks would compensate Dudley with a multiyear deal after this season because he would become their own free agent and his salary would not count against the cap -- circumvented the rules.
The league appealed the decision. Both sides are awaiting the selection of a three-member arbitration panel to review the appeal. But if the appeal is shot down, the league thinks it will not be long before other imaginative maneuvers are used by team officials and players.
"One of the principal tenets here is that you should be encouraged to create salary cap room if you want to go after free agents," Granik said. "And having created salary cap room, perhaps more salary cap room than anybody else, you should be able to gauge what your competition is. Instead, if players are able to make deals where they receive only a relatively small amount of money in the first year because they know they'll get it back in later years, that eliminates that part of the system."
Stern also addressed character issues, adding that the league is wrestling with franchises' enforcement of uniform code-of-conduct rules. "We are concerned about our ability to help our athletes by holding them to standards that say that criminal conduct is not an acceptable part of life in the N.B.A.," he said.
But most of his time was spent detailing the problems and concerns involving the two-year-old labor agreement, a six-year pact that may not make it to its third year.
"The last couple of years when we were heading into our last bargaining agreement, things were heading in the wrong direction," Stern said. "Our concern is whether or not we can extend the gains we made in the first two years of the new deal. If not, then some action might be inevitable."
Added Granik, "We have no choice but to keep working to build a better mousetrap."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Jobless Rate at 7-Year Low

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate fell in August to 5.2 percent, the lowest jobless rate in seven years, the state's Department of Labor said yesterday. The rate in July was 5.4 percent.
But the news was less positive on another closely watched measure. In July, New Jersey had stood on the verge of becoming the first state in the New York City metropolitan region to regain the same number of jobs that were lost in the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's. It was a symbolic threshold that many economists expected New Jersey to cross in August. 
 Instead, the state fell back, losing 8,300 jobs, state officials said, mainly because of the effects of the strike at United Parcel Service. The state has about 10,300 U.P.S. employees, officials said.
As of August, New Jersey had regained 254,000 jobs through five years of the recovery, or about 97 percent of the jobs lost in the recession. Many of the jobs that were lost were in manufacturing, while the new ones tend to be lower-paying jobs in the service industry.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
August Jobless Rate Fell To Its Lowest in 7 Years

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate fell to 5.2 percent in August, the lowest jobless rate in seven years, the state's Department of Labor said yesterday. The rate in July was 5.4 percent.
But the news was less positive by another closely watched measure. In July, New Jersey stood on the verge of becoming the first state in the New York City metropolitan region to regain all the jobs that were lost in the deep recession of the late 1980's and early 90's. It was a symbolic threshold that many economists had expected the state to cross in August. 
 But New Jersey fell back instead, losing 8,300 jobs, state officials said, mainly because of the effects of the teamsters' union strike at United Parcel Service. New Jersey has about 10,300 U.P.S. employees, the state officials said.
As of August, New Jersey had regained 254,000 jobs through five years of recovery, or about 97 percent of the jobs lost in the recession. New York State, which has not yet reported its August job count, had regained 319,000 jobs, or about 55 percent of its losses as of July.
Connecticut had added 101,000 through July, recovering about 65 percent, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

HEADLINE: Fuel's Paradise

BYLINE: By Malcolm W. Browne; Malcolm W. Browne writes about science for The New York Times.

 BODY:

The Fusion Quest
 By T. Kenneth Fowler.
 Illustrated. 250 pp. Baltimore:
 The Johns Hopkins University Press. $29.95. 
 DREAMS of fueling the world with water (or something just as plentiful) have inspired countless charlatans to hawk fraudulent additives and machines for converting water into fuel. But the dream has also engaged the creative energy of many gifted scientists who believe that one day unlimited electric energy will be produced by the same natural process that fuels the sun.
However, controlled hydrogen fusion -- the continuous joining together of the nuclei of hydrogen atoms -- has proved to be a far tougher nut to crack than optimists believed in the 1950's after the first thermonuclear bombs were detonated. Critics of fusion research sneer that fusion is the energy source of the future -- and always will be. Congress has grown bored with expensive fusion experiments that never result in the sustained thermonuclear burning of hydrogen fuel. Consequently, research funds for most (but not all) fusion research have dried up.
Earlier this year the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory in New Jersey was forced by reductions in Federal funding to shut down its huge Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor, the largest fusion machine of its type ever built. Proponents of fusion research like T. Kenneth Fowler, the author of "The Fusion Quest," were embittered. Although the reactor did not achieve ignition, they acknowledge, it did produce brief pulses of fusion power as high as 10 million watts.
But the light at the end of the fusion tunnel has remained discouragingly dim. The problem is scale. The heating and squeezing together of hydrogen nuclei works fine in a reactor the size of the sun, where stupendous and uniform gravitational forces compress the entire star into a reasonably smooth sphere. The solar fusion system efficiently contains its hydrogen fuel, which therefore keeps burning. But an earthbound reactor is much smaller, so its fuel must be confined by something other than gravity: either a complex web of interlocking magnetic fields or the violent, machine-gun-like implosions of many pea-sized capsules of thermonuclear fuel.
Fowler, one of America's leading experts in plasma physics (the physics of ultra-hot, electrically charged gases, including fusion fuel), has spent a lifetime pursuing the fusion dream. His employers have included Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, the General Atomics Company of San Diego and the University of California, Berkeley. He also served as a Government adviser on fusion problems, and few scientists have as broad an understanding of the labyrinthine problems fusion researchers confront.
Not surprisingly, he is an ardent partisan of fusion research. His book argues that there has been important progress in recent years and that the commercial exploitation of fusion power will be attainable, even if it takes 50 years or more. But Fowler makes his case awkwardly, encumbering his prose with so much technical detail that a lay reader may end up feeling bewildered. Evidently he could not decide whether to write an overview for ordinary readers of a textbook for engineering students. The reader plows through this book and must survive many brushes with difficult physics, engineering and mathematics. At its conclusion there is even a 10-page appendix (replete with equations) called "Designing Your Own Fusion Reactor." "The Fusion Quest" also fails to take note of some rather cogent arguments against the promise of hydrogen fusion that have been put forward by experts at the Electric Power Research Institute and various universities.
Most of the book deals with physical and engineering difficulties involved in satisfying the "Lawson criterion" -- a function of plasma pressure and energy confinement time in a thermonuclear reaction. If the Lawson number can be pushed high enough, Fowler explains, a sustained thermonuclear reaction can be ignited. Heating a mixture of deuterium and tritium fuels to more than 72 million degrees Fahrenheit in a very large reactor, he says, should do the job, provided the gas remains efficiently confined. (The reader will notice that the probable fuel for "hydrogen" fusion reactors is not ordinary hydrogen; instead, it is likely to be a mixture of two much rarer forms of hydrogen: deuterium, a trace component of sea water, and tritium, a radioactive hydrogen isotope produced by fission reactors burning uranium.)
There are other tricky requirements; for instance, most heating of the thermonuclear fuel must come from fast-moving alpha particles (helium nuclei). Alpha particles are produced by the fusion reaction itself, but they are difficult to corral. Another engineering nightmare is transporting useful heat from a fusion reactor's core to an electric generation plant. The heat must be extracted from neutrons spawned by the reactor, and as these particles speed away from the thermonuclear furnace they must be captured by some liquid coolant. The problems involved in making this neutron-absorbing "blanket," experts agree, are formidable.
Fowler frequently lapses into the annoying pedagogical habit of inserting "simple" or "well-known" in front of jargon that is left inadequately explained; the reader may feel shamed by not knowing what the author considers obvious. A case in point is his reference to the "well-known" Rayleigh-Taylor instability, one of the nastiest problems in controlled fusion. Some popularizers of fusion physics describe this phenomenon as what is seen when a bottle of oil and vinegar is inverted. The oil rises, not uniformly but in a chaotic pattern of thrusts up into the unstable vinegar layer. Hydrogen plasma trying to escape a confining magnetic field behaves the same way, greatly complicating the task of keeping it in place; it is as difficult to confine the plasma within the needed shape and volume as it is to manually squeeze a greased balloon into a regular shape. The author does not make this clear.
A reader looking for the drama of memorable fusion experiments will be disappointed. A high point, for example, was the night of Dec. 9, 1993, when the Princeton reactor delighted an audience of luminaries by delivering a record pulse of three million watts of fusion power. Fowler mentions the achievement but does not convey the electric thrill experienced by onlookers when that surge of power registered on computer monitors. This interesting, flawed book suggests that sometimes a scientist should seek help from a professional writer to organize his presentation.

HEADLINE: Uneasy Partners

BYLINE: By Sebastian Mallaby; Sebastian Mallaby, formerly the bureau chief for The Economist in Tokyo, is now The Economist's Washington bureau chief and the author of its Lexington column on American affairs.

 BODY:

THE CLASH
 A History Of U.S.-Japan Relations.
 By Walter LaFeber.
 Illustrated. 508 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.
 
 ALTERED STATES
 The United States and Japan
 Since the Occupation.
 By Michael Schaller.
 Illustrated. 320 pp. New York:
 Oxford University Press. $30. 
 AMERICAN foreign policy is going through a noble phase just at the moment. In Eastern Europe, the United States is erasing the divisions of the cold war, bestowing NATO's security upon grateful Czechs, Poles and Hungarians. In the Middle East, it is rededicating itself to the peace process, a task so thankless that a saintly glow illuminates anyone fool enough to undertake it. In the Balkans, America is the scourge of war criminals; in Myanmar, it denounces human wrongs. But foreign policy is not always like this. Look at America's Japan policy.
America's dealings with Japan have seldom been about human rights or justice or peace mediation. They have been about profits and guns. In 1851 Japan was minding its own business when President Millard Fillmore wrote the Emperor a letter demanding that the two countries commence trade; since then, the American clamor for access to Japan's markets has continued unabated. In the early 1940's, after commercial rivalry in continental Asia got out of hand, the two nations fought a horrendous war; at other times, their armies have lined up on the same side. Warm or hostile, the United States-Japan relationship has been driven by calculations of raw power. Principle was just about irrelevant.
This is how the Japanese wanted it. When Japan was forced out of isolation by Fillmore's letter, Asia was being carved up by colonists spouting fine principles from the decks of their gunboats. Japan resolved to escape principled subjugation by amassing commercial and military power, and by shutting its ears to foreigners' beguiling rhetoric. As a result, Japan has traded with America only when it stood to gain; it has never believed (until recently, at least) that a consistent commitment to free trade is good on principle. Equally, Japan has entered security alliances with America only on terms that suited its narrow interests. It has been indifferent (again, until recently) to abstractions like human rights and international justice.
Japan's determined Realpolitik, and America's response, lie at the heart of two scholarly new books on the bilateral relationship. In "The Clash," Walter LaFeber, a diplomatic historian at Cornell University, takes the story back to the 1850's. Michael Schaller, a professor of history at the University of Arizona, deals with the period after 1945 in "Altered States." Both offer dense chronological accounts that are not for the fainthearted. Both draw few general lessons from their research, which may disappoint nonspecialist readers. Nevertheless, both books suggest that today's noble phase in foreign policy may soon bump up against its limits.
The noble foreign policy is based on two ideas: that America has the power to force other countries to behave in a principled way, and that its power allows it to take its core security for granted. The history of Japan policy shows that both assumptions are dangerous. Even at times when America boasted overwhelming power vis-a-vis Japan, it has not been able to make its principles stick. And, despite American power, Japan has often behaved in ways that threatened American security.
Consider first America's failure to make Japan accept its principles. For 150 years, as LaFeber shows, America has preached the value of free trade; for 150 years Japan has listened only when convenient. In the late 19th century, Japan was weak, so it backed America's "open door" policy on Chinese trade and grabbed the commercial opportunities that this policy created. In the early 20th century, Japan was strong, so it reversed its attitude to the open door and seized a chunk of China for its own companies. After 1945, America continued to explain that free trade yields benefits for everyone. Japan pretended to listen.
Japan, LaFeber tells us, has defied the United States on more than just trade. In 1904 Japan took advantage of American diplomatic support to go to war against Russia. This did not prevent Japan from entering into an alliance with Russia in 1910 to thwart American policy in China. After World War I, the United States emerged as the most powerful nation on earth: its industry had escaped destruction, its Navy was building formidable new ships, foreigners (including the Japanese) depended on New York for capital. But at the Versailles conference Japan steadfastly refused to bend to Woodrow Wilson's request that it should give up some territorial gains. "Wilson found himself now controlling the world's greatest economic and military power," LaFeber writes, "but it was not enough to have his way with Japan."
After World War II, this pattern continued. America's relative power increased; its military bases in Japan protected the Japanese from Communism. But this did not stop the Japanese from defying America repeatedly, refusing to rearm as rapidly as Washington wanted, demanding that the southern island of Okinawa be returned, undermining the American boycott of China after the Tiananmen massacre. Japanese leftists wanted the alliance revoked; when, in 1960, America's Ambassador in Tokyo met Japan's Foreign Minister to exchange signed copies of the security pact, arrangements had to be made for the two to escape over a back wall if rioting mobs caught up with them. Even the pro-American right wing has doubted the security alliance. In 1972, according to a poll cited by Schaller, only 44 percent of Liberal Democrat candidates for the Diet supported it strongly.
The high point of American power over Japan came right after 1945, when America's occupation force thought it could remake Japan in its own image. As a biographer of Douglas MacArthur, the general who reigned over occupied Japan, Schaller is especially expert on this folly. The United States started out by purging militarists from public life, hoping that new leaders would sprout up who shared American principles. When the vacuum seemed likelier to be filled by a pro-Communist left wing, Washington changed course. Nearly 200,000 Japanese had their purge orders revoked; these ex-militarists accounted for 42 percent of the new members of the Diet's lower house after the 1952 election. In 1957, Nobusuke Kishi, who had cosigned the declaration of war against the United States in 1941 and been imprisoned for war crimes, visited America as Japan's Prime Minister and Eisenhower's guest. Schaller mentions that he was invited to throw out the first ball at a game between the New York Yankees and the Chicago White Sox.
This visit was humiliating; but it teaches a useful lesson about the limits to American power, and so the limits to its ability to pursue principled foreign policy. On principle, America should have punished war criminals. But it simply could not afford the risk that Japan might acquire weak or Communist leadership. On principle, today, America is right to push Japan to open its markets and shoulder more of the defense burden in Asia. But perhaps it cannot afford to risk a Japanese backlash -- just as it must beware of provoking Southeast Asians when it speaks up for human rights and Russians when it enlarges NATO. It is not a pleasant thing to say, but noble ideals can sometimes be a poor guide to foreign policy.

HEADLINE: Hitler's Legacy

BYLINE: By Joshua Rubenstein; Joshua Rubenstein, the Northeast regional director of Amnesty International U.S.A., is the author of "Tangled Loyalties: The Life and Times of Ilya Ehrenburg."

 BODY:

THE BEAST REAWAKENS
 By Martin A. Lee.
 Illustrated. 546 pp. Boston:
 Little, Brown & Company.
 $24.95. 
 FOR several decades following the end of the Third Reich, extreme right-wing political movements around the world had to camouflage their true colors. "Fascists had no choice but to maintain a low profile," Martin A. Lee says in "The Beast Reawakens," because the Nazi horror delivered "state terror, genocide and mass destruction on an unprecedented scale."
Lee, a journalist who has written for several publications, has good reason to introduce his account of present-day fascism by recalling the fate of prominent Nazis who avoided serious punishment after the war and went on to successful careers in international intrigue and the arms trade. For several decades, their true vocation was to serve as living links to Hitler himself, inspiring young neo-Nazis in Germany and elsewhere.
Nazi apologists also sustained the cause. Most Americans are unfamiliar with people like Willis Carto. But Lee reminds us how Carto's Liberty Lobby and his magazine, Spotlight, forged links with the Republican Party in the 1960's, gaining a measure of legitimacy (and not inconsiderable funds) for Carto's promotional efforts among American and European neo-Nazis.
The underground culture that veteran Nazis and Nazi apologists helped to nurture did not reach genuinely dangerous proportions until the late 1980's, when developments like the end of the cold war made a number of European countries vulnerable to fascist appeals. Germany served as an unhelpful bellwether. During the immediate postwar period, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appointed well-known former Nazis to high-ranking positions. By 1991, as skinheads and other domestic neo-Nazis grew more brazen, staging outright pogroms against immigrant and refugee families, Chancellor Helmut Kohl refused to respond with the kind of urgent measures that his Government had enacted against extreme leftists. German justice appeared to be blind in the right eye.
Lee provides a vivid survey of fascist resurgence throughout Europe. In Italy, Romania, France and Austria, demagogic political leaders have tried to divert "economic and social resentments toward national and racial preoccupations." In Croatia, President Franjo Tudjman has based much of his electoral appeal on rehabilitating his country's Nazi-allied wartime Government. To do so, he has whitewashed the slaughter of Orthodox Serbs and Jews, a kind of double holocaust that extreme Croatian nationalists now claim did not occur. Even in Russia, where, one might expect, the ravages of World War II would make it impossible for explicitly fascist rhetoric to gain a foothold, there are politicians and newspapers prepared to glorify Hitler, while fascist supporters can be found hawking swastika buttons within yards of Red Square.
The United States is not immune to this virus. Lee finds evidence that at least some leaders of the militia movement have links to neo-Nazis. Their mistrust of government authority may lack a well-defined political orientation, fascist or otherwise, but in a broad survey of fascism today, Lee would be remiss not to underscore the fact that many militia members and even a few candidates for high office are prepared to glorify violence and exploit irrational fears about foreigners, two elements of fascism's appeal that are not unfamiliar on the American political landscape.
Several decades ago, the German philosopher Theodor Adorno regarded the continued existence of fascism "within democracy" as "more threatening than the continued existence of fascist tendencies against democracy." Adorno's cautionary observation underscores a principal theme of "The Beast Reawakens." Although fascism requires political and economic instability in order to make serious gains, alert fascists can always be relied on to exploit the failure of democratic leaders to defend democratic values without apology.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1444 words

HEADLINE: In the Absence of Language

BYLINE: By Jim Shepard; Jim Shepard's most recent book is a collection of stories, "Batting Against Castro." His new novel, "Nosferatu," will be published next year.

 BODY:

ALL AROUND ATLANTIS
 Stories.
 By Deborah Eisenberg.
 244 pp. New York:
 Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23. 
 IN his preface to "What Maisie Knew," Henry James reminds us that "small children have many more perceptions than they have terms to translate them; their vision is at any moment much richer, their apprehension even constantly stronger, than . . . their at all producible vocabulary." In other words, their feelings can be complex even when their language is not. The writer, James was suggesting, might by a certain sleight of hand grant fictional children a language that honors these intuitions, this inner life. (This strategy is also attractive because it enacts the children's helplessness while returning to them their dignity.)
No contemporary American fiction has demonstrated James's suggestion more powerfully than Deborah Eisenberg's, beginning with her first story collection, "Transactions in a Foreign Currency" -- particularly the gorgeous and heartbreaking "What It Was Like, Seeing Chris" -- and continuing with her newest, "All Around Atlantis." In some of her most memorable stories the protagonists are adolescent or preadolescent -- "fine and shy and anxious with the passion that precedes knowledge," to return to James for a moment -- almost always affluent and always neglected.
As in the case of Kyla, the protagonist of "Mermaids," a story of nearly unremitting sadness about a miserable spring-vacation trip to New York City, these children are repeatedly shunted aside and left to wait for adults who remain fixed with an iron graciousness in their own agendas and who choose to assume that privilege will redress emotional isolation. Kyla lives in a world of expectations, admonitions and exhortations, a world that believes in the relative immutability of adults, even as its children are open to scrutiny, correction and evaluation. Eisenberg is expert on the cruelty of such expectations. (Kyla's friend Janey, when Kyla is offered some ice cream, requests some as well. Her mother responds: "There's some fruit for you. Remember those five pounds.")
These children are expected -- usually by their mothers -- to maintain a certain independence. ("Kyla leaned against her mother's coolness. 'Don't cling, darling,' her mother said. 'You're getting much too big.' ") Their mothers have an unfortunate gift for "the automatic nuancing of the unspoken," leaving the children in sole possession of a terrible silence. These women are ciphers, the decoding of which offers the children their only hope of decoding themselves: "Her mother's bed was tightly made; the bedspread was as mute as the surface of a lake into which a clue had been dropped long before"; "In the mirror . . . her mother's eyes lay across her own reflection like a mask." Like James, Eisenberg uses children to make seemingly ignoble people worthy of our attention; like Maisie, by the play of their good faith, these children make their parents "concrete, immense and awful."
The children in Eisenberg's stories only occasionally reveal the gaps in their precociousness. "Kyla looked at her. Flirting. Flirting, actually, was when you . . . 'What was he doing?' she asked." In these stories, comedy often operates that way: the precociously complex followed by the resoundingly down-to-earth. Francie, the main character in "The Girl Who Left Her Sock on the Floor," notes that "when her mother and Mrs. Peck emerged from the office together that afternoon, a blaze of triumph and contempt crackled behind the veneer of patently suspect humility on her mother's face. Mrs. Peck, on the other hand, looked as if she'd been bonked on the head with a plank."
The tension between vocabulary and perception creates in Eisenberg's young people a kind of uncanny eloquence of the nearly articulate: "When people got angry, they were angry and then they stopped being angry, and it was something that went from them to you. But when people were disappointed in you, it was something that went from you to them." Thus the children puzzle through larger philosophical understandings ("Just think," Francie muses, "things that you did went on and on, turning into situations, for example. Into people.") while perceiving events with a lyricism apparently charged with an emotional meaning that needs to be teased out. Visiting her mother's room after her death, Francie notices that "a fine coating of city grime sealed the sills in front of the closed windows like insulation."
Whether born to economic privilege, like Kyla, or selected for it, like Francie, the scholarship girl trapped in a snooty boarding school, these characters are always aware of class issues. Francie, remembering that her mother was often described as "proud," bristles: "But what did that mean, 'proud'? Proud of her poverty. Proud of her poor education. . . . Proud of bringing up her Difficult Daughter, Without an Iota of Help. So what was the difference, when you got right down to it, between pride and shame?"
"What you can do if something belongs to you!" another character realizes. "The way you can behave!" Three of the seven stories widen the collection's political scope and make the ramifications of class international by plunking down well-meaning and well-off Americans in Latin America and then probing their national collective shame as tourists "on the brink of doing or thinking something unworthy." In "Tlaloc's Paradise," for example, a refugee from the McCarthy purges, waiting in a Mexican village for her husband to return from a battery of medical tests in America, catches a glimpse of a local history she'd overlooked -- a history of refugees, disappearances and secret wars.
In "Someone to Talk To," an aging pianist, in an attempt to recapture a bit of the old adulation, agrees to perform in a concert sponsored by a murderous regime that supports the arts to divert international attention from its other activities. And in "Across the Lake," a college student gives himself over to two slightly feral Americans of the sort who turn up regularly in Robert Stone's fiction. Not surprisingly, he finds himself in the kind of deep water that Stone's guilty innocents have a genius for discovering. Drug runners, revolutionaries and counterrevolutionaries trade the subtlest lethal gestures as our hero, Rob, frets over whether one of his fellow travelers has noticed his infatuation with her.
While Rob, in trying to make sense of this new world, like Stone's or Malcolm Lowry's hapless adventurers, follows "a trail of instructions . . . as far as it was possible to go," the reader comes to apprehend some of the complexity of his -- and our -- relationship to such places ("He could buy or not buy; he could exercise his power and money or refrain from doing so, and that was the extent of his choice") as well as the complexity of their relationship to us: "The shop owner was a large woman. Some automatic function was releasing rage evenly into her face." All the stories, featuring their protagonists' previously untested integrity and convenient innocence, maintain as their subtext willfully overlooked suffering.
The title story works the most explicitly to demonstrate the indivisibility of the personal and the political. Middle-aged Anna, on the death of her mother, Lili, imagines what she might say now to Peter, who was a boarder with the family when she was a child. Lili's entire circle, including Peter, were refugees from one Hungarian catastrophe after another, but poor Anna didn't qualify, having been brought to America as an infant. Competing with a long-lost and idealized past of which she'd had no part -- the lost city of the title -- as well as discovering herself to be in a half-understood sexual competition with her mother for Peter's attention, she was left an emigre in her own home.
Not all the strategies that recur in Eisenberg's stories are endlessly pleasing. Occasionally, the noticed detail is too flatfootedly an objective correlative (as Francie starts to face her shattered life without her newly deceased mother, "out the window a wrecking ball swung toward a solitary wall") and there's a fondness for pointedly illuminating chance encounters with eccentrics, who through their ramblings focus the stories' themes while bringing the usually somewhat baffled protagonists up to speed.
But if Deborah Eisenberg's young people, like Francie, are forced to train themselves in matters of empathy without the help of any obvious mentors, we as readers reap the benefits of their hard work: these stories are spirited and masterly road maps through sad and forbidding and desolate terrain.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1293 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Public Sculpture the Public Likes. Really.

BYLINE: By ROBIN CEMBALEST; Robin Cembalest is the arts editor of the Forward.

 BODY:
IN 1995, WHEN THE SCULPTOR Tom Otterness was asked to create an artwork for a plaza outside the Sacramento Federal Courthouse, he had an inspiration: a four-foot-tall chess set that reflected the drama of the proceedings unfolding inside. In his first proposal, he envisioned one side as the financial establishment -- rooks as banks, bishops as lawyers, king and queen as rich entrepreneurs. The other would be an army of working-class pawns bearing shovels, mallets and serving trays.
Bronze casts of those pieces are in Mr. Otterness's show that opens Thursday for a monthlong run at the Marlborough Gallery on West 57th Street, where he moved from a SoHo gallery last year. But the works never made it to the plaza. A community panel convened by the General Services Administration, the Federal agency that commissioned Mr. Otterness, deemed the idea inappropriate and asked him to try again, a normal part of the back-and-forth nature of public projects. 
 The plaza, which opens next spring, now has a very different configuration: a tableau depicting the history of Sacramento, with salmon, gold miners, a covered wagon and scenes from the building of the railroad.
Though the final result bears no resemblance to his original design, Mr. Otterness is philosophical. "I said, 'What do you want?' " he recounts. "They said, 'Eagles.' I thought, 'Here's a chance to do a series of vignettes of Western culture.' I look at it positively."
That willingness to compromise is one reason Mr. Otterness is one of the country's busiest public sculptors. Nearly every work in the Marlborough show was generated by a public project. There are the canine prosecutor and feline defendant (telltale feather in its mouth) completed last May at the United States Courthouse in Portland, Ore. An alligator chomping off a man's head belongs to "Life Underground," a series of more than 20 bronzes that will be installed in December at the subway station on Eighth Avenue and 14th Street in Manhattan. A "frog rock" and other anthropomorphic stone characters are adapted from a piece for the United States Courthouse in Minneapolis, scheduled for next year.
With the debacle of Richard Serra's "Tilted Arc" still alive in the memory of the committees that commission public art, Mr. Otterness's frolicking figures offer everything that monolithic abstract sculpture lacks: humor, narrative, tactility, accessibility and an obvious, yet unthreatening, artistic sophistication.
"There's public art that I like, there's public art my son likes, but this is something we both like," says Tom Finkelpearl, a former director of New York City's percent-for-art program. "That it could exist for a 4-year-old and an adult expert is something Tom's acutely aware of."
Mr. Finkelpearl describes Mr. Otterness's elaborate vignettes as a contemporary version of church frescoes that spun complex allegories for an illiterate public. Others have likened his chubby cast of characters to the Pillsbury Doughboy, Babar the Elephant, James Thurber's cartoons, Disney animations and Holbein's portraits; his narrative style to Delacroix's history painting, Chinese tomb sculpture and Roman friezes; his sense of the absurd to Kafka.
IT TAKES A MOMENT OF LOOKING at Mr. Otterness's work to realize just how dark its content can be. His creatures may be adorable, but they are also greedy, cunning and destructive, engaged in life-or-death dramas in which the small and meek often emerge as losers. In "The Tables," a 1987 piece owned by the Whitney Museum of American Art, scores of tiny figures course through a city threatened by an atomic bomb shaped like a whale, a gargantuan spider and a cracked world hanging overhead.
"The Disney thing is the window into the work," says the artist, a mild-mannered man of 45 with below-the-shoulder graying blond hair and a goatee. "Disney has this nightmarish quality that I am convinced is its attraction -- the underpinnings of dysfunction and turmoil."
While many successful public artists work almost exclusively in the civic arena, Mr. Otterness is one of the few, among them Vito Acconci and Siah Armajani, who have a strong presence in the gallery and museum world as well.
According to Adam Weinberg, a curator at the Whitney, "Otterness engages a lot of the issues of current contemporary art -- popular culture, the pitfalls of capitalism, the downfall of communism, sexual politics. But he is really sui generis. There are not many artists I can relate him to."
Mr. Otterness plays down the political implications of his art, preferring to emphasize its personal approach to economic issues. "Instead of looking at this social system we're in from a great distance, I'm looking from inside my family out," says the artist, who has a wife and a 5-year-old daughter. "From the point of view of one of those figures looking up at one of those ominous forces."
Besides, he notes, what may seem heavy-handed to some may appeal to others. That was the case when the art museum in his hometown, Wichita, Kan., invited him to build a piece for its lawn and he offered an enlarged detail from "The Tables": a 15-foot-tall woman with a sickle standing over a fallen man with a hammer. "We were prepared for the worst," says Inez Wolins, the museum's director. But when the sculpture was installed in 1995, "Not a single person complained."
GROWING UP IN KANSAS, where his father worked for Boeing and his mother worked as a waitress and sold real estate, Mr. Otterness had no doubts about his calling. "I used to tell my teachers I didn't need to know how to spell because I was going to be an artist," he says. He proved himself right when he won a scholarship to attend the Art Students League and at 19 he found himself in New York. To support his studies, he catalogued pre-Columbian collections at the Museum of Natural History, where the Aztec and Mayan pieces exerted great power on him. "They had a beautiful formal quality combined with horrific decapitations and sacrifices," he says.
Mr. Otterness joined the Lower East Side artists who in 1977 founded Collaborative Projects, aspiring to take art out of galleries into mainstream settings like Times Square. In 1980, he provoked a small scandal when it emerged that he had made a film of a dog being shot, a seemingly uncharacteristic gesture that he has since declined to discuss.
Mr. Otterness has refined the characters he started working with in the late 70's, though he still uses five wax prototypes: a nude, a blue-collar worker, a white-collar worker, a police officer and a generic rich person. In his 9,000-square-foot Brooklyn studio under the Manhattan Bridge, as many as 12 assistants help him churn out his public projects.
The figures have gradually increased in size -- his largest so far is the 30-foot-tall "Uberfrau" outside the state library in Munster, Germany -- and he wants to make them bigger still. "I'd like to have figures that function as architecture," he says. "I'm trying to get into Las Vegas to do a theme park." Another ambition is to move into animation and toys.
Meanwhile, he is juggling the details of his public projects: his "Visionary," a 17-foot-tall woman holding her detached head in her hands, will be installed by the Public Art Fund at the Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn next month; he is finishing gates for the garden of the Cleveland Public Library. At the request of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, he recently removed a "rat cop" from "Life Underground," which is on view in Battery Park City until its installation in the subway.
"My philosophy is try to yield to every request so that the work can survive and end up in public," he says. "Then an active debate can happen."
