SECTION: Section 6; Page 66; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3180 words

HEADLINE: Can the Man Who Made Sun City Make It In Atlantic City?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Rabinovitz; Jonathan Rabinovitz is a reporter in Hartford for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Sol (the Sun King) Kerzner was casino hopping.
His casinos. Wednesday found him at his beachfront resort in the Bahamas, where card sharks watch real sharks in what Kerzner claims is the world's largest open-air aquarium. Thursday he turned up in Atlantic City to plan a $150 million overhaul of Resorts Casino Hotel, his newest toy. And Friday his jet landed in Connecticut for a party at Mohegan Sun, a stadium-size gambling palace that he built last year on the Mohegan Indian reservation. 
 Although Kerzner's name is little known in this country, one of the resorts that he built in his native South Africa -- Sun City -- was notorious. In the 80's, it inspired a hit anti-apartheid song and a boycott by superstars like Bruce Springsteen and Bob Dylan. Kerzner, who is sometimes called the Bugsy Siegel of the bush veld, was accused of bribery and was roundly denounced for using apartheid to advance his business interests. And time and again, when someone has stood in his way -- a politician or investigator or regulator -- that person has wound up with a comfortable job or a stake in the company or tax revenues he can't refuse.
Over the last three years, though, as chairman of Sun International Hotels, Kerzner has presided over the rise of one of the hottest gambling companies in the United States, its market value increasing fourfold since 1995 to about $1.2 billion earlier this month. With his casinos in Connecticut, the Bahamas and, if he has his way, Atlantic City, Kerzner is giving people like Steve Wynn and Donald Trump a run for their money, and Sun has a shot at becoming the dominant gaming company serving the East Coast.
Because of his and his company's cloudy history, Federal regulators initially balked at approving Kerzner's deal with the Mohegans. New Jersey gaming regulators have just completed the latest investigation of his dealings as part of the review of his application to operate in Atlantic City, and hearings are scheduled to begin tomorrow. Kerzner and industry observers are upbeat about his prospects.
The Friday-night party at Mohegan Sun offered a glimpse of why anyone trying to stop the Kerzner juggernaut has his work cut out for him. Clouds scudded across the ceiling, and there was the sound of a rushing stream. We were surrounded by trees, cliffs and boulders typical of a New England forest. "It's very Mohegan," Kerzner said. Even louder than the stream was the clanging of nearly 3,000 slot machines.
As hundreds of Mohegans in tuxedos, ball gowns and buckskin danced to an R & B band, the tribe's chief, Ralph Sturges, greeted Kerzner like a brother, giving him a hug. Roland Harris, the tribal council chairman, called him a "good friend." A letter was read from Gov. John G. Rowland -- who had once opposed Kerzner -- hailing the casino as an economic shot in the arm for the region. Senator Christopher Dodd made a speech, recalling some "very, very dicey times" but ultimately recounting "the pleasure" of working with Kerzner, who looked positively stunned by the praise. "What an outstanding guy," Kerzner said. "Incredible!"
Perhaps the most incredible thing of all is how respectable Sol Kerzner has become. Apartheid has ended, and he is on good terms with President Nelson Mandela. Liberal Democrats and Indians, who would once have been outraged by his South African past, are his allies. And Mohegan Sun, the nation's fifth-most-spacious casino, rakes in a million dollars a day.
An old friend, Lynton Israel, describes Kerzner as a "party animal." For his 50th birthday, the mogul chartered a 747 for more than 100 friends, with showgirls doing stripteases in the aisle. But now, 12 years later, he insists that he has mellowed.
Kerzner looks like a truck driver and has worked as a bouncer. He wears a construction helmet more often than a tie. He went years without reading a novel, does not like Champagne and at a Chinese restaurant at Mohegan Sun sent back his soup because the noodles kept slipping off his spoon. It is only his well-groomed hands that hint at his station. "I have lover's hands," says Kerzner, who is engaged to a 35-year-old model after three marriages, two of which ended in divorce and one of which ended in his wife's suicide.
Paul M. Dworin, publisher of International Gaming and Wagering Business magazine, calls him a "visionary" who should not be underestimated. "He's unpolished," Dworin says, "but unpolished by choice."
On a winter afternoon in the Bahamas, where Kerzner is adding a 23-story hotel to his Atlantis resort, he walked a vacant 30-acre lot in his usual jeans, polo shirt and scuffed Reeboks. "It looks like a big sandbox," he said. "Come back here in six weeks and the structure will be flying." By Christmas 1998, he added, the site, which is loosely based on the theme of Plato's fabled Lost City of Atlantis, will feature a gold-leaf domed palace, a Mayan temple with water slides and Kerzner's version of Atlantis ruins.
Later that day, he sat in a construction trailer, jiggling the worry beads that he has carried since 1983, when he suffered a heart attack and quit his three-pack-a-day cigarette habit. Poring over a restaurant blueprint, he suddenly frowned. "You can't walk into this room with the ass end of the bar out," he growled, gesturing at a design in which the bar blocked the restaurant entry. He told a construction executive to call the designers. "That plan is hopeless," he shouted into the phone, and ordered them to fix it.
The designs of Sun casinos are not driven by Kerzner's creative whims as much as his understanding of gaming trends. Kerzner couldn't tell you much about Mohegan history or Atlantis mythology. Like his Las Vegas counterparts, he once marketed his casinos as racy adult playgrounds. But now, reflecting his own transition from a jet-setting party animal to a doting grandfather, he has become a leader in the current industry trend: casino resorts as purveyors of wholesome, environmentally correct family entertainment.
Casinos are now legal in 26 states, up from 2 a decade ago. In 1995, according to one survey, American casinos had more visits than amusement parks, touring Broadway shows or major-league baseball games. With more gamblers but also with more casinos competing for their money, the operators need to offer more to lure people. Besides a splashy, if not altogether consistent, theme, the Bahamas Atlantis offers basic classes in blackjack, roulette and craps. Executives say that even though only 1 out of 5 Atlantis guests lists gambling as a reason for the visit, 9 out of 10 end up betting.
Kerzner clearly knows how to build these populist Xanadus. The Lost City, a 1992 addition to Sun City that was his first project to use the theme of a vanished ancient civilization, has been described as a surfer's paradise in the arid interior of South Africa, with an imported jungle of more than one million plants, a manmade ocean of six-foot waves and its own mythology (written by the resort's California architect). Herbert Muschamp, the architecture critic for The Times, called the Mohegan Sun's interior, which was created by the designer of the Planet Hollywood restaurants, "as ambitious a piece of stagecraft as anyone has realized since the days of Cecil B. DeMille." For the Atlantic City Resorts Casino, which Kerzner bought from Merv Griffin late last year, Kerzner plans the Beach Club, which will evoke the Boardwalk hotels of the turn of the century -- the ones that were gutted to make way for casinos like his own.
While Las Vegas has become a haven for Disneylike attractions, Atlantic City has lagged behind. Civic boosters see Kerzner as part of a group of developers who will recast the town as a destination resort. Gaming-industry analysts point to his success in turning around the Bahamas casino, another failing Resorts property that Griffin had owned.
"Is this the Atlantis Plato envisioned when he wrote of a utopian vision?" intones a promotional video for the $460 million addition that's now under way there. The footage shows young women in bathing suits playing in the water. Kerzner has flown in "disease resistant" palm trees and stocked an artificial coral reef with 13,000 tropical fish from as far away as Australia. New slot machines have motifs like "Shakin' Shark" and "Crazy Crab."
"Obviously this new development takes on a lot of Plato's thinking," Kerzner says.
Has he read Plato?
"I get summarized versions."
Born on Aug. 23, 1935, Solomon Kerzner was the youngest son of Orthodox Jewish parents who immigrated to South Africa from a shtetl in Eastern Europe. He grew up in a poor Johannesburg suburb, and his parents worked seven days a week in their own cafe. As a college boxer, he occasionally faced better fighters, but no one knocked him out, and he was welterweight champion at his school.
By age 28, having quit his job in accounting, he managed to sweet-talk some of his former clients into financing his plan to build a luxury hotel, even though he had never built anything. Before construction started, he spent two days touring hotels in Miami Beach and a day in Manhattan. The Beverly Hills Hotel, South Africa's first five-star resort, opened in December 1964.
From this start, Kerzner teamed up in 1969 with one of South Africa's largest companies to develop a chain of 29 hotels. Fourteen years later, he joined with new partners to establish another company that soon had a virtual monopoly on the casino market in South Africa, where headlines still refer to him simply as Sol. He brought Frank Sinatra to Africa and married and divorced one of the country's most famous women, a former Miss World. He has estates on the Riviera, on a mountaintop near Cape Town and outside Oxford, England. One report valued his family trusts at $750 million in 1994.
Kerzner would not have achieved this success without apartheid. All of his casinos were built in the homelands -- desolate reservations where black people were herded, which the apartheid regime began spinning off as independent states in 1976. Every other country refused to recognize these puppet states, and the African National Congress urged businesses to stay out of them. Kerzner rushed in.
Casinos were banned in South Africa but not in the quasi-independent homelands. He built Sun City on barren land in Bophuthatswana, two hours by car from Johannesburg. As part of the deal, Kerzner gave the homeland a substantial stake in the company that controlled the casino. The resort -- sometimes called Las Vegas on the veld, sometimes called Sin City -- drew white South Africans to gamble, ogle topless dancers and maybe have interracial sex, all of which were illegal in South Africa.
"Sol Kerzner was an unforgettable and important brick in the wall of apartheid," says Randall Robinson, president of the Washington-based lobbying group Trans Africa. "He and what he was doing were an essential part of the Government's strategy to defend that awful system."
Sun City became a symbol of apartheid's evils. In 1985, it was a target of the American anti-apartheid movement, with more than 50 musicians producing the album "Sun City." The title cut's chorus, "I ain't gonna play Sun City," urged performers to stay away.
Today, while Kerzner calls apartheid "unacceptable," he says that he was a businessman, not a politician. "Your role as a chief executive is to take care of your shareholders," he says. "We did what we could. That was very, very little."
Apartheid has been a defining issue in Kerzner's business life, partly because it allowed him to vastly expand his fortune and partly because his controversial way of doing so has dogged him ever since. His attempt to profit from the homelands backfired, for example, in the Transkei. For the past 10 years, he has been in and out of trouble over a charge that he paid a $600,000 bribe to a leader of the homeland, since deposed, to guarantee his monopoly in that market. Kerzner acknowledges the payment but considers it extortion. South African prosecutors finally dropped the case in April; New Jersey investigators have carefully studied it.
The connection to apartheid initially hindered Kerzner's efforts to expand beyond South Africa. But in the 1990's, when the country underwent radical change, so did his fortunes. By the time Mandela emerged from prison after 27 years, Kerzner had cultivated good relations with his African National Congress -- too good, said some critics, who cite reports that Kerzner wined and dined A.N.C. officials, that he covered some wedding costs for one of Mandela's daughters and that he helped pay for a 50th-birthday party for Mandela's heir apparent, Thabo Mbeki. Kerzner denies these reports, but he admits to contributing roughly $125,000 to the A.N.C. in 1994 -- a charge that he initially told journalists was "outrageously false."
President Mandela appears to harbor no ill will toward Kerzner for his apartheid-era profiteering. Before Kerzner was welcomed into the Bahamas, Prime Minister Hubert Ingraham talked to Mandela about him. "He felt Mr. Kerzner would be good for the Bahamas," Ingraham says, "and he didn't think there were any reasons whatsoever why the Bahamas ought not welcome him to do business here."
Yet each time Kerzner undertakes an ambitious new project, the same criticisms crop up. Two years ago, it was in Washington. Trading Cove Associates, a partnership in which Kerzner's company has a 50 percent stake, had a contract with the Mohegans to build and run the casino that required the approval of the National Indian Gaming Commission. The Federal agency had a backlog of cases, but the Mohegan contract -- the largest deal that had ever come before the commission -- received priority handling. Senator Dodd's office made several calls to the agency urging it to hurry up. "All we wanted them to do was make a decision," Dodd says. "It had gone on for a long time."
When two of the three commissioners recommended against approval until further review of Kerzner, the third commissioner, the chairman, Harold Monteau, overruled his colleagues. Monteau argued, in an unusual but legal move, that the Mohegans had waited long enough -- two years -- and that the law did not require a more thorough review. One year later, the Mohegans hired Monteau's assistant, Tom Acevedo, and an aide to Senator Dodd, Charles F. Bunnell, as chief and deputy chief of staff, respectively, for the Mohegan tribal chairman.
"This doesn't even pass the smell test," Senator Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, said of Acevedo's hiring when he spoke in October before the Committee on Indian Affairs. Reid also questioned why the casino's management company receives as much as 40 percent of the gaming profits -- about 10 percent above the norm. Three months later, Monteau, under fire for this and other problems, resigned from the gaming commission, saying he wanted to work outside government. Kerzner says he wasn't involved in the commission's review or in the Mohegans' hiring of any employees, including Acevedo.
In Connecticut, Kerzner's arrival also caused a stir. At first Governor Rowland voiced "grave concerns" about giving a state casino license to someone plagued by bribery allegations. But in July 1996, after the Connecticut state police conducted an investigation, Kerzner received a license. Less than a year later, the Mohegans had hired two of the state investigators to work for the tribe's own gaming commission.
Kerzner has offered as evidence of his integrity a 1994 report compiled by a private investigator for the tribe. Francis M. Mullen, a retired F.B.I. official and former head of the Drug Enforcement Agency, interviewed Derek Hawton, a South African business colleague of Kerzner's. The report noted that according to Hawton, "President Mandela himself has stated to him that 'Sol Kerzner would be prosecuted over my dead body.' " In March, the morning after I faxed this quote to Mandela's office for confirmation, a frantic Kerzner called. He had already spoken to Mullen, who after completing the report became the Mohegans' top regulator. "Somehow this got fouled up," Kerzner told me, adding that Mullen had made a mistake that caused "huge bloody problems." According to Kerzner, Mullen had meant to write that Hawton had "heard" that President Mandela had made this remark. Kerzner insisted that the quote should not be reprinted. The next day, Mullen said that the report was most likely in error, though he was not sure. Mandela's office denied that he made the statement.
The allegations of influence peddling are very much alive in New Jersey, where state regulators are currently considering Kerzner's application for the Atlantic City casino license. The review is the most comprehensive that he and his company have yet undergone, its scope unprecedented even by New Jersey gaming standards.
And the Atlantic City project carries considerable business risk. For the first time, Kerzner may be going head to head with some of the casino industry's biggest players, among them Donald Trump, who owns 3 of the 12 casinos in Atlantic City but whose company's market value was one-third of Kerzner's earlier this month, and Steve Wynn, whose Mirage Resorts had a market value roughly four times greater than Sun's in the same period. Kerzner has already scaled back his plans from a half billion dollars to $150 million, though he says he is bullish on Atlantic City. People who blocked his entry in 1983 are now talking about the jobs he will bring. "The name of the game is not to oppose," said Pierre Hollingsworth, the former head of the Atlantic City N.A.A.C.P. chapter, who protested Kerzner's proposal years ago. "He's going to be bringing work." Several people familiar with Atlantic City regulations say they will be shocked if Kerzner, who has an army of supporters ready to attest to his good character, is not licensed by the end of the year.
That is why many people are betting that Kerzner is here to stay. Since Mohegan Sun opened in October, it has brought in at least $325 million in gaming revenues. More than $58 million of that went to Governor Rowland and the Connecticut budget as part of a deal that gives the state 25 percent of the casino's slot-machine revenues. Another cut of casino profits went to the Wall Street investors who put up the construction money. Several thousand people have jobs because of the casino, and when Senator Dodd campaigns for re-election he will undoubtedly remind them that his support of Mohegan Sun helped make those jobs possible.
While the blots on Kerzner's record are unsightly, no one has ever proved them to be illegal. People may mistake his crudeness for shadiness, even as Kerzner is so consumed with his chase for profits that he ignores appearances. And with every coin dropped into a slot machine, it becomes clearer and clearer why it would be so difficult for any government or regulatory agency or Wall Street banking house to turn him away. Sol Kerzner knows how to make money.

LENGTH: 1692 words

HEADLINE: Helping Women With World of Finances

BYLINE: By RAHEL MUSLEAH 

 BODY:
TO Marilyn Crockett and Diane Terman Felenstein shopping for stocks is not much different from shopping for clothes and groceries. They liken bond ratings to pantyhose sizes and the buying of stocks in downturns to buying tuna fish on sale.
Their mission, to demystify money for women, has earned them reputations as the Ann Landers and Dear Abby of women's finances. 
 Ms. Crockett and Ms. Terman Felenstein founded the 008-Investment Club, an organization for women that meets in Manhattan. They share their story in "The Money Club: How We Taught Ourselves the Secret to a Secure Financial Future -- and How You Can, Too," written with Dale Burg (Simon & Schuster).
"Money is on the dark side of the moon for women," said Ms. Crockett, first vice president of investments at Paine Webber. "It's an unexplored frontier."
Ms. Crockett was invited to serve as the club's financial adviser by Ms. Terman Felenstein, who formed the club after being inspired by an article about the Beardstown Ladies, 16 women from Illinois who wrote a best-seller about their investment club.
Although Ms. Terman-Felenestein presided over a public relations and marketing company with clients like Prestige Cosmetics, Slim Fast and United Cerebral Palsy, she said she considered personal finances, even her own, to be "the world's most boring topic." At meetings with accountants and insurance agents, she said, she "zoned out and doodled."
When she contacted friends, successful professionals and businesswomen, fund-raisers and spouses of top executives, many with houses on Long Island, she found that few knew more than she did about managing their money. That cemented her resolve to form an investment club.
Ms. Terman Felenstein, 56, has now taken charge of her own stock portfolio, reorganized her insurance and estate plans, and even requested and received financial newsletters as birthday presents.
The 008-Club, so named because eight is a "power number" connoting financial success in numerology, lived up to its inspiration. Its portfolio has gained 29 percent a year since it began in June 1995. Its membership has grown, from 18 to 39 women. The group charges $1,100 as an entrance fee and $115 monthly for investments and expenses.
The club is one of 31,800 investment clubs worldwide, according to the National Association of Investors Corporations, headquartered in Michigan. Sixty percent of the 500,463 members of the clubs are female, and the average return on investments is 12 percent, according to the association.
Although the association was founded in 1951, most of its growth has been in the last three years, a spokesman said. Statistics in "The Money Club" show that all-female investment clubs in the United States account for 41 percent of the total clubs and that they outperform all-male clubs -- 13 percent -- by a 3-to-1 margin.
Ms. Crockett, who also advises a men's investment club in Manhattan, Stocks and Bondage, said she noticed a more competitive environment there, in contrast to the supportive atmosphere at the 008-Club.
She added that women were better investors than men, because they took time to understand each stock instead of making quick decisions and "shooting from the hip."
Most investment clubs are simple partnership agreements that have average portfolios of $87,000.
The 008-Club educates members through reports, speakers and seminars. In addition to Ms. Crockett, a financial consultant always attends the 7:30 A.M. meetings in Ms. Crockett's office.
No coffee, no doughnuts. No question is stupid.
"The single biggest mistake women make about money is that they're afraid to find out what it's all about," Ms. Terman Felenstein said. "They don't understand it. Money means another responsibility. There isn't enough time to do everything. So it becomes something to get to tomorrow.
"Women should be more afraid of the consequences. Ignoring your financial safety can lead to disaster. Learn the language. Assess what you have. Don't sign papers unless you know what they are. One small thing could change your life. Be honest about asking for help."
Women also fear taking risks, added Ms. Crockett, who learned about risk when as a college student she performed in an acrobatic show with the Florida State Flying High Circus.
"When you fear making a mistake," the book advises, "the most obvious tactic is to make no decision at all. But if you're not on the field you can never be a winner."
Chapters on investments, retirement and estate planning, insurance and transitions like marriage and divorce offer strategies for beginners.
To illustrate the message that women have to protect themselves the book is peppered with "horror stories" like the following:
*Harriet Mosson, 54, president of Liz Claiborne Dresses, was left destitute when her husband died unexpectedly and his former wife was still the beneficiary of his life-insurance policy.
*The 48-year-old owner of a dry-cleaning business gave her husband power of attorney when they were selling a former business. Ten years later, on the verge of separating, she came home after a vacation to find that her husband had used the power of attorney to sell the house that they owned jointly.
*A 39-year-old textile designer placed an order to buy stock for "a thousand" -- meaning dollars -- and was charged $12,000 for 1,000 shares.
"The message of the book is that it could be you," Ms. Terman Felenstein said.
Ms. Crockett, 49, who majored in college in home economics, said she got her wakeup call nine years ago while she was a flight attendant at Pan American World Airways. The company went out of business, and almost simultaneously, an 18-year relationship ended.
Ms. Crockett realized that she had assumed that her boyfriend would assure her financial security. When she examined her pension, she found it provided only $100 a month after she turned 62.
With no money, no job and no financial experience, she decided to capitalize on her fascination with business. In her years as a flight attendant in the first-class section, she had become hooked on business magazines and began investing "as a lark."
She applied for a position at a Wall Street brokerage, was accepted, and brought in more business than anyone else in the six-month training class that year.
"When a personal crisis touches you, the words you hear about financial security suddenly become poignant," said Jane Bishop Shalam of Old Westbury, executive vice president of the club. "You need that jolt."
Ms. Shalam works with many cultural organizations and is married to John Shalam, founder and chief executive officer of Audiovox, which imports sound equipment for cars and specializes in cellular phones. She grew up in Kings Point, the only daughter in a family of four children.
Her father had a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, she said, but did not teach her much about money.
"The family looked at me as a princess," Ms. Shalam recalled. "Today, I'm the person today who's managed the entire family with self-taught skills. The club has been my tool."
Five years ago, her sister-in-law died in a car accident in Indonesia. Her brother and their 7-year-old, Naomi, were seriously injured, Ms. Shalam recounted. But he had not paid his insurance a few weeks earlier and was left without coverage.
"I needed a lot of money fast to take care of the family," Ms. Shalam said. "It cost me $28,000 to get them out of a jungle hospital. Had I been on my own I wonder where my resources would have come from. It made me realize I had to be more knowledgeable about what I did and didn't have."
She spent two months in Indonesia, brought her brother back to the United States and has been raising the girl for four years, along with her own three sons.
Ms. Shalam took a hands-on approach to the responsibility each club member had -- researching and reporting on companies. When she was working on Home Depot, she spent a day going down the aisles of a store. When she reported on a hearing-aid company, she tried out all its products.
The women stressed that their first goal was to learn, not to make money. But their new-found knowledge has transformed their interests.
"I used to talk about buying Armani clothes and going to the theater," the president of the club, Joann Jordan, said. "Now instead of recommending the latest movie to people I ask how their stock portfolio is doing. I've become somewhat of an evangelist. As a widow I can't tell you how confident I feel that I'm the master of my own finances."
Ms. Jordan, a real-estate broker with houses in Manhattan and East Hampton, said she acquired more financial sophistication than many other women early on as she watched her father lose money because "he didn't pay attention."
When her husband died a year ago, the club was both a nurturing environment and a diversion, she said.
The club inspired Enid Rosenthal, a friend of Ms. Terman Felenstein, to form a women's investment club on Long Island, the Millennium Club.
That organization has capped its membership at 30, said Ms. Rosenthal, who lives in Old Westbury. The group meets monthly at restaurants and has been surpassing the Dow Jones Industrial Average every month.
For Carol Safir, a real estate broker and the wife of the New York City Police Commissioner, membership in the 008-Club meant that she felt equipped to manage a pension fund from her husband's former consulting business. She initially divided the fund four ways, allotting three parts to three brokers and controlling one part herself.
"After three years," Ms. Safir said, "I produced the best results. I created my own mutual fund, and it grew 35 percent. Now I will probably consolidate it and manage it all myself."
The Safirs have homes in Manhattan and Southhold. One important outcome of Ms. Safir's involvement in money matters is that her children, Jennifer, 26, an agent at the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Adam, 24, a lawyer, have begun creating their own investment strategies.
"Mothers give advice," Ms. Safir said. "But children learn by example."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Philadelphia;
Penn Planning to Build Hotel and a Commercial Hub

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
NEARLY 30 years after its last major construction project added dormitories, the student bookstore and a new research center, the University of Pennsylvania is in the midst of two major building and renovation projects that will again reshape its campus.
One of them, called Sansom Common, will include in its first phase a 250-room hotel, shops and a new bookstore at an estimated cost of $73 million. The site is at the heart of the campus on a block bounded by Walnut, Sansom, 36th and 37th Streets that for years has been a two-acre parking lot. 
 The second phase will include the creation a new north-south street linking the hotel entrance to Chestnut Street, a major artery leading to downtown Philadelphia.
University officials are now considering proposals for the the block between Sansom and Chestnut Streets to add town houses and retail space and renovate existing high-rise dormitories and add retail space. The total budget for Sansom Common is $120 million.
The other project, Perelman Quadrangle, consists of $62 million in improvements to 19th-century academic buildings and pathways and lawns between them near the corner of 34th and Spruce Streets. The area will include a plaza or amphitheater area that will be used for gatherings.
"These projects will shape Penn as a residential community, particularly for undergraduates," said Judith Rodin, who became president of the university in 1993.
They also are significant in a wider urban context. The university, in West Philadelphia a mile west of downtown, is the city's largest private employer, with more than 25,000 workers at its campus and hospital. It is in an area where 72 percent of the residents are black and 20 percent are below the Federal poverty level, according to the Philadelphia City Planning Commission.
There are other educational institutions in the area, known as University City, including Drexel University, the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science and a satellite campus of Lincoln University.
The 260-acre Penn campus has only one street with a significant number of privately owned stores, said Judy Wicks, who has run the White Dog Cafe and Black Cat gift shop for 25 years. Along Sansom Street, one block east of Sansom Common, there are about two dozen brick buildings with restaurants, cafes, pubs and an international newsstand. "It's important that the university have a commercial hub in the middle of the campus," Ms. Wicks said.
Planners say the first phase of Sansom Common will move the university in that direction. The cost of the hotel -- The Inn at Penn -- and the 55,000-square-foot bookstore and other stores -- will be paid for through long-term contracts or leases with their operators. The hotel operator has yet to be designated.
DR. RODIN, the university's president, predicted that the project would create the atmosphere of a European village with residences, shops, theaters and galleries. "It will give us the chance to re-animate Walnut Street, where there's more that goes on at night," she said.
The university spent $15 million last year to acquire the University City Sheraton Hotel for use as temporary living quarters while dormitory renovations are under way.
The bookstore at Sansom Common, a Barnes & Noble operation scheduled to open in the fall of 1998, will have a cafe and a children's activity area. Once the Barnes & Noble store opens, the 50,000-square-foot campus bookstore at 38th Street and Locust Walk and several nearby stores may be demolished, possibly to be replaced by a 300,000-square-foot building to be used by the Wharton School, Penn's business and management institution.
The 6-story, 190,000-square-foot hotel is scheduled to open in the fall of 1999, according to construction plans by LaSalle Partners of Chicago, the university's development manager. The hotel and bookstore have been designed by Elkus/Manfredi Architects Ltd. of Boston.
"The project itself has flown," said John A. Fry, the executive vice president at Penn, who is Sansom Common's project director. "We've gone from feasibility to construction in less than 12 months."
Retailers have been eager to reach the 22,000 students and thousands of people who work nearby, Mr. Fry said. But despite strong demand for stores, there are few sites on which to build more. The university's for-profit real estate company, UCA Realty Group, has built retail space on Walnut Street since 1987, usually with offices or parking above. UCA Realty owns and operates more than 70 properties in West Philadelphia, 40 of them residential.
Until recently, colleges and universities viewed their campuses as islands separate from their host communities, but that attitude is changing, said Gregory Clement, principal at Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates in New York, which has worked on projects for Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., and Baruch College in New York City.
"Penn's integration in that area has never been as clearly demarcated as at Columbia or Harvard," Mr. Clement said. "The fabric of Penn's campus really blends into the community and vice versa. It feels like it's part of the community, rather than a gated facility where you feel you need a card to get in."
CITING the need to work with the community, university officials note that Sansom Common will create 200 full-time jobs at the hotel and stores. The school already directs a portion of its equipment purchases and hiring to local sources, Mr. Fry said.
In the late 60's, Penn's last major construction project produced high-rise apartment towers in stark contrast to the local community's rowhouses. Local civic leaders say the university is now mindful of esthetic, economic and social concerns in developing its projects. To encourage such town-gown cooperation, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has made grants to colleges and universities that create partnerships in their communities to solve local problems. Penn received a $400,000 grant last year.
One key liaison with the community is Ira Harkavy, an associate vice president at Penn who is director of the Center for Community Partnerships. The center coordinates the university's involvement in West Philadelphia. In 1969, when Mr. Harkavy was a junior at the university, he led a protest against the school's construction of dormitories and research facilities that replaced existing houses.
A study by Mr. Harkavy's department found that 8 of the nation's 20 largest cities -- Indianapolis, San Francisco, Baltimore, San Diego, Washington, Philadelphia, Milwaukee and Columbus, Ohio -- all have a college, university or medical facilities as their largest private employers.
"Universities in the 1960's tried building barriers, but they also created distrust, hostility and affected the education of students who were part of the urban campus," he said. "Universities should make contributions to improve the quality of life in that environment. But they have not made optimal use of their locality as a place for students and teachers to address one of the most pressing issues of the day -- solving the problems of the American city."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Richard B. Erickson;
For Government on a Regional Footing

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
SINCE 1961, Richard B. Erickson has been involved in regional planning issues in Connecticut. That was the year Mr. Erickson, a county planner in New Jersey, became executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Regional Planning Agency, which became the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments in 1991.
Mr. Erickson is a native of Massachusetts, and earned degrees in geography at Clark University in Worcester, Mass. His career came about pretty much by accident. He had just gotten out of the Army as a Sergeant First Class in military intelligence when a friend mentioned a job in planning. Mr. Erickson thought it would be a good use of his geography skills, and took a job at the Cape May Planning Board in 1958. 
 Mr. Erickson, 65, recently informed his board of directors that he would retire in January, but was prevailed on to stay for another year. During an interview at his office on Boswell Avenue in Norwich recently, he reflected on his four decades as an advocate of regional planning, most of it in a state where there is a strong tradition of independent municipalities. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What kind of changes have you seen in Connecticut?
A. There's been in certain instances a greater willingness to use regional service organizations, such as the regional water authority, regional transit districts, solid waste authorities, tourism district.
There has not been an abandonment, in any sense, of the philosophy of home rule. That's still quite strong. But I think it's been tempered by the changes taking place, almost overwhelming -- that there has to be a coming together of the local communities.
But we're light years away from any sort of regional organization that would bring together, in one agency, the governmental powers now scattered around.
Q. Would that be preferable, to have all these regional authorities under one office?
A. In theory, yes. In practice, at this point, I would say no. I don't think it could be achieved, to begin with. Secondly, I think if it were imposed by state fiat, it would be disastrous. The only way you can establish regional programs, in a state like Connecticut with a long history of home rule, is on a cooperative basis where partners are stepping to the table willingly.
Q. Does the state make regionalism more difficult with laws like that requiring more than 60 percent of municipalities in an area to approve the creation of a council of governments?
A. The advantage of the rule is that it insures you have a core of communities, more than half of the municipalities in a region, that have by their own choice opted to participate in the program. Anything less raises the question of how much of a base of support you have.
In the case of the formation of the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments, there was an effort in 1980, which was a total failure, and another in 1990, which was a total failure. On the third try, in less than nine months, we had all the municipalities signed up.
Q. What changed?
A. There was the announcement of the impending cuts at Electric Boat. It was only after we took a hard look at the region's economic future that we were able to convince the towns that now was the time to proceed.
Q. So it was a crisis that prompted the creation of the council?
A. Oh, yes. In fact the creation of almost all the major regional organizations is linked to a crisis. That was true for the water authority (the severe droughts in the late 1960's), for the solid waste authority (the towns were overwhelmed). Southeast Area Transit was created when the Arab oil embargoes were imposed in the mid-1970's.
Q. Does the same hold true for the rest of the state?
A. Yeah. Connecticut is not a hotbed of regionalism.
Q. Why is that?
A. This is a state that did away with county governments in the late 1950's, and has great emphasis on having governmental decisions made as close as possible to the affected population. The related factor is the high dependence of the towns on the property tax. That creates an environment in which it is very understandable for the towns to be very self-focused.
And I think to a degree it's the nature of people in New England. Municipalities were formed first, and I think there has always been a degree of suspicion of our neighbors in New England -- and I can say that as a native New Englander.
Q. Where has regionalism worked?
A. The far West. Oregon, for example, has very strong regional legislation, as does the state of Washington. Minnesota has been very progressive. In New England, Vermont is probably the most advanced. They've put teeth, for example, into state and regional review of local land use decisions and planning, which is not available to us here in Connecticut. In the case of the Six Flags amusement park proposal, in Vermont, there would have by law been both a regional and state review.
Q. What kind of services are best provided on a regional basis?
A. Traditionally infrastructure, because infrastructure is typically needed irrespective of municipal boundaries. Economic development is another area. Land use management is an area which, if we continue to depend heavily on local property tax, should remain under local control, but my personal view is there's a need for a broadened, at least advisory review at the regional level.
One other area that I think will emerge over the next few years is the management of human service programs.
Q. Are there any services that really require municipal control?
A. In almost every instance there are going to be elements that will need to be performed at the local level. The degree of that will vary depending on the type of service and the size and complexity of the municipality.
For instance, comparing the city of New London with rural Voluntown, you're talking about a different environment in terms of the need for service and the resources available locally. The smaller towns, particularly, might be the primary beneficiaries of a regional program to supplement their local services.
Some regions in the country provide a circuit-riding town manager. We provide a technical assistance program to local planning and zoning and wetlands agencies. That's used periodically even by the largest towns, and we have a regular relationship with some smaller towns.
Q. Can larger towns can benefit from regionalism?
A. They can use the regional programs to supplement their local staffing in technical areas when a workload peaks or a special project arises.
Q. Are there any disadvantages to regionalism?
A. The biggest disadvantage right now is pulling together everyone who has to participate. We have 20 member municipalities, and most of the chief elected officials are up for election every two years. Two years ago we had a 55 percent turnover in the organization. This year, we're going to have at least a 35 percent turnover. That means every couple of years, you have to begin almost anew to develop an understanding on the part of the board of directors about what their function is and what the organization does. Most important, they have to develop working relationships and a level of trust with each other and with the staff of the council. That's a challenge. It makes it difficult to make sure you have continuity. But there's nothing much we can do to change that except to realize this is a critically important characteristic of councils of government, and we need to provide as much support as possible to members.
Q. New London County, with a population of 250,000, has a wide range of towns, from the affluent rural Stonington to an almost inner city area in New London and Norwich. Would regional government sort of smooth out those differences?
A. I think the most that can be expected from a regional structure is a balancing of the interests of those municipalities. There is nothing that would create a homogenized region, and it would create a pretty boring region if you could get that. I certainly am not going to advocate for that.
Many of these differences are the result of historic events in the settlement and gradual development of the towns. Realistically, those differences are going to continue, and may be highlighted and accentuated in the years ahead.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard B. Erickson is a regional planner in a state where regionalism is not always popular. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Women Leaving Medicine for Home

BYLINE: By DARICE BAILER 

 BODY:
WHEN Dr. Ruth Martin graduated from the George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences in 1981, she was proud to be one of 49 women in a class of 148. In 1970 there had been only 13 women in the school's freshman class of 127. In the 1960's there had been only three or four women in each class.
Dr. Martin, whose training was in psychiatry, said she was pleased not to be an old-fashioned housewife; she was embarking on a career in what had been a predominantly male profession. 
 But eight years ago the Greenwich resident became a member of a new minority: women leaving medicine. Dr. Martin didn't leave because she was frustrated by trying to satisfy the demands of managed care or because practicing medicine was not as lucrative as it once was. She left, she said, because she suddenly realized that she wanted to stay home with her first child more than she ever thought she would.
Before her daughter Helena was born, Dr. Martin said, medicine had been her whole life. After the birth, the doctor found herself "frantic to get home" to see her baby. She was discovering that there was something equally, if not more, important to her than her medical practice. "I had to face the fact that I was a mother and I wanted to be with my child," Dr. Martin said.
Dr. Martin said she considered working part-time. But, she said, "I was burned out. My heart just wasn't in it."
The Martin family wasn't dependent on Dr. Martin's salary; her husband, Raymond Martin, is president and an owner of Solomon Broadcasting International in Stamford and can support the family, which has grown to three children, on his income.
Dr. Martin's situation is an exception to the rule. In 1995, according to the Census Bureau, the median income for married couples with children under age 18 and an unemployed spouse is $35,181.
Linda W. Finnie, a marriage and family therapist with offices in Greenwich and Wilton, says "I support women having choices, and yet we know that all women can't choose because of socioeconomic issues." Mrs. Finnie noted that women who are doctors have spent many years in the educational system training for their careers before choosing to give priority to raising their children. "It's wonderful that they have the possibility or the option to do that," she said. "It would be wonderful if all women had that choice."
Dr. Martin, 44, is glad that it is financially possible for her to stay home with Helena, now 9, her son Criswell, 3, and her daughter Meredith, 1. Mr. Martin travels a great deal, and Dr. Martin believes there is a calmness in her house that would not be there if she were working as well.
Five years ago, Dr. Randi R. Diamond, 38, quit her job as director of the geriatrics program at Norwalk Hospital to become a two-day-a-week attending physician at the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield. Dr. Diamond, who is married to an internist, Dr. Howard Eison, is home-schooling their children -- Daniel, 11, and Kaile, 9 -- in Weston. Feasible or not, the choice wasn't easy. "It was the hardest decision I ever made," Dr. Diamond said. "There are not a lot of people who have stepped back and said 'I need to limit my professional involvement to have more time with my family.' "
Jeanine Freliech, 32, is a part-time pediatrician at Doctors Pediatrics in Wilton. Dr. Freliech is the mother of Lydia, 2, and Cecily, 6 months. For now, Dr. Freliech said, "it's the best of both worlds." She works two days a week, doing what she was trained to do, and has five days home with her daughters.
Dr. Patricia Horton, 45, of Wilton, and Dr. Elizabeth (Lisa) Antell, 35, of Greenwich have also put their medical careers on hold.
Dr. Horton quit pediatrics after 15 years to stay home with her children, Whitney, who is now 16, and Andrew, 12.
Dr. Antell graduated from Cornell University Medical College after the birth of her first child, but did not continue with her training. She is married to Dr. Darrick Antell, a plastic surgeon in Manhattan; the two have three children.
Jeff Roames, director of student services at the George Washington School of Medicine and Health Services, says he has seen doctors drop out of medicine during his 22 years at the university. Mr. Roames said what he's noticed recently "a change in attitude not only for the female students, but also for the male." Medicine is no longer the single focus of student lives, but one of many focuses. "It's fitting medicine into a complete life style," Mr. Roames said.
When a male physician quits medicine, however, it's usually because he's frustrated dealing with managed care or is unhappy by the constraints on doctors' incomes. It's not to devote more time to his family.
Is it acceptable for female physicians to put family first? "I would imagine that there are many doctors, both male and female, who would be very angry at them," said a male physician in private practice in Norwalk, who would speak on this sensitive issue only on condition of anonymity. He said he did not see anything wrong with women's decisions to leave medicine. "If they want to do it, and that's their choice, then they should do it," he said. "There are certainly people who go through hell to maintain their practice and raise their children. It's really hard."
But what about all the money spent training these doctors, only to have them leave? Medical students are heavily subsidized by their universities. While law schools and business schools generally make money for universities, medical schools are a drain.
Mr. Roames of George Washington says "Tuition cannot even come close to covering the cost of medical education." There are 3,000 faculty members to pay, and building costs. "We are running in the red," he said.
Dr. Horton -- who noted that she's been criticized for wasting resources and a spot in UConn's medical school despite having worked for 15 years -- worked for the student health service at Brown University before resigning in 1992 to move to Tokyo with her family. (Her husband, Rick Horton, is with IBM.)
Dr. Horton loved her job at Brown, but she had never traveled abroad before. The idea was very tempting. Still, she said, "I was dragged kicking and screaming."
Then she discovered that she enjoyed being a full-time mother, being able as she put it to go on field trips, help out in the classroom or attend impromptu school coffees or presentations. Dr. Horton recalled her daughter asking, "Can you come to school and do this?" "The answer was always no." Dr. Horton said. "She would have had to let me know three months in advance to get out of my schedule at the office."
The Horton family moved from Tokyo to Wilton a year ago, but Dr. Horton hasn't returned to work. She knows she has only a few years left with her children before they leave for college, and she says she wants to be around. She's planning on going back to work one day, though.

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Daniel A. Biederman;
The Greening of Downtown Districts

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
IF midtown Manhattan is a bit safer and a lot cleaner, there are those who think Daniel A. Biederman of Chappaqua deserves some of the credit. Mr. Biederman is president of the Grand Central Partnership and the 34th Street Partnership and executive director of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation. Together they make up the largest complex of private downtown management districts in the United States.
Mr. Biederman is what is called a downtown manager. As such, he works with city officials and property owners to raise money and maintain the acreage within his jurisdictions. For his work, specifically at Bryant Park, he was recently awarded the International Downtown Association's 1997 Special Achievement Award. 
 Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him:
Q. What is a management district?
A. There are many cases in the United States where people with great economic stakes in neighborhood health have turned over a significant amount of responsibility outside their building to what is called a downtown manager. I'm the largest of those, because these districts cover about half the real estate in midtown Manhattan. This is done through a number of vehicles financially. Some are called tax-increment-financing districts; some are called business improvement districts; some are called downtown development corporations. Our combination covers the two main rail terminals of the city and Bryant Park.
Q. What do you do? Have you replaced the city government?
A. We work closely with the city, and it was under the impetus of the three mayors -- Koch, Dinkins and Giuliani -- that we started initially. Essentially, we manage jointly with the city the environment from building line to building line. Out on the sidewalks and in the streets and in the parks is a private entity that is spending a lot more money than government can afford to spend -- but spending it extremely wisely because it is being watched very closely by their board members.
Q. Where does your money come from?
A. Principally from assessments set on every building in the office district. If you're a commuter from Westchester with an office on a floor in a building near Grand Central Terminal, your landlord is paying about 15 cents per square foot for the services we provide that we think have remade the neighborhood in a much safer, much cleaner and more attractive way. There are some other revenues, particularly in Bryant Park, but the great bulk of the $20 million a year we have to spend on our districts comes from that assessment vehicle.
Q. At what point did those business owners vote to bring you in?
A. That happened in three different ways. In 1984, we established a district around Bryant Park to fix that park, which had tremendous problems. In 1988, such a decision was made at Grand Central and in 1992 at 34th Street, the area that includes Penn Station, the Empire State Building and Madison Square Garden, Macy's and Herald Square.
Q. Describe what Bryant Park was like 15 to 20 years ago and what you did to change this.
A. The park had serious problems of design and the like and had declined significantly with active crime problems and vandals. It became unusable by people other than drug sellers. In fact, the number of people using the park declined to as few as 1,000 a day, whereas today we'll have 5,000 to 6,000 just at any one time at lunch. There was really no money in the city budget to hire enough police or park workers to clean it up. So the Rockefellers stepped in and hired me.
Q. So what did you do?
A. We redesigned the park and put in a terrific private security force and private maintenance. We put in various attractive amenities that involved food so there would be a reason for people to go to the park at off hours. We lit the park beautifully so it would be usable at night and to prevent vandalism, and we put in a phenomenally clean restroom right on 42d street so people would stop urinating in the park. We put in the best flower gardens, we think, anywhere in midtown Manhattan, and we put in interesting programs -- cultural, dance music, spoken word, a Monday-night movie series -- so there were other reasons to come into the park. And we put in 2,000 movable chairs.
Q. People have not been walking off with the chairs?
A. No. We lost fewer than 100 in 6 years to pilferage, whereas they usually just wear out. That's a key element. The park is jammed with people who like to sit on a chair -- choose their spot, in the gardens, wherever.
The tough thing about Bryant Park was it took nine years to execute the plan; five or six years were consumed with the process. We went through massive approvals to get the plan accepted.
Q. What about the Grand Central Partnership? What is that about?
A. That really came from a decision by Mobil Oil to leave the district and complain about it on their way out. They were leaving for Virginia and told Mayor Koch and his very smart Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Ken Lipper, that they were unhappy about conditions in the district. They made a videotape showing how terrible life in the Grand Central area was for their employees. The Mayor, through Ken Lipper, reached out to me and said, "Would you consider helping us with this because we want to fix this area up, and we don't have any money to do it?" Luckily, they also reached out to Peter Malkin, who is a Fairfield resident and became chairman, and I became the president of a new entity called Grand Central Partnership. Its aim was to apply some of the same private management techniques we were using in Bryant Park to the streets surrounding the terminal.
It has taken a few years, but in the early 90's we really started commanding the streets and installing attractive amenities and cleaning all the litter, removing the graffiti. And the crime rate, with a great help from the mayors, especially Giuliani, has been cut by 70 percent.
Q. What about the 34th Street Partnership?
A. That involved Peter Malkin, Bernard Mendik and me. A property owner said to us: "What you have done at Grand Central is so amazing. Do the same thing around Penn Station because we're dying down here." The litter was ankle deep in the terminal, and you had parks with a lot of crime and vandalism and dark, unattractive streets, a lot of clutter. After a massive effort, we now, in contrast, have competition from retailers who want to be in that district.
Q. All this begs the question: Why cannot the city do this? Is it too large to govern?
A. I think the Mayor has shown the city is not too big to be governed, that they can focus on individual block conditions. We started before Mayor Giuliani came in, when the city was in a worse fiscal condition and hadn't yet gotten to individual problems that were driving office workers and residents crazy. I think it's a combination of that and a combination of the use of our expertise. It sounds maybe overly proud, but I think we've developed a phenomenal team of experts on every area that needs to be worked on so a downtown can be well managed. And the city is organized differently by agencies, and they have many massive problems in other areas that they have to work on and greater responsibility.
Q. How does your security force interact with the police?
A. We call ourselves the eyes and ears of the police. We probably have more people out on the street on foot patrol than they do, but we don't have guns and we allow the police to actually make the arrest, although we may hold someone for an arrest. We work very closely with them.
Q. The Mayor has gotten a lot of attention for dealing with the so-called quality-of-life issues, but there is some concern that people are being arrested too aggressively. How do you see the balance?
A. I think what the Mayor has done is terrific. I think a lot of the criticism of the Mayor is purely political. I think anyone who has worked with the Police Department knows there were years in the 80's when the police were really disarmed. The police have now been unleashed to do their job -- not to abuse people. The cases of abuse are so few compared to the number of innocent lives saved from some character hanging around giving the police probable cause to believe a crime was going to be committed -- legal reason to search the guy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daniel A. Biederman of Chappaqua, in Bryant Park. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
For Rent: The Castle, $17,000 a Month, 28 or 35 Rms

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
OVER the last 18 months, eight prime houses in Greenwich have been rented for $15,000 to $25,000 a month in leases running for a year or more.
But there appears to be little comparable on the market in Fairfield County today -- with one exception -- a French neo-Renaissance chateau in Stamford, available for $17,000 a month. 
 Known as The Castle, the 15,000-square-foot cement-over-brick and steel residence has 28 to 35 rooms, depending on whether one counts as rooms the chauffeur's waiting room, the sewing room, darkroom, coatcheck room, pool changing room, and other limited-use spaces.
Built in 1912 at 1 Rogers Road on Shippan Point, the house sits on a rise with views of Long Island Sound across a courtyard, terraced lawns, specimen plantings and a 20- by 40-foot swimming pool. It is modeled after the Loire Valley chateaus.
Thomas L. Rich, who has an option to purchase the house, fell in love with it while accompanying a friend who was just looking. Mr. Rich is the 38-year-old senior vice president of the F. D. Rich Company, son of Robert Rich, the developer who rebuilt downtown Stamford.
He intends to live in the house some day, but in the meantime he is looking for a tenant seeking a lease of one to four years, and a buyer for a half-acre of the 1.67-acre property fronting on Rogers Road, priced at $500,000. Anyone living in the house is permitted four employees for a home-based business under Stamford zoning.
Mr. Richard's option to purchase expires next April 1, but it can be exercised on 60 days' notice or extended. "I might accept $15,000 a month," he said, adding that "for anyone paying the full $17,000 I will furnish the main living, dining and great hall areas."
The Castle, originally constructed for $140,000, has been on the market since September 1994. A price of $2.875 million was reduced to $2.75 million in 1996 and to $2.45 million in February of this year when Juner Properties of Stamford took over from a former broker. When it didn't sell through the summer it was reduced again, to $1.995 million. Neither June Rosenthal, owner of Juner Properties, nor Mr. Rich would disclose the price finally agreed upon.
"It's not a house for everyone," said Ms. Rosenthal, "but you couldn't duplicate it for many millions more, and you would have to bring craftsmen over from Europe." She said that taxes on the property were $29,500 a year and heating and cooling costs were about $11,000 a year.
The current co-owners and occupants for the last 19 years are Gordon Micunis and Jay Kobrin. After graduating from Yale they became partners in theatrical, fashion and interior design. After buying The Castle in 1978 they converted billiard and recreation rooms on the upper floors of the seven-level house into studios, using the main rooms as a showcase for their business and for numerous parties benefiting local charities.
Careful not to modernize the house, they have preserved original wrought-iron wall sconces and balustrades and a massive built-in oak icebox (supplemented by a 1920's double refrigerator) and restored broken stained glass and leaded windows.
They converted original gas-lighting fixtures to electricity, repaired the elevator and mined their professional access to European-styled wallpapers, fabrics, antique furniture and accessories and animal-head trophies, now in the great hall. "We do not hunt," Mr. Kobrin explained. "We bought them because they are suitable."
Still in use is the original kitchen incinerator, and in the paneled library there are original hand-held electric sconces attached to the bookcases by stretchable coils, the better to peer at book titles. The library contains the only fireplace in the house other than the walk-in fireplace in the great hall; its murals were painted in 1915 by Howard McCormick, muralist for the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan.
Central air-conditioning, steam and forced-air heating were installed or upgraded and an eight-burner restaurant gas stove replaced an outmoded range. Original marble over steel staircases, unblemished oak floors and slate roofing are all intact, as well as garden stepping stones of a thickness rarely seen today, chestnut kitchen cabinets, master bedroom wardrobes fitted with dozens of labeled drawers and an orchestrion that simulates 40 musical instruments.
In 1982 the house was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in response to an application filed by the two owners.
The Castle was built by Frank J. Marion, who made a fortune producing one-reel films for nickelodeons and, as a colleague of Thomas Alva Edison, collaborated in various motion-picture inventions.
A man of expensive tastes backed by ample financial resources, he hired the Manhattan architectural firm of Richard Morris Hunt to design the house, which he named Terre Bonne. The firm also designed The Breakers in Newport, R.I., for Cornelius Vanderbilt and The Biltmore in Asheville, N.C., for George W. Vanderbilt, as well as several Fifth Avenue mansions.
The steel work was done by the American Bridge Company, builders of the Brooklyn Bridge. Wadley and Smythe, landscape architects, designed the Terre Bonne gardens, which extended to the water on what was then a four-and-a-half acre tract. When the waterfront parcel was sold off the owners of The Castle retained in perpetuity a right of way to the private beach and two boat moorings.
"When we took the house I was the same age as Marion was when he moved in," said Mr. Micunis. "I swore we would stay as long as he did, but I give up." He and Mr. Kobrin have bought a six-room apartment in Stamford and will spend more time at their sprawling adobe house in Santa Fe, N.M. Whatever furnishings were not moved to the two residences were disposed of in an auction at The Castle last weekend.
AFTER Frank J. Marion's death in 1963 at the age of 94, David and Martha Cogan bought what had come to be known as Marion Castle, using it as a summer home. Mr. Cogan was an inventor and major manufacturer of the color television tube. His wife was instrumental in rescuing dozens of children from the Nazis during World War II.
Thomas Rich will continue the succession of entertainment-oriented owners with his parallel careers of real estate developer and actor. He has had roles in five off-Broadway plays, 20 commercials, some low-budget films, and eight television shows, including a recent bit part in "Beverly Hills 90210." Because of his film work he keeps a home in Los Angeles, and when attending to real estate he lives in Stamford.
He is currently planning to develop a prime parcel of Stamford real estate opposite the new University of Connecticut branch nearing completion on Broad Street. The site could accommodate a 350,000-square-foot office building or a combination of offices and retailers.
"I'm not sure when I will move into The Castle," he said, "but I would like to settle down and raise a family there."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Tempo Picks Up on Warehouse-Distribution Projects

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WORK began Sept. 10 on transforming a patch of farmland not far from Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike into a 2 million-square-foot industrial park. Its first building will be constructed on speculation over the next nine months.
The initial high-ceilinged structure in the 150-acre Cranbury Business Park, which will be developed over four years on Cranbury-South River Road, will have 201,600 square feet of warehouse, distribution and office space. The entire project will be developed in two phases by Security Capital Industrial Trust of Aurora, Colo., one of the nation's largest industrial real estate investment trusts. 
 In addition to the first structure, phase one will include five more speculative buildings together totaling 1.26 million square feet of space; the second phase of up to 800,000 square feet will be in buildings for specific tenants. The project, which will cost more than $50 million, marks the company's first foray into new construction in the state. Since it entered New Jersey last year it has acquired 2.5 million square feet of industrial space in eight buildings.
The Cranbury Business Park venture is part of the latest wave of building activity in the Exit 8A region as developers try to capitalize on a strengthening industrial market and what they say is a demand for modern high-ceilinged warehouse distribution buildings.
Several other projects, together totaling an additional 2.7 million square feet of space, are being built or planned in Cranbury, Monroe and South Brunswick and Jamesburg Townships in Middlesex County. Its location -- midway between New York and Philadelphia via the turnpike and Routes 1 and 130, which also link it to points up and down the Eastern Seaboard -- makes it among the favored spots for such development.
Some buildings are being built on speculation, others are being planned as build-to-suit structures for specific users. And the activity has spread farther south to Exit 7A of the turnpike, where construction is under way on three build-to-suit buildings, with a total of 508,000 square feet, at the 553-acre Northeast Business Park in Washington Township. That site will ultimately have 2 million square feet of space.
Several factors are stoking the building activity in the area, as well as in other parts of the 11-county northern and central New Jersey market, industry executives said. Among them is the state's improving economy, which has translated into a demand for industrial buildings from some companies expanding within or into the state as well as others looking to consolidate operations from several locations into one.
Through June, 2.3 million square feet -- most of it warehouse and distribution space in greater-than 100,000-square-foot blocks -- was leased or sold in the region. That, along with limited building, reduced the supply of available space of that size to 2.1 million from 4.2 million in July 1996, and the vacancy rate to 6 percent from 10 percent. At $4.43 a square foot, average asking rents remain healthy, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage.
Because much of the available space is obsolete and capital has become available "the market in general and in 8A in particular is starting to see speculative construction," said Andrew J. Merin, executive director of the financial services group at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield.
Mr. Merin said the presence of REITs (real estate investment trusts, which are publicly owned vehicles for purchasing and operating real estate) and pension and insurance companies in the marketplace provide ready financing for construction. And, he added, the cost of buying industrial buildings in prime locations like the Exit 8A area was close to or exceeded the cost of new construction.
"The question," said Mr. Merin, "is can the demand in the market sustain all the new development?"
FOR Security Capital, starting the Cranbury Business Park "made sense because there is limited opportunity to buy buildings and a selective need for new product to meet the needs of today's tenants," said Michael Nachamkin, a company vice president who runs its New Jersey operations, which are based in Edison.
The park is being built in a community where zoning has until recently restrained warehouse development and kept Cranbury from capturing its share of development during the mid-80's building boom. But a year and a half ago Cranbury Township rezoned some 1,200 acres east of Route l30, which bisects the community, to warehouse use from office and industrial use.
It did so, said Mayor Alan A. Danser of Cranbury, because there was a "need for ratable growth" to strenghten the township's commercial base and reduce the tax burden on its 2,500 residents.
Cranbury Business Park, made possible by the rezoning, is the first major commercial development in the township in 10 years. The project's initial 1.26 million square foot phase alone is expected to generate $400,000 to $500,000 in new tax revenue for the township, said Mayor Danser.
There are three other warehouse projects in various stages of approvals in the township that together would produce 1.3 million square feet of such space. Plans are moving forward on a fourth project that would mix 216,000 square feet of office space with 650,000 square feet of warehouse space in three buildings, according to data from the township's Planning Department.
Mr. Nachamkin said Security Capital was developing the Cranbury site "as much to create an identity for the company as to create a destination in the region."
The park's first 201,600-square-foot building, like its others, will have 32-foot-high ceilings and 3 to 5 percent of its space dedicated to office use. While rents have not yet been set, they will be competitive, said Mr. Nachamkin.
Elsewhere in the Exit 8A region the Matrix Development Group of Cranbury is developing with different partners two speculative warehouse distribution projects. One is a 259,369-square-foot building on a site along Matrix Drive within the 900-acre Center Point business park straddling Monroe and South Brunswick Townships. Matrix is developing the building (the steel skeleton is now half complete) with the Prudential Insurance Company based in Newark.
The other, a joint venture with AMB Realty Advisors in Boston, is the renovation and expansion of a 1950's warehouse on Dock's Corner Road in South Brunswick into a modern 1.2 million-square-foot building. The partners have demolished 100,000 square feet of the existing, mostly occupied, 650,000-square-foot building, and are now adding 650,000 square feet of new space.
"Even in the worst of times there was still activity in the 8A region and now demand for space is strong," said Joseph S. Taylor, Matrix's president and chief executive. Rents at both projects will be competitive, he added.
And after a slow start activity is also picking up in the market off Exit 7A of the turnpike, said Mr. Taylor. There, Matrix is developing the 2-million-square-foot Northeast Business Park in partnership with Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, an industrial and office REIT in Melville, L.I. Reckson is providing a $6 million mortgage secured by the park, where the focus will be on build-to-suit deals.
The two companies formed a joint-venture partnership last May to develop and buy industrial properties in New Jersey.
"We think tenants will come farther south to 7A and the park will capture its share of the market because of cheaper rents, equal access to the major Northeast transportation corridors, an excellent labor pool and stable taxes," said Mr. Taylor. "The 8A area does not have to be saturated before companies will leapfrog to 7A."
Some already have. Construction is under way on a 265,000-square-foot building for Hahn & DePalmer, a full-service marketing company; the Amway Corporation, a direct-mail company, and McLean Engineering have signed on for 113,306- and 130,000-square-foot buildings respectively, said Mr. Taylor. "There is a risk of saturation," he said of the amount of activity in the market. "But I don't see it right now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: First building in Cranbury Business Park will be a speculative warehouse, distribution and office structure. (Kehrt Shatken Sharon)
